DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE GULF ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Army Unveils Weapons, Equipment of Wars of the Future
DOC.TEXT: Tropical chocolate, a synthetic that tastes like the real thing but won't melt in the heat, could be ready for shipment to the Persian Gulf in time for the holidays. The all-electric tank won't be. Military historians are fond of saying that generals are forever fighting the last war. The Army Materiel Command has the job of making sure that doesn't happen. The AMC, which is responsible for research and development of gear used by the Army, is playing host this week to an exposition of what the future may hold for the nation's warriors. ``The soldier in the field is our customer,'' said Edward Brown, civilian deputy director of the AMC Office of Technology Management and Planning. The projects presented at this base 30 miles north of Baltimore are in various stages of development - from a wild idea to a concept on the verge of production. The all-electric tank, which would use batteries or superconducting technology, is one of those projects way off in the future. Taken as a whole, the projects represent the beginning of a shift from a near-total preoccupation with the Soviet threat to a realization the nation could face a myriad of military challenges in coming years. ``The buzzword we use these days is that instead of weapons of mass destruction, we're looking to produce weapons of mass disruption,'' said Brown. The object, said Brown, is to create a smaller, leaner but more effective force that can fight a small-scale war in a jungle as well as it could a major tank battle in central Europe. To that end, the Army and its scientists are pushing against the frontiers of science. In laboratories across the country, researchers are looking for military applications for the next generation of supercomputers and trying to harness recent breakthroughs in magnetics and superconductors. They are working with corporations and universities on new fabrics to improve uniforms, new materials to enhance tanks and personnel carriers and robots to reduce the danger to soldiers. The scientists and managers gathered here envision an army in which the soldier has ``enhanced survivability and enhanced lethality.'' In the next century, the GI on patrol may carry his own computer along with tastier rations. He may be wearing a self-contained air-conditioned uniform to protect him from the heat as well as chemical weapons. Generals will be able to rely on computers that produce corps-level battle plans in 40 minutes, a task that now takes at least a day. And those computers will be able to give commanders a range of options and tell them when a battle plan isn't working and suggest appropriate responses. Officers will brief their troops using TV screens, instead of pointers and paper maps on easels. The technology expo is designed to spark new ideas as well as sell the nation on the importance of such work in an era of budget cuts. ``The decision was very specifically made to keep the R&D as high as possible because that's the seed corn,'' Brown said. ``That's the future. We're going to push the technology.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Launches Rocket With Navigation Satellite
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has added a ninth navigation satellite to an orbiting network capable of pinpointing U.S. military units anywhere in the world to within 50 feet. A Delta rocket blasted off with the $65 million Navstar satellite at 5:56 p.m. Monday.About 25 minutes later, the satellite separated from the booster as planned and settled in an orbit 12,532 miles above Earth. ``Everything appears to have gone well,'' said Air Force Lt. Col. Jim Jannette. Two launch attempts late last week were delayed by bad weather. The 3,675-pound satellite is part of a series of advanced Global Positioning System spacecraft designed to guide warplanes, ships and other military craft with extreme accuracy. The first Navstar was launched in February 1989. Fifteen more Navstar satellites are scheduled to be launched by early 1993 under the $8.5 billion program. Three will serve as spares. The satellites, which have a working lifetime of 7{ years, keep track of the speed of vehicles on land, sea or air to within a fraction of a mile per hour. Inside each is an atomic clock with an error rate of one second every 300,000 years. The spacecraft can pinpoint locations within 50 feet in any weather anywhere in the world - in some locations, within 10 feet. Military personnel use receivers as small as telephones to tune into the network. Seven earlier, less sophisticated satellites still are functioning.

DOC.HEAD: City Faces-City Fears: One in a Series
For Teacher, There's Frustration, Fatigue - but Small Victories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
With Logo
DOC.TEXT: With the dangers and failures of urban public schools chronicled almost daily in the news, why would someone choose to teach? This fourth part of the series, ``City Faces, City Fears,'' follows one teacher through her tumultous day for the answer. ---

It was 11:30 a.m. when rude laughter and the whoosh of rushing water sundered Deborah Terrell's algebra lesson. The odds against the lesson already were high enough for Ms. Terrell and her 19 eighth-graders at Burnet Street Elementary School, a magnet school where 200 of 500 children are homeless. This day, like most Ms. Terrell has spent here for the last decade, would be a melange of frustration, fatigue, self-doubt and, perhaps, a small victory or two. But as she spoke of equations, a former student in a prankish mood gleefully sprayed the glass in her classroom door with jets from the hallway fire extinguishers. ``See that?'' she said, pointing angrily to the truant. ``This is fun? What kind of life is that?'' Later that day, as if sent to restore her faith, a second visitor dropped in: Tawana Woolridge, a prim, polite 12th-grader at Newark's tough Central High whom Ms. Terrell had taught five years earlier. ``She was my favorite teacher,'' Tawana said. ``She wasn't too strict, but she didn't let you get away with anything, either.'' ``When one kid like that comes back and is making it, that's what makes it all worthwhile,'' said the teacher. --- 3 p.m. at last. Most of the students leaving Room 303 headed for Baxter Terrace or other downtown Newark housing projects. Three caught buses for homeless shelters at the Lincoln or Carlton Hotels. Ms. Terrell slumped back in her chair, exhausted. She hadn't always wanted to be a teacher. She studied psychology at Rutgers University but quickly lost her taste for it after an internship at a mental health center: ``Too depressing.'' ``When I went to school, everyone wanted to be a teacher. I came here to Burnet to do my student teaching. The seventh-grade teacher left one day, and the principal just gave me her class. The rest is history.'' At age 36, her chosen career now earns her about $33,000 a year. ``I don't see myself here for another 10 years. But I guess I wonder: if I leave, who's going to be here for these kids?'' Later, back home in her neat, wood-frame house on a tough-looking downtown Newark street, she'd make sure her sons Malcolm, 8, and Toussaint, 9, buckled down to homework, as her own mother once had for her. But now, as the last pupil straggled out, she needed to decompress. ``I have to wind down before I can see my kids,'' she said. ``If I don't take half an hour to wind down, I might take things out on them.'' After dinner, homework awaited - grading neatly bound projects hr students had prepared on the evils of drugs to mark National Drug Awareness Month. Then she planned to phone parents to exhort them to attend open school night. She wondered aloud: ``Am I just speaking to the air? Did anyone learn anything today?'' She thought. ``Well, I know Murad learned something.'' Murad, a bright, cocky, reed-thin boy, is quick with excuses and short on study habits. Ms. Terrell had forced him to sit in a desk alongside hers, a spot known in her class as ``Out of Society.'' But today Murad actually had taken notes in class and used them to solve a math problem. A small victory. And Ronald. A big day for him, too. Quiet, withdrawn, homeless for the last year, Ronald had stood up for the first time and given an oral presentation. The class had applauded. Ronald had smiled shyly. Another victory. Victories come hard at Burnet Street, designated four years ago a magnet school for homeless children in kindergarten through eighth-grade. Only last year did the board of education add staff and resources to help the school accommodate this most troubled population. Teachers say they have yet to get any formal training on how to deal with them. ``Kids were sleeping on desks, had to meet bus schedules, had to make stops at the grocery stores,'' Ms. Terrell said. Average daily attendance at Burnet Street is just 87.6 percent; the national average is more than 92 percent. Twenty percent at Burnet need special help with basic skills, and 15 percent have been held back a grade or more. Only 5 percent of parents participate in school activities, according to New Jersey state statistics. For Ms. Terrell, teaching is a daily gantlet of delays, interruptions, excuses. The PA system squawks messages. The bell rings every 45 minutes. In the space of a morning, the attendance teacher knocks on the door to take roll. Four Hispanic students get pulled out of class for special English classes. Eight others are summoned for remedial classes to boost low English and math test scores. Still another group goes for computer instruction. In the afternoon, Ms. Terrell's homeless students are called away early to catch buses to shelters. And then there are the excuses. A kid tells her she didn't do her homework because ``I left the book in school, OK?'' At that, Ms. Terrell's mouth twists upward in a streetwise curl that says without words: You think I haven't heard that nonsense a thousand times before? You think you're kidding me? I was raised in the same streets you were. ``No,'' she finally says. ``That's not OK. You know how I feel about excuses and that's not even a good one. And get rid of the gum!'' She has a way of mixing humor, affection and discipline. On her desk is a small sign: ``U toucha My Desk, I breaka U face!'' Sometimes she'll say with a hint of a smile: ``You know how un-rational I am.'' How do the kids feel about her? Defiant. Yet dependent. She sometimes invites her students to write what they think, without signing their papers. They write her things they wouldn't tell their parents: about drugs, AIDS, their neighborhoods, being homeless. --- Her kids say Ms. Terrell sometimes gets teary during her ``life lectures,'' when she speaks about what she wants for them, why she's there. One such talk comes minutes after the class's standardized state test scores arrive. The 7th grade scores, the ones her kids took the spring before, show only 28 percent testing above average in math - the lowest passing rate in the school by far. ``Oh brother,'' she says. ``We're the lowest on the list. ``Everyone has so much time to talk and play, talk and play. What bothers me is I know you can do better. These scores are garbage. That's a reflection on me. Whatever I have to do to get this up, I will do. ``You always should expect to do the best for yourself. There's too much potential in this room. I'm just here to help you. But you have to help me help you. You already have the strikes against you. You're minorities, blacks, Puerto Ricans. So people look at these scores and say, `What did you expect?' ``I know where you belong, and I want to take you. I certainly don't want any of you in here next year shooting fire extinguishers at the window.''

DOC.HEAD: Facts, Figures on Urban Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-City Faces-Teacher
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 40 percent of the nation's minority students and about 30 percent of its poor children are educated in large, urban school districts, according to data collected by the Council of Great City Schools. About 11 percent, or 4.5 million U.S. schoolchildren, attend school in the nation's 37 largest urban districts, according to the council. Urban districts with the biggest enrollments are New York, 940,000; Los Angeles, 592,000; Chicago, 394,000; Miami-Dade County, Fla., 268,000; Philadelphia, 191,000; Houston, 190,000; Detroit, 174,000; Dallas, 131,000; San Diego, 117,000; Baltimore, 107,000, and Memphis, Tenn., 106,000. The families of nearly 1.5 million urban schoolchildren are below the poverty line; 408,000 are enrolled in classes for the handicapped; 293,000 have limited English proficiency. Forty-five percent are black, 26 percent white, 23 percent Hispanic, and 5 percent Asian. Daily attendance averages 94 percent in urban elementary schools, 91 percent in middle schools and 87.6 percent in high schools. The national average for all schools is 92 percent. Excluding federal funds and capital spending, Pittsburgh spent the most per pupil among the 50 largest school districts: $7,163, according to 1988-89 data from the American Federation of Teachers, the latest comparable statistics available. Memphis, Tenn., at $2,521, spent the least. The 50-district average was $4,365. Average class size in the the 50 largest U.S. districts is about 17 students, compared with the 17.4 average for the entire nation, according to AFT statistics. Newark, N.J., had the best pupil-teacher ratio, 11.5, followed by St. Louis, 12.4, Boston, 12.6, Baltimore County, 13.5, Pittsburgh, 14.0, Orange County (Orlando) Fla., 14.5, Denver, 14.5, and Columbus, Ohio, 14.5. Los Angeles had the most crowded classes among the 50 largest districts, with a student-teacher ratio of 24. Some 203,000 teachers work in inner-city schools. Among urban districts with settled contracts in 1990-91, Philadelphia teachers earn from $24,000 to $49,600; Newark teachers, $23,867 to $50,757; Minneapolis teachers, $22,192 to $47,273; Cincinnati teachers, $21,679 to $44,847; Baltimore teachers, $22,162 to $43,002; and Dade County, Fla., teachers, $26,500 to $49,400.

DOC.HEAD: For Salvadoran Chopper Pilots, a Perilous Job Becomes More So ^Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Enrique Torruella swooped the UH-1H ``Huey'' helicopter below 1,000 feet into the range of guerrilla rifle fire. He banked the craft steeply in a tightening gyre, then abruptly landed in the combt zone. The copter's deafening rotor flattened the waist-high grass. Pvt. Manuel Zepeda, squinting through swollen eyes, his face bloodied by shrapnel from a grenade, ran to the waiting ship. So did another soldier carrying on his back Pvt. Santos Alfaro, badly wounded in the head and arm by the same explosion. The aircraft was on the ground less than a minute. Torruella revved the turbo-jet engine and raced off. Before the aircraft reached safety beyond the range of enemy fire, medic Cpl. Tomas Vasquez had a needle in Alfaro's arm and plasma dripping into his veins. The Grupo de Helicopteros at Ilopango air base five miles east of San Salvador embodies the single most significant tactical advantage government forces have over the FMLN leftist rebel army. Military analysts consider the infusion of helicopters and pilot training provided by Washington from 1982-85 crucial in preventing the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front from winning the civil war. The fleet provides transport of troops and supplies, rocket and machine-gun support for ground troops and evacuation of nearly all the wounded government soldiers. According to casualty statistics, no job in the military is as dangerous as that of the squadron's 60 pilots. During the past 18 months it has become more so. The guerrillas since early 1989 have worked diligently on anti-aircraft tactics. Virtually all the approximately 65 aging Hueys and the few, newer Hughes 500s making up the squad have been hit by ground fire. Several, perhaps a dozen, have been shot out of the sky. The precise number is classified. Thirty pilots have been killed in action since the group was formed in 1982. Most of the survivors have been wounded. Part of Torruella's right foot was shot off in August 1989 when rifle fire pierced the floor. Charcoal portraits of 26 of those killed adorn a wall of the lobby of the group's headquarters. Once the four pending portraits are added, there will be space for only two more before room will have to made on another wall. The air force jealously guards information on rebel effectiveness against its planes and helicopters. But, by way of indication, on both days an AP correspondent and photographer accompanied crews on ``medivac'' missions, at least one ship was struck by gunfire. Most of the time, damage is limited to perforations of the fuselage. But if 7.62mm fire from guerrilla AK-47s strikes the engine, the tail rotor or hydraulic hoses, the helicopter may crash or be forced to land off base. ``Rene,'' a guerrilla squad leader based on the slopes of Guazapa Mountain 20 miles north of San Salvador, sat in the shade one recent afternoon and described ``triangulation.'' The tactic concentrates fire of up to 15 AKs on helicopters descending to either pick up wounded or deliver supplies. The circling and dipping practiced by the pilots are intended to minimize guerrilla efficiency. ``If you approach in a straight line, they get a bead on you,'' said Torruella, a smooth-faced 24-year-old. Like several of the squad's members, he looks out of uniform more like an adolescent than a combat chopper-jockey. All the pilots except one - a recent graduate of the local aviation school - were trained at the U.S. Army's Fort Rucker in Alabama. ``They have the same training as U.S. pilots. That instruction combined with constant combat has made them among the best in the world. Practice makes perfect,'' said Lt. Col. Arch Kielly, U.S. Air Force attache in El Salvador. Military analysts say the air force, especially the helicopter squadron, was essential to beating back November's large-scale guerrilla offensive. The FMLN accused the government of indiscriminate rocket fire and strafing of densely populated urban neighborhoods where guerrillas had dug in. Air force authorities and U.S. advisors dispute the allegation, saying dozens of requests from ground troops for air support were denied for fear of inflicting unacceptable civilian casualties. Judging from what reporters saw during the offensive and from inspections of battle-scarred neighborhoods afterward, the truth is somewhere between the government and guerrilla claims. Aerial machine-gun fire perforated roofs in several areas and rockets were launched into a few residential districts. But intense use of air power appeared to have begun on the offensive's fourth day, when most civilians had evacuated the battle zones. With the insurgents talking of a new offensive in coming weeks, the pilots face a new peril. The rebels' reported acquisition of scores of shoulder-fired surface-to-air missiles could prove to be a strategic watershed in the nearly 11-year-old war. Employment of similar weapons in the 1980s by U.S.-backed Afghan guerrillas was one of the keys to the success of their campaign against Soviet forces.

DOC.HEAD: Tales From the Trenches of the `Potato Front'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12 sent Oct. 1.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people, from alcoholics to soldiers, are slogging through the nation's potato fields in a race to salvage the rotting crop and save Muscovites from a hungry winter. Joining the forced laborers in the muddy trenches of what the press has dubbed ``the potato front'' are volunteers who are lending a hand so they can carry home a sack or two of the starchy staple that has vanished from store shelves in the capital. Tatyana Shcherbach, who was ordered into harvest duties by her bosses at the Lepes Metallurgical Factory, laughed heartily as her three co-workers joked about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We've been wondering whether Gorbachev eats potatoes like this,'' she said, holding up a half-rotten one, ``or if he gets potatoes from the States.'' Her laughter spilled across the collective farm's half-plowed rows in the village of Peshki about 30 miles northwest of Moscow along the highway to Leningrad. The 44-year-old woman giggled, saying she and her colleagues had concluded Gorbachev would opt for the Soviet spud because ``he's not the kind of man to eat anything special.'' As a stiff wind blew chilled unprotected hands in the 40-degree temperatures, Shcherbach said: ``It helps to joke and make fun of one another. It makes the job much easier, and such weather requires jokes.'' She and about 100 colleagues from the factory plunked the potatoes into pails and carried them to large sacks standing in the rows. Many potatoes in the field already were rotten, Shcherbach said, holding a shriveled one in her soiled, thin cotton gloves before discarding it. Drenching rains have turned the fields to mud, crippling harvest operations for most of September and killing much of the crop. Moscow has only 7 percent of the potato stock it needs for the winter. Students and soldiers were drafted into the harvest weeks ago, and leaders of Moscow's regional government invited city dwellers to go to nearby collective and state farms to help dig potatoes - with an option to buy them at low prices. As Shcherbach spoke, young Red Army soldiers busily collected the 110-pound sacks of potatoes and hefted them into the arms of compatriots riding atop an open trailer pulled by an old tractor. ``We'd rather be doing something else,'' admitted Pvt. Taras Grebnichenko of Kiev. The Soviet Union has ordered 23,000 soldiers into harvest duties in the Moscow area. ``Welcome to the Gulag Archipelago!'' laughed one of a half-dozen soldiers warming themselves at a nearby bonfire, referring to the Alexander Solzhenitsyn book about Soviet labor camps. The soldiers roasted some potatoes on the embers. A blackened one was picked from the ashes and handed to a comrade who pulled a folded up newspaper containing salt from beneath his tunic, seasoned it, and offered it to eat. They kidded each other as they passed around the potatoes. ``Do you know how to speak Arabic?'' one joked, alluding to the Persian Gulf crisis and possible duty in a drier climate. The mood was more sullen about 50 yards away, where 40 recovering alcoholics from Moscow methodically picked up the potatoes under the close supervision of a brigade leader. Alcoholics in the Soviet Union's treatment centers frequently do such forced labor. Working in a different part of the field and espousing a different attitude was Nikolai G. Gorodetsky. ``I'm eager to help, and get some potatoes as a result, because the shelves are picked clean,'' he said. Individuals like Gorodetsky are entitled to keep every sixth sack of potatoes they dig, or pay 45 cents for every 2.2 pounds for their entire bounty. The engineer, joined by his wife, Lyudmilla, and teen-age son, Sergei, said his family would harvest four sacks - about 440 pounds - and give two of them back to the collective farm, taking home 220 pounds at a cost of about $45. That price is no different than in state stores, but long lines of shoppers have snapped up all the potatoes in those establishments. Those few potatoes still in Moscow's markets are grown in private plots by farmers who are charging more than three times the state price. Rooting in the field for potatoes is not humiliating work, said Gorodetsky, who lives in the surrounding Solnechnogorsk region but grew up in a village. ``I like to do it,'' he said. ``I like being the master of the soil. No one forces me. This is the Russian character.'' Yevgeny A. Nazarov, of the Moscow suburb of Khimki, also said he would carry home two sacks. ``I'm here because potatoes are very expensive in the market and because of the recent rumors that in the winter we won't have any, so it's the only way to provide for one's family,'' said the 37-year-old aircraft designer who has a wife and two children. Nazarov, who said the potatoes would hold them for half the winter, admitted to being frightened by reports of a winter of food shortages but added: ``We hope the situation will change. I'm an optimist.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Saudis Wait For Winds Of Change
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Lama al-Suleiman is angry at an American woman soldier she saw on television. ``This woman said: `All those Saudis have got to know that slavery time is over,''' Mrs. al-Suleiman snapped. She decried the image of Saudi Arabia abroad, saying: ``It's a picture of being imprisoned, of women being beaten .... We're not maltreated. We just need a little bit of change.'' Some young Saudis say change could be one result as foreign troops, including women, flood Saudi Arabia to confront Iraq. Other observers say Iraq's invasion of Kuwait might slow the pace of change - the 15-year-old civil war in Lebanon and the 1979 revolution in Iran have made the Saudis skittish about aping the West, seen here as the main cause of both upheavals. ``With the crisis, people will rethink what they're doing. It's like walking on a knife blade,'' said lawyer Majid Ghazawi. However, other Saudis view the confrontation with Iraq as a strong catalyst for change. ``Part of the basic education of any nation is to go through a crisis to mature,'' said Nidhal Taibah, a 25-year-old architecture student. In the meantime, young Saudis point out how much Saudi Arabia already has changed. ``Whatever you write, don't bring in tents, Bedouins or camels,'' Mrs. al-Suleiman said. Young men and women acknowledge that their lives, from studying to working to attitudes toward sex, are packaged by rigid social and religious codes that many would like relaxed. But the tribal hierarchy frowns on public debate, much less rebellion, so they say they'll have to wait until the whole country wants to alter its ways. Free speech, women driving, more public mingling between the sexes, a more flexible educational system, greater access to the arts and late marriages are all on their agenda. ``You can force change from the top, but if you do it too fast you tear the social fabric,'' said a young official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Saudi Arabia has no taxes. Work hours are limited and long vacations are not unusual. Government housing loans are interest-free. The state pays for medicine and education. College students get stipends of $266 a month. Saudis acknowledge the largesse breeds complacency. ``We have to put some of the blame on ourselves for not demanding the things we want,'' said Manal Fakeeh, a 24-year-old manager at a hospital. Recent graduates said they got a basic university education here. But many, especially the women, said their choices were limited and classes uninspiring. ``They think engineering's too tough for women to handle,'' said Mrs. al-Suleiman, who is pursuing a master's degree in biochemistry. Because women are not permitted to mingle with men under strictly observed Islamic law, they watch their professors on closed-circuit television. ``It's more like corresponding than attendance,'' Mrs. Fakeeh said. ``With time you don't feel you have the right to ask for what you want because you think this is only for boys,'' said Dina bin Mahfouz, a 25-year-old sociology graduate. ``If you think you have the right, people will let you know you're extreme, moving out of society, trying to change things. They don't like change.'' Both men and women said they face intense pressure to get married after graduation. Marriage, although no longer arranged, is still a family affair where the woman's reputation is everything. Premarital sex is almost unknown. ``It's a big no-no. It's something that doesn't happen,'' Taibah said. ``If it happened in Riyadh, you'd hear about it in Jiddah.'' ``You have to be a virgin because you're a Moslem. I wouldn't even think of it,'' Miss bin Mahfouz said. Many young Saudis accept the morality of Islam, but reject the ways its rules have been interpreted. No one will criticize the government directly for the record. But many regret what they see as a timid stance on reform and the toleration of religious teachers who issue bizarre statements like one proclaiming the world is flat. While princes are accessible, public debate and any hint of political organizing is squashed. Those who push too hard for change have their passports confiscated and are ostracized. ``You don't tell the ogre its eyes are red,'' said one young Saudi who has been behind bars. He spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Fountain May Require Tourists to Charge-It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
Eds: Edd is cq in 12th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1 sent Oct. 1.
DOC.TEXT: A flood of criticism of a pay-as-you-spray scheme to activate the city's Claude and Mildred Pepper Fountain with credit cards hasn't splashed cold water on the plan. The idea came up two weeks ago because the city says it can't afford to spend the $42 an hour or so it costs to run the $3.2 million fountain, whose computer-controlled water jets are designed to mimic the sea. And city commissioners appear prepared to at least consider the proposal to install a machine like a bank's automatic teller, despite a deluge of ridicule. ``It's the most preposterous thing I've ever heard of in my entire life,'' said Howard Kleinberg, former editor of the Miami News and now a history columnist for The Miami Herald. ``To think of the endless possibilities this opens to credit cards!'' As plastic as the plan may seem, the commissioners are considering it as a sort of user fee to save taxpayers' dollars. As it stands, no money is budgeted in the tight fiscal year that started Monday to run the fountain named after the late Miami congressman and his wife. City Manager Cesar Odio said his $269 million budget just can't spare the $370,000 a year it would cost to keep the fountain running. ``We can only afford to run it about two minutes a day,'' he quipped. The city is in the midst of its worst financial squeeze in at least 10 years. So why not let those who want to muse before the mists pay for the pleasure? ``I don't see anything negative about it,'' said Commissioner J.L. Plummer. The fountain, at Bayfront Park in the heart of the tourist district, was switched on in July, and runs just several hours a day. The rest of the time it sits idle, its empty moat attracting skateboarders, its saucer-shaped granite centerpiece dry. An electrical contracting firm whose principals are active in civic affairs suggested the credit-card scheme. ``I hate to see the city of Miami get a black eye over this,'' said Paco Farach, president of the company, Edd Helms Electrical Contracting Inc. ``The credit card thing is an interim solution to attract attention and create initial excitement.'' Farach says the company would guarantee to run the fountain at least 3,000 hours during the next three years at a cost of about $150,000. And it has offered $10,000 to start a corporate sponsorship program that would allow the credit-card machine to offer discounts to employees of companies that sign up as sponsors. He envisions a machine that would take VISA, American Express and MasterCard. The concept would have greatly disturbed the late Isamu Noguchi, said Shoji Sadao, the architect who worked with the sculptor on the fountain. ``He'd be very upset and very disappointed and just completely discouraged,'' said Sadao. ``It certainly is a last resort. If I had my choice, I would not want to have something that's for the public having to be funded by private citizens. But if it gets down to either that way or no fountain at all, then I'd have to go with that choice.'' One fan of the fountain is Bryn McKim, a recent transplant from Oregon, who loves to spend her lunch hour in the sun, reading next to the spray. ``Sure, I'd use an ATM machine,'' McKim said. ``I've never heard of anything like that before. But, hey, you have to try new things.'' Pointing to the dry fountain, McKim said, ``Like that, it looks like a meteor struck the park.'' Jeff Homer, whose nearby office building faces the fountain, disagrees. ``It seems tacky,'' Homer said of the credit-card plan. ``If they found all that money to build this, they should be able to find the money to keep it going.''

DOC.HEAD: Political Landscale of Northeast Asia Changing
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The strategically located Korean peninsula is in the vortex of rapidly developing new relationships that may change the political landscape of Northeast Asia. For the first time since the end of World War II, countries that have been bitter adversaries and battleground enemies are talking to one another. Delicate relations are being slowly, cautiously realigned. Northeast Asia is unique in that it engages the vital interests of four of the world's great powers: the United States, the Soviet Union, Japan and China. The tense and bitterly divided Korean peninsula sits at its geographical heart. All four countries are involved in, and will be affected by, changes in Korea. All four governments have an interest in security and peace on the peninsula and all four have economic reasons for wanting to encourage friendly ties between North and South Korea. The result is a gradual restructuring of alliances, some of them unthinkable as recently as two or three years ago. South Korea and the Soviet Union established full diplomatic relations on Sunday for the first time since Russia and the Yi Dynasty broke off ties in 1905. The announcement followed by three days North Korea's stated intention to open talks on normalizing relations with Japan. The two moves are seen as catalysts in breaking down Cold War barriers and point toward the possibility of eventual recognition of the rival Koreas by the others' allies - the United States and Japan recognizing North Korea, and Beijing and Moscow recognizing South Korea. The surge in political activity comes as the divided Germanys unite, an event that holds deep emotional significance for all Koreans who feel shamed at the division of Korea. The mending of decades of distrust between two Koreas with starkly opposing ideologies is not expected to be quick or easy. President Roh Tae-woo hopes to see unification by the end of the century. Dissidents and radical students who harp on immediacy say it will take five years. ``Confrontation and tensions continue to hamper the relations between the two divided parts of Korea,'' said Roh said on Monday. But he said new ties will make it ``impossible for North Korea alone to resist the tidal wave of change.'' Prime Ministers of the Koreas held talks in September, the highest-level contact ever between the two nations. A second round of talks is scheduled for this month. Because of its geography, Korea long has served both as a buffer and an invasion route for its powerful neighbors. In the last century alone, three wars have been fought on Korean territory. For 35 years until 1945, Korea was occupied by the Japanese. The peninsula was divided in 1945 and in 1950 North Korea invaded the south, launching a three-year civil war that left more than 4 million people killed and wounded. A peace treaty was never signed. The border remains tightly sealed. Distrust and suspicion are rampant. There is no mail, telephone, communication or travel between the two sides. The long-sought impetus for change has been the need for money and technology. North Korea is virtually bankrupt. Wealthy Japan, just 350 miles away, could provide desperately needed capital and technology. Japan could find in North Korea cheap labor, raw materials and a land route into Asia. The Soviet Union, also in need of capital, has found in South Korea a willing investor as well as factories anxious to build and market high technology. The Seoul government reportedly expects to sign an agreement for more than $2 billion in aid to Moscow. Some also see the Soviets' ties to Seoul as bait for Japan, which has turned down Moscow's overtures for investments. China, long-time ally of North Korea, needs to expand its markets and is expected to open trade offices with Seoul before the end of the year. South Korea hopes relations with both China and the Soviet Union will stop Beijing and Moscow from vetoing its attempts to enter the United Nations. For its part, Washington hopes eased tensions will insure stability in the region, eventually allow a scaleback of 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea and remove an excuse for anti-Americanism. For South Korea, new relations with the Soviet Union are the culmination of a vigorous two-year campaign to develop ties with allies of the North. ``The ties between Seoul and Moscow will have significant bearing on the charting of a new world order,'' said Kim Hak-joon, a top aide to Roh. ``We are seeing new opportunities for progress in Northeast Asia.''

DOC.HEAD: American in Saudi Arabia: French Foreign Legion `My Family'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
LaserPhotos YAN2, YAN102 sent Sept. 30.
DOC.TEXT: When Martin Meyer of Chicago set out to join the French Foreign Legion, the legendary fighting force enshrined in film and song, he faced one big hurdle: finding their Paris outpost. It took Meyer 24 hours of wandering the French capital before he stumbled upon Fort Norgent, and told the burly legionnaires inside he had come to join up. ``I knocked on the gate,'' he recalled. ``They tell you to wait.'' It may not have been a glorious start to Meyer's stint in the Foreign Legion, whose troops are the veterans of countless battles in jungles and deserts the world over, their exploits made famous in P.C. Wren's novel ``Beau Geste.'' But now he is a 28-year-old corporal, and was among the first legionnaires to land in Saudi Arabia as part of the multinational force deployed to the region after Iraq invaded Kuwait. There are 2,300 legionnaires among the French ground troops, and Meyer is one of three Americans. The legion is 40 percent French and 60 percent foreigners, culled from 90 nationalities. Like countless hard-living legionnaires before him, Meyer left behind a troubled past. A native of Arvada, Colo., he crisscrossed the United States with a mother and two brothers. He was the child of a broken home, he said. ``We had a lot of family troubles,'' said Meyer. ``I've always been the black sheep.'' Five years ago, he said, his wife walked out on him in Mexico, Mo., taking their baby with her. ``I just wanted to disappear,'' he said. ``I'll never see them again.'' He had first headd about the Foreign Legion during a three-year stint with the U.S. Air Force in West Germany that ended in 1981, and read about it in combat magazines. After his wife left, he said, he checked out a book on the legion from the public library. He applied for a passport, and he left Chicago on a chilly autumn day in 1985. In some ways, Meyer was a textbook recruit. Legion officials say most applicants are mavericks who find they just do not fit into society. False identities are not uncommon, nor are past brushes with the law. Murderers and serious criminals are not welcome, however. In Paris, once Meyer had passed an initial round of interviews with the legion, they took away his possessions and shipped him south to their headquarters in Aubagne. There, he underwent a two-week round of physical and mental tests, and relentless questioning. About half of the would-be volunteers are accepted. They agree to stay in the force for at least five years. They learn French, and undergo difficult, even brutal physical training. Legionnaires get regular army pay. Afterward, they are recommended for French citizenship. Formed in 1831 by King Louis-Philippe, the legion lost some of its luster in recent years with France's bruising defeats in Algeria and Vietnam. But a modern-day legionnaire is still likely to see action in France's far-flung former possessions. Six months after joining, Meyer was sent to the former French colony of Djibouti, on the Red Sea, then the African nations of Chad and Gabon. The legionnaires arriving in Saudi Arabia are heading for the front in armoured personal carriers with some light artillery. ``We are very... I'm losing my English,'' said Meyer, searching for the word, ``... expendable. We are the front-line forces.'' He has never seen combat. He hopes he will, in the Saudi desert. ``I love it. This is what we trained for,'' he said. ``I just hope they let us do it.'' He does have one worry - chemical weapons. Iraq is known to possess them, and has used them in combat. ``But we have to be ready for anything,'' he said. ``If it's a man-to-man, troop-to-troop battle, we will win.''

DOC.HEAD: Islamic Uzbeks Fuming as Soviet Democratic Reforms Pass Them By
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of KGB and police officers gathered recently around the blue mosque in Tashkent's crumbling old city and listened warily as an Islamic cleric boomed out a call for political action. ``Allah Akbar (God Is Great!)'' shouted thousands of male voices in response to the mullah's call for Islam to replace Communism. A few miles from the mosque, workers were building an iron and concrete fence around the Uzbekistan Communist Party headquarters, which local newspapers report is being converted to a presidential palace. Workers said the fence will be electrified to hold back any mobs that might attack Uzbek leaders, as Romanian mbs did during a revolution in that Balkan nation last year. ``They fear the Romanian variant,'' said Abdulrashid Sharif of Berlik, an Uzbek popular movement. He said public anger was rising against the reported corruption of Uzbekistan's Communist leadership. Uzbekistan, a central Asian republic of 20 million about the size of soon-to-be united Germany, is a backwater of poverty at the edge of the democratic reform sweeping other parts of the Soviet Union. Some local leaders have called for political unity among the Central Asian republics against the ethnic Russian-dominated leadership in Moscow. Unrest already has broken out in three areas of Uzbekistan, and the republic's Communist officials appear to be girding for more demonstrations. ``We see on television what is happening in the Baltics, in Russia and Moldavia,'' Sharif said. Unlike their counterparts in the Baltic and Russian republics, the Uzbek Communist Party has kept its grip on power. It banned demonstrations in February and suppressed a democratic opposition movement, activists said. ``In Uzbekistan, the power of the Communists has not changed since the days of stagnation,'' said activist Igor Kadirov, who lives in the industrial city of Almalyk. The ``period of stagnation'' is the Soviet term for the 1964-82 rule of Leonid Brezhnev. Uzbekistan's per capita income is half the Soviet average, and 10 percent of the population is jobless. Many of the high-paying jobs in the gold and gas fields go to Russians rather than the native Uzbeks. The Uzbeks make up 69 percent of the population, Russians 11 percent, with the rest a mixture of ethnic groups. The gas and gold produced in Uzbekistan is controlled by the central government in Moscow, with few benefits flowing to the people of Uzbekistan, said poet Yodgor Obid, a member of Berlik. Natural gas lines to Russia pass right through Uzbek villages which have no gas themselves. Uzbek reformers have their eyes on the new president of the Russian Federation, Boris Yeltsin, who quit the Communist Party in July and has persuaded the legislature to approve sweeping political and economic changes. But Uzbek Communist leaders have suppressed the local democratic movement, reformers say. While tens of thousands were allowed to march to the Kremlin walls in July and September to denounce Communism, demonstrations in Uzbekistan have been banned since February. The Uzbek Communist Party says its publishing house - the only one in the republic capable of printing newspapers - will refuse to print national publications it does not approve of. Kadirov said the new national law on freedom of the press, which took effect in August, is being ignored in Uzbekistan. Leaders of Berlik, the popular movement that claims 1.5 million members, said members are often arrested and beaten by police. Uzbekistan already has exploded in ethnic, economic and political violence in the Fergana, Andizhan and Parkent areas. As many as 800 were killed in June in Uzbek-Kirgiz clashes in Osh, just over the border in Kirgizia. Locals say such bloody outbursts could recur. ``The situation is very dangerous and tense,'' said Damin Narzikolov, a Berlik leader. The tension is causing many ethnic Russians to flee. They crowd the Tashkent rail office every day, arranging their moves back home. ``We're afraid. It's dangerous to walk on the streets,'' said railworker Yuri Yurtaev, an ethnic Russian. ``We have nothing against Russians who want to work,'' said Yodgor Obid. ``But those who want to command, as a colonial power - those can go.'' Despite the efforts of Uzbek authorities to control dissent, more and more infrmation is being published on corruption among officials. Newspapers recently disclosed that for the past 30 years, only children of the party elite have been accepted to prestigious foreign language and law schools. The Soviet press has carried numerous stories about official corruption in Uzbekistan, and many of the republic's top leaders were convicted for collecting payments for non-existent cotton. The gradual lifting of restrictions on religion has freed Moslem leaders to move into politics, leading Russians and non-Moslems to worry they will follow the lead of nearby Iran into religious fundamentalism. Signs of fundamentalism were visible at the blue mosque, where young Moslem men glared in fury at a foreign woman escorted briefly into the service by an Islamic official.

DOC.HEAD: 30,000 Hindu Outcastes Convert to Buddhism
DOC.TEXT: About 30,000 Hindus considered ``untouchables'' in the country's rigid caste system have adopted Buddhism in the largest mass conversion in nearly a decade, according to news reports. The ceremony took place Saturday in Agra, the site of the Taj Mahal, about 110 miles south of New Delhi. The Indian Express newspaper said the conversions were prompted by clashes in June with upper-caste Hindus near Agra. Seven people were killed and 110 were injured in the three-day riots that began when a wedding procession was attacked by upper-caste Hindus protesting the noise. Welcoming the converts, a local politician, Sangh Priya Gautam, said Buddhism was the only religion based on ``realism and equality,'' Press Trust of India reported. The converts, called Harijans, were below the complex Hindu caste system that determines a person's social standing by birth, and often affects economic position. Harijans are not assigned any caste, making them ``untouchables'' for the higher-born Hindus. In many Indian villages, the so-called outcastes are not allowed to use umbrellas or wear shoes when in an upper-caste neighborhood. Despite official government rejection of the caste system, it is prevalent in rural India. Efforts by Harijans to assert their rights have often led to clashes with the upper castes. University students who belong to upper castes have also been protesting - some by self-immolation - an August government decree setting aside 49 percent of civil service jobs for low-caste workers. Saturday's ceremony took place while Hindus celebrated one of their most important festivals, the Dusshera, which marks the victory of good over evil. About 60 monks supervized the conversion, the largest since 1981, when about 300,000 low-caste Hindus embraced Buddhism in the western town of Nagpur. There are about 4.7 million Buddhists in India, comprising less than 1 percent of India's 800 million people. Hindus make up about 82 percent of the population. Buddhism, which does not have castes, was founded in India as a religion and philosophy about 2,500 years ago by Siddhartha Gautama. It teaches the practice of meditation and observance of moral principles.

DOC.HEAD: Majestic Park to Celebrate 100th Birthday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY formation of Sierra Nevada, followed by glaciers. ADDS graf at end to explain formation.
DOC.TEXT: Yosemite National Park celebrates its 100th birthday Monday, hundreds of millions of years after the formation of the Sierra Nevada that glaciers later carved into majestic valleys. The 748,542-acre park was created by Congress on Oct. 1, 1890, 26 years after the federal government gave Yosemite Valley to California for use as a public park and recreation area. The park is about 130 miles east of San Francisco. John Muir, a naturalist, first saw the area in the 1860s and his enthusiastic reports help spark interest in preserving Yosemite. Now, some 3.4 million people visit the park each year. During the past century, Yosemite has seen controversies and disasters. Development interests and concessionaires have battled environmentalists about how much to build in the park. This summer, a fire raged through Yosemite, closing the valley for 11 days and burning 23,000 acres. But the park that includes El Capitan, Half Dome, Yosemite Falls - one of the world's tallest waterfalls - has survived, its granite rock faces and tall trees reaching ever upward. ``We believe we've seen 100 years of preservation, and we're working hard to ensure that the next 100 years are even going to be better for the visitors and the park,'' said Yosemite Superintendent Michael Finley. A ceremony marking the milestone will be held Monday. The Sierra was created hundreds of millions of years ago when the Earth's plates collided, according to generally accepted scientific theory. Ice ages then came, unleashing glaciers tens of thousands of years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say War More Likely as Iraq Driven Into Corner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The likelihood of war in the Persian Gulf has grown significantly as sanctions and a hostile world push Saddam Hussein into a corner with no diplomatic escape, European and Israeli military analysts say. But they say there is still a window for peace, before the effects of sanctions sink in further and U.S.-led forces in Saudi Arabia become strong enough to consider launching a military operation to push Iraq out of Kuwait. ``I think another six to eight weeks is available to prevent a conflict, but after that it becomes almost inevitable,'' said Paul Beaver, publisher of Jane's Defense Weekly. With the United Nations demanding an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and Iraq reiterating almost daily that it will never leave, the analysts see little room for a negotiated solution. ``Saddam Hussein could well now be driven into a corner which makes negotiations difficult and we could see a situation where he is left with very few options - and those all being of a military nature,'' Beaver said in an interview. Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute for International Relations in Paris, said he would ``love to see a diplomatic option'' but ``it would mean that ... Saddam Hussein gives in to Western pressure, and it's rather unlikely.'' A compromise is still possible, he said, in which Iraq would withdraw in return for agreement to hold an international conference to redefine Kuwait's boundaries, give Iraq access to the sea and redistribute Kuwaiti oil reserves. ``But I do not see it in the cards right now,'' Moisi said. ``Maybe in the very beginning a diplomatic option might have been open. Now it's a bit late.'' Even if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, which would satisfy the United Nations, the rest of the world has to be assured that Saddam doesn't have the potential to strike again or continue developing nuclear and chemical weapons, Beaver said. Col. Andrew Duncan, assistant director for information at the International Institute of Strategic Studies, endorsed what he called a scattershot search for a peaceful solution being pursued by individuals and groups in the Arab world and the West. But ``both the United Nations and the Arab League have got to be the major players in the solution,'' he said. Iraq believes support for the U.N. embargo will eventually crack, said Ian Anthony, a researcher at the Stockholm Peace Research Center. ``Iraq's agenda now is to change the situation so radically in Kuwait that it can never be put back to where it was,'' Anthony said. He said Iraq recently tried to depopulate Kuwait by opening its borders. Baghdad has also moved large numbers of Palestinians into Kuwait to change the population balance. Moisi said he believes American objectives can only be achieved through war. ``So unfortunately, I think that war is the most probable outcome although paradoxically, no one really wants it,'' he said. American military leaders ``are obsessed'' with the limitations imposed by the government on the U.S. military during the Vietnam War, ``and are not likely to engage in a war ... without using all the means at their disposal,'' Moisi said. Duncan said Iraq missed its best chance to attack Saudi Arabia immediately after its Aug. 2 invasion, when the Americans were not yet on the scene. The U.S.-led forces now ``are just about in position to defend Saudi Arabia but a lot more is required before an offensive operation to retake Kuwait,'' Beaver said. U.S. ground forces are not strong enough, Duncan said, and it will be at least a month before enough tanks to face the Iraqis arrive in Saudi Arabia. ``The world alliance ... will not even be prepared for a military action until sometime in November,'' said Joseph Alpher, deputy head of the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University. The ideal option for U.S.-led forces would be to wait for Iraq to make the first move and respond, which would be more popular in the West, and especially in the Arab world, analysts said. ``But I don't think it will be a prerequisite for a U.S. and allied action,'' Alpher said. If the mulinational force attacks, a U.S.-led air strike followed by a ground attack would almost certainly be used to try to recapture Kuwait, the analysts agreed. ``Will it be on Kuwait or will it be on Iraq itself? I think all options are open,'' Moisi said. An attack by Arab terrorists could also trigger a war, the analysts said. Israel also has to give credence to Saddam's threat to attack Israel if the embargo strangles his country, Alpher said. ``I think the danger is to underestimate Saddam Hussein, to believe he will be a fool,'' Moisi said. ``He has not been a fool so far.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Toasts 41 Years of Communist Rule
DOC.TEXT: As much of the world retreats from Communism, Chinese Premier Li Peng has toasted the party's 41-year rule with praise for its ``great, glorious and correct'' leadership. Li also lauded the army and police for their roles in controlling dissent and implementing new anti-crime measures. Li made the toast Sunday at an annual reception for foreign diplomats on the eve of the anniversary of the 1949 birth of the People's Republic of China following the overthrow of the Nationalist government. Athletes from China's Asian Games team also attended and mingled with the top leaders, who begged for autographs. The 36-nation games are under way in Beijing and scheduled to close Oct. 7. The Communist Party turned ``an impoverished, backward old China which was subjected to the bullying and enslavement by colonialism and imperialism, into a socialist new China with initial prosperity,'' Li said in his 15-minute toast. ``The Communist Party of China is a great, glorious and correct party. We have every ability to manage our own affairs well and socialist China has a bright future full of infinite promise,'' he said. Chinese leaders maintain that the collapse of socialism in Eastern Europe is only a temporary setback, and capitalism will eventually fail. Since putting down a pro-democracy movement in 1989, Chinese officials have kept tight controls on any dissent and filled the official media with praise of the party. The premier's annual National Day toast serves as an abridged state-of-the-nation address, summarizing China's political and economic situation and the basic domestic and foreign policies. This year's toast contained no surprises, reaffirming the government's determination to maintain a planned economy. Li said the government was intensifying efforts to complete a new Five-Year Plan for submission to the party Central Committee. He gave no explanation for the plan's delay, believed to be the result of sharp disagreement over resuming market-style economic reforms. The new plan is due to take effect in January. Li praised an anti-crime campaign that has resulted in more than 650 death sentences being handed down from January to August, according to the human rights group Amnesty International. In an unusual move, party General Secretary Jiang Zemin attended the reception, held in the Great Hall of the People. The annual event generally is considered a state affair, rather than a party function. The exiled leader of Cambodia's rebel resistance, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, also attended and sat between Jiang and Li. Sihanouk said several weeks ago that he was ailing and would take a leave of absence from political and diplomatic activities. He showed no sign of illness, however, maintaining a brisk conversation with Jiang. Several party elders were absent, including Vice President Wang Zhen, 82. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping, 86, has retired from all party and government posts and has not attended in years.
Here, at a glance, are details of the deficit-reduction agreement that President Bush and congressional leaders announced Sunday:
DOC.HEAD: Size:
DOC.TEXT: Saves $40 billion in the fiscal year that begins Monday, $500 billion over the next five years.
DOC.HEAD: Components:
DOC.TEXT: For the five years, $134 billion of the taxes will come from new taxes and fees; $182 billion from defense and domestic programs, almost all of it expected to come from defense; $119 billion from entitlement benefit programs like Medicare; and $65 billion from resulting lowered payments on the debt.
DOC.HEAD: New taxes:
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline tax, now 9 cents per gallon, up 5 cents Dec. 1, 2 cents Jan. 1 and an additional 5 cents next July 1. Cigarette tax, now 16 cents per pack, up 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. The 16-cent tax on six-packs of beer rises to 36 cents, the $12.50 per gallon hard liquor tax goes up $1.20, and the 3-cent tax on a bottle of wine goes up to 24 cents, all in January. Cars worth more than $30,000, private boats exceeding $100,000, furs and jewelry exceeding $5,000 face a 10 percent on their value exceeding those levels. Tax applies to newly manufactured items. Individuals or couples earning more than $100,000 could lose 3 percent of their deductions for their income over that amount. The 1.45 percent tax taken out of paychecks to support the Medicare program would apply up to $73,000 in annual earnings. It now applies only up to $51,300. The largest increase in federal fees will be an increase in the amount the government charges banks to insure deposits, a boost that will garner $4 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Tax breaks:
DOC.TEXT: For companies that do business in deteriorating urban and rural areas, search for energy or do research. Special credits for small companies. Slight increase in the earned income tax credit, used by low-income people.
DOC.HEAD: Medicare:
DOC.TEXT: The program providing medical care for the elderly and disabled will be cut $60 billion, half for recipients, half for doctors and hospitals. The bulk of the government's savings for recipients comes from two areas. The monthly $28.60 premium for doctors' bill will increase to about $34.30, although not for the poorest people. Also, recipients will have to shoulder the first $150 in each year's doctors' bills, up from $75 now.
DOC.HEAD: Other benefit programs cuts:
DOC.TEXT: $13 billion from agriculture; $8 billion by no longer letting civil service retirees take their benefits in a lump sum, after a one-month grace period; $4 billion from postal reforms, $2 billion from student loans; $4.6 billion from delaying start of unemployment insurance; $2.5 billion from Federal Housing Authority; $1.6 billion from changing the way the government buys drugs.
DOC.HEAD: Defense:
DOC.TEXT: Cut $68 billion below the amount needed to stay even with inflation for the first three years, as much as $182 billion over five years.
DOC.HEAD: Domestic programs and foreign aid:
DOC.TEXT: Stay even with inflation first three years. For last two years, combine into one category with defense; savings of $115 billion required for this new, combined category.
DOC.HEAD: What's next:
DOC.TEXT: Bush and congressional leaders pledged to try to write their agreement into legislation and enact it by Oct. 19.

Here is a transcript of remarks made by President Bush and congressional leaders Sunday at a Rose Garden ceremony announcing a budget agreement between the White House and congressional negotiators: I am joined here today by the leadership of the Congress - the speaker of the House, the Senate majority leader, the Senate repubican leader, the president pro tem of the Senate, the House majority leader, and the House Republican leader and other members of the budget summit negotiating group. The bipartisan leaders and I have reached agreement on the federal budget. Over five years, it would reduce the projected deficit by $500 billion. That is half a trillion dollars. The agreement has five basic parts. First it would save $119 billion in entitlement and mandatory programs. Second, it would produce $182 billion in discretionary program savings. These savings would come principally from defense. In the next three years defense outlays would be reduced by $67 billion relative to the projected baseline. All other discretionary programs would be firmly capped at the projected baseline level. That is, for the next three years, they would in total be allowed to grow at no more than the inflation rate. Third, the agreement would increase tax revenues by $134 billion. The largest single increase, single contributor would be a phased-in increase in the gasoline tax of five cents per gallon in the first year and another five cents in the following years. I do not welcome any such tax measure, nor do I expect anybody up here does. However, this one does have the virtue not only of contributing to deficit reduction but also, overtime, of decreasing America's dependence on foreign oil, an objective whose importance has become increasingly evident in the face of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. I am pleased to be able to note that the budget agreement also includes several new incentives to increase domestic exploration and development of our own gas resources. The combination of these measures should help reduce America's vulnerability to the interruption of supplies of foreign oil imports. Fourth, the agreement extends the Gramm-Rudman budget discipline for five years. In addition, it improves the budget process and substantially strengthens the enforceability of the five-year budget plan to which we have agreed. Fifth, this agreement includes important new initiatives to stimulate economic growth. It authorizes new tax incentives for the development of enterprise zones, extends the r&d tax credit, it provides powerful new incentives in the kinds of companies that account for most of America's job growth. These incentives include a new 30 percent credit for r&d, 25 percent deduction for the purchase of new equity, indexing of the basis of new stock in such companies, expansion of investment in tangible equipment and scientific equipment, a minimum basis rule. It encourages investment in new ventures and in companies with high-growth potential and other such incentives. In addition to these targeted-growth incentives, I would note that prompt enactment of this entire five-year deficit-reduction package would itself help stimulate long-term economic growth. With a half-a-trillion dollars in real deficit reduction - and let me repeat, the leaders here and I think that these are real deficit reduction figures - long-term interest rates should be able to come down. This package should be a strong component of a positive, responsible fiscal and monetary policy. I heartily thank the negotiators who have worked so long and so hard to develop this package. The bipartisan congressional leadership and I have pledged our very best to get this entire package signed into law by October 19th. As any such plan would have to, ours requires that virtually everyone contribute in some way. It is balanced, it is fair, and in my view it is what the United States of America needs at this point in its history. And we are united in our fim determination to see this program enacted. I do not want to imply that some who have not been in the final negotiations are for every part of this, but I can only speak for my part and then the top leadership here will speak. But I will simply say: this is priority. This is priority for our nation. This is something that the country is calling out for and world markets are looking for. And so there will be some tough fights ahead. But I have pledged to the speaker, to Congressman Gephardt, to Bob Michel on our side, to George Mitchell and Bob Dole and the Senate pro tem leader, Senator Byrd, that I will do everything I can to lay aside partisanship here and to take this, take the case for this deal to the American people in every way I can. Sometimes you just don't get it just the way you want. And this is such a time for me, and I suspect such a time for everybody standing here. But it's time put the interests of the United States of America first and get this deficit under control. And Mr. Speaker, I'm grateful to you, the Democrats and the Republicans for seeing that the interests of this country come first. Thank you for what you've been doing and I'd appreciate it if you want to say a few words.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: few words.
DOC.TEXT:
Speaker of the House Tom Foley: Thank you very much Mr. President, I'll be brief in just echoing what you have yourself just said sir. This is a package that your negotiators and the bipartisan participating negotiators from the House and the Senate ranking Republican members, chairmen and the leadership on both sides have sought to achieve. It's not going to be easy or simple to obtain the votes that are necessary in both the House and the Senate, the majority of both parties in both bodies, that will have to be found to enact this package and within the next three weeks. But we pledge our efforts with yours to convince our colleagues and the country that this is strong undergirding of our economic future, our national prosperity and joint national interests. And in that spirit we are going to begin today to present to you legislation which will allow the orderly functioning of the federal government for the continuation of this next week in preparing to take the first step to implement this program. I want to pay a word, if I can, a special thanks to all my colleagues who participated in this, and especially to Dick Gephardt, the chairman of these budget negotiations who all sides, Republicans and Democrats, Senators and House members and you yourself have spoken eloquently to his patience and leadership. Thank you sir, for your involvement and your determination to aid in the process of bringing this package in the interest of the country to final achievement.
Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell: Thank you Mr. President. Now comes the hard part. It's one thing to get a budget agreement among ourselves, for which all involved should be commended. It's another thing to get the votes to pass it through the House and the Senate. That is a task to which we must now commit ourselves. This agreement is a compromise. Both sides can accurately say that the agreement includes provisions they don't like. Both sides can also accurately say the agreement doesn't include some provisions they think should be included. Cutting the deficit requires difficult choices but our nation's economic future requires that we make those choices. We have already debated too long. Now we must act decisively.
Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole: Mr. President, thank you very much and I want to thank my colleagues, and again particularly Dick Gephardt. The nay sayers, the nit pickers may have a field day because the easy vote in this case is to find something you don't like and vote no. But in my view we owe more to the American people than finding fault with what I consider to be a good agreement. Good positive, solid agreement, that in my view will help the American economy and demonstrate to the American people, who are sometime somewhat cynical, that the congress and the president and of the United States can work together and we can look ahead and we can do the right thing for our country. And so I would hope that my colleagues, and I speak now to my colleagues, certainly will study this document very carefully, will give it their best effort and when the roll is called that we will have a majority of Republicans and Democrats for this outstanding package. Thank you, Mr. President.
House Majority Leader Dick Gephardt: Forty years ago a mountaineer who joined in the first successful climb of Mt. Everest explained the success by saying, ``no expedition enjoyed better teamwork.'' To the speaker of the House, Congressman Foley, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, to the members of Congress who are here with us on the stage, to the administration and their representatives and the great staffs of all sides who worked so long and so hard with us, you have been heroic as we've made this climb together. The American people are today asking why was this summit necessary, why did it take so long and what did it achieve? If we are to enact this agreement, and I think we must, these questions must be answered persuasively and honestly. For ten years we have chosen a course together that has created large deficits and limited our capacity to meet the needs of our people and the demands of a very challenging age. Today we face a weakened economy and high rates of interest and inflation. Tomorrow, in absence of an agreement, massive across-the-board budget cuts would occur. The alternative to this agreement is fiscal chaos. To meet our responsibility to America's working families, this summit simply had to succeed. What delayed us for months is what has divided us for a decade. The parties to these talks had and continue to have deep disagreements over values, the role of government and the fairness of our taxes. But we all made compromise in the national interest. To bring this process to a successful conclusion, all of us, the American people and our national leaders must accept the responsibilities of the day. And as this debate unfolds I hope this will be said - that we achieved the largest deficit-reduction package in our history. That we focused the national debate on whether the tax code will be based on everybody's individual ability to pay. That vital issues, investing in our people, making our nation competitive and realizing social justice will rise again on the national agenda and that enactment of this measure will enable us to confront these important issues successfully in the years to come. I thank you, Mr. President and I thank all of the members of the summit.
House Minority Leader Bob Michel: Thank you Mr. President and my colleagues. I support the package wholeheartedly because I was one of the narrower group that within the last days, last ten days or so, made some of the final decisions. There may be some reservations with respect to some of our other summiteers on the platform. I think probably rightly so because we're making decisions that reach far out into five years. Everyone is entitled to know exactly what we have wrought in the printed word. As a matter of fact, I don't have, wasn't privy to the last few lines that were written early this morning. But, on balance, when I look at what we were originally faced with and here we are refraining from increasing marginal rates and not touching the unmentionable out there - Social Security. And then to have the incentives for growth that I see here and the expenditure caps over the next several years, that are real and enforceable, it seems to me that in the alternative so much better that we've done what we've done and hopefully that in the ensuing days we'll be able to sell a majority of the members on both sides of the aisle in both houses to give us the affirmative, both that I think is so imperative that I think that we have before we adjourn.
President Bush: Thank you all very much and let me conclude by singling out the White House team by name - Secretary Brady and Dick Darman, John Sununu, who stayed in there day in and day out with the members of Congress. In my view they did an outstanding job too. You know, Sen. Bentsen said in this meeting, I it's not betraying a confidence, that he hoped that I would do my level best to take this case to the American people. And I told him inside what I want to repeat here - that I will do everything I can to generate support from the American people for this compromise. I am convinced that the American people do not want to see us continue to mortgage the futures of their children and their grandchildren. And as I say compromise is the word here. All of us have had to do that. But to Sen. Bentsen I said in there and I would say here publicly, I want the American people to understand how important we feel this is. I want them to understand this is real. This is not a phony smoke and mirrors deficit-cutting program and I will do everything in my power to help the leadership, Republican and Democrat, get this passed in the United States Congress. Thank you all very much for coming.
End BC-Bush-Budget-Text - 2 Takes

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0429; changes cycle designator; inserts Bjt designator.
This Better Mousetrap Is a Loaf of Bread
LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.TEXT: Breadlines are forming in the streets of Washington these days. But this isn't a story about poverty. To the contrary. This is about people who, to their own amused astonishment, are willing to wait an hour to lay out $3.75 for a two-pound loaf of rye. ``It's bizarre,'' exults baker Mark Furstenberg, surveying people streaming hopefully into his Marvelous Market, even though the sign on the door proclaims, ``Sorry - no more bread.'' Furstenberg, 52, started selling bread on Connecticut Avenue eight weeks ago - traditional French baguettes, boules and brioches; fragrant rosemary bread; pungent sourdough full of black olives; sweet fig and currant loaves; course-grained, slightly bitter ryes; multigrain loaves. Handsome, hefty, old-fashioned loaves of bread that cost $1.25 to $7.50. Initial production was 300 pounds a day. Now that the local press has taken notice, the oven works from 11 p.m. through the night and into the following afternoon, producing 1,200 pounds daily. It still can't meet demand. Furstenberg is proving an old adage. But better bread is his better mousetrap. Most days, the breadline forms an hour before opening time. The overnight production is gone within a few hours. People who ordinarily would fuss about a five-minute wait in a supermarket hang around for the fresh production. Satisfied, some break off their first bite on the way out. The State Department, putting on a banquet, asked to buy an entire day's output. Furstenberg refused; he wouldn't deprive his neighborhood customers. Suburbanites drive in for the bread. The bakery rations sales to two loaves per customer. Some make extravagant appeals for a third loaf - ``for my pregnant sister who can't come in.'' They beg to have bread air-expressed to distant relatives. ``Who are these people?'' Furstenberg asks in mock despair. ``After all, it's only bread.'' But he knows who they are. For 30 years, he said, he'd heard people say the same thing: ``You can't get good bread in Washington.'' He said it himself. So he invested $80,000 in savings, borrowed more from a bank, studied baking in France, traveled this country to sample loaves. He imported an oven from France and dispatched two employees to spend a month in Los Angeles learning the craft from Nancy Silverton, proprietor of famous La Brea Bakery, whose bread Furstenberg most wanted to replicate. Business was good even before The Washington Post discovered Marvelous Market and fell in love. The newspaper's Home section wrote about the bread on a Thursday, the Food Section the following Wednesday and restaurant reviewer Phyllis Richman on Sunday. (``Now Washington has world-class bread.'') The New York Times also took approving notice. That's when the lines started forming. One morning last week, Sylvia Mulhauser, a visitor from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was asked if she ever thought she'd wait 45 minutes for bread. ``No,'' she said, ``and I never thought I'd pay $3.75 for a loaf, either.'' Asked why she'd do it, Mrs. Mulhauser spelled out her reasons: ``Crunchy. Chewy. Flavorful. Good texture.''

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Opener Leaves the Big Question Unanswered
DOC.TEXT: Return with us now to the fictional town of Twin Peaks, where nothing is quite what it seems and everyone is out to lunch. Food is still a central theme, although this time cherry pie has taken a back seat to huckleberries. And half of Twin Peaks' inhabitants are still playing life's card game without picture cards. No, no one ever came right out and said who killed homecoming queen Laura Palmer during Sunday night's two-hour season premiere of ABC's truly bizaare soap opera. But then no one has ever accused ``Twin Peaks'' creators David Lynch and Mark Frost of writing in declarative sentences. For Peaks freaks, though, Sunday's second season opener provided a host of substantial, if sometimes incomprehensible, clues to Palmer's murderer. First things first, however. No, pie-loving FBI agent Dale Cooper is not dead, despite taking three slugs in last season's cliffhanger ending from an unknown assailant at point-blank range. Yes, he was wearing a bulletproof vest. But it seems a bothersome wood tick had caused Cooper some discomfort and he had hitched up his vest to get at it. His unprotected abdomen was hit. This, though, did not stop him from springing out of his hospital bed to find Palmer's killer. It did cause him to see a vision of a giant bathed in white light who gave him three clues to the cosmic goings-on in Twin Peaks. One of the profound nuggets: ``There's a man in a smiling bag.'' You hate to see that. The mill did indeed burn to the ground. And if you listened to the recently released cassette of Cooper's dictated ramblings to his secretary, you would have already known that consumate witch Catherine Martell and mysterious widow Josie Packard are missing. Most of the other wacko residents are in comas or the hospital. Nadine Hurley survived her suicide attempt but is comatose. And the reason she always wears that eye patch is that her husband accidentally blinded her in one eye during a hunting trip that doubled as their secret honeymoon. Catherine's long-suffering husband, Pete, suffered smoke inhalation during the sawmill blaze, as did Shelly Johnson.
