The model plane had a wing span of 4 feet, investigators said. ``I felt a shudder about a half-mile from the landing strip,'' Nicolary said. ``I never saw a plane. But witnesses told us they did.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Burn Transmission Tower of Pro-Sandinista Station
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen raided and burned down a a pro-Sandinista radio station's transmission tower on the eve of planned demonstrations against the government of President Violeta Chamorro. The radio station manager, William Grisby, estimated damages at more than $200,000. He did not speculate on who carried out Sunday's attack. Grisby, a Sandinista and deputy in the National Assembly, has had public differences in recent weeks with some Sandinista leaders. His station, La Primerisima, is a cooperative that follows the political line of the opposition Sandinista National Liberation Front. The Sandinistas have been increasingly at odds with the government in past weeks. The leftist Sandinistas governed Nicaragua until April, when they were succeeded by Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed coalition. Her forces beat the Sandinistas in February elections that signalled an end to a nine-year insurgency by U.S.-supported Contra rebels. In recent days, the Sandinistas have issued calls for mass protests against the new government. They have planned nationwide marches for today to protest scheduled massive firings by the government and other austerity measures. Describing the attack at the transmission station, Victor Sanchez Lopez, who was on duty there at the time, said four men came to the tower claiming to be inspectors for the Interior Ministry. ``They forced me out of the room and then sprayed gasoline all over the equipment and set it on fire,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Most Comprehensive Fetal Disposal Law Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: A state law requiring hospitals and clinics to arrange for the burial or cremation of aborted fetuses instead of flushing them into the sewer system became effective today. The measure, considered the nation's strictest, was strongly opposed by medical groups, which contended that it added costs and risks to disposal. Abortion rights advocates charged it might have a chilling effect on women considering an abortion. ``I think it says that in Minnesota we regard the remains of unborn babies with dignity and not something to be thrown down the sewer system,'' said Brian Gibson, director of Pro-Life Action Ministries of the Twin Cities. Gibson's group helped initiate the law by exhibiting an aborted fetus it said came from a clinic's garbage container. The clinic denied it. Dave Feinwachs, general counsel for the Minnesota Hospital Association, complained that the law ``makes illegal the common, sanitary practice of flushing fetal tissue into the sewer system.'' ``Storing tissue in barrels of formaldehyde and trucking it around is just plain stupid,'' he said. Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, said the law is ``designed to give the inference that the state of Minnesota is saying to women, `You just committed murder. You just killed a little person.' '' The law also prohibits the burning of fetal tissue in hospital incinerators, another common disposal method. The law applies to miscarriages as well as induced abortions. It carries up to 90 days in jail and a $700 fine. Planned Parenthood sued to block the 1987 law, contending it was vague and would stifle abortions by adding costs and psychological trauma. A federal judge agreed in 1989, but a federal appeals court overruled him in August. Rebecca Palmer, a Planned Parenthood laywer, said the group decided against appealing to the U.S. Supreme Court because of the high court's 1989 decision giving states greater leeway to restrict abortion. Laws, regulations or city ordinances in at least 15 other states have called for special disposal of fetal remains, said Thomas Strahan of the Rutherford Institute in Charlottesville, Va., a non-profit legal services organization. But some of those laws were struck down as unconstitutional and others do not have penalties or are too vague to be enforced, he said. Minnesota's law is ``the most comprehensive and definitive,'' Strahan said. Hospitals and abortion clinics have complained to the Health Department that some funeral homes and cemeteries have refused to take fetal remains, fearing pickets from anti-abortion groups. Dan McInerney, deputy state health commissioner, said his department will approve alternatives only when burial and cremation prove impossible to obtain. ``We've been advising our members to cooperate,'' said Gary Larson, executive director of the Minnesota Funeral Directors Association. ``But on the other hand, a funeral home is not responsible for handling fetal tissue. We are in business to provide funerals for families of people who die.'' Dale Carlson, president of the Minnesota Association of Cemetery Officials, denied there is any widespread opposition to taking fetuses. ``It's really not for us to pick and choose or question how they (specimens for burial) got to that point,'' he said. Minnesota averages 16,000 to 17,000 abortions annually, and Feinwachs said it is unclear how many miscarriages there are. It's also unclear what the additional costs will be. ``Whatever it is, it's a waste of money because it's unnecessary,'' he said. ``Now we are faced with the very sensitive dilemma of telling them (women who have miscarried) that there's this extra cost for a funeral.''

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Plane Goes Down During Fire Battle From Earlier Crash
DOC.TEXT: A tanker plane crashed, killing two people, during a battle against a forest fire that was itself ignited by a crash that claimed two lives, authorities say. The firefighting Lockheed Neptune P-2V went down Sunday in sight of a command post set up because of the first crash, of a single-engine Cessna on Saturday. The irst crash ignited a fire in Olympic National Forest that grew to 15 acres, the U.S. Forest Service said. Killed in the accident were David L. Wurscher, 46, of Bremerton, and Tom Eller, 62, of Newman Lake, officials said. Wurscher owned the plane and was practicing search-and-rescue under Eller's supervision, said Brian Holmes of the state Aeronautics Division. Its wreckage was spotted in a steep, heavily wooded area early Sunday, he said. The tanker was owned by Black Hills Aviation of Alamogordo, N.M., and was under contract to the Forest Service, said company President Arnold Kolb. The plane made one drop of retardant on the fire, then ``settled into the trees,'' he said. Killed were the pilot, Ralph Glasgow of Honeyville, Utah, and the co-pilot, Steve Bovey of Alamogordo, N.M., Kolb said. He did not know their ages.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Looks at Payroll Tax for Crimefighting
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins wants to pay half the cost of thousands more police officers through a new payroll tax on residents and commuters who work in the city. From 5,000 to 7,500 new officers and 2,500 civilians to take over desk work would be hired under recommendations to be unveiled today by Police Commissioner Lee Brown, newspapers reported. The city has 25,556 officers. The heftier force is part of a broader anti-crime strategy of the mayor's in response to a string of shootings, many of them involving children hit by stray bullets. ``We the people,'' Dinkins said when asked who would pay for the plan. Newspaper have reported the mayor's crime-fighting proposals would cost between $500 million and $1 billion. The payroll tax would start at 0.1 percent of a worker's adjusted gross income next year and go to 0.15 percent the year after that. The tax, which requires approval by the Legislature, would cost a worker earning $50,000 in adjusted gross income $50 next year and $75 in subsequent years. Employers would have to match the amount their workers paid, The New York Times said today. Dinkins said Friday that hiring more police officers ``will demonstrate that this administration has responded in an intelligent, reasonable, responsible way'' to concerns about crime. Dinkins has insisted on waiting for Brown's recommendations before committing himself to hiring a specific number of new officers.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Along Eastern Seaboard
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered along the Eastern seaboard early today and fog shrouded the Appalachians. Skies were mostly clear in the Midwest, West and parts of the South. Today's forecast called for temperatures in the 60s in the northern Plains and Northeast, 70s in the Midwest, Pacific Northwest and southern Rockies, and 80s in the South and lower Plains. The desert Southwest was likely to see temperatures soar into the 90s. Rain and isolated thunderstorms were likely today in the Ohio Valley and Great Lakes regions. Rain also was expected from the coast of South Carolina to Florida's panhandle. Heavy rain was expected in eastern Florida. In the Southwest and southern Rockies, scattered rain was expected later in the day and heavy rain in west Texas could cause flooding. Showers were expected along Washington's coastline. The nation's high on Sunday was 103 degrees at Red Bluff, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Church President In Serious Condition After Return To ICU
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson remained in serious but stable condition today at LDS Hospital's intensive care unit, where he was returned Sunday after gastrointestinal bleeding was detected. Church spokesman Don LeFevre said the internal bleeding was discovered by doctors Sunday morning and apparently was not related to two operations earlier to remove blood clots from his brain. The 91-year-old church leader was hospitalized Sept. 18, complaining of severe headaches and difficulty swallowing. The next day, doctors operated to remove two large blood clots from his brain. On Sept. 23, the church leader underwent a second operation when one of the subdural hematomas reformed. But brain scans since then have shown no recurrence, LeFevre said. Earlier, LeFevre said if Benson continued to progress, he could be released from the hospital before the faith's General Conference next weekend. LeFevre was unsure Sunday when Benson would be released from the hospital. ``We'll have to leave that up to the doctors,'' he said. Benson has been church president of the 7.5 million member church since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Papal Mass Opens Monthlong Synod on Formation of Priests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts top 2 grafs to CLARIFY that church is seeking candidates for priesthood. Pickup 3rd graf, ``The pontiff...''
DOC.HEAD: By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has opened a worldwide synod of bishops to address such questions as how to persuade more men to become priests without abandoning rules demanding that they be celibate and forsake marriage. The monthlong synod on the priesthood is to focus on the problem of ``burnout'' among the church's `shepherds', challenges to celibacy and the dwindling number of candidates interested in the priesthood. The pontiff inaugurated the assembly on Sunday by celebrating a solemn Mass in St. Peter's Basilica for some 1,000 priests, bishops and cardinals from around the world. The synod, an advisory body that meets to discuss major issues in the Roman Catholic Church, was called by John Paul to discuss the formation of priests. ``Let me express the hope that your labors here will produce the abundant fruit which the ecclesiastical community is expecting,'' the pope, clad in gold robes and miter, said in his homily. He noted that bishops from China, Vietnam and Laos were missing from the gathering, and said he hoped they would join the synod later. No reason was given for the absence of bishops Jean Khamse of Laos and Cambodia, Paul Nguyen Van Hoa and Emmanuel Le Phong Thuan of Vietnam, and Lucas Liu Hsien-Tang of China. The Vatican says the church faces serious restrictions in those Communist countries. At the last synod in 1987, dealing with the laity, Vietnamese prelates arrived midway through the assembly. The synod is expected to focus on the difficulty in maintaining the church's rules ``in a world characterized by eroticism,'' as a working document put it. The rules themselves are not expected to be subjects for debate, however, as the pope has shown no indication they might be changed. Several sexual scandals have embarrased the church in recent months. The archbishop of Atlanta, Eugene A. Marino, resigned in July following revelations of a two-year ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman. In Newfoundland, Canada, a report in July by a church-appointed commission said priests had sexually abused boys in the province for more than a decade. ``Some priests question this requirement (celibacy) and some candidates leave formation for this reason,'' the working document said. It noted that in public opinion, celibacy is ``often incomprehensible and ridiculed.'' A priest who accepts celibacy ``is sometimes looked upon in a strange way,'' it said. ``In this situation a priest can become totally isolated and misunderstood to the point of becoming deeply demoralized,'' it said. ``In some cases, the crisis in the priestly identity can explain why priests leave the ministry.'' The Vatican cited ``the phenomenon of burnout, from which priests of all ages seem to suffer. They live in situations marked by tiredness, resignation, lack of creativity.'' The document lamented the shortage of priests and declining number of candidates in some countries. ``The shortage of priests carries the further consequence that those older priests who are still active might become overburdened, thus making them subject to stress and to approach their work ... simply as functionaries,'' it said. According to the latest statistics, there are 400,000 priests in the world, down from 406,000 five years ago. In the United States, students in the last four years of seminary numbered 3,698 this year, compared with 7,855 in 1968. The 200 bishops at the synod included Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago, Cardinal James Hickey of Washington, D.C., Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati and Bishop John Marshall of Burlington, Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Search Continues For Victims in Clear Lake Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: Annoyance at the pilot of a World War II Navy plane intruding on a air show quickly turned to horror when the craft plunged into a lake, killing at least seven people. ``It was all over in just a split second. A plume of water, parts up in the air. You heard the sound of the impact,'' said Stan Sinn, a San Jose pilot who was among 350 spectators and competitors who watched the crash Saturday. ``Then, in less than a minute, the lake looks like nothing ever happened. It happened so quick if you had blinked your eye you would have missed it.'' Authorities believe seven people were on board. No one survived, said Walt Smith, a Federal Aviation Administration official based in nearby Santa Rosa. Six bodies have been recovered from the murky water, and rescuers intended to search for a seventh victim today. Federal and county officials haven't released the identities of those aboard the plane. But the family of San Rafael pilot-plane owner Doug Lacey said they believe he was on board when it crashed. Officials have said that Lacey, 40, was at the controls of the aircraft when it stopped at Sonoma County Airport Saturday morning to refuel. But Lacey's family doubts the experienced pilot could have been at the controls when it crashed, said Rosemary Wurst, a cousin. ``He was an excellent pilot. Somebody screwed up, but they don't think Doug was flying the airplane,'' she said, adding that one of the passengers migtt have been the pilot. Just before the crash, the bulky aircraft made four low passes over the crowd and floating seaplanes meeting for the annual ``Seaplane Fly-In'' at Clear Lake, about 100 miles north of San Francisco. ``We could see it was a dangerous situation. We were in the process of getting our aircraft out of the air when he made the last pass, the fatal one,'' Sinn said. The plane flew straight up to about 500 feet and stalled on its final pass, Sinn said. An instant later, the wing dipped and the plane turned upside down, plunging nose first into the water and sending up a plume of water 60 to 70 feet high, he said. The plane landed in six feet of water about 50 yards offshore on the lake's west end, the FAA said. Officials said an initial investigation indicates a heavy load of fuel and passengers combined with high temperatures may have caused the plane to stall. The plane had taken off from the Sonoma County Airport in Santa Rosa, south of Lake County, investigators said. The plane, believed to date from 1945, was not part of the seaplane convention, said Walter Windus, vice president of the Seaplane Pilots Association, an event sponsor. ``He was strictly an intruder,'' said Windus, who witnessed the crash. ``He saw an opportunity to show off and he took advantage of it. He was doing air maneuvers that were not appropriate to that type of aircraft.'' Convention organizers tried desperately to contact the pilot of the mystery plane by radio, planning to tell him to leave, but could not reach him, he said. ``His behavior was so obnoxious,'' Windus said, ``I was going to tell him to go away or I was going to report him to the FAA.''

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Writer, White, Dead at 78
DOC.NOTE: Eds: subs 3rd graf, ``White, a...'' with 1 graf to say he won Nobel Prize in 1973. Subs 11th graf ``His novel...'' to CORRECT, removing reference to winning prize for one book, as it is given for a body of work.
DOC.TEXT: Patrick White, a British-born writer whose Nobel prize-winning fiction drew inspiration from life in Australia's outback, has died, his literary agent said today. White was 78. Barbara Mobbs, White's agent, said the author died Sunday of respiratory failure after a lengthy illness. White, a rancher-turned-writer, frequently set his novels in the outback. Considered one of this country's leading authors, his works were required reading in many high schools and universities. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in literature in 1973. The Sydney Morning Herald today eulogized White as the ``greatest Australian writer to date by far.'' ``He transcended the cultural divisions from the past. He was both contemporary and a traditionalist, an Australian and simultaneously an international writer,'' the newspaper said. The poet, playwright and novelist was born on May 28, 1912, in London. He was educated at King's College, Cambridge. He later worked as a ``jackaroo,'' or rancher, in New South Wales state and then returned to England to study languages at Cambridge. He served as an intelligence officer in the Royal Air Force in the Middle East during World War II. ``Since the war, my life has been practically uneventful,'' White wrote for a 1955 reference work on authors. ``I returned to Australia to a small property in Castle Hill, a town about 25 miles from Sydney, where I breed schnauzers, saanen goats, cultivate olives and citrus fruit, grow vegetables and live more or less off my own produce.'' His first novel, ``Happy Valley,'' published in 1939, was awarded the Australian Literary Society Gold Medal. His 1955 novel, ``The Tree of Man,'' won the same prize. His novel, ``Eye of the Storm,'' portrayed the final days of an elderly woman whose greedy relatives returned to Europe to await her death. ``Eye of the Storm'' also explored Australians' attitudes toward their European cultural roots. Essayist Margaret B. Lewis once wrote: ``White is a writer who makes serious demands of his readers, straining prose to the utmost poetic limits, putting severe pressure on syntax and vocabulary and stretchin credence to an unusual degree in his search for the transcendent in the lives of his idiosyncratic characters.'' White's plays included the 1977 ``Big Toys'' about the government's uranium mining policies, ``Signal Driver'' in 1982, and ``Netherwood'' the following year. He also wrote a screenplay, a book of verse and a 1981 autobiography, ``Flaws in the Glass: A Self-Portrait.'' Critics described his autobiography as a merciless self-examination. It omitted his acts of generosity, such as his support for Aboriginal education and his use of Nobel money to establish an award for older Australian writers. In ``Flaws in the Glass,'' White wrote frankly of his homosexuality, a subject he also had addressed in ``The Twyborn Affair'' in 1979. There was no immediate word of survivors. A spokesman said funeral arrangements were being kept private.

DOC.HEAD: Disaster Declaration Sought Because of Gas Leak in Kazakhstan
DOC.TEXT: The president of Soviet Kazakhstan has called for an independent, international inquiry into an explosion and toxic gas release from a nuclear fuel factory in his republic. The official news agency Tass said Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of Kazakhstan, sent a telegram to the Kremlin asking officials to declare an ecological disaster near the Ulbinsky metallurgical plant. The official news agency Tass said Saturday that a Sept. 12 explosion and fire at the plant affected ``a considerable part of the population of Ust-Kamenogorsk.'' Ust-Kamenogorsk, a city of 20,000 people, lies near the border with China and Mongolia in the Altai mountains. The plant is one of the largest producers of fuel for nuclear power plants in the Soviet Union. The explosion and fire sent toxic gas into the densely populated area around the plants. Preliminary tests showed twice the permitted levels of beryllium in air and water samples. Several people were injured in the blast. There was no report of radiation release. Beryllium is a very light metal that can catch fire easily and burn rapidly, vaporizing and releasing deadly beryllium oxide. ``The public of Kazhakstan and population of the city demand urgent measures to improve the situation and they demand compensation for damage to their health,'' Nazarbayev said in his telegram to Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Nazarbayev was quoted as saying that local authorities have already declared the region around the plant an ecological disaster zone.

DOC.HEAD: Flight 103 Inquiry Opens in Scotland
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one months after Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, a public inquiry opened today focusing on how similar terrorist bombings can be prevented. The hearing will look into security lapses but not criminal responsibility for the crash on Dec. 21, 1988, which killed 270 people. That key question is still being investigated by police. The fathers of two of the mainly young victims urged that the presiding judge should call airline and government witnesses to account for the tragedy. ``Hopefully, they will go into the culpability of Pan Am, the State Department, the Federal Aviation Administration, the British government and the German government,'' said George Williams of Joppatowne, Md. ``I want people from Pan Am jailed, people from the government censured and fired that were involved in the cover-up, and I want the criminals executed,'' he told reporters. Williams, whose son, Geordie, 24, was killed in the crash, and Dr. Jim Swire, spokesman for the British relatives' group, U.K. Families-Flight 103, were among about 30 spectators at the start of the inquiry. Swire's daughter, Flora, 24, was killed. The fatal accident inquiry, expected to last three months, is being held a hall converted into a court at Dumfries' Crichton Royal Hospital 10 miles from Lockerbie. The judge, Sheriff Principal John S. Mowat, is due to decide whether there were ``reasonable precautions, if any, whereby the deaths might have been avoided,'' the Scottish Courts Administration says. The first witness, Pan Am aircraft mechanic Paul Whiteley, 41, testified that he led a crew which did routine maintenance on Flight 103 at London's Heathrow Airport on Dec. 21, 1988, and believed the Boeing 747 was airworthy. Alan Topp, 54, an air traffic controller at Prestwick, Scotland, said Flight 103's radar blip suddenly vanished. He said he checked other controllers and the pilot of a KLM plane to try to locate the Pan Am flight but no one could find it. Scottish and U.S. officials said in December that there was not enough evidence to prosecute anyone for the bombing. Prime suspects are Ahmed Jibril's radical Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, and Mohammed Abu Talb of the Popular Struggle Front, who was convicted of bombings in Europe. The inquiry will examine security at Heathrow Airport in London, the last stop for the New York-bound flight, and may hear testimony from Pan Am baggage handlers at Frankfurt Airport, where the flight originated. Police have said the bomb hidden in a radio-cassette recorder in a suitcase was probably put aboard the flight in Frankfurt. The flight changed from a Boeing 727 to a Boeing 747 at Heathrow. Scotland's senior law officer, Lord Fraser, the Lord Advocate who is presenting the government's case, was quoted in an interview today in Scotland's Daily Record as saying the bombers will be caught. ``Make no mistake. The Lockerbie bombers will eventually be caught. There will be no letup in the investigation ... we are much further on than we were months ago,'' he was quoted as saying. Scottish investigators have denied a report in London's Sunday Times that the investigation ``has almost ground to a halt'' because of ``incompetence, rivalry between police forces and interference by foreign intelligence services.''

DOC.HEAD: Housewife Dreams of Operating Family-Run Power Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, ``She's got . . .' to CORRECT quote, `row to hoe,' sted `road to hoe.'
DOC.TEXT: A middle-aged housewife who fought to gain government approval for one dam she bought and another she leased has one more hurdle in her quest to build a family-owned hydroelectric company - financing. Elaine Hitchcock is struggling to secure $800,000 in loans for equipment and start-up costs to begin operating the dams in 1991. ``I made a choice to see these up and running and they will be. I won't give up,'' she said last week. Mrs. Hitchcock, who decided in 1982 to establish a power company, has worked out deals with utilities to buy power from her and has persuaded family members to raise the capital needed to get federal licenses on the dams. After spending $180,000 on consultants engineers, environmentalists and other technical people to prepare her applications, Mrs. Hitchcock gained approval in March 1989 from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Mrs. Hitchcock, who lives in Kohler, a city of 1,650 about 50 miles north of Milwaukee near the Lake Michigan shoreline, said she has contacted about 40 lending institutions for financing and encountered ``absolute discrimination.'' One bank told her ``no woman should get more than $50,000,'' said Bob Everett, a lawyer for Mrs. Hitchcock from Ashland, Ky. ``This lady has a iron stomach,'' he said. ``There are corporations who cannot handle this sort of hostile business climate.'' Her quest for loans rests on a 1978 federal law that requires utilities to purchase power from private operators. The state has agreed to reduce interest on her debts from market rates to 3 percent once loans are obtained. Mrs. Hitchcock, who said she is in her early 50s, began researching in 1982 the idea of buying dams abandoned in the 1950s and 1960s. Her husband is an engineer. She reasoned the dams would provide a renewable and environmentally safe source of energy. The profits - perhaps $100,000 a year - would ensure financial stability for herself, husband and three adult children. Friends and relatives questioned whether it was worth it; at one point her family told her to quit. Only a handful of people across the nation have started family-owned hydroelectric plants. One recently failed in Indiana. In 1985, Mrs. Hitchcock leased a dam on the Eau Galle River and a year later bought the Rock River dam and its power plant in Watertown for $3,122. Mrs. Hitchcock's son, Carl, 30, has leased two more dams for the family - one on the Sheboygan River and another on the Red Cedar River. The dams have working generators but are awaiting federal licenses. Northern States Power Co. signed a 20-year contract to buy electricity from Mrs. Hitchcock, and a similar deal is about to be signed with Wisconsin Electric Power Co., she said. Mrs. Hitchcock estimates the Eau Galle River project will furnish the yearly electrical needs of as many as 30 homes. Dan Moran, an analyst for the state Division of Energy, said about 20 small hydroelectric plants, owned by mostly local governments, operate in Wisconsin. Another 20 are idle but have working equipment that could provide a ``reasonable payback'' for private owners, he said. But John Bartel, a spokesman for Wisconsin Electric, the state's largest electric utility, said Mrs. Hitchcock's venture is risky and faces unpredictable weather and operating costs. Last year, only 2 percent of the utility's output came from the 16 hydroelectric plants it operates, he said. ``She's got a tough row to hoe,'' he said. ``I hope she is successful.''

DOC.HEAD: Source Tells Paper a Man Known by Humphrey is Also Suspect
DOC.TEXT: Police have found evidence indicating the presence of a man other than the most prominent suspect at the scenes of two of the five college student slayings, an unidentified source told one newspaper. A second newspaper has cited an unnamed source that a man known to that suspect, Edward Lewis Humphrey, is also a suspect in the five murders. Humphrey, who has not been charged in the slayings, has been jailed in Brevard County for a month on $1 million bond in the beating of his grandmother. Laboratory analysis shows another man left important physical evidence at the scene of at least two of the five murders last month, law enforcement officials told the St. Petersburg Times. Investigators still consider Humphrey a suspect in the slayings based on other evidence, however, and they are awaiting more lab test results. Those tests could take as long as six months to complete. If officials know who left the physical evidence at the two crime scenes, they aren't saying. But they do say it's possible the killer may have worked in concert with a second person. The mutilated bodies of Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26. The next morning, Christa Hoyt, 18, was found decapitated. Manuel Taboada and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found dead Aug. 28. On Sunday, the Tampa Tribune quoted a law-enforcement source it did not identify as saying that a ``person known to be an associate of Humphrey is a suspect'' and that his name became known to investigators soon after the killings. The man was living in Gainesville at the time of the murders but his whereabouts now are unclear, the source said. The lawyer representing Humphrey said he finds it hard to believe the slayings could have been the work of more than one person. ``I'm no expert on crime scenes and crime suspects, but it doesn't seem likely to me to be a multiple participant case,'' Brevard County public defender J.R. Russo said. ``We're not going to exclude the possibility that more than one person could be involved,'' said Gainesville police Sgt. Dick Gerard, spokesman for the 150-member task force investigating the slayings. A day after the fourth and fifth victims were found in late August, Gainesville police Chief Wayland Clifton said he believed the killings were the work of one person. Humphrey faces trial Oct. 8 on an aggravated battery charge in an attack on 79-year-old Elna Hlavaty. Relatives identified Humphrey, 18, as her assailant on the night of the attack, but Mrs. Hlavaty has since denied she was beaten by Humphrey.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian and Saudi Ministers Discuss Ties, Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with background on past relations. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The IRNA...'
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of Iran and Saudi Arabia met over the weekend, Iran said today, in the first talks between senior officials from the countries since they broke diplomatic ties 2{ years ago. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said that during the meeting Sunday in New York, the diplomats discussed restoring diplomatic relations and traded views on the Persian Gulf crisis. The ground-breaking meeting apparently did not go much beyond both sides spelling out their positions. But it was the most positive sign yet that the two countries may be moving toward a rapprochement amid the political upheaval triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A reconciliation would help draw Iran into the anti-Iraq camp and intensify Saddam Hussein's isolation. Saddam has been courting neighboring Iran, which was at war with Iraq from 1980-1988, for help in puncturing the U.N. economic embargo imposed after the invasion. Saudi-Iranian ties were severed in a dispute over the number of Iranians allowed to attend the annual Moslem pilgrimage to holy sites in Saudi Arabia. There had been several violent incidents that the Saudis said were incited by Iran's fundamentalist leaders. The Islamic Republic News Agency dispatch said the meeting between Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran and Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia took place at U.N. headquarters. The official agency did not say how long it lasted. The ministers were in New York for a global summit on children. IRNA quoted Velayati as telling Prince Saud that the main obstacle to resumption of relations was the dispute over the number of Iranians allowed into Saudi Arabia to worship at Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina. The Iranian agency quoted Prince Saud as saying his government is eager to resolve this issue before the next pilgrimage in June. The agency said Prince Saud ``promised that his government will do its best so that Iranian Moslems perform their rituals in a suitable matter.'' In 1987, violent riots in Mecca killed 402 people. Most victims were Iranians defying Saudi orders that ban political rallying during the pilgrimage season. The following year, the Saudis announced a quota system that restricted the number of pilgrims allowed to participate in the annual event to 1,000 per one million population for each country. The Iranias protested the move, which would have cut the size of their contingent by more than two thirds - from 150,000 to 45,000. They called for stripping King Fahd of Saudi Arabia of custodianship of the holy shrines. In April 1988, the Saudis severed relations with Tehran, accusing Iran of subversion and terrorism. The Iranian complaints grew louder this year after 1,426 people died in a stampede in a pedestrian tunnel in Mecca. Tehran accused the Saudis of failing to provide adequate protection for the pilgrims. During its 1980-88 war with Iraq, Iran accused the Saudis of bankrolling Baghdad's war effort. Also during Sunday's meeting, Velayati explained Iran's position on the Persian Gulf crisis triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, IRNA said. It said Velayati told Prince Saud that Iran ``is strongly opposed to the presence of foreign forces in the gulf and especially holy lands.'' ``Regional countries must cooperate for the security of the gulf and liberation of Kuwait from Iraqi occupation,'' the news agency quoted Velayati as saying. Saudi Arabia invited the multinational force onto its territory, fearing an Iraqi invasion. About 200,000 U.S. and other foreign troops have massed in the Persian Gulf, mostly in Saudi Arabia, to counter Iraq. Baghdad's government, capitalizing on Iran's anti-Western sentiment, moved quickly after the invasion of Kuwait to formalize a peace deal with the Iranians, accepting all their terms for settling a border dispute. Although Tehran says it is committed to the U.N. embargo of Iraq, there have been increasing reports it is allowing food and other goods to move across the common border to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Temporary Halt in Plan for Indian Job Quotas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, ``Acting Chief...'' with 1 graf to SPECIFY that injunction will be in effect until court rules.
DOC.TEXT: India's Supreme Court today ordered the government to halt its job quota program. The court said it hoped its temporary injunction would stop a wave of student protests and suicides. The five-judge panel also advanced the date for hearing arguments on the legality of the program by two weeks to Oct. 25, Press Trust of India reported. The court said the government could continue preparations for carrying out the plan, which reserves 27 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. The government is assembling a list of thousands of castes which will qualify for preference in job applications. Another 22 percent already are set aside for the lowest strata in the rigid hierarchy of Indian society, tribespeople and the so-called untouchables. Acting Chief Justice Ranganath Mishra said he hoped that peace would be restored while the issue was being studied by the nation's highest court. The temporary injunction will remain in effect until the Supreme Court rules on the legality of the quotas. At least 70 people have died in demonstrations against the plan, announced Aug. 7 by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. About 20 were upper-caste students who committed suicide by self-immolation or poisoning after claiming they were victimized by the plan. In Parliament, the government faced a separate problem when it failed to pass a constitutional amendment extending federal rule in the northern state of Punjab, where Sikh militants are fighting for independence. The state govenment in Punjab was dismissed in 1987 and replaced by federal rule, which the Constitution limits to three years. Amending the document requires a two-thirds majority. In a surprise move aimed at embarassing the government, the opposition Congress Party refused to support the bill. Leaders of all the parties were summoned to the speaker's chambers to find a way out of the impasse. Singh' 10-month-old government suffered another setback when the speaker of the legislature agreed to hold a debate on a motion seeking to censure the government for mishandling the student protest. The motion, if passed, would put pressure on the government to quit, said Kewal Verma, a parliamentary analyst. ``There is no legal obligation on the part of the government to resign, but it would amount to its defeat in moral terms,'' said Verma. In the parliament, Congress Party members accused Singh of being ``obstinate'' for refusing to suspend or reconsider the affirmative action plan. ``Down, down, resign, resign,'' they shouted as Singh stood up to speak. He was prevented from addressing the house. ``Can't you see there is blood in your hands,'' said Congress lawmaker Ajit Panja. Some members advanced menacingly at Singh but were stopped by colleagues. ``You are a bloodstained politician,'' said Panja. Former Congress minister Vasant Sathe said he was beginning a ``fast unto death'' until Singh stops ``police terror'' on the students. In the northern town of Jammu, 17-year-old student Sandeep Sharma set himself on fire today in the latest suicide bid to protest the job quotas. He suffered third-degree burns over most of his body. At least 20 students have died in the past 12 days from self-inflicted injuries. Most left notes blaming Singh's job policy. In addition, 50 people have died by police gunfire in street battles. Singh announced the policy Aug. 7 to increase the quota for low-caste Indians in government jobs to 49 percent, saying he was seeking social justice for Indians discriminated against because of the social station of their birth. Upper-caste students say reverse discrimination will deprive them of government jobs for which they are better qualified. Singh also is facing a revolt in his own Janata Dal party over the issue. Former Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal resigned his parliamentary seat on Sunday, and dissidents called for a new party leader. But the party's parliament bloc, a key forum, gave Singh a vote of confidence. Allied parties whose tacit support keep the governing coalition in power also have attacked the government's handling of the demonstrations, although none has criticized the idea of reserving jobs for deprived classes.

DOC.HEAD: Writer, Ethnologist Michel Leiris Dies
DOC.TEXT: Michel Leiris, a writer who helped lead the surrealist movement in the 1920s and later authored innovative studies of ethnic groups, has died at his country home, associates said today. He was 89. He died Sunday in the town of Saint Hilaire, southwest of Paris. The cause was not disclosed. Leiris published his first work at the age of 25 - a collection of poems. He became involved with surrealist writers and artists, and was a contributor to the movement's journal, ``The Surrealist Revolution.'' He broke with the movement in 1929 and two years later joined a two-year research mission across central Africa. Upon returning to France, he published an account of the mission, ``Phantom Africa,'' combining poetry and stream-of-consciousness prose with more traditional ethnological analysis. He also accepted a post at the Musee de l'Homme (Museum of Man) in Paris as head of its section on sub-Saharan Africa. Later works included ``L'Age d'Homme'' (The Age of Man) and ``La Regle du Jeu'' (The Rule of the Game), as well as art criticism and essays about his trips to China, Cuba, Africa and the Caribbean. In his later years, he sought privacy. He refused to accept the National Grand Prize of Letters in 1980, saying he did not want to be media topic, and he was rarely photographed. No information was immediately available regarding his survivors or funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Scouts Find Stolen Wedding Items
DOC.TEXT: Boy Scouts cleaning highway litter gave two newlyweds a belated wedding present when they found a bundle of checks and cards stolen from them earlier this month. A soggy cardboard box spotted over the weekend by the White Beat Lake troop also contained a copy of vows Cynthia and Karl Rutherford read to each other at their wedding in Eagan Sept. 1. The box was stolen from the couple's pickup truck the day after the wedding, along with Cynthia's wedding dress, her husband's tuxedo and their luggage. ``It kind of put a halt to their honeymoon all at once,'' said Gordon Byers, the bride's father. ``They came back home Sunday because they were penniless.'' Byers estimated that $500 in cash and checks were in the box when it was stolen. The cash was not recovered. Scouts said they were surprised to find the box while they were cleaning Minnesota Highway 96 in Grant Township as part of the Minnesota Transportation Department's adopt-a-highway program. ``We just expected to find the usual highway trash,'' Ryan True, 11. ``He said the same thing I did,'' said True's mother, Sue. ```How could someone rob someone on their honeymoon?' It just makes you sick.'' Byers said his daughter would be happy to have the greeting cards back. ``Some of them had special messages on them,'' he said. ``Some of these people haven't even been thanked.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Pact Forestalls Federal Shutdown, But Budget Fight Not Over Yet
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 8th graf, White House... to UPDATE with Bush planning to sign stopgap bill this afternoon; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and key lawmakers avoided a crisis as the new fiscal year dawned today but they now must convince an election-year Congress to vote for $134 billion in new taxes and widespread cuts in federal programs. ``It's going to be very difficult for us,'' House Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois said today. But White House Chief of Staff John Sununu said President Bush would lobby hard and, ``I think in the long run it will be supported by a majority of Republicans.'' ``It's a tough sale,'' said Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, one of many lawmakers who was troubled by what he was hearing of the package Sunday. Democrats, too, were expected to swallow hard before agreeing to raising Medicare premiums while cutting the benefits, increasing taxes on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes, and trimming everything from defense to student loans. And despite a claimed $500 billion in deficit reduction, it would stretch out the goal of a balanced budget and let the national debt increase another $1 trillion. The $40 billion in deficit reduction for the fiscal year beginning today would still leave a record annual deficit of $254 billion. Following President Bush's announcement of the budget accord at the White House Rose Garden on Sunday, the House and Senate easily approved and sent to Bush legislation avoiding a government shutdown which was threatened for today. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the stopgap resolution, which keeps the government going for five more days while more work is done on the budget, would be signed by Bush this afternoon. Because of the delays in enacting the fiscal 1991 budget the new fiscal year was starting without any of the normal spending bills required by law for government operations. But while the stopgap bill was approved easily, the votes in no way were endorsements for the budget agreement. Michel, appearing on NBC's ``Today'' show, said he wouldn't be surprised if the budget pact failed to pass its first test votes later this week. ``This is not going to be easy for everyone, but it is necessary. ...'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said on the same program. Sununu, who appeared on ABC-TV, said the president would ``support it aggressively.'' ``Nit-pickers may have a field day, because the easy vote in this case is to find something you don't like and vote no,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Sunday. Many on both sides seem ready to do just that. ``I don't think its a compromise. I think it's totally caving in to the Democratic liberals ... that's going to tax us right into a recession,'' said Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif. ``It looks like a tax on people who are hurting the most - excise taxes,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y. ``And you leave the richest of the rich alone.'' The budget deal would raise taxes $134 billion over the next five years, cut benefit programs $119 billion and, for the remainder, trim defense and domestic programs. The most attractive part of the package politically may be that it is the only thing being offered to prevent the 33 percent, across-the-board spending cuts of the Gramm-Rudman law. Those cuts, if they took effect, would cause everything from eliminating student loans to furloughing federal employees. ``There are no pleasant choices here,'' said Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio. ``The president, as well as the Democratic leadership, is going to have to help sell it to the country.'' Bush promised to do just that. ``I will do everything I can to generate support from the American people for this compromise,'' he said. He'll also have to work hard on his not-always-loyal congressional Republicans. One House GOP leader, Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, refused to attend the Rose Garden ceremony Sunday even though he was one of the negotiators. Aside from the Gramm-Rudman cuts, the selling points amount mainly to vague promises about beneficial effects on the economy. Presumably, the Federal Reserve would be able to reduce interest rates if the Treasury's insatiable craving for credit were reduced. But the downsides of the package are much more clear. Even as the agreement was being announced, a group that lobbies for more benefits for the elderly was drumming up opposition. ``It places a disproportionate amount of deficit reduction on the backs of older mericans,'' said Martha McSteen, president of the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare. About $60 billion of the deficit reduction would come from the Medicare system, roughly half by containing payments to health care providers and the rest from the elderly and all taxpayers. The Medicare payroll tax that now stops when a taxpayer's income hits $51,300 would keep going until a $73,000 income cap. State employees who currently don't pay the Medicare tax or Social Security would be brought into the system. Meanwhile, Medicare patients would pay more of their doctor bills. The annual deductible would double in two years from $75 to $150; coverage for clinical testing would drop from full to 80 percent; and monthly premiums would rise from $28.60 to about $34 next year. By 1995, they would rise to about $54 a month. ``It's asking the elderly to take a very hard hit,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif. ``The elderly didn't cause this problem. I plan to vote against it.'' Strident opposition also was certain to raising the gasoline tax by 12 cents by next summer, increasing the cigarette tax by 8 cents over the next two years and even a $25 annual fee on boaters. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the deputy Democratic leader, said the best selling points for the plan may be the things that it does not contain: a capital gains tax cut, anathema to most Democrats; an income tax rate increase opposed by Republicans; or a cut in Social Security benefits, considered poison by almost everyone in Congress. The president and congressional leadership have set a tight timetable, with the first direct votes on the plan by Friday and an Oct. 19 deadline for enacting the deal.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Despite Ballyhooing, Budget Pact Won't Cure Deficit
LaserPhoto WX8
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, Richard Darman, to CORRECT that deficit with package would be $254 billion; without package, $294 billion
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has put to rest his ``no new taxes'' pledge with a $134 billion flourish, developing a plan with key congressional leaders that will prompt several weeks of tenacious debate. But it won't solve the deficit crisis. As the budget summit was ending in the White House Rose Garden on Sunday, Bush's budget director was releasing a new deficit projection that showed that the agreement's $40 billion in 1991 savings already had been lost to economic reality. Richard Darman blamed the nation's poor economic performance and the spiraling costs of the savings and loan bailout for the worsening figures. He said the fiscal year that begins today would end with a deficit of at least $254 billion, even if Congress goes along with the budget package. A big if. And, without the package, the deficit would soar to $294 billion. Just because an impressive array of Republican and Democratic leaders shared the platform with Bush in announcing the $500 billion, five-year agreement doesn't mean it's a done deal. Far from it. The agreement could have difficulty winning approval in both the House and Senate, although leaders can mount a strong case that it may be the last hope Congress and the White House may ever have for reaching accord on cutting the deficit. One key conservative, Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the No. 2 Republican leader in the House, walked away from the pact and would not pose with Bush in the Rose Garden with the others. And with only three weeks remaining to enact the agreement, a minority in the Senate could keep the measure from passage through the threat of filibuster and other parliamentary maneuvering. For all the ballyhooing by Bush and congressional leaders about the boldness of the ``compromise'' plan, the pact - although ambitious in scope, particularly in later years - will not keep the fiscal 1991 deficit from being a record shortfall in excess of $250 billion. And it exacts a hard price on many Americans. Of the total $500 billion deficit reduction package, $133.8 billion is to come from new taxes and other revenue increases. Taxes on gasoline would more than double, Medicare premiums would rise, farm subsidies would be cut and government services would decline. Well-off families earning over $100,000 would find new limits on what they could deduct from their taxes. And sharp new levies would be slapped on nonessential items like cigarettes, booze and luxury boats. Bush said he would ``do my level best to take this case to the American people,'' but he didn't elaborate. White House officials said a prime-time television address to the nation was a good possibility. The president made the vow just days after he told Republican audiences in the Midwest he would take his case against congressional Democrats to ``every state in the nation.'' Bush had scheduled a month of travels for October to speak on behalf of GOP candidates. Presumably, he will add a call for enactment of the bipartisan agreement to his stock speech. The president has a history of compromising, particularly on domestic issues. So his willingness to stump the nation for an agreement that undoes two major tenets of his 1988 presidential campaign should not be a surprise. Still, in going along with the pact, Bush formally put an end to his ``no new taxes'' campaign vow. And he also abandoned, at least for now, a feature that until Thursday he was insisting must be a part of any budget compromise - a lower capital gains tax. Not only did Bush not get a capital gains tax reduction in the package, but the final measure also would have the effect of increasing taxes on the wealthy - both through a 10 percent fee on luxuries and through new limits on tax deductions for higher income families. White House aides pointed to a variety of other incentives in the plan designed to spur business investment and business growth. But the fact remained that Bush gave up plenty to get a budget agreement. ``I don't think we're going to get into the hot rhetoric of what gain or loss there is in ... political terms,'' said Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu. ``There will be a lot of time for that to take place in the days and weeks ahead.'' One final irony is that as negotiators were working hard to come up with even $40 billion in tax increases and spending cuts for the fiscal year that begins today - about $10 billion smaller a package than originally planned - budget officials were privately upping the estimate the deficit by an identical $40 billion. Before Sunday, budget officials warned that without a budget agreement the deficit for fiscal 1991 would be some $250 billion, a record. Then Darman on Sunday said the deficit - even with the agreement - will be somewhere around $254 billion. That's a far cry from the $64 billion deficit figure called for under Gramm-Rudman. Faced with such a huge gap, Congress decided to change the Gramm-Rudman target and give itself and the White House another five years - until 1998 - to balance the budget. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Helicopter Crashes at Sea with Three Aboard
DOC.TEXT: A Navy helicopter participating in a U.S.-Canadian military exercise went down at sea about 30 miles from Tillamook Bay, Ore., officials said. The SH-60B Lamps Mark III helicopter with three people aboard was returning to the guided missile frigate USS Crommelin when the accident occurred Sunday night, said Lt. Cmdr. John Carmam, a spokesman for the U.S. Third Fleet. Four U.S. Navy ships, a Canadian Navy ship and a Coast Guard helicopter were searching for the three crew members, Carman said. An investigation into the accident's cause was under way, he said. The Crommelin was involved in a combined U.S.-Canadian anti-submarine warfare exercise, Carman said. The names of the helicopter crew, based at Naval Air Station North Island, San Diego, were withheld pending notification of next of kin, he said. The Crommelin is based at Long Beach, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Case on Discrimination Abroad
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether U.S. businesses break the law if they discriminate against Americans they employ outside the country. The justices, setting the stage for an important ruling, said they will decide whether Congress intended a major anti-bias law to reach beyond the nation's borders. A federal appeals court, ruling in a case from Saudi Arabia, said the law has no effect outside the country. But federal trial judges have ruled in several other cases that the law does apply abroad. The justices acted on appeals by the Bush administration and a former oil industry employee. Ali Boureslan of El Paso, Texas, is a naturalized citizen who was born in Lebanon. An engineer, Boureslan began working in 1979 for Aramco Services Co., the Houston-based subsidiary of the Arabian American Oil Co. (Aramco). He was transferred to Saudi Arabia in 1980, and alleges that once there he was subjected to racial and religious discrimination. After filing a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Boureslan sued Aramco Services and its parent company. He charged them with violating an anti-bias law called Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The two companies contested the suit, contending that Title VII does not apply to alleged discrimination outside the United States. A federal trial judge agreed, and threw out the suit. Last February, the entire 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal by a 9-5 vote. In urging the justices to reverse the appeals court ruling, EEOC and Justice Department lawyers said such a limiting interpretation of Title VII's reach ``would withdraw the act's protection from the many Americans who spend a portion of their careers abroad.'' The government appeal relied heavily on an exemption written into the law, one that says the law ``shall not apply to an employer with respect to employment of aliens outside any state.'' That exemption ``would be entirely superfluous if the act did not apply abroad in the first place,'' the government appeal contended. But the 5th Circuit court said the exemption could be read to reflect ``a congressional intent to provide Title VII coverage to aliens employed within (but not outside) the United States.'' The cases are EEOC vs. Arabian American Oil Co., 89-1838, AND Boureslan vs. Arabian American Oil Co., 89-1845.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Supports Baltics for Membership in European Group
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, hosting a 35-nation European conference, today gave its support to full membership for the three Baltic republics and said Albania may be allowed to participate as an observer. The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which seeks to bridge East-West differences, is preparing to hold a summit meeting in Paris Nov. 19-21. The projected centerpiece is the signing of a treaty between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact to reduce U.S. and Soviet tanks, anti-aircraft artillery and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The treaty is nearing completion. The last roadblocks may be cleared at a meeting Wednesday between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. A U.S. official, briefing reporters, said the Bush administration would not go ahead with the summit unless the treaty is ready to be signed. ``We do expect that things will shape up so that we will have an agreement at the time,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The 35 nations are all the European countries except Albania plus the United States and Canada. East Germany will drop out later in the week when it is merged into West Germany to become one nation. However, the U.S. official said, the Baltic states - he referred to them as countries - of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia want to participate in the conference as observers or members. ``We do hope they will be in a position to join,'' he said. That could mean a further separation of the Baltics from the Soviet Union. Albania, meanwhile, is emerging from diplomatic isolation. Its participation in the conference would expand European membership. Among the issues facing the 35 foreign ministers here is where to base the small, permanent secretariat that will be approved. Czechoslovakia has strong support in pitching for Prague. ``That's a real possibility,'' the official said. He stressed, meanwhile, that the Bush administration does not want the European group to take on military functions. The official said that role is reserved for NATO, and it will remain important so long as the Soviets have a large army.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmakers Give Final OK To New Religion Law
DOC.TEXT: The national legislature gave final approval today to a law on freedom of conscience aimed at ending decades of repression against religious believers. The Supreme Soviet approved the law by a vote of 341-2, with no abstentions. The legislators approved the law in principle on Wednesday but met again today to resolve a dispute between the two chambers over a clause permitting the use of school buildings for religious classes after regular hours. The legislature voted 303-46 with 16 abstentions to remove the clause after a confusing and tedious parliamentary dispute. One of the chambers, the Council of the Union, had voted to remove the clause last week but the other, the Council of Nationalities, had no quorum for a vote. Patriarch Alexi II, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, said he favored the clause, as long as parental approval is required for students to attend after-school religious classes. ``If we remove this part of the law today, we would be taking a step backward in our democratic development,'' the patriarch said. He also said church activities are now restricted to within the walls of churches because all schools were nationalized after the revolution. Historian Roy Medvedev, a member of the Supreme Soviet, also supported the clause, arguing that in some small villages there is no place for students to gather for religious classes except public schools. But other delegates argued that strict separation of church and state precludes the use of public schools for religious classes. Ukrainian legislator Sergei Ryabchenko argued that allowing schools to be used for religious classes could ``ignite religious tensions'' in some areas of the Soviet Union such as the western Ukraine, where there is conflict between Ukrainian Catholic and Russian Orthodox Churches. The legislature's agreement to drop the clause came after a meeting of a joint committee from the two chambers. The lawmakers made other small changes, voting to tax the profits of businesses run by religious organizations at the same rate as other businesses. Soviet religious leaders said Thursday they are satisfied with the law but believe it should be shorter, clearer and firmer. After the revolution, the Communists seized some church property and assets and prohibited the teaching of religion. They converted some churches into factories and established an officially atheist society. The new law forbids the government from interfering in the practice of religion. It also improves the legal status of religious organizations, guarantees the right to study religious doctrine and calls for a religious council to advise the government on human rights. Western scholars estimate a quarter of the 285 million Soviet people practice some faith, and the number appears to be rising fast as official tolerance replaces hard-line Communist opposition to religion. In recent years, churches confiscated by the government have been reopened, Jews have been allowed to hold Hebrew classes, state-run television has broadcast holiday church services and government propaganda against religion has subsided.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Reinstating Libel Suit Against New Yorker Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider reinstating a libel lawsuit against Janet Malcolm, a staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, by a psychologist who says she made up quotes attributed to him. The justices said they will review a federal appeals court ruling that last year threw out Jeffrey Masson's suit. The appeals court ruling was criticized by some who said it recognized ``the right to fake quotes.'' Specifically, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that public figures who sue for libel over allegedly altered quotes must show that the quotes are not even ``rational interpretations'' of what was said. Private citizens who sue for libel must prove only that the sued-over statements are false and were made negligently. But public figures who sue for libel must prove the statements are false and were made with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of falsity. In dismissing Masson's suit, the 9th Circuit court said, ``Malice will not be inferred from evidence showing that the quoted language does not contain the exact words used ... provided that the fabricated quotations are either rational interpretations of ambiguous remarks made by the public figure ... or do not alter the substantive content of unambiguous remarks actually made by the public figure.'' The appeals court did not rule on whether Ms. Malcolm actually fabricated quotes attributed to Masson, a former projects director of the Sigmund Freud Archives. It instead said the fake quotes alleged by Masson, when compared to what he contends he said, do not amount to actual malice. The appeals court vote was 2-1. Judge Alex Kozinski, in a dissenting opinion, said, ``While the courts have a grave responsibility under the First Amendment to safeguard freedom of the press, the right to deliberately alter quotations is not, in my view, a concomitant of a free press.'' Ms. Malcolm's two-part article in The New Yorker focused on Masson's struggle with other archives officials over Sigmund Freud's abandonment of a theory that certain mental illnesses originate in sexual abuse during childhood. The article discussed Masson's claim that his contract with the archives was terminated because he made public his views that Freud abandoned the theory simply to further his career and placate his colleagues. The article subsequently was published in book form by Alfred A. Knopf Inc. Masson's suit named The New Yorker and Knopf as defendants also. The case is Masson vs. The New Yorker, 89-1799.

DOC.HEAD: Lights! Camera! German Unification Action Starts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New 5th graf, ``The mass-circulation... '' to UPDATE with report that radicals will disrupt celebration. Pickup 6thgra, ``For 40...''
DOC.TEXT: Workmen set up floodlights outside the Reichstag today and camera crews from around the world filmed the carnival-like scene at the Brandenburg Gate, in the final countdown to German unification. It looked more like a Hollywood set than the remnants of one of the most sinister sites of the Cold War. Organ grinders played, young women hastily planted new flowers and the sellers of Soviet bloc military memorabilia could hardly keep with the demand from thousands of visitors. At midnight Tuesday, as many as million people are expected to pack the squares in front of the Reichstag and at the Brandenburg Gate 200 yards away. Chancellor Helmut Kohl will lead the official celebrations close to where the Berlin Wall once divided the city. The mass-circulation Bild newspaper said that 10,000 leftist radicals were expected to rampage in Berlin on Tuesday night and into Wednesday to disrupt the unity fest. West Berlin police spokesman Joerg Gallas said he thinks the predicted number was ``exaggerated,'' but said authorities were prepared for trouble from leftist and rightist extremists. ``For 40 years, there was dictatorship in East Germany,'' said 60-year-old Ferdinand Scheben of the West German city of Cologne. ``Now, I'm glad that we're finally unifying in a peaceful way.'' Scheben promised to be at the Tuesday night celebrations. ``I plan to film the whole thing,'' he said, holding up his video camera. Germans from East and West, joined by thousands of foreign tourists, will start the nation's party of the century Tuesday afternoon. The beer will flow and fireworks will light up the sky as the Germans usher in unification with a wild street celebration that will be repeated in dozens of cities nationwide. Still, there is trouble on the horizon, as many predict clashes between leftist and rightist radicals. ``I'm afraid that's something we will have to count on,'' said West Berlin policeman Manfred Seelig. But for the jolly, barrel-chested Seelig, there was much more satisfaction in thinking about the historic merger. ``Certainly, everyone thought it would come, but no one, not even the politicians thought it would come so quickly,'' said the 42-year-old policeman. Around him, there were dozens of cranes and booms hauling up film crews to get a better shot of the scene. Thousands of people strolled the area, jamming the Pariser Platz on the Eastern side. Under the Communist regime, East Germans were hauled in to the police just for approaching the deserted square, while those on the Western side looked on to the site from special bleachers. But for some, the joy of unification was tempered by apprehension. ``There are a lot of negative things that will happen,'' said Sylvia Reichenbach from East Berlin. ``And unemployment is in first place among them.'' The 26-year-old nurse said she still has her job, but her mother will lose hers next week and her father most likely will be out of work next year. ``I don't plan to come here tomorrow night. We're worried about riots,'' said Ms. Reichenbach, holding onto her 3-year-old daughter, Julia, as she tottered along one of the low walls in front of the Reichstag. The Reichstag, the historic site of the German parliament, will on Thursday play host to the first meeting of the joint parliament comprised of German lawmakers from East and West.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Allow Nativity Display in Virginia Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to allow the display of a Christmas nativity scene on the lawn of a county government building in Charlottesville, Va. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that allowing a private group to display the nativity scene, or creche, on public property would violate the constitutionally required separation of church and state. The Albemarle County Board of Supervisors approved a request by the local chapter of the Jaycees to display the creche, and it was set up on the front lawn of the county office building from Dec. 6, 1987, until Jan. 10, 1988. A group that included Unitarian ministers and a Jewish rabbi sued the board in federal court over allowing the display. The county officials said the lawn is a public forum where many public activities have been permitted, including a beauty pageant, a United Way billboard, weddings and a civil rights demonstration., The officials said the free-speech rights of the Jaycees would be violated if the group were barred from displaying the creche. The officials also noted that the creche was accompanied by a sign that said it was sponsored by the Jaycees, not the county. A federal judge declared the display unconstitutional, and the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling last February. ``The unmistakable message conveyed is one of government endorsement of religion,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court relied heavily on a 1989 Supreme Court ruling that said a nativity scene standing alone inside a government building in Pittsburgh was unconstitutional. The justices that same day allowed a Jewish Hanukkah menorah to be displayed outside a Pittsburgh government building a block away because it was accompanied by some secular, or non-religious, items. The rulings last year were the high court's latest pronouncements on what has become a familiar issue for the justices. But the Pittsburgh decisions left unclear whether either building there was a public forum where individuals or groups traditionally exercise freedom of expression. The court split, 4-4, in 1985 in forcing the affluent New York City suburb of Scarsdale to permit a private group's nativity scene in a village park where non-religious displays were allowed. The Albemarle County officials said the lawn in front of the county building is a recognized public forum just as that Scarsdale park was. The Charlottesville case was clouded by the absence of the Jaycees as a party to the dispute. In effect, the county officials defended the free-speech rights of the Jaycees. The case is County of Albemarle vs. Smith, 89-2010.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Leaders of Argentina, Uruguay
With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Argentine President Carlos Menem said today that Iraq's Saddam Hussein ``has to be stopped,'' but declined to say whether he was prepared to send Argentine forces into battle to force Iraq out of Kuwait. President Bush conferred separately this morning with Menem and Uruguay President Luis Alberto Lacalle, thanking both Latin leaders for their solidarity in the international stand against Iraq for invading Kuwait. Menem also assured Bush that he has ``completely deactivated'' a secret Condor missile development program that past Argentine military governments had pursued. The United States has feared that the program could make it easier for hostile regimes in Libya and elsewhere to get their hands on such medium-range missiles. Menem, questioned about whether he was prepared to commit his forces to fight against Iraq, said, ``We have sent this group of professional officers ... to consolidate and give support to the embargo that was decided upon by the U.N.'' But, ``I cannot give you an opinion on something that has not yet happened,'' he said. Did Bush give Menem the impression that war was likely? ``No, no, no,'' said Menem, adding that they did not discuss ``the possibility of war.'' But, he said, ``we have agreed that Iraq's president has to be stopped.'' Menem recently dispatched two warships to the Persian Gulf, becoming the first and so far only Latin leader to commit forces to the international armada. Bush called Menem ``courageous,'' and said, ``The United States is very grateful to you,'' not just for his stand in the gulf crisis but his economic reforms as well. Lacalle told Bush that Uruguay has been ``really hurt'' by honoring the sanctions. ``We had $30 million of meat, mutton, ready to be sent'' to Iraq under recently negotiated contracts, he said. ``It's two punches: the oil and the cutting of those contracts.'' Uruguay is asking the United Nations for some of the international aid that will be distributed to third countries that bear the brunt of the effort to isolate Iraq. ``Uruguay is a country that has paid a serious price for complying with the sanctions,'' Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said afterwards. ``We would hope that their claim would be looked on sympathetically and seriously.'' On the Condor missiles, Aronson said Menem told Bush it had been ``completely deactivated.'' ``We certainly take Menem at his word,'' said the State Department official. ``That's a major step in reducing the threat of missile proliferation. Menem also said he is cooperating with Brazil on efforts to assure safeguards in the Latin countries' nuclear programs. Bush and the Latin leaders also discussed efforts to forge a common market of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, and their desire to see the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade produce a breakthrough on lowering trade barriers around the world. Bush told Menem the United States shares Argentina's concerns about the agricultural subsidies that the European community provides its farmers, Aronson said.

DOC.HEAD: State Helping Black Families Trace Former Slaves
DOC.TEXT: The state's Department of Archives and History is opening up windows to the past by offering the public a way to trace the roots of former slaves. The department is establishing a computer index of the first labor contracts that one-time slaves in Mississippi entered into as free people in 1865 and 1866. ``We plan to make the information available to the public in February,'' said H.T. Holmes, director of the department's library division. The computer searches would be free. Librarians would guide families through thousands of labor contracts kept by the Freedmen's Bureau, formed by Congress after the Civil War to ensure former slaves were treated fairly, Holmes said. The contracts detailed the former slaves' names, where they were working, their bosses, terms of their pay, and, in some instances, their general health. The Washington-based documents are extensively used, said Judy Thorne, a consultant at the National Archives. ``A lot of people who are doing Southern history are interested in them. A lot of people interested in Afro-American history use them and a few military historians are interested in them because the military was running the project,'' Thorne said. The Freedmen's Bureau supervised abandoned or confiscated land, issued rations of clothing and medicine, established hospitals, monitored working conditions, recorded new and old marriages and set up schools. Mississippi had 436,631 slaves in 1860 out of a total population of 791,305, according to the Mississippi Statistical Summary of Population for 1860.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Hear San rrancisco Case on Police Authority to Pursue
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said today it will try to clarify what authority police have to pursue and detain people who run away after seeing police. The justices agreed to consider reinstating the cocaine conviction and 68-month sentence of an Oakland, Calif., youth who a state court said was chased and caught unlawfully by police. California Attorney General John Van De Kamp argues that the state court ruling limits too severely police authority in such situations. Two members of the Oakland Police Department's drug task force were on patrol April 18, 1988, when they saw four young men standing by a parked car. The youths saw the officers when the patrol car was about 40 yards from them. They immediately ran away, and the parked car sped off. The officers, who said they suspected they had interrupted a drug transaction, decided to give chase. Officer Jerry Pertoso took a course that resulted in his running straight into a youth identified as Hodari D. Initially looking over his shoulder, the youth did not see the officer until they were about 10 feet apart. Pertoso testified that the youth then threw away what turned out to be a rock of cocaine. Pertoso stopped Hodari D., forced him to the ground and handcuffed him. The officer then retrieved the cocaine. Hodari D. was found to have possessed cocaine by a juvenile court judge who ordered him placed in an appropriate county facility for five years and eight months. A state appeals court, however, overturned the youth's conviction. The appeals court ruled that the police chase, undertaken without a reasonable suspicion that a crime had been committed, amounted to an unlawful detention. The appeals court also ruled that Hodari D.'s abandonment of the cocaine rock was a direct result of the unlawful detention - so the drug should not have been used as evidence against him. The Constitution's Fourth Amendment generally requires police to obtain a court warrant before conducting searches or making arrests. Courts have allowed some warrantless searches and arrests, but only when police do not have time to get a warrant and have probable cause or a reasonable suspicion to suspect a crime. The California Supreme Court refused to hear the state's appeal last March 15. In the appeal acted on today, Van De Kamp argued that a police chase never can be a detention. ``When a citizen exercises his constitutional right to leave the vicinity of a police officer, the former is not detained until the latter has forcibly restrained him,'' the attorney general said.
