In deciding a Michigan case in 1988, the nation's highest court said officers sometimes may chase someone who starts running at the sight of them even if they have no reason to suspect criminal conduct. But the court left undecided whether police pursuit ever could amount to a seizure. The case is California vs. Hodari D., 89-1632.

DOC.HEAD: Administrators Say UDC Now Open, But Hundreds of Students Say No
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates and tightens throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: University of the District of Columbia officials said today that the embattled school is now open, but some 400 protesters urged students to continue a boycott that halted classes for three days last week. ``At this time, compromise is not in our vocabulary,'' said Mark Thompson, a leader of the protest. ``It is ludicrous for the board not to do what we are asking them to do.'' Students barricaded themselves in a university building last Wednesday and refused to leave unless 11 mayoral appointees to the board of trustees agreed to immediately resign. Interim University President Miles Fisher said staff and administrators were reporting to school today at their regular times. A meeting between students and administrators was scheduled today, along with two student rallies. Hundreds of students gathered outside campus buildings today, still calling for the resignations of the board members appointed by Mayor Marion Barry. The resignations would take effect March 31. Protesters claim board members have lost touch with students and allowed the quality of the 12,000-student university's academic programs to decline. Students also are upset at plans to renovate a building to display the controversial feminist artwork ``The Dinner Party.'' The renovations, a condition of acquiring the work, would cost the financially-strapped school $1.6 million. Trustee Roger Wilkins, a veteran civil rights activist, said school officials had agreed to reconsider that decision and had come to terms with students on about 40 demands. ``The negotiation sessions have been civil and very professional,'' he said Sunday. ``They have been marked, in my judgment, by a mutual desire, a very strong desire on each side, to improve this university and to heal it.'' Wilkins said two board members resigned voluntarily for personal reasons, though others on the 15-member panel refused to do so. The trustees, nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the City Council, cannot be forced to resign without cause. The school's faculty senate and several city officials have voiced support of the students. City Council members have attempted to get past stalemated negotiations by offering to consider expanding the board to 21 members. Trustees have offered to support the idea. Wilkins said demands to which the board has agreed include assuming control of the school's cafeteria, providing day-care facilities and establishing a formal grievance procedure to resolve student complaints.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Hear Extortion Case from West Virginia
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear an appeal by a former West Virginia legislator convicted of extorting money from a group of foreign-trained doctors and not reporting it as taxable income. The court said it will consider overturning a $50,000 fine and three-year suspended prison sentence and probation for Robert L. McCormick, a former member of the West Virginia House of Delegates. McCormick, who represented an economically depressed coal-mining region suffering from a shortage of doctors, was a longtime supporter of legislation allowing foreign-trained physicians to practice in under-served areas of the state without meeting full licensing requirements. Federal prosecutors said that in 1984 McCormick told John Vandergrift, a lobbyist for the doctors, that his reelection campaign was expensive and that he had not ``heard from'' the physicians. Vandergrift then delivered an envelope to McCormick containing nine $100 bills from Dr. Ernesto Manual, head of the group, called the Coalfield Health Care Association. Prosecutors said McCormick received additional cash payments, bringing the total to $4,300. McCormick sponsored legislation in 1985 to give permanent medical licenses to experienced foreign-trained doctors who failed to get passing grades on licensing exams. The doctors had been practicing with temporary permits. McCormick was convicted of extorting $900 from the doctors and not reporting it as taxable income. The jury deadlocked on counts of the indictment charging him with taking additional payoffs. The former lawmaker said the money was a campaign contribution and said he did not report it to the Internal Revenue Service because the cash reimbursed him for expenses. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in upholding the conviction in February, ruled there was substantial evidence for the jury to conclude McCormick was guilty of extortion. The appeals court said it is not necessary to show there is a ``quid pro quo'' exchange of money for government favors to prove a violation of the federal Hobbs Act outlawing extortion. ``Such a quid pro quo may be present in an extortion. But as long as the use of official power is the basis for the extortion, then it is not an essential element of the crime,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also noted that West Virginia law forbids cash campaign contribution of more than $50. McCormick's acceptance of money in violation of state law is additional evidence of extortion, the appeals court said. It also rejected McCormick's argument that the money was not taxable personal income but reimbursement for campaign expenses. The jury had ample evidence to conclude the $900 was not a legitimate campaign contribution and therefore to decide it was taxable, the appeals court said. The case is McCormick vs. U.S., 89-1918.

DOC.HEAD: Court Affirms Ban On Government Employees' Political Activity
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected a challenge to the federal law barring some state and local government employees from being political candidates. The court, without comment, let stand Connecticut's loss of about $150,000 in federal welfare money because two welfare workers ran for office. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Connecticut argued that the federal law, known as the Hatch Act, violates the constitutionally protected right of political association and tramples state sovereignty. A federal trial judge and the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rejected those arguments previously. The Hatch Act limits not only the political activities of federal employees but also those of state and local government workers employed by agencies that receive federal loans or grants. The act bars federal employees from taking ``an active part in political management or in political campaigns.'' It originally imposed such a ban for some state and local government workers but was narrowed so that now only political candidacy is barred for them. In 1985, Wayne Camillieri worked for the Connecticut Department of Human Resources in a position involved with federally funded programs. Camillieri since 1983 had been a member of the Hartford City Council. The U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board in mid-1985 informed Camillieri that the Hatch Act prohibited him from seeking re-election to the city council if he remained in his state government job. Camillieri nevertheless ran for re-election. He was defeated in the Democratic primary. The board subsequently ordered the state agency to remove Camillieri from his position, warning that failure to do so within 30 days would result in the withholding of federal loans and grants equal to two years pay for Camillieri. The state agency refused to remove him, and $90,150 in federal funds were withheld. Jack Winkleman also was an employee of the Connecticut Department of Human Resources involved in federally funded programs when in 1986 he was endorsed by the Republican Party as a candidate for probate judge. Winkleman ran for the office while holding his state agency job, but he was defeated in the general election. The federal board later ordered that Winkleman be removed from his job, threatening to withhold federal money equal to two years of his pay if he were not within 30 days. The agency balked, and $60,896 in federal money was withheld. State officials sought review in federal court, but the withholding of funds was upheld by U.S. District Judge Jose Cabranes. Citing past Supreme Court rulings, Cabranes said, ``Infringements upon the ability of government employees, be they federal or state, to be candidates for elective office do not violate the First Amendment.'' He also rejected arguments that the federal government's action against the state violated the 10th Amendment's granting of state sovereignty. The appeals court upheld Cabranes' ruling in a brief order last January. State officials then sought help from the nation's highest court. The case is Connecticut vs. U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board, 89-1582.

DOC.HEAD: San Jose City Council Member Loses Libel Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A former San Jose City Council member who won, and then lost, a $1.01 million libel award against his local newspaper lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that Claude Fletcher failed to prove the San Jose Mercury News in California published statements about him with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of their falsity. Fletcher sued the Mercury News over a series of 1984 articles reporting on his conduct while a city council member and as a board member of a local antipoverty agency. Fletcher's 1984 bid for re-election failed after the articles were published. The articles reported that five agency officials said Fletcher tried to steer a $1.6 million contract to an insulation business in which he became a partner. The articles quoted the agency's executive director as saying that Fletcher once offered him and his wife a trip to Hawaii, which the agency official interpreted as a bribe. A jury in 1986 awarded Fletcher $250,000 in general damages, $25,000 in special damages and $735,000 in punitive damages. But the trial judge threw out the award, ruling that Fletcher had failed to prove the articles were published with actual malice - a burden facing any public official who sues for libel. Private citizens who sue for libel need only prove that an allegedly libelous statement was false and made negligently. A state appeals court upheld the dismissal of the award, and the California Supreme Court refused to hear Fletcher's appeal last February. In its 1989 ruling, the appeals court said, ``The evidence suggests a sincere attempt to report what the Mercury News viewed as unethical behavior on the part of a San Jose public official.'' It added, ``Clearly the articles contained factual errors. But was there clear and convincing evidence that (the paper's reporter) did not believe his story was true? We do not think so.'' In the appeal acted on today, Fletcher said the articles about him represented ``highly unreasonable conduct constituting an extreme departure from ordinary standards of investigation and reporting.'' He said there was sufficient evidence of actual malice. The case is Fletcher vs. San Jose Mercury News, 89-1788.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Offers to Pay Mayor's Salary If He'll Quit
DOC.TEXT: Worried that the mayor's mind is elsewhere, a Nashville car dealer has offered the city's chief executive $75,000 to quit. But Mayor Bill Boner's answer will have to wait until he returns from Hawaii where he reportedly has gone to marry an aspiring country singer today. ``It is obvious to all of Nashville that Bill Boner is distracted from his job,'' businessman Lee Beaman said Friday. ``Our city is suffering from the void in leadership. For the good of the city, Bill Boner should resign so we can elect a mayor in a special election and move our city forward. ``In order to make it easier for Mayor Boner to resign, I have offered to pay the $75,000 in salary he would be giving up if he resigns now.'' Boner, 45, turned heads in Nashville when he announced his engagement ot Traci Peel, 34. At the time, he was still married to his third wife. Boner's exploits were chronicled far and wide after the Nashville Banner published an interview with Peel in which she said the mayor's passion could last seven hours. Bumper stickers quickly appeared in Nashville that said: ``Seven hours for Traci, three years for Nashville.'' Beaman, head of Beaman Automotive Group and an officer with the Beaman Bottling Co., said he made the offer a month ago to two longtime Boner supporters. Boner spokesman Rick Runyeon said he knew nothing of the offer. ``The mayor is certainly committed to fulfilling his term of office, and also committed to resolving some critical issues in this final year,'' Runyeon said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Turns Down Appeal of Pennsylvania Man in Environmental Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today turned down the appeal of a Pennsylvania man given the longest prison sentence and biggest fine in U.S. history for any person convicted of an environmental crime. The court, without comment, let stand the three-year prison term and $200,000 fine John Pozsgai of Morrisville, Pa., received for violating the Clean Water Act. Pozsgai's lawyers told the justices his punishment was unfairly severe for ``what was essentially a regulatory offense.'' ``There was no evidence that any wildlife or fishery habitat was harmed, or that water quality was impaired,'' Pozsgai's appeal said. Yet his punishment included, the appeal said, ``the longest unsuspended jail term imposed in the history of the United States for any environmental crime, including the dumping of extremely toxic and hazardous wastes and where people were even injured and killed.'' Pozsgai, 57, operates a truck-repair business from a garage behind his house in the small town near Trenton, N.J. Across the street from his house is a 14-acre lot that for years had been used as a dumping site, mainly for thousands of old tires. A small stream ran through the lot, leaving at a point not far from the Pennsylvania Canal. While Pozsgai in 1986 was negotiating to buy the lot, engineering and environmental consultants told him the lot was considered protected ``wetlands.'' Any development would have to be approved by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Pozsgai was told. He began filling a portion of the property even before finalizing the purchase in June 1987. In April of that year, a Corps of Engineers inspector warned Pozsgai that federal law barred him from continuing to deposit fill on the land without first obtaining permits. According to court records, truckloads of fill continued to be dumped on the land. In September 1987, Pozsgai was informed that the filling was a violation of the Clean Water Act and was ordered to stop all such activity. The filling continued. The federal government sued Pozsgai in the summer of 1988 and obtained a court order directing him to immediately stop depositing fill on the land. In a jury trial, Pozsgai was convicted on 40 counts of violating the Clean Water Act. Asked by federal prosecutors to ``send a message to all property owners,'' U.S. District Judge Marvin Katz sentenced Pozsgai to three years in prison, five years of probation and one year of supervised release. He also fined him $200,000. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the conviction and sentence last January. In the appeal acted on today, Pozsgai's lawyers argued that his due-process rights had been violated at trial and that his punishment was too stiff. ``Since the Justice Department has announced its intention to use this case and others like it to bring a `reign of terror' upon environmental violators, however minor the offense, this court should ensure that the rules they play by are lawful ones,'' the appeal said. The case is Pozsgai vs. U.S., 89-1735.

DOC.HEAD: Court Turns Down Appeal of Former CIA Operative
DOC.TEXT: Frank Snepp, the ex-CIA operative turned author, lost a Supreme Court appeal today in his fight with the spy agency over getting prepublication clearance for some of his work. The court, without comment, left intact rulings that put the burden on Snepp, not the CIA, to seek a court's help if disagreements arise over what the agency is entitled to censor. Snepp worked for the Central Intelligence Agency from 1968 to 1976, working either in Vietnam or on Vietnam matters at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va. In 1977, Snepp published a critical account of the final days of U.S. involvement in Vietnam. The book, ``Decent Interval,'' was published without first having been submitted for agency preclearance. The Supreme Court in 1980 ruled that Snepp's publication of the book was a breach of his employment contract with the CIA, and ordered that he forfeit all proceeds from the book to the agency. The high court also ruled that the CIA could continue to require Snepp to submit any agency-related writings for prepublication approval. A footnote to the 1980 decision said allowing such preclearance was not condoning censorship. ``If (Snepp), in compliance with contract, had submitted his manuscript for review and the agency had found it to contain sensitive material, presumably ... an effort would have been made to eliminate harmful disclosures,'' the court said. ``Absent agreement in this respect, the agency would have borne the burden of seeking an injunction against publication,'' the footnote said. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Snepp said that 1980 footnote overturned what had been the CIA's policy of forcing employees and ex-employees to go to court to challenge an agency decision not to allow publication of certain material. Prior to the 1980 Supreme Court ruling in Snepp's case, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had ruled that CIA employees and ex-employees should have the responsibility for initiating court fights when disputes arise over the agency's preclearance procedures. The current dispute between Snepp and the CIA stems from his submission for preclearance review in 1985 of a potential television mini-series called ``Background: Lawcase Story.'' After several rounds of negotiations, the CIA sought just one deletion but by that time the television deal had fallen through. The 4th Circuit court last February rejected Snepp's contention that the agency had been obligated to seek a court's help in its effort to keep Snepp from publishing the submitted manuscript. The appeals court said the 1980 Supreme Court footnote did not reverse its previous ruling absolving the CIA of the responsibility of seeking judicial review. The case is Snepp vs. U.S., 89-1853.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Allow Random Drug Testing of New York Jail Guards
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today permitted the random drug testing of New York City's 10,000 jail guards. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the guards' labor union, which said the tests violate the officers' privacy rights. The New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, upheld the city Department of Corrections drug-testing program by a 4-3 vote in May. The city uses a computer to select 50 guards at random every two weeks for urine tests. The state court said the city has a compelling interest in requiring the tests and said the guards, who undergo other inspections not required of ordinary citizens or other government workers, have a diminished expectation of privacy. ``By choosing to work in the paramilitary milieu of the city Corrections Department, guards voluntarily sacrifice certain cherished freedoms,'' Judge Joseph Bellacosa wrote for the state court. He noted that the guards already undergo drug tests - apart from the random program they challenged - when they apply for jobs and while they are on probation. The city also has a big stake in assuring the guards are drug free, he said. ``The prevention, detection and resolution of the myriad daily crises in this nether world demand the acutest sensory awareness, undulled by the use of illicit drugs,'' Bellacosa said. Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, in a strongly worded dissent, said the state court ruling made ``an important constitutional right the latest casualty in the war on drugs.'' Union officials for the guards said tests should be required only of those the city has reason to believe are using drugs. The union said the guards do not have direct responsibility for protecting the safety of the general public and, because they work in confined quarters, are less likely to be exposed to drugs. The union, noting the city's claim that 1.2 percent of tenured guards and 2.9 percent of probationary officers use drugs, said random testing is unwarranted when such a ``minute'' proportion of the staff may be using drugs. The Supreme Court in 1989 upheld mandatory blood and urine tests for railroad workers involved in accidents and for U.S. Customs Service employees seeking drug-enforcement jobs. The high court has not ruled specifically on random tests for government workers. But it repeatedly has denied, without comment, appeals by such employees challenging random tests. Police officers in New York City also must undergo random drug tests. They did not challenge the tests in court. New York state officials have not instituted such tests for prison guards who have completed probation. The case is Seelig vs. Koehler, 90-48.

DOC.HEAD: Atheists Lose Court Challenge on Jury Oath
DOC.TEXT: A group of atheists challenging an oath for potential trial jurors that includes the phrase ``So help me God'' lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, let stand rulings in a Texas case that excluding atheists from jury service for refusing to take such an oath does not violate their rights. The court also rejected the atheist group's challenge of Texas courts' policy of asking potential jurors about their religion. Use of the juror oath and questionnaire, challenged by famed atheist Madalyn O'Hair and her Austin-based Society of Separationists, was upheld by a federal judge and the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. In its ruling last February, the appeals court said, ``The occasion to serve on a jury in undeniably a duty, a privilege and an opportunity for many citizens to actively and personally serve their government ... Even so, jury service has not been construed as a constitutionally protected right.'' The appeals court also said that the ``So help me God'' phrase in the juror's oath for Travis County, Texas, trials is merely a solemn declaration of truthfulness, not an oath to a deity. About potential jurors being asked on information cards to state their religious affiliation, including atheism, the appeals court said, ``Atheism is indeed a relevant factor for the parties and attorneys involved in the jury selection process - as much so as whether a potential juror is a Baptist, a Presbyterian or a Buddhist.'' The case is Murray vs. Travis County District Court, 89-2018.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Policy Letting Banks Sell Insurance in Indiana Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a policy that lets federally regulated banks sell insurance. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by insurance industry lawyers who said the Federal Reserve Board policy could lead banks into the same ``morass that has befallen the savings and loan industry.'' The cost to American taxpayers of bailing out the thrift institutions recently was estimated at $500 billion, the insurance officials reminded the court. The Independent Insurance Agents of America and other groups challenged a 1989 Federal Reserve Board order permitting two Indiana banks acquired by a bank holding company to sell insurance. The Fed said the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 does not bar bank holding companies from acquiring bank subsidiaries engaged in non-banking activities. The board acted after a congressional moratorium had been lifted on non-banking activities by banks. Merchants National Corp., a bank holding company, was granted permission by the Fed to acquire the Anderson Banking Co. and the Mid State Bank of Hendricks County in Indiana. Anderson Bank has sold insurance since the bank opened for business in 1916. Mid State purchased an insurance agency in 1985. ``The ability of bank holding companies to enter risky businesses directly threatens to compromise the financial stability of bank holding companies,'' insurance industry officials said in their high court appeal. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in November that the Fed did not exceed its authority in the Merchants National case. The case is Independent Insurance Agents of America vs. Federal Reserve System, 89-1620.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Reinstate Texas Murder Conviction
ssociated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate the murder conviction of Clarence Lee Brandley, a former high school janitor set free this year after more than nine years on death row in Texas. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that Brandley, who is black, was denied a fair trial in the rape-murder of a 16-year-old white girl. The justices' rejection of an appeal by Texas officials appears to put an end to the much-publicized case. Prosecutors said previously they would not retry Brandley if the high court rejected their appeal. The case generated widespread attention, with charges that racially biased police officers concealed evidence, failed to pursue leads and mistreated key witnesses. Brandley, 39, of Houston, once came within five days of being executed. He now is studying to become an electrician. He was freed in January after the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals threw out his conviction for the Aug. 23, 1980, murder of Cheryl Dee Fergeson. She was strangled after attending a volleyball tournament at the Houston-area high school where Brandley worked as a janitor. Brandley's first trial ended in a hung jury. An all-white jury convicted him of capital murder in his second trial. Brandley's lawyers said he was the victim of racism, and Texas courts lent support to charges he was accused falsely. A judge in 1987 recommended a third trial, citing discrimination against Brandley. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals said last December that Brandley was the victim of ``blatant unfairness.'' ``The violent end to Cheryl Fergeson's young life is both senseless and tragic,'' the state court said. ``Our outrage over her murder, however, cannot justify the subversion of justice that took place during the investigation.'' The state court noted that prosecutors relied heavily on contradictory testimony by three other janitors, all of them white. Moreover, the state court said, Texas Ranger Wesley Styles, who headed the investigation, failed to question the other janitors separately when he conducted a ``walk through'' of the events of the day of the murder. The state court noted that one of the janitors who testified against Brandley later admitted he had lied, saying he was afraid of Styles and one of the other janitors. The state court cited evidence ``the murder investigation was so contrived that it created false testimony and ... failed to follow any leads which did not comport with the preconceived, premature notion that (Brandley) committed the murder.'' District Attorney Peter Speers of Montgomery County, Texas, took the appeal to the Supreme Court. State Attorney General Jim Mattox refused to go along, saying Brandley's conviction was ``racially tainted.'' The case is Texas vs. Brandley, 89-1887.

DOC.HEAD: Two Teens Die During Checkpoint Shooting in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Two teen-agers were killed and a third injured when soldiers fired on a stolen car that failed to stop at a checkpoint in west Belfast, police said today. The fatalities Sunday night were identified by police as Martin Declan Peake, 17, the driver; and Karen Reilly, 18, a passenger. A 16-year-old girl in the car was slightly injured but was not immediately identified, police said. Authorities said the car struck a soldier and was then fired on. The soldier was not seriously hurt. Police said the car had been stolen from government property nearby. Meanwhile, authorities said a part-time police officer was slightly injured when a booby-trap bomb exploded near a bridge in County Fermanagh. Police said the officer was driving his truck when the bomb went off.

DOC.HEAD: Court Kills Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today killed a 9-year-old libel lawsuit stemming from two letters written to then-President Reagan opposing a North Carolina man's appointment as a federal prosecutor. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that dismssed the 1981 suit filed by David Smith of Greensboro, N.C., against Robert McDonald, the operator of child-care centers in Virginia. Smith was seeking nomination and appointment as a U.S. attorney in North Carolina when McDonald wrote the letters opposing Smith. Copies of both letters, one mailed in late 1980 and one in early 1981, were sent to various members of Congress and Edwin Meese, who guided Reagan's transition team. According to court documents, the letters accused Smith of ``violating the civil rights of various individuals'' while a state judge, and charged him with ``extortion or blackmail'' and ``violations of professional ethics.'' Smith's suit against McDonald went all the way to the nation's highest court before it ever reached a trial. In 1985, the Supreme Court justices used the case to rule that people may be sued over allegedly libelous statements made in letters and petitions to government officials. The decision said the First Amendment right to petition the government did not cloak McDonald in absolute immunity from being sued over what he said about Smith. The case then went to a federal jury, which awarded Smith $200,000 in damages. But the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in February threw out that award after ruling that McDonald was entitled to absolute immunity under North Carolina common law. In the appeal acted on today, Smith argued that the state's common law provides only qualified - not absolute - immunity from lawsuits in such circumstances. The case is Smith vs. McDonald, 89-1818.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Steel Giant Loses Discrimination Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ruling that USX Corp. illegally discriminated against blacks at a Fairless Hills, Pa., steel mill. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments that a federal appeals court ``flagrantly disregarded'' a 1989 Supreme Court decision in ruling against the giant manufacturer. The Philadelphia-based 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that USX, formerly known as U.S. Steel Corp., discriminated against blacks who applied for non-skilled production and maintenance jobs at the steel mill. The justices then ordered the appeals court to restudy that ruling in light of their 1989 decision, called Wards Cove Packing Co. vs. Antonio. In it, the high court made it far more difficult for workers to win some job-bias lawsuits. The court's Wards Cove ruling was one of several 1989 decisions Congress is seeking to overcome in a major civil rights bill passed, in slightly differing versions, by both the House and Senate. President Bush, saying he believes the legislation would force employers to adopt racial quotas, has threatened to veto the bill unless considerable changes are made before it reaches his desk. After re-examining the Fairless Hills case, the 3rd Circuit court again ruled against USX. ``Although Wards Cove may have reduced the employer's burden of showing a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for the challenged practices, we perceive no reason to disturb the district court's, and our own, prior rejection of USX's assertion'' that its practices were not discriminatory, the appeals court said. ``Although Wards Cove may have relaxed the employer's burden to rebut the plaintiff's ... case, we do not read the decision as requiring us to accept at face value an employer's explanations of adverse impact of its hiring practices on blacks,'' the appeals court added. A federal judge in 1983 ordered USX to end all discrimination in the hiring of production and maintenance employees at the Fairless Hills mill, and awarded more than $12.3 million to those represented by a ``class action'' lawsuit. The judge ruled that statistics showing the disparity between the percentages of black applicants and black hires proved that USX violated a federal anti-bias law, known as Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The appeals court upheld the judge's Title VII ruling but ordered him to reconsider the monetary award in a way USX lawyers said could raise the award to about $30 million. The Fairless Hills mill, where 7,000 to 10,000 workers are employed at a given time, hired 5,516 people - including 977 blacks - to production and maintenance jobs in the years 1971-82. In those years, blacks represented 25.9 percent of the applicants and 17.6 percent of the hires. In the appeal acted on today, USX lawyers argued that the 3rd Circuit court ``flagrantly disregarded (the justices') mandate by giving Wards Cove only lip service.'' ``The 3rd Circuit imposed on USX the burden of proving that innocent factors, not race, caused the bottom line disparities, rather than merely producing a reasonable business justification for the specific employment practice at issue,'' the steel company's appeal said. The case is USX vs. Green, 89-1816.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Nine French Hostages Can Leave Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th pvs, `Some 6,000...' to CORRECT that number of Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait now believed to be 4,200. Pickup 8th, `In Sunday's...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today ordered the release of nine French nationals, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The Frenchmen were among hundreds of Westerners believed held at key military and other installations Saddam fears might be attacked by the West. It was the second gesture by Iraq toward France in as many days. On Sunday, Saddam complimented French President Francois Mitterrand for offering ``positive'' ideas to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. The Iraqi agency, monitored in Nicosia said: ``President Saddam Hussein has issued orders to allow some French guests to leave Iraq in the company of Mr. Gilles Munier, the president of the Association of Franco-Iraqi Friendship.'' INA, the report added, ``has learned that nine Frenchmen are included in this humanitarian gesture.'' Foreigners, mainly Westerners, were banned from traveling after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent annexation of the oil-rich emirate. As of late last month, 4,200 Westerners remained in Iraq and Kuwait, including an undetermined number being held at Iraqi military installations. In Sunday's message, Saddam softened his confrontational stand in the gulf crisis, calling for replacing the language of ``threats and warnings'' with a dialogue. However, he again linked any solution to an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories. The United States has rejected that proposal, insisting on an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. But Mitterrand, in a speech before the U.N. General Assembly last week, stressed the need to resolve other issues, although he demanded an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He also suggested a simultaneous withdrawal of the Iraqis from Kuwait and the U.S.-led multinational force from Saudi Arabia. In his message to Arabs and Moslems released by the official media on Sunday, Saddam said he intended to initiate contact with Paris. He said Mitterrand's ``initiative'' could be developed to serve as a foundation for a settlement in the gulf. But Britain and France responded that there would be no dialogue with Iraq until Saddam's troops are out of Kuwait. The Frenchmen to be released were identified by INA as: Bouban Jean Ive, Frank Ouzeau, Gerard Wisat, Laurant Lucal, Christophe Corrisier, Akbar Ali Ramadan, Din Mahmoud Taki, Hassan Ali Mansour Husseun, and Dorneau Michel Henry Paul. The names were transliterated from Arabic.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Urges Peaceful Dialogue
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th pvs, `Any useful...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that 4,200 Westerners now believed in Iraq and Kuwait. Pickup `Britain, another...'
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq says he is ready for a dialogue with his international adversaries in the Persian Gulf crisis, but he is still tying any settlement to other conflicts in the region. His message Sunday, addressed to the Arab and Islamic msses, represented a departure from previous, more bellicose declarations. He said he wanted to launch a dialogue with France to explore the possibility of using President Francois Mitterrand's ideas on the crisis as the basis for a settlement. Saddam urged his 1 million-member army to remain ready to fight any foreign attempt to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait, which they invaded Aug. 2. But - in another switch from past speeches - not once in almost 45 minutes did he renew his pledge never to relinquish the emirate he seized two months ago. Responding to Saddam's overture, France's foreign minister said France and Iraq have not discussed opening negotiations. ``Any useful discussion can take place only if two conditions have been fulfilled: the evacuation of Kuwait by Iraqi troops and the release of all the hostages,'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas told the French radio network RTL on Sunday. As of late last month, 4,200 Westerners remained in Iraq and Kuwait, including an undetermined number held at key Iraqi military installations. Britain, another leading member of the multinational military force standing up to Saddam, also rejected his latest proposals. ``There is nothing new in this,'' a Foreign Office official said on condition of anonymity. Saddam's message was read over state television and radio by announcer Mikdad Murad and monitored in Nicosia. The backdrop behind Murad alternated between a portrait of Saddam in a Western suit and one of him in military uniform praying in front of a picture of minarets. His message marked the birthday of the 7th-century Prophet Mohammed and was punctuated by lengthy recitations from the Koran, Islam's holy book. Saddam said reducing tensions could begin ``if dialogue replaces the policy of threats and warnings, if the language of peaceful politics replaces the policy of troop buildups and threats of the use of force.'' He withdrew his previous opposition to the involvement of foreign powers in the search of a settlement to the dispute. ``Should the international community be involved in a solution to the crisis, then the emphasis should be on the initiative of Aug. 12, 1990, which underlined that ... peace could not be achieved without the settlement of all the problems of the region,'' he said. On Aug. 12, Saddam linked an Kuwaiti settlement to Israel's withdrawal from the occupied territories. He has also tied it to a Syrian pullout in Lebanon. In earlier statements, he has also rejected any outside involvement, insisting the problem is for Arabs to resolve. Saddam said Sunday, ``Withdrawal of foreign forces from the lands of Najd and Hejaz (Saudi Arabia) and the Arabian Gulf, and ending the blockade of Iraq, is a slogan for all Arabs and believers to raise.'' But he did not repeat an earlier threat to dislodge these troops from the region by force. In Mitterrand's speech before the U.N. General Assembly a week ago, he suggested a serious drive toward settling the conflict over Kuwait in concert with other problems in the region, including the Israeli occupation of Arab territories and the Lebanese civil war. Mitterrand was the only Western leader to link the problems. The United States has rejected such a connection, setting off Arab accusations that it is applying double standards in the Middle East toward Iraq and Israel. Saddam said, ``We view the speech of the French president, despite certain reservations, of being of a different language, and we hope that our positive interpretation is correct. ... ``It is not important to agree or disagree with this initiative or that, including that of French President Mitterrand. ``What is important that a serious dialogue be launched in search of a possible, just and comprehensive solution that would allow peace to prevail. ...'' The Iraqi president said, ``We intend to launch contact with the French government with the aim of formulating a precise viewpoint . . . so that action could be launched on clear and solid foundations.

DOC.HEAD: Court Dismisses Claims from Indians in South Dakota, Iowa, Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today killed Sioux Indian tribes' legal challenges stemming from their loss, through U.S. treaties, of some 27 million acres of land stretching across three states. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that the tribes waited too long to attack a 1972 plan by Congress for distributing a $6 million settlement between the tribes and the federal government. Under that plan, the tribes will receive three-fourths of the money and 1,970 descendants who are not themselves tribal members will receive one-fourth. The tribes contended in their 1987 lawsuit that they are entitled to 100 percent of the $6 million settlement fund and the interest it has earned since 1972. The dispute has its roots in treaties of 1830 and 1851 in which the Sisseton and Wahpeton Sioux ceded to the United States vast stretches of land in what now is South Dakota, Iowa and Minnesota. The tribes sued the government about 100 years later, contending that they had not received just compensation. The suit was settled and Congress in 1968 appropriated the money to pay the settlement. Four years later, Congress devised the distribution plan but the tribes did not challenge it in court until 1987, when the Bureau of Indian Affairs indicated the 25 percent set aside for non-members of the tribes was almost ready for distribution. U.S. District Judge Paul Hatfield in Montana threw out the suit, ruling that the tribe had only six years to sue after Congress unveiled the distribution plan. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal last February, and the tribes then sought help from the nation's highest court. The case is Sisseton-Wahpeton Sioux vs. U.S., 89-2015.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Couple Loses Adoption Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today turned down the appeal of a Kentucky couple who say they were disqualified as adoptive parents for a biracial child because they are white. The justices, withut comment, let stand state court rulings that threw out Lisa and Ronald Wilson's civil rights lawsuit against the Kentucky Cabinet for Human Resources and several of its officials. The Wilsons contend that their race-based disqualification was automatic. But state officials say the couple's race was taken into account but was not the controlling factor. The state agency in August 1984 took legal custody of a month-old child, Maria, who had been born to a white woman and a black man. She was placed in a foster home with a woman known by Lisa Wilson, then 24 and single. Lisa started taking Maria home with her every weekend, and then four or five days each week. In August 1985, Lisa inquired about adopting Maria. After a 1986 meeting with Cabinet for Human Resources employee Brooke Darrow, Lisa received a letter telling her she and Ronald Wilson, whom she planned to marry in early 1987, would not be considered in selecting Maria's adoptive parents. ``If parental rights are terminated we will be requesting an interracial adoptive family since (the child) is biracial,'ile, live in an integrated neighborhood ... and live an integrated lifestyle,'' he said. Two months before the Wilsons married, Maria was placed in the home of an interracial couple who had been selected as prospective adoptive parents. The Wilsons sued in state court, contending they had been discriminated against. After a 1988 trial, a jury ruled against the Wilsons. The Kentucky Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last year, and the Kentucky Supreme Court refused to review the Wilsons' ensuing appeal. In the appeal acted on today, the Wilsons challenged what they called the state agency's ``automatic race-matching of adoptive parents and adopted children.'' But state officials urged the justices to reject the appeal, noting that the prospective adoptive parents with whom Maria was placed had been approved more than a year before Lisa Wilson first inquired about the possibility of adoption. The case is Wilson vs. Darrow, 90-123.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of prepared remarks by President Bush to the United Nations General Assembly. Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General. Distinguished delegates to the United Nations. It is a great privilege to greet you today as we begin what marks a new and historic session of the General Assembly. Forty-five years ago, while the fires of an epic war still raged across two oceans and two continents, a small group of men and women began a search for hope amid the ruins. They gathered in San Francisco, stepping back from the haze and the horror to try to shape a new structure that might support an ancient dream. Intensely idealistic, and yet tempered by war, they sought to build a new kind of bridge, a bridge between nations, a bridge that might help carry humankind from its darkest hour to its brightest day. The founding of the United Nations embodied our deepest hopes for a peaceful world. And during the past year, we have come closer than ever before to realizing those hopes. We've seen a century sundered by barbed threats and barbed wire give way to a new era of peace, cooperation and freedom. The Revolution of '89 swept the world almost with a life of its own, carried by a new breeze of freedom that transformed the political climate from Central Europe to Central America, and touched almost every corner of the globe. That breeze has been sustained by a now almost universal recognition of a simple, fundamental truth: the human spirit can't be locked up forever. The truth is, people everywhere are motivated in much the same way. And people everywhere want much the same things: the chance to live a life of purpose - the chance to choose a life - in which they and their children can learn, grow healthy, worship freely and prosper through the work of their hands, their hearts and their minds. We're not talking about the power of nations, but the power of individuals. The power to choose, the power to risk, the power to succeed. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Top Court Won't Let Newspaper See Some Pentagon Probe Documents
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let the St. Louis Post-Dispatch see some confidential documents in the government's corruption investigation of Pentagoncontracts. The court, over two dissenting votes, let stand a ruling that the privacy rights of McDonnell Douglas Corp., the nation's largest defense contractor, and some of its employees outweigh the public's right to know more about the weapons procurement case. Justices Byron R. White and Harry A. Blackmun voted to hear arguments in the case, but four votes are needed to grant such review. The Justice Department investigation, called ``Operation Ill Wind,'' began in 1987 and has yielded more than three dozen guilty pleas or convictions on fraud- and bribery-related charges. Among the contractors investigated was McDonnell Douglas, which is based in the St. Louis area and receives some $9 billion a year in Pentagon contracts. The FBI in 1988 conducted a search of defense contractor offices, including those of McDonnell Douglas and its vice-president Thomas Gunn. Search warrants were based on information the FBI obtained listening to wiretapped telephone conversations. The Post-Dispatch asked to see sealed documents related to the warrants, particularly government affidavits that mi the company and its employees ``weighs heavily in favor of the privacy interests and non-disclosure.'' ``These search warrant affidavits implicate some individuals directly in criminal misconduct, others only indirectly,'' the appeals court said. ``Disclosure could seriously damage their reputations and careers.'' Lawyers for The Post-Dispatch said the appeals court ruling created ``novel rights of privacy that prevail over the First Amendment interests of the public and the press.'' The newspaper's appeal said the appeals court ruling ``held without precedent that in pre-indictment situations privacy concerns outweigh access ... even when, as here, the government favors access.'' The case is Pulitzer Publishing Co. vs. Certain Interested Individuals, 89-1974.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide if Jurors May Be Barred in Non-Criminal Cases Because of Race
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether lawyers in non-criminal cases may bar potential jurors because of their race. The justices said they will use the case of an injured black construction worker in Louisiana to decide whether such racially motivated exclusions are prohibited in 982, five years after leaving the U.S. Marine Corps. In the interim five years, he had served in the Marine Corps Ready Reserve, both as a member of the Individual Ready Reserve and the Selected Marine Corps Reserve. All Ready Reserve members may be called to active duty in the event of war or national emergency, but Individual Ready Reserve members have no required training obligations. When Kolkhorst began his police job he was an IRR member, and therefore had no drill or camp obligations. Since 1979, the 2,900-member Baltimore Police Department had limited to 100 the number of police officers permitted to join an active military reserve unit. The department's policy was motivated by two concerns: -Activation of local reserves during civil disturbances or other emergencies would deplete the department's manpower to a point that would jeopardize public safety. -Most reserve training takes place in summer months, when vacation and other leave requests are at their highest. Kolkhorst subsequently joined a Selected Reserve unit and received orders to report to Camp Lejeune in North Carolina in the summer of 1986. When notified of those orders, the Police Department told him to quit the active reserves immediately. He quit but sued, claiming the department had violated the Veterans' Re-employment Rights Act. A federal judge last year ruled that Kolkhorst must be allowed to join the active reserve unit, and ordered the police department to pay him $4,164 in damages - the amount of income and benefits he would have earned by participating in the reservist training. The 4th Circuit court upheld that ruling. The case is Tilghman vs. Kolkhorst, 89-1949.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration Position on Local Pesticide Laws
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration its views on a state court ruling that bars communities from regulating the use of pesticides. The court asked Justice Department lawyers to comment on an appeal by the rural town of Casey, Wis. The appeal had been supported by state officials. The justices are not expected to say whether they will grant review to the town's appeal until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled in March that local regulation of pesticide use is pre-empted by the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act of 1972. Opponents of local regulation argue that towns and cities cannot cope with ever-changing scientific advances and the complexities of pest control. But local officials say they are the only ones familiar with local conditions and hazards. The Wisconsin court said it did not weigh the merits of the policy dispute, relying instead on Congress' intent in passing the federal insecticide law. ``We conclude ... the pre-emptive action of the Congress deprived the town of Casey of its police power to regulate pesticides,'' the state court said. Officials in Casey, a town of some 400 people in Wisconsin's northwest corner, required permits for pesticide use and aerial spraying. The local law imposed fines of up to $5,000 for each violation. The ordinance was challenged by a group that included farmers and tree growers, and a state judge declared it invalid in 1986. The case is Wisconsin Public Intervenor vs. Mortier, 89-1905.

DOC.HEAD: Court Wants Administration's Opinion on Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration for its views of a ruling that could help elect blacks to a Florida county commission and school board. The court wants to know what Justice Department lawyers think about an appeal by Liberty County, Fla., officials who said a lower court went too far in seeking to protect the voting rights of the county's black minority. The government's comments could take months to reach the justices, who aren't expected to say until then whether they will grant review to the Liberty County case. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in April ruled in favor of black voters challenging the at-large method of electing commissioners and school board members in Liberty County. Blacks want members of the two bodies elected by district-wide voting. One of the five county districts has a majority of voting-age blacks, while blacks comprise only 11 percent of the county population. A black never has been elected to the county commission or school board, each with five members. The 11th Circuit court stopped short of eliminating county-wide elections. But it sent the case back to a federal judge with instructions that may lead to district-wide voting. The appeals court's 10 members were evenly divided over exactly how to implement its ruling. The decision relied heavily on a 1986 Supreme Court ruling that made it easier for minorities to challenge redistricting plans that may dilute their voting strength. The high court in that case struck down a North Carolina legislative redistricting plan as a violation of the Voting Rights Act. Congress in 1982 amended the 1965 voting rights law to eliminate the need for minorities to prove intentional bias when challenging districting plans. The new law requires only that minorities show that districting plans have the effect of diluting their voting strength, regardless of intent. In the Liberty County case, the 11th Circuit court said there is sufficient evidence the black population is concentrated and politically cohesive and that the vote is racially polarized. An opinion signed by five judges on the 11th Circuit said, ``Black voters have never had an opportunity to elect a black representative, despite their manifest preference for those black candidates that have presented themselves. Six futile elections is enough.'' A separate concurring opinion signed by five other judges on the appeals court expressed reservations about their colleagues' opinion. They said that opinion ``would create a right to proportional representation for all large, compact and cohesive minority groups.'' The case is Liberty County vs. Solomon, 90-102.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Census Begins
DOC.TEXT: About 750,000 part-time workers started a head count of some 120 million people across the country Monday as part of the government's 15th national census. Japan's census, conducted every five years since 1920, is known for its thoroughness and accuracy. Each of 750,000 census takers temporarily recruited for task must distribute to and collect questionnaires from 50 households. The questionnaire not only asks names and addresses, but also birth dates, marital status, academic records and even the income of the household. The national census law allows police to jail people who refuse to be counted. ``I think we will get a response at the rate of more than 99 percent,'' said Tomoyuki Suzuki of the Management and Coordination Agency's Statistics Bureau.

DOC.HEAD: UNITED NATIONS: is completed.
DOC.TEXT: Let me also emphasize that all of us here at the U.N. hope military forces will never have to be used. We seek a peaceful outcome - a diplomatic outcome. And one more thing - in the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe that there may be opportunities: For Iraq and Kuwait to believe that there may be opportunities; For Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel. But, the world's key task - now, first and always - must be to demonstrate that aggression will not be tolerated or rewarded. Through the U.N. Security Council, Iraq has been judged by a jury of its peers - the very nations of the earth. Today, the regime stands isolated and out of step with the times, separated from the civilized world not by space, but by centuries. Iraq's unprovoked aggression is a throwback to another era, a dark relic from a dark time. It has plundered Kuwait, terrorized innocent citizens, and held even diplomats hostage. Iraq and its leaders must be held liable for these crimes of abuse and destruction. But this outrageous disregard for basic human rights does not come as a total surprise. Thousands of Iraqis have been executed on political and religious grounds, and even more through a genocidal, poison gas war waged against Iraq's own Kurdish villagers. As a world community, we must act - not only to deter the use of inhuman weapons like mustard and nerve gas - but to eliminate the weapons entirely. That is why, one year ago, I came to the General Assembly with new proposals to banish these terrible weapons from the face of the earth. I promised the United States would destroy over 98 percent of its stockpile in the first eight years of a chemical weapons ban treaty, and 100 percent - all of them - in 10 years, if all nations with chemical weapons capabilities sign the treaty. We've stood by those promises. In June, the U.S. and the Soviet Union signed a landmark agreement to halt production, and to destroy the vast majority of our stockpiles. Today, U.S. chemical weapons are being destroyed. But time is running out. This is not a merely bilateral concern. The gulf crisis proves how important it is to act together - and to act now - to conclude an absolute, worldwide ban on these weapons. We must also redouble our efforts to stem the spread of nuclear weapons, biological weapons, and the ballistic missiles that can rain destruction upon distant peoples. The United Nations can help bring about a new day, a day when these kinds of terrible weapons - and the terrible despots who would use them - are both a thing of the past. It is in our hands to leave these dark machines behind, in the dark ages where they belong, and to press forward to cap a historic movement towards a new world order and a long era of peace. We have a vision of a new partnership of nations that transcends the Cold War. A partnership based on consultation, cooperation and collective action, especially through international and regional organizations. A partnership united by principle and the Rule of Law, and supported by an equitable sharing of both cost and commitment. A partnership whose goals are to increase democracy, increase prosperity, increase the peace and reduce arms.

DOC.HEAD: Five Members Named to Stamp Committee
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON AP) - Actor Karl Malden is joining the panel that recommends subjects for new U.S. postage stamps, the U.S. Postal Service announced Monday. Malden, president of the academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is one of five new members chosen for the Citizens' Stamp Advisory Committee. The group screens the nearly 30,000 letters received annually suggesting stamp subjects and makes recommendations to the postmaster general. In addition to Malden, new committee members are David Lewis Eynon, executive vice president of Amichetti, Lewis and Associates, Bryn Mawr, Pa.; Bernard Henning Sr., attorney, Chicago; Stephen T. McLin, president, American First Financial Corp., San Francisco, and Robert H. Power, general partner, Nut Tree Restaurant, Nut Tree, Calif. Persons who want to suggest a subject for future postage stamps can do so by writing to the Citizens' Stamp Advisory Committee. Room 5670, 475 L'Enfant Plaza, S.W., Washington, D.C., 20260-6753.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration Opinion on `Lemon Laws'
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration whether state ``lemon laws'' should be allowed to give buyers of chronically defective automobiles more legal protection than they receive under federal law. The court invited Justice Department lawyers to comment on arguments by domestic and foreign car makers that such state laws impermissibly conflict with federal law. The justices are not expected to say whether they will grant review to the manufacturers' appeal until hearing from the government, which could take months. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled against the car makers when it upheld New York's lemon law last March. ``Congress did not intend to occupy the field of informal dispute resolution mechanisms (and) it is possible to comply with both the New York and federal schemes,'' the appeals court ruled in giving car consumers a significant victory. Congress in 1975 passed the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act, aimed at giving consumers more information about the warranties provided on the new cars they buy. The law does not require that a warranty be provided, but requires that if one is given it not be misleading. The law also permits car manufacturers to require consumers with complaints about the cars they bought to resort to some informal type of dispute resolution, such as arbitration, before suing. The federal law was not successful in resolving consumer problems with chronically defective cars, and many states responded by assing their own lemon laws. The New York law, enacted in 1983, requires manufacturers to give consumers full refunds or to replace defective cars if unable to repair the same problem after four tries or if a car is out of service for 30 days or more within the first two years or 18,000 miles of operation. The law was amended in 1986 to make any arbitration decision binding on car manufacturers but not on consumers and to entitle consumers to oral arbitration hearings. The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association and the Association of International Automobile Manufacturers sued over the 1986 amendments. A federal judge ruled that the amendments are pre-empted by the Magnuson-Moss Act, but the 2nd Circuit court reversed that ruling. The case is Motor Vehicles Manufacturers Association vs. Abrams, 89-2026.

DOC.HEAD: UNITED NATIONS: reduce arms.
DOC.TEXT: And as we look to the future, the calendar offers up a convenient milestone, a signpost by which to measure our progress as a community of nations. The year 2000 marks a turning point, beginning not only the turn of the decade, not only the turn of the century, but also the turn of the millennium. And ten years from now, as the 55th Session of the General Assembly begins, you will again find many of us in this hall, our hair a bit more gray, perhaps a bit less spring in our walk. But you will not find us with any less hope or idealism, or any less confidence in the ultimate triumph of humankind. I see a world of open borders, open trade, and - most importantly - open minds. A world that celebrates the common heritage that belongs to all the world's people, taking pride not just in hometown or homeland but in humanity itself. I see a world touched by a spirit like that of the Olympics: Based not on competition that's driven by fear, but sought out of joy and exhilaration and a true quest for excellence. I see a world where democracy continues to win new friends and convert old foes, and where the Americas - North, Central and South - can provide a model for the future for all humankind - the world's first completely democratic hemisphere. And I see a world building on the emerging new model of European unity. Not just Europe, but the whole world - ``whole and free.'' This is precisely why the present aggression in the Gulf is a menace not only to one region's security, but to the entire world's vision of our future. It threatens to turn the dream of a new international order into a grim nightmare of anarchy, in which the law of the jungle supplants the law of nations. That is why the United Nations reacted with such historic unity and resolve. And that is why this challenge is a test we cannot afford to fail. I am confident we will prevail. Success, too, will have lasting consequences - reinforcing civilized standards of international conduct, setting a new precedent in international cooperation, brightening the prospects for our vision of the future. There are ten more years until the century is out. Ten more years to put the struggles of the 20th Century permanently behind us. Ten more years to help; launch a new partnership of nations. And throughout those ten years - and beginning now - the U.N. has a new and vital role in building towards that partnership. Last year's General Assembly showed how we can make greater progress towards a more pragmatic and successful U.N. And, for the first time, the U.N. Security Council is beginning to work as it was designed to work. Now is the time to set aside old debates, old procedures, old controversies, and old resolutions. It's time to replace polemic attacks with pragmatic action. We have shown that the U.N. can count on the collective strength of the international community. We have shown that the U.N. can rise to the challenge of aggression, as its founders hoped it would. And now in this time of testing, we must also show that the U.N. is the place to build international support and consensus for meeting the other challenges we face.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Condemns Saddam But Offers Hope For Diplomatic Solution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sub 2nd graf, `Also tday...' with 1 graf and inserts 2 grafs after 15th, `I think...' to UPDATE with Israeli army to distribute gas masks to all Israelis. Pickup 16th, `The official...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today condemned Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein for his invasion of Kuwait, but he also offered an opening to Baghdad, suggesting that an Iraqi withdrawal could lead to settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Also today, Iraq ordered the release of nine French nationals in its second conciliatory gesture in as many days. And in Israel, the army said it will give out gas masks to every Israeli to protect them in the event of a war. On Sunday, Saddam Hussein urged an international dialogue and mentioned France as a possible partner. U.S., French and British officials rejected the offer, saying they wouldn't talk until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait. The nations allied against Iraq, meanwhile, were laying the groundwork for possible military action. U.S. and Soviet officials were reported Sunday to be drafting new U.N. resolutions that would authorize the use of force against Iraq if the U.N.-ordered economic blockade fails to force Saddam out of Kuwait. In his address to the U.N. General Assembly today, Bush mixed harsh language against Saddam with an overture for a resolution of the 2-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. ``Iraq's unprovoked aggression is a throwback to another era, a dark relic from a dark time,'' Bush said in his prepared remarks. But he added: ``We seek a peaceful outcome, a diplomatic outcome.'' ``In the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe that there may be opportunities,'' he said. ``For Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel. In past speeches, Saddam has linked an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. He repeated those conditions Sunday. In other developments, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati and his Saudi counterpart, Prince Saud al-Faisal, met in New York to discuss resuming diplomatic relations and ending a 2{-year rift, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said today. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said in a dispatch from New York that the meeting took place Sunday at U.N. heaquarters. It was the first time senior officials from the two countries have met since the Saudis broke off ties in April 1988, citing terrorism and subversion. It was the most positive sign yet that they may be moving toward rapprochement. Thousands of French troops joined the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia on Sunday, and U.S. and British warships in the Persian Gulf stopped and searched an Indian ship carrying refugees from Kuwait. The refugee ship was not found to be in violation of the U.N. embargo. European and Israeli military analysts said the likelihood of war has grown significantly as sanctions and a hostile world push Saddam into a corner with no diplomatic escape. ``I think another six to eight weeks is available to prevent a conflict, but after that it becomes almost inevitable,'' said Paul Beaver, publisher of the respected Jane's Defense Weekly, in an interview in London. Such reports prompted the Israeli army to announce today that it will begin distributing gas masks to Israel's 4.7 million citizens next week. The announcement follows threats by Saddam to attack Israel, including one in which he said he would burn half the Jewish state with chemical weapons. The official Iraqi News Agency said today that Saddam has ordered the release of nine French nationals. They are believed to be among the Westerners Saddam has ordered placed at strategic sites to serve as shields to prevent potential Western attacks. On Sunday, in a speech on Iraqi state TV and radio, Saddam said he no longer opposes involvement by foreign powers in seeking a settlement to the crisis, which was precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Saddam's speech, read by an announcer, said tensions can be reduced ``if dialogue replaces the policy of threats and warnings, if the language of peaceful politics replaces the policy of troop buildups and threats of the use of force.'' However, he again linked any solution to an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories. And he said Iraq would defend Kuwait if necessary. Saddam said he wanted to open a dialogue with France to explore the possibility of using President Francois Mitterrand's ideas on negotiating a broad Middle East peace as basis for a settlement. He said he viewed Mitterrand's proposals as ``being of a different language'' than past foreign denunciations of Iraq, adding: ``We hope our positive interpretation is correct.'' In a U.N. speech on Sept. 24, Mitterrand suggested settling the conflict over Kuwait together with other regional problems that might include Israel's occupation of Arab territories and the Lebanese civil war. But he also insisted that if Iraq wants to see foreign military forces leave the region it must quit Kuwait and release the estimated 2,200 Western hostages it holds. Responding to the overture, France, Britain and the United States said they would not negotiate without an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. ``It still doesn't address the two basic U.N. resolutions, which are withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of the government,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Stalls
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending stalled in August following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait after posting its first gain in four months in July, the government said Monday. Only an increase in government projects kept overall spending from declining. ``Confidence is the major problem we have across-the-board right now,'' said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. ``Confidence is certainly at the lowest point we've seen in a long time.'' The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government spending was virtually unchanged at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $442.5 billion following a revised 0.3 percent increase in July. The often-volatile government spending jumped 6.1 percent, offsetting declines of 1.2 percent in residential construction and 4.3 percent in non-residential outlays. ``The residential sector was very weak,'' Delano said of the $186.9 billion spending rate for single- and multi-family buildings. ``It's consistent with everything we've seen in that sector.'' Residential spending has fallen for five straight months. Single-family spending was down 1.3 percent to an annual rate of $108.5 billion following a 1.2 percent loss a month earlier. Apartment construction was up 1.1 percent to $19 billion after a 0.5 percent gain in July. But non-residential spending, which advanced 4.2 percent in July, fell 4.3 percent to annual rate of $104.8 billion in August and more than erased the gain. Industrial spending, which jumped 16.2 percent in July, slipped back 12.7 percent. ``There's a lot more weakness to come,'' Delano said. ``It's consistent with a lack of confidence and a wait-and-see attitude.'' Government spending totaled an annual rate of $115.1 billion following a 2.7 percent decline the previous month. Spending on highways and streets led the advance with a 9.0 percent gain. The 0.3 percent increase in construction spending in July was the first advance since a 0.4 percent gain in March. Spending fell 2.8 percent in April, 0.2 percent in May and 0.6 percent in June. In addition to consumer caution over the state of the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis, analysts have attributed the general weakness in the construction industry to high interest rates, tight lending requirements, and, in some areas, overbuilding resulting in high vacancies. The weakness has been illustrated in recent Labor Department reports showing the loss of nearly 100,000 construction jobs in the past three months. This included 40,000 jobs, after a seasonal adjustment, in August, the sixth consecutive monthly decline. Construction spending in August was 2.0 percent above the $433.9 billion in the same month of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration Comment on Hazardous-Shipment Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration whether states should be allowed to regulate the shipment of hazardous substances by railroads. The court said it wants to hear from Justice Department lawyers before deciding whether to review a ruling that such Ohio regulations are pre-empted by federal laws governing rail safety. The justices are not expected to say whether they will review the Ohio case until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. Ohio's appeal to the high court was supported by nine other states, a nationwide alliance of state regulators and a railroad union group. They urged the justices to overturn 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that invalidated Ohio's hazardous substance controls. Leaving regulation of such shipments to the federal government is an invitation to disaster, the state officials said. ``When rail hazardous materials accidents occur, the results can be catastrophic,'' the officials said. They noted that billions of tons of dangerous substances are transported each year and said federal agencies lack the staffs or will to carry out adequate inspections and enforcement. Supporting the Ohio appeal were Arizona, California, Louisiana, Missouri, Montana, Nevada, Tennessee, Texas and Washington. The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, representing officials in all 50 states, also urged the high court to step in. The Railway Labor Executives Association, representing the railroad unions, said the number of accidents involving trains carrying hazardous material increased from 351 in 1987 to 517 last year. The unions accused the Federal Railroad Administration of doing little to correct the problem, leaving regulation to the railroads themselves. The unions said that if the 6th Circuit ruling were to apply nationwide ``all railroads that transport hazardous materials and toxic substances can effectively avoid compliance with any and all regulation.'' The 6th Circuit court has jurisdiction in Ohio, Kentucky, Michigan and Tennessee. The appeals court last April ruled in favor of four railroads that challenged Ohio's regulations. The railroads are CSX Transportation Inc., Conrail, Norfolk and Western, and Grand Trunk Western. The appeals court said the Federal Railroad Safety Act strictly limits the power of states to regulate rail safety. The aw generally bars states from duplicating federal safety rules, the appeals court said. But Ohio and the other states argued that a second federal law specifically gives the states power to control shipments of hazardous material by any form of transportation, including railroads. Ohio officials said that law, the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act, established a dual system of federal-state regulation. State rules must be consistent with federal regulations under the law, the Ohio attorney general's office said. Ohio enacted its hazardous material control law after a 1986 accident in which 15 cars on a Baltimore & Ohio train derailed in Miamisburg, Ohio. A tank car containing phosphorous ruptured, causing $3.5 million in property damage and prompting evacuation of some 40,000 people. A report on the accident by the National Transportation Safety Board said the Federal Railroad Administration had not exerted sufficient control over tank car safety. The case is Public Utilities Commission of Ohio vs. CSX Transportation Inc., 90-95.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Abandoning Decisions on Sentencing in Ohio Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 8-9, Rejected an appeal, with other case.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court opened its new term today by agreeing to review its recent decisions barring sentencing juries from considering the character of the defendant's victim or the grief of the victim's family. There were only eight justices on the bench as the court issued some 1,000 orders after returning from a three-month summer recess. It denied review in the vast majority of the cases. David H. Souter is expected to receive Senate confirmation Tuesday as the nation's 105th justice of the Supreme Court. In the sentencing case, the court agreed to consider reinstating an Ohio man's death penalty for a love-triangle murder. In other action, the court: - Agreed to decide whether lawyers in non-criminal cases may bar potential jurors because of their race. The justices said they will use the case of an injured black construction worker in Louisiana to decide whether such racially motivated exclusions are prohibited in civil as well as criminal trials. - Rejected an appeal by an Ohio woman who gave birth to a healthy boy after she underwent an unsuccessful abortion. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that barred the woman from suing a doctor and hospital for the costs of rearing her child. - Asked the Bush administration whether employers ever may bar their workers from joining or serving in the military reserves. The court wants to hear Justice Department lawyers' views on a ruling that struck down the Baltimore Police Department's policy of limiting the number of employees allowed to be in active reserve units. - Said it will try to clarify what authority police have to pursue and detain people who run away after seeing police.
