The justices agreed to consider reinstating the cocaine conviction and 68-month sentence of an Oakland, Calif., youth who a state court said was chased and caught unlawfully by police. - Agreed to decide whether U.S. businesses are lawbreakers if they discriminate against Americans they employ outside the country. The justices, setting the case for an important ruling, said they will decide whether Congress intended a major anti-bias law to reach beyond the nation's borders. - Agreed to use a dispute over the settlement of a strike by Continental Air Lines pilots to set new guidelines on the duties of unions to represent their members. The court said it will consider killing a lawsuit against the Air Line Pilots Association by striking pilots who said the union denied them fair representation. - Permitted the random drug testing of New York City's 10,000 jail guards. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the guards' labor union, which said the tests violate the corrections officers' privacy rights. - Let stand a ruling that church-run schools must pay employees the federal minimum wage and may not pay women teachers less than men. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by officials of a Baptist church in Virginia who said forcing the church to abide by federal labor law violates its religious freedom and other constitutional rights. - Rejected the appeal of three white men from New York City convicted in the ``Howard Beach incident'' of 1986, a racially motivated attack in which a black man died. The justices, without comment, let stand the manslaughter and assault convictions of Jon Lester, Scott Kern and Jason Ladone. Lawyers for the three men had argued they wrongly were limited in excluding blacks as trial jurors. - Agreed to consider letting states outlaw all barroom-style nude dancing as it voted to her an effort to reinstate such an Indiana law. The court said it will review a ruling that ``non-obscene nude dancing performed as entertainment is expression and as such is entitled to limited protection under the (Constitution's) First Amendment.'' In the Ohio sentencing case, Ediberto Huertas fatally stabbed Ralph Harris Jr. in Lorain, Ohio, on June 7, 1986. He now is serving a life prison term for the crime. On leave from the Air Force, Harris was spending the night with Elba Ortiz. Huertas, who had fathered two children with Ms. Ortiz, allegedly warned Harris he would ``waste him'' if he continued to see the woman. A state jury imposed the death sentence after hearing evidence that Harris' parents wanted Huertas to die for his crime. Elizabeth Harris, the victim's mother, also testified emotionally she was proud of her churchgoing son and that his death had devastated his son. The Supreme Court in 1987 ruled that such ``victim-impact'' evidence should not be considered by sentencing juries. And last year, the justices voted 5-4 that a jury generally may not be told about the victim's character. The court said a South Carolina murderer unfairly was sentenced to die because the jury heard such testimony. That ruling was written by Justice William J. Brennan, who has since retired. The four justices who dissented from last year's decision said then they were ready to overturn the 1987 ruling and permit victim-impact testimony in criminal sentencing. The Ohio Supreme Court relied on both U.S. Supreme Court rulings when last May it reduced Huertas' death sentence to life in prison. Prosecutors argued that the jury should have been allowed to consider the impact of Harris' murder on his family because Huertas and Harris had been high school friends and Huertas knew the family. The killer was aware of the impact his crime would have on the family, they said. But the Ohio Supreme Court said such evidence is relevant to the sentence only when the evidence has ``a connection to the defendant's personal responsibility and moral guilt.'' Otherwise, the state court said, such testimony undermines the defendant's right to be sentenced by an impartial jury. The case is Ohio vs. Huertas, 89-1944.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Dallas Police Chief's Trial Transferred to Criminal Court
DOC.TEXT: A state district judge ruled today that the ousted Dallas police chief's perjury trial belongs in a lower court. State District Judge Joe Kendall transferred Mack Vines' trial to Dallas County Criminal Court, saying his court lacks jurisdiction because the perjury indictment does not allege official misconduct. ``Nothing in the indictment in this case distinguishes the charge in this case from that against any other member of the general public,'' Kendall said. Dallas County Assistant District Attorney Ted Steinke said the transfer to criminal court ``would have no bearing at all on the case.'' Steinke, who argued today that Kendall's court had jurisdiction in the case, said the lack of mention of Vines' role as a public official was not an omission in the indictment. But he refused comment on whether it should have been included. ``This was the court's decision to make. We have no quarrel with it,'' Steinke said. Vines' lawyer, Bill Boyd, praised the ruling. ``It's certainly not bad for (Vines) and it's good for him in that we're clearly dealing with a misdemeanor,'' he said. ``Obviously, on the advice of my counsel, I am satisfied,'' Vines said. ``I guess we just go on from here to a misdemeanor court.'' State district courts have jurisdiction over felony charges, while criminal courts handle misdemeanors. Steinke said the main difference is that six criminal court jurors will hear the case as opposed to 12 in state court. Vines pleaded innocent Sept. 12 to the perjury charge. Hours later, he was fired by City Manager Jan Hart. The misdemeanor charge alleges that Vines lied to a panel investigating a police shooting about a conversation he had with his assistant, Greg Holliday, Aug. 2. Vines has maintained his innocence. Holliday said Vines called him late at night and tried to influence Holliday's testimony before the special panel, which he was scheduled to give the next day. Holliday told Ms. Hart of the conversation and she suspended both men with pay. Holliday later was reinstated.

DOC.HEAD: Court Permits Prosecution of Honduran in Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today permitted the prosecution of an alleged Honduran drug dealer who said U.S. officials kidnapped and tortured him. The court, over one dissenting vote, rejected arguments that the defendant should be freed because U.S. officials violated international law and the U.S. and Honduras constitutions. Only Justice Byron R. White voted to hear arguments in the case. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in February refused to bar prosecution of Juan Ramon Matta-Ballesteros, who faces drug charges in Arizona and California and was sentenced in a federal court in Florida to three years in prison for an earlier escape. Matta escaped from the Eglin Air Force Base prison in Florida in 1971 and fled to his native Honduras, which does not extradite its own citizens. He was arrested by Honduran authorities at his home in Tegucigalpa on April 5, 1988, and was turned over to U.S. marshals. Matta said the marshals, who took him to a federal prison in Marion, Ill., beat him severely and burned him with a stun gun that uses electric pulses to immobilize victims. U.S. officials denied those allegations and said any mistreatment Matta suffered while in custody was the work of his Honduran captors. Matta was transferred from Illinois to Florida, where he was convicted of escaping from federal custody. The 7th Circuit court ruled that even if Matta's rights were violated, he is not entitled to be freed. ``For the past 100 years, the Supreme Court has consistently held that the manner in which a defendant is brought to trial does not affect the ability of the government to try him,'' the appeals court said. If Matta was mistreated, the appeals court said, his remedy is to sue the government and the officials who allegedly violated his rights. A related issue has been raised by the arrest of a Mexican suspect in the 1985 murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. A federal judge has ruled that U.S. officials violated an extradition treaty with Mexico when they seized Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, a gynecologist accused of administering drugs to Camarena while the agent was tortured. Justice Department lawyers are appealing the judge's ruling. The Mexican government protested Alvarez's arrest, in contrast to Matta's capture in which the Honduran government cooperated. The Supreme Court last February bolstered the fight against drug smuggling and terrorism when it ruled that U.S. agents do not need warrants to search in other countries. The court upheld the warrantless search of the home of a suspected Mexican drug smuggler. The case acted on today is Matta-Ballesteros v. Henman, 89-1797.

DOC.HEAD: Impeached Ex-Judge Seeking Running In Florida Runoff
DOC.TEXT: Impeached former federal judge Alcee Hastings is trying to make a comeback in public life, running for Florida secretary of state with the same defiance he displayed toward prosecutors and U.S. senators. Hastings faces ex-newspaperman Jim Minter for the Democratic nomination for secretary of state in the only statewide race in Tuesday's primary runoff election in Florida. ``A lot of people really do know that I took a political hatchet in the face,'' Hastings says of his impeachment, which came despite his acquittal in court on bribery charges. ``I will not be made into some kind of clown.'' The 53-year-old former judge, removed from office by the U.S. Senate in 1989, finished second to Minter ina three-way primary that also featured former Ku Klux Klan Grand Dragon John Paul Rogers, who got more than a quarter of a million votes. Polls show Minter leading Hastings by 11 percentage points, but more than a third of those questioned were undecided. Well-financed Republican incumbent Jim Smith would beat either candidate in the Nov. 6 general election, the polling data indicates. Low voter turnout for Tuesday's runoff could benefit Hastings, who has picked up support from the state's labor unions and has a strong base among minority voters in his Miami home. Dot Joyce, director of the Division of Elections, predicted a ``miserable'' turnout Tuesday that might reach 20 percent if the weather is good. Hastings, who decided to run for secretary of state after a brief campaign for governor, was Florida's first black federal judge when appointed by President Carter in 1979. The Senate ousted Hastings from the federal bench for conspiring to obtain a $150,000 payoff involving the alleged fixing of court cases. A friend of Hastings', William Borders, was convicted of bribery conspiracy in the case, but Hastings was acquitted in a 1983 jury trial. The impeachment proceeding ``gives new meaning to double jeopardy and renders a severe blow to ... the jury system,'' Hastings declared after the Senate removed him from office 11 months ago. Minter, 52, resigned as an editorial writer and columnist for the Tallahassee Democrat to seek his first political office. He cites his experience as a speechwriter for former Gov. Reubin Askew and as an aide to ex-Secretary of State George Firestone to show he knows his way around the Capitol. Minter, who has picked up nearly every newspaper endorsement, has directed his low-budget campaign toward those he calls ``good government folks'' such as political activists and environmentalists. ``It's going to be a very close race and it depends entirely on the turnout,'' Minter said. ``If the good government folks don't turn out, the Democrats are going to wind up with a strange bedfellow.'' Hastings bristles at the comment, pointing out that he is the only candidate who was selected by a president for a federal office. The ex-judge also said the state's newspaper editorial boards haven't treated him fairly. ``They formed their judgments without even hearing from me,'' he said. ``I will beat the living daylights out of every daily newspaper and prove they cannot elect people.'' Hastings has proposed abolishing the independently elected state Cabinet as too cumbersome, even though he seeks a seat on it. And he has suggested that legalized casino gambling might help solve the state's budget problems. The secretary of state is Florida's top elections official and oversees corporate charters and state records. Minter and Hastings have called for campaign finance reform and both have outlined positions on the environment, education and other issues that face the Cabinet, which makes a wide range of executive decisions.

DOC.HEAD: UNITED NATIONS: we face.
DOC.TEXT: The world remains a dangerous place. And our security and well-being often depends, in part, on events occurring far away. We need serious international cooperative efforts to make headway on threats to the environment, on terrorism, on managing the debt burden, on fighting the scourge of international drug trafficking, and on refugee and peacekeeping efforts around the world. But the world also remains a hopeful place. Calls for democracy and human rights are being reborn everywhere. These calls are an expression of support for the values enshrined in the U.N. Charter. They encourage our hopes for a more stable, more peaceful, more prosperous world. Free elections are the foundation of democratic government, and can produce dramatic successes, as we have seen in Namibia and Nicaragua. And the time has come to structure the U.N. role in such efforts more formally. And so today, I propose that the United Nations establish a Special Coordinator for Electoral Assistance, to be assisted by a U.N. Electoral Commission comprised of distinguished experts from around the world. As with free elections, we also believe that universal U.N. membership for all states is central to the future of this organization, and to the new partnership we've discussed. In support of this principle, and in conjunction with U.N. efforts to reduce regional tensions, the United States fully supports U.N. membership for the Republic of Korea. We do so without prejudice to the ultimate objective of reunification of the Korean Peninsula, and without opposition to simultaneous membership for the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Building on these and other initiatives, we must join together in a new compact - all of us - to bring the United Nations into the 21st Century. And I call today for a major, long-term effort to do this. We should build on the success of our distinguished secretary general, my longtime friend and colleague, Javier Perez de Cuellar. We should strive for greater effectiveness and efficiency of the U.N. The United States is committed to playing its part, helping to maintain global security, promoting democracy and prosperity. My administration is fully committed to supporting the United Nations, and to paying what we are obliged to pay by our commitment to the charter. International peace and security - and international freedom and prosperity - require no less. The world must know and understand: From this hour, from this day, from this hall - we step forth with a new sense of purpose, a new sense of possibilities. We stand together, prepared to swim upstream, to march uphill, to tackle the tough challenges as they come - not only as the United Nations - but as the nations of the world united. Let it be said of the final decade of the 20th Century: This was a time when humankind came into its own. When we emerged from the grit and the smoke of the industrial age to bring about a revolution of the spirit and of the mind, and began a journey into a new day, a new age, and a new partnership of nations. The U.N. is now fulfilling its promise as the world's parliament of peace. I congratulate you. I support you. and I wish you Godspeed in the challenges ahead.
DOC.HEAD: End Bush-Text, 5 Takes
Precede NEW YORK
Teachers in Washington, New York Reach Tentative Agreements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughott to UPDATE with tentative agreement reached in Washington state. Edits to trim. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators in Washington state reached a tentative agreement today in the longest teachers' strike and New York City's 85,000-member union, the nation's largest, averted a walkout just hours after its contract expired. In Everett, Wash., negotiators sat down at 1 p.m. Sunday and met through the night with three state mediators until reaching an agreement about 8:30 a.m. today, said Washington Education Association spokesman John Cahill. The proposal was to be brought before teachers in the Mukilteo School District for ratification this afternoon, Cahill said. He declined to release details of the agreement until it was presented to the district's 460 teachers. The Mukilteo strike began Aug. 30 and classes were to start Sept. 5. Key issues included class size, teacher assignment and transfer policies, school decision-making panels and pay for extra time, responsibility and incentives. In New York, the city and its teachers' union reached tentative agreement today on a contract that would raise salaries 5.5 percent, both sides said. Union spokesman Bert Shanas said the two sides agreed on a one-year contract, and a statement from the school chancellor's office said the raise would bring starting salaries to $26,375 and senior salaries to $52,750. The old contract, covering 65,000 public school teachers and 20,000 other school employees, expired at midnight. School was in session today. Meanwhile, the nation's largest labor dispute involving teachers continued in Louisiana. The strike by public school teachers entered its third week today after union negotiators rejected what Orleans Parish School Board officials said was a $13 million contract. In New York, Neill Rosenfeld, a spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers, said earlier that agreements were reached on all non-economic issues, but the two sides were haggling over the size of a pay raise. Last week, the union rejected the city's offer of a 4 percent raise. Rosenfeld said the city raised that offer, but he would not how high. Teachers in New York City make a starting salary of $25,000 and can earn up to $50,000. The new contract will cover employees of about 1,000 elementary, junior high and high schools that serve about 946,000 students. The 20,000 employees who are not teachers include counselors, social workers and secretaries.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Consider Prisoners' Rights Case From Ohio
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether unfit prison living conditions may amount to cruel and unusual punishment when there is no evidence officials acted maliciously. The justices said they will hear an appeal by an Ohio inmate who accused officials of being indifferent to overcrowding, rat-infested kitchens, freezing cold, oppressive heat and other miserable conditions. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in January threw out a suit by Pearly Wilson, a prisoner in the Hocking Correctional Facility in Nelsonville, Ohio. Wilson said prison officials violated the Eighth Amendment to the Constitution, which forbids cruel and unusual punishment. He said the inmates were in cramped cells, subject to excessive noise, foul lavatories and housed with the physically and mentally ill. The prison is frigid in winter and stifling in summer, he added. But the appeals court said Wilson did not demonstrate that officials have engaged in ``persistent malicious cruelty.'' At worst, the state is guilty of negligence and that does not prove any constitutional violation in such circumstances, the appeals court said. Wilson argued that evidence of deliberate indifference is enough to warrant intervention by the federal courts to order states to improve living conditions. He also said the 6th Circuit court ruling conflicts with decisions by other federal appeals courts. Ohio officials, in urging the high court to reject Wilson's appeal, said the inmate filed more that 70 lawsuits against the state since 1976, almost all them frivolous or premature. The officials also said there is ample evidence the state tried to improve conditions at the facility. The case is Wilson vs. Seiter, 89-7376.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma City School Busing Case Back on Supreme Court Docket
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court hears arguments Tuesday in a case that could define the federal judiciary's duties and responsibilities after a school system is declared desegregated. In the long run, up to 500 school districts nationwide could be affected by the high court's decision, say lawyers for both sides in the case. It's not known when the court will rule. The question before the court is whether the Oklahoma City School Board's 1985 decision to abandon forced busing will lead the district away from a desegregated or ``unitary'' system. U.S. District Judge Luther Bohanon ruled in 1985 that the federal court could not intervene to stop the board's neighborhood school plan, which abandoned forced busing for students in kindergarten through fourth grades. Students in upper grades are still bused. Bohanon reasoned that since he had declared the Oklahoma City district desegregated in 1977, the federal courts no longer had jurisdiction. The NAACP appealed and the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed Bohanon. The school district appealed to the Supreme Court. The 10th Circuit said federal court supervision in such cases ``extends beyond the termination of the wrongdoing.'' It said the Oklahoma City School Board had a continuing duty to refrain from any action that would weaken racial balance in the public schools, and ordered Bohanon to study ``alternatives to maintain racially balanced elementary schools.'' School Superintendent Arthur Stellar maintains that no segregation results from the neighborhood school plan. Steller said there are no identifiably white schools left in the district, but admits that 10 of the 58 elementary schools ``are 90 percent or more black.'' He blamed that on the fact that ``the neighborhoods are not entirely integrated.'' But, he added, ``if the present trends continue, they would become more and more integrated.'' ``I think ideally we would live in a world where schools, churches and neighborhoods would all be integrated. Unfortunately, that's not the situation in which we live,'' Steller said. Not everyone agrees the system is desegregated. ``We have 32 elementary schools in Oklahoma City that are racially identifiable, and by racially identifiable I mean 90 to 98 percent one race or the other,'' said Roosevelt Milton, president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Milton said the neighborhood plan has shortchanged blacks. ``I'd say essentially we're getting inexperienced educators and a lack of adequate books and supplies, and I think relegating a very high number of socio-economically deprived students into the same school,'' he said. The case has spanned nearly three decades. In October 1961, A.L. Dowell, a black optometrist, filed a lawsuit contending his son, Robert, was denied admission to a predominantly white high school. He alleged a quota system was used to keep black enrollment at predominantly white schools to a minimum and that there was a double standard for the two races. Nearly two years later, Bohanon ordered the district to take extensive steps to bring racial balance to the schools. In the 1972-73 school year, court-ordered busing began and thousands of children were transported throughout a district where only 25.1 percent of the students were black and 74.9 percent were white. About 5,000 children rode school buses before Bohanon's 1972 busing order. That number jumped by 15,000 for the 1972-73 school year, according to minutes from school board meetings. Many whites left the school district for the suburbs. From an enrollment of 68,904 in 1971, the district dropped to 59,241 the next year. It was down to only 37,735 pupils in the school year just completed. White students were the minority last year, 44.7 percent of the total enrollment. Black enrollment was up to 40 percent, while the remaining 15.3 percent was listed as Spanish, American Indian or Oriental. Six years after the forced busing began, Bohanon ruled that it had achieved its objective. He declared the Oklahoma City School District to be desegregated and ended court supervision. School officials continued the busing until the 1985-86 school term, when the neighborhood school concept was implemented.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Force Kentucky to Open Juvenile Records
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to force states to allow some public access to juvenile court hearings or records. The justices, without comment, let stand Kentucky court rulings that upheld the mandatory secrecy of the state's juvenile courts. Kentucky's policy was challenged in 1988 by The Courier-Journal and Louisville Times after a newspaper reporter was forbidden to see transcripts of a juvenile court hearing. The dispute arose over the case of a 16-year-old youth, identified in court records by the initials F.T.P., who fatally beat another juvenile who lived in the same state-run facility. After F.T.P. was charged, state prosecutors sought to have his case transferred out of juvenile court so he could be tried as an adult. In response, lawyers for F.T.P. asked a juvenile court judge to declare the state's transfer law unconstitutional. The judge did so. It was the hearing on the transfer law's constitutionality that the Louisville newspapers sought to attend. They later sought to obtain transcripts and records from the hearing. A trial judge ruled that the juvenile court proceedings must remain secret, and the Kentucky Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last year. The Kentucky Supreme Court refused to hear the newspapers' appeal last April. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the newspapers argued that past rulings by the nation's highest court established ``a presumption of openness in criminal trials and pretrial proceedings.'' ``There is simply no reason why proceedings which the Constitution would require to be presumptively open if the accused was an 18-year-old can be mandatorily closed when the accused is 17,'' the appeal said. ``Juvenile courts in Kentucky are not required, or even allowed, to consider closure on a case-by-case basis, inquiring into the existence and intensity of interests supporting closure,'' it added. The case is Courier-Journal vs. F.T.P., 90-107.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Americans Evenly Divided on U.S. Military Response
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans re about evenly divided on the question of how strong the U.S. military response should be if Iraq attacks American forces in the Persian Gulf, according to a poll released Monday. Of the 1,000 people surveyed, 49 percent said the United States should respond with the limited force necessary for defense, while 47 percent said it should launch an all-out war. Four percent said the United States shouldn't respond with force. But a majority - 69 percent - said the United States should give the international economic sanctions against Iraq time to work before considering war. Twenty percent said the United States should not start war under any circumstances. The survey was commissioned by Americans Talk Security, a bipartisan organization of pollsters who gauge attitudes to matters of national security. Forty percent of those polled said U.S. forces should remain in the gulf region a year or more; 22 percent said they should remain ``as long as it takes;'' and 6 percent said U.S. troops should start leaving immediately. If U.S. forces start to leave, 66 percent of the respondents said the United States should negotiate an agreement with Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states to have a permanent deployment of American troops in the region. In the event of a protracted stalemate with Iraq, 73 percent said the United States should launch a massive, all-out war and 19 percent said the United States should use nuclear weapons in such a case. Ten percent said the United States should use chemical weapons; 56 percent said it should not. But 56 percent said a stalemate was unlikely or impossible, while 40 percent said it was likely. Asked what the United States could have done to avert the crisis, 21 percent said there should have been increased research and development of energy sources other than oil and 18 percent said the United States shouldn't have helped Iraq in its eight-year war with Iran. The respondents were asked to rate the top U.S. priorities in the gulf confrontation. Producing a lasting peace in the Middle East was first followed by removing Iraqi President Saddam Hussein from power and the free flow of oil from the Mideast. At the bottom of the list was returning Kuwait's royal family to power. Interviews for the survey were conducted between Sept. 21 and 26. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Tavianis Make Film of Tolstoy's `Father Sergio'
DOC.TEXT: Father Sergio Giuramondo's quest for inner peace provides the drama on screen in the Taviani brothers' ``Night Sun.'' Off screen, finding the actor to play Father Sergio was an equally difficult task. ``We had an image in our head and we couldn't find someone in Italy or in France,'' said Paulo Taviani in a press conference with brother Vittorio after the film's recent screening at the New York Film Festival. ``One day, we saw a picture of (English actor) Julian Sands, and just from his face, his body, we thought he would be right. ``We met with him for a long time. We had him read parts from other films of ours. It was a little difficult at first not to have an actor who's Italian, but it's happened many, many times. Perhaps because we belong to an underdeveloped country that has to borrow bits of culture from others,'' joked Paulo, whose previous films with Vittorio include ``The Night of San Lorenzo'' and ``Good Morning Babylon.'' ``Night Sun'' is based on ``Father Sergio,'' a short novel by Leo Tolstoy, and takes place in 18th-century Naples. The original story was based in 19th- century St. Petersburg. As a boy, the intense Sergio wishes to serve his King and eventually receives his wish. But the King pushes him into a disastrous engagement with the beautiful Cristina (Nastassja Kinski), who reveals that for a year she was the monarch's mistress. An enraged Sergio storms out of her home and decides to become a monk. The monastery also proves unsatisfactory (too close to the temptations of the secular world), and Sergio chooses to become a hermit. Even then, his will is tested. He is twice visited by women who desire him sexually and receives unwanted fame when villagers believe he is responsible for making a dumb boy speak. The film ends with Sergio wandering from village to village. ``The film centers on the predicament of one's desire for privacy and one's desire to interact with others,'' explained Vittorio Taviani. ``A constant was a desire to tell a beautiful story,'' added Paulo. ``The most important stories, such as `The Iliad,' often have a journey as their theme.'' ``Night Sun'' runs for 112 minutes and does not have an American distributor. The New York Film Festival opened Sept. 21 with ``Miller's Crossing'' and closes Oct. 7 with ``The Nasty Girl.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Estranged Wife, Child, Before Committing Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A man fatally shot his estranged wife and 2-year-old daughter, and their two dogs, before putting the gun to his own head and killing himself, police said. ``There was a Bible over the little girl's chest, right over the gunshot wound,'' said Shelby County Coroner Billy Thompson. Police said Herbert Kim Deneau, 37, killed his daughter, Julia Deneau, and his wife, Judy Ann Watson, 37, along with the family's two collies. Officers said Deneau called a friend Sunday and reported the slayings. The friend alerted police. All of the victims, including the dogs, were found in a walk-in closet off an upstairs bedroom, authorities said. The Birmingham Post-Herald quoted unidentified neighbors as saying that Deneau and his wife separated about a month ago and were going through a divorce. They said Deneau continued living in the house after his wife, who used her maiden name, moved out. Police Sgt. J.B. Thrasher said there was almost no furniture in the house in the well-to-do Birmingham suburb because Ms. Watson had taken it with her. Neighbors told the Post-Herald that Deneau was a stockbroker who had been unemployed for more than a year and that he was intensely private, posting ``no trespassing'' signs to keep people away from his yard. `I was sort of afraid of him,'' one neighbor told the newspaper. ``I thought that he could do something like this. Whenever my husband was away, I stayed inside.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Steals Plane, Buzzes Downtown Anchorage Buildings
DOC.TEXT: A man has been accused of stealing an airplane and buzzing downtown highrise buildings before crashing into a wooded area. Jeffrey Campbell, 33, faced charges of theft, burglary and criminal mischief. The single-engine Cessna 172 was stolen early Sunday from Anchorage Air Center at Merrill Field, said Police Sgt. Gary Lee. The pilot then flew it between the Arco and Hunt office building towers, circled the Sheraton Anchorage Hotel a few times and slipped between the towers of the Hotel Captain Cook. ``He did a few very erratic maneuvers,'' Lee said. ``Then he disappeared.'' The plane crashed on a firing range at Fort Richardson, but the pilot managed to walk away and call a cab to take him home, Lee said. Campbell, an unemployed cab driver, was arrested later in the day, examined at a hospital and taken to jail, Lee added.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Syria Reportedly Agree on Hostage Release; Shiites Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th pvs, `However, there...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with White House comment. Pickup 7th, `Iran's ambassador...'
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Syria have agreed on a plan to free Western hostages in Lebanon, a Beirut newspaper reported today. Also today, the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army said it freed 40 Shiite Moslem detainees to mark the birthday of the Prophet Mohammed. The demands of the Shiites holding most of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon include the release of the 340 Moslems held by the South Lebanon Army. The Westerners comprise six Americans, four Britons and two West Germans and a missing Italian. Most are believed held by Shiite factions linked to Hezbollah, Tehran's main ally in Lebanon. The conservative daily Ad-Diyar, citing unidentified diplomatic sources, said Syrian President Hafez Assad worked out the accord to free the Westerners in talks in Tehran last week with President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran. The Iranian Embassy in Beirut and the headquarters of the Syrian security force in west Beirut declined comment on the newspaper report. In New York, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We welcome the release of the 40 Shiite Muslim prisoners in Lebanon. ``It is consistent with our position that for humanitarian reasons, all persons being detained without legal basis in the Middle East should be released immediately. Our particular concern is quite naturally the Americans being held hostage in Lebanon, and we call upon all parties to use their influence to effect their immediate and unconditional release. ``As President Bush has indicated, the release of American hostages would help improve our relations with countries contributing to that release.'' There have been other indications that efforts to free the captives were gathering momentum amid the Persian Gulf crisis triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iran's Ambassador to Pakistan, a country used by the Americans as a conduit into Tehran, said shortly before Assad's visit to the Iranian capital that some hostages could be freed soon. And Iran and Britain restored relations last week, ending a 19-month rift. Ad-Diyar said the releases would begin not with the freeing of a Westerner held in Lebanon but with Iran freeing British businessman Roger Cooper ``within the next few days to warm up the newly resumed diplomatic ties between Britain and Iran.'' Cooper has been in prison in Tehran since 1985. Iran says he is a spy and was convicted last year, but has never disclosed his sentence. Ad-Diyar said that after Cooper's release, pro-Iranian Shiites in Lebanon would free their British hostages. Shiite political and religious leaders have said privately that two of the missing Britons, World War II flying ace Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett, have never figured in negotiations to free hostages. These talks have involved only Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite and journalist John McCarthy, they said. Ad-Diyar said the third stage of the plan would be the start of serious negotiations for releasing six U.S. hostages simultaneously with the release of frozen Iranian assets held in the United States since 1979. The United States agreed to hand over assets worth at least $200 million last month, and sources close to a U.S.-Iranian tribunal in The Hague have said larger claims are nearing settlement. Among the Americans held in Lebanon is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He is the longest held of the hostages. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Home-Buying Ability Improves in August
DOC.TEXT: Falling prices and mortgage rates combined with rising incomes in August to improve the typical American family's ability to buy a home, a real estate trade group said Monday. But the National Association of Realtors said the improvement was curtailed by the Persian Gulf crisis and weakness in the overall economy. The Realtors said its housing affordability index rose from 102.4 in July to 105.6 in August. That meant a family with a median income of $34,467 had 105.6 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $97,000. The median means half of the families earn more and half earn less, or that half of the houses sell for more and half for less. ``Declining interest rates in early August, which brought borderline buyers into the market, had the biggest positive impact on the index reading last month,'' said Realtors President Norman D. Flynn. ``However, the decline was short-lived due to the Middle East conflict and resulting United States military build-up in the Persian Gulf.'' Flynn said that while the problems with the economy were not rooted in the Persian Gulf crisis, the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has ``greatly increased the chances for a recession.'' ``Due to increasing oil prices, we expect rates to increase during most of the fourth quarter, pushing the housing affordability index down,'' Flynn said. ``However, we don't expect the index to go much below the 100 mark.'' The interest rate used to calculate the index declined from 10.15 percent in July to 9.98 percent in August but has returned to double-digits. The rate is a composite of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages as reported by the Federal Housing Finance Board. The median price for a house fell $1,800 from $98,300 in July, while the median income rose $109 from $34,358 the previous month. The changes resulted in a $19 decrease, to $680, in monthly mortgage payments including principal and interest. The August median income exceeded the $32,633 needed to qualify for a median-priced home. A family earning the median actually would qualify to buy a home priced at $102,400 using conventional financing covering 80 percent of the cost. Under August's affordability conditions, a family earning $20,000 would have sufficient income to qualify for a $59,500 home using a $47,600 loan. A family earning $30,000 would qualify for an $89,300 home with a $71,400 loan. A family earning $40,000 would have sufficient income to qualify for a $119,000 home with a $95,200 loan. And a family with a $50,000 income would qualify for a $149,000 home using a $119,000 loan.

DOC.HEAD: It's Chaos - The Science, Not Confusion - at College
DOC.TEXT: Things may get a bit chaotic with about 4,000 people expected to be on hand, but then the subject that's attracting everyone is chaos. The growing field of mathmatics will be discussed at the the 26th annual Nobel Conference at Gustavus Adolphus College. At its basic, chaos says that very simple mathematical formulas can produce very complex behavior. It also says that some very complex and irregular action has underlying simplicity. Chaos seems to have application in such diverse fields as weather forecasting, psychology and economics. Samuel Patterson, professor of mathematics at Carleton College in Northfield, referred to chaos as the study of turbulence. The two-day conference, which starts Tuesday, has the official endorsement of the Nobel Foundation, which presents the Nobel Prizes. The foundation provides only its name, not funding, said school spokesman Brett Pyrtle. Each year a group at Gustavus Adolphus picks a topic, invites experts to speak and the public to listen. It has been practice to have at least one Nobel Prize winner at the conference. This year it is Ilya Prigogine, who received the prize for chemistry in 1977 and is author of several books on chaos. Among the speakers will be John Polkinghorne, an Anglican priest and president of Queen's College at Cambridge, England, who puts a theological twist on chaos. He says chaos allows for free will and divine influence, concepts at odds with Newtonian mathematics that imply the universe runs like a clock. The final speaker for the conference will be journalist James Gleick, whose 1987 book ``Chaos: Making a new Science,'' won a National Book Award. The book has sold 300,000 copies in paperback. David Reese, associate professor of economics at Gustavus Adolphus, said he has been meeting for about a year with a group of people ranging from psychologists, who think chaos might explain how people think, to biologists, who see chaos patterns in the body's circulatory system. ``Chaos is tantalizing. It can be a new tool to research systems - including economic - that don't repeat themselves, but stay within certain boundaries,'' Reese said. An example of implications of chaos is the ``Butterfly Effect.'' In 1960, meteorologist Edward Lorenz discovered, while testing a computer simulation of weather, that very small differences at the outset resulted in very large differences at the end. That means very long-range weather forecasting is impossible because forecasters could never know enough of the original conditions. The name Butterfly Effect refers to the notion that the motion of a butterfly's wings disturbing the air in Beijing might lead to tornadoes in Kansas.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
VICTIM IMPACT
The court agreed to review its recent decisions barring sentencing juries from considering the character of the defendant's victim or the grief of the victim's family. The court agreed to consider reinstating an Ohio man's death penalty for a love-triangle murder. The Supreme Court in 1987 ruled that ``victim-impat'' evidence should not be considered by sentencing juries. Last year, the justices voted 5-4 that a jury generally may not be told about the victim's character. That ruling was written by Justice William J. Brennan, who has since retired. The four justices who dissented from last year's decision said then they were ready to overturn the 1987 ruling and permit victim-impact testimony in criminal sentencing. The case is Ohio vs. Huertas, 89-1944.
OREGON DEATH ROW
The court let stand rulings Oregon officials say will require new sentencing trials for up to 22 of the state's death row inmates. The justices, without comment, refused to review Oregon Supreme Court rulings that last Jan. 11 overturned the death sentences of three convicted murderers. The case is Oregon vs. Wagner, 89-1867.
JURORS RACE
The court agreed to decide whether lawyers in non-criminal cases may bar potential jurors because of their race. The justices said they will use the case of an injured black construction worker in Louisiana to decide whether such racially motivated exclusions are prohibited in civil as well as criminal trials. The case is Edmonson vs. Leesville Concrete Co., 89-7743.
UNSUCCESSFUL ABORTION
The court rejected an appeal by an Ohio woman who gave birth to a healthy boy after she underwent an unsuccessful abortion. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that barred the woman from suing a doctor and hospital for the costs of rearing her child. The case is Harmath vs. Goler, 89-1824.
RESERVES
The court asked the Bush administration whether employers ever may bar their workers from joining or serving in the military reserves. The court wants to hear Justice Department lawyers' views on a ruling that struck down the Baltimore Police Department's policy of limiting the number of employees allowed to be in active reserve units. The case is Tilghman vs. Kolkhorst, 89-1949.
SEIZURE
The court said it will try to clarify what authority police have to pursue and detain people who run away after seeing police. The justices agreed to consider reinstating the cocaine conviction and 68-month sentence of an Oakland, Calif., youth who a state court said was chased and caught unlawfully by police. The case is California vs. Hodari D., 89-1632.
BIAS ABROAD
The court agreed to decide whether U.S. businesses are lawbreakers if they discriminate against Americans they employ outside the country. The justices, setting the case for an important ruling, said they will decide whether Congress intended a major anti-bias law to reach beyond the nation's borders. The cases are EEOC vs. Arabian American Oil Co., 89-1838, and Boureslana vs. Arabian American Oil Co., 89-1845.
PILOTS
The court agreed to use a dispute over the settlement of a strike by Continental Air Lines pilots to set new guidelines on the duties of unions to represent their members. The court said it will consider killing a lawsuit against the Air Line Pilots Association by striking pilots who said the union denied them fair representation. The case is Air Line Pilots Association vs. O'Neill, 89-1493.
DRUG TESTING
The court permitted the random drug testing of New York City's 10,000 jail guards. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the guards' labor union, which said the tests violate the corrections officers' privacy rights. The case is Seelig vs. Koehler, 90-48.
CHURCH SCHOOLS
The court let stand a ruling that church-run schools must pay employees the federa minimum wage and may not pay women teachers less than men. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by officials of a Baptist church in Virginia who said forcing the church to abide by federal labor law violates its religious freedom and other constitutional rights. The case is Shenandoah Baptist Church vs. Dole, 90-16.
HOWARD BEACH
The court rejected the appeal of three white men from New York City convicted in the ``Howard Beach incident'' of 1986, a racially motivated attack in which a black man died. The justices, without comment, let stand the manslaughter and assault convictions of Jon Lester, Scott Kern and Jason Ladone. Lawyers for the three men had argued they wrongly were limited in excluding blacks as trial jurors. The case is Kern vs. New York, 89-2032.
NUDE DANCING
The court agreed to consider letting states outlaw all barroom-style nude dancing as it voted to hear an effort to reinstate such an Indiana law. The court said it will review a ruling that ``non-obscene nude dancing performed as entertainment is expression and as such is entitled to limited protection under the (Constitution's) First Amendment.'' The case is Barnes vs. Glen Theatre Inc., 90-26.
PRISONS
The court agreed to decide whether unfit living conditions may amount to cruel and unusual punishment when there is no evidence officials acted maliciously. The justices said they will hear an appeal by an Ohio inmate who accused officials of being indifferent to overcrowding, rat-infested kitchens, freezing cold in winter, scalding heat in summer and other miserable conditions. The case is Wilson vs. Seiter, 89-7376.
HONDURAN
The court permitted the prosecution of an alleged drug dealer who said U.S. officials kidnapped and tortured him. The court, over one dissenting vote, rejected arguments that the defendant should be freed because U.S. officials violated international law and the U.S. and Honduran constitutions. The case is Matta-Ballesteros vs. Henman, 89-1797.
HILARY FORETICH
The court refused to block any future broadcast of part of a television documentary about the internationally publicized custody battle over Hilary Foretich. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that it would be unlawful censorship to keep off the air a four-minute portion of the telecast dealing with alleged sex abuse. The case is Foretich vs. Lifetime Cable, 90-35.
LIBEL
The court agreed to consider reinstating a libel lawsuit against Janet Malcolm, a staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, by a psychologist who says she made up quotes attributed to him. The justices said they will review a federal appeals court ruling that last year threw out Jeffrey Masson's suit. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that public figures who sue for libel over allegedly altered quotes must show that the quotes are not even ``rational interpretations'' of what was said. The case is Masson vs. The New Yorker, 89-1799.
ATHEISTS
The court turned down an appeal by a group of atheists challenging an oath for potential trial jurors that includes the phrase ``so help me God.'' The court, without comment, let stand rulings in a Texas case that excluding atheists from jury service for refusing to take such an oath does not violate their rights. The case is Murray vs. Travis County District Court, 89-2018.
ENVIRONMENTAL FINE
The court turned down the appeal of a Pennsylvania man given the longest prison sentence and biggest fine in U.S. history for any person convicted of an environmental crime. The court, without comment, let stand the three-year prison term and $200,000 fine John Pozsgai of Morrisville, Pa., received for violating the Clean Water Act. The case is Pozsgai vs. U.S., 89-1735.
CABLE TV
The court agreed to resolve a dispute from Arkansas over the power of states to tax cable television companies and subscribers. The court said it will review a ruling that Arkansas may tax cable TV as long as it also imposes the levy on similar communication services, such as the unscrambling of satellite signals. The cases are Pledger vs. Medlock, 90-29, and Medlock vs. Pledger, 90-38.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Prize Guessing Game: a Scandinavian Tradition
DOC.TEXT: The Norwegian Nobel Institute and the country's news media are in the throes of a guessing game with traditions as strong as the Peace Prize itself. The ritual is simple: Norway's press tries to guess the name of the annual Nobel laureate. And the institute says nothing, even though the decision was probably made several months ago. ``We never say who the winner is before the official announcement,'' said institute director Geir Lundestad. There are 100 nominations, including 26 organizations, for the 71st Peace Prize, he said. The winner will be announced Oct. 15 in Oslo. The other Nobel prizes will be announced in Stockholm, starting with medicine on Oct. 8. The economics prize, established in 1968 and funded by the Bank of Sweden, will be announced Oct. 16. Physics and chemistry prizes, funded by income from the will of dynamite-inventor Alfred Bernard Nobel, will be announced Oct. 17. The date for the literature prize has not been announced. This year's prizes are worth $695,000. ``There is an opportunity for one more meeting, but most of the pieces have fallen into place,'' Lundestad said when asked if a 1990 Peace Prize winner had been selected. The media has picked four hot names: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, African National Congress Deputy President Nelson Mandela, Chinese pro-democracy student leader Chai Ling and Czechoslovak President Vaclev Havel. Their brash predictions are sometimes off by a continent or two. Late last year, newspapers were betting on Eastern Europe's democratic reform leaders when the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, had probably already been selected. Other recent winners were Lech Walesa, leader of Poland's Solidarity Union, South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Mother Teresa and the United Nations Peace keeping Forces. Lundestad said the great secrecy about the coveted prize, first awarded in 1901, protects some candidates from reprisals or keeps their activities confidential. Names of candidates are never released. No notes leave the room after deliberations by the five-member Nobel Peace Prize Committee, appointed by Norway's parliament for six-year terms. But nominations are often announced by those forwarding a candidate. ``There are thousands of people and organizations with the right to nominate, including former laureates, elected officials, even some university professors and organizations,'' said Lundestad, who is not a voting member of the committee. The picture becomes more clouded by scores of nominations from groups who have no right to make them. Norway's largest labor union, for example, announced its enthusiastic but invalid nomination of Gorbachev. ``In that particular case, the name was also forwarded in several other valid nominations,'' Lundestad said. He confirmed the nomination because several groups have announced it. The five-employee institute sifts through thousands of letters a year, hunting for valid nominations that arrived before the Feb. 1 deadline. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce this year pushed for the award in a secret campaign that appears to have started after a winner had already been selected. ``It doesn't do any good anyway,'' Lundestad said about such campaigns. The fiercely independent committee, aided by institute researchers, searches for a person or group fulfilling criteria set in Nobel's will. There have been 19 years in which no prize was awarded.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Get Unification Gift: Freedom
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The gray doors of a prison swung open Monday and Karsten Petermann strolled into the sunlight, a free man in a free land for the first time in his life. ``It's a new chance,'' Petermann, 21, said as he walked through the massive steel gate of East Berlin's high-security Rummelsburg Prison. Petermann was among the first convicts freed after the East German Parliament, in one of its last official acts before German unity on Wednesday, adopted a broad amnesty plan for people behind bars. The program, meant to make up for the harsh sentences handed down by the former Communist regime, trims prison sentences by a third for all inmates who were not convicted of violent crimes. It was also a bit of a shock for inmates who were released not only into a newly democratic East Germany, but one that is two days from being absorbed by West Germany. Sven Heyse, 20, served 13 months of a 20-month sentence he said was handed down because he stoe 50 East German marks from his sister's boyfriend. That cash was the equivalent of about 20 West German marks ($12) under the former official exchange rate. ``We lived in an oppressive land and we could never have expected this kind of amnesty from the Communists under Honecker and Mielke,'' he said, referring to ousted Communist Party boss Erich Honecker and the chief of his secret police, Erich Mielke. Heyse, from the East German city of Magdeburg, said he plans to live in West Berlin. ``We wanted very much to be out here,'' said Sven Bein, 22, an East Berliner who also was released from Rummelsburg on Monday. Petermann, who said he was convicted of breaking into a house and given a severe sentence because of his political views, said the amnesty is a ``great chance to start over.'' ``I'm for unification,'' said Petermann, who served 20 months of his sentence. ``I never thought it would happen so fast.'' Heyse, Bein and Petermann were among five youthful offenders freed Monday from the 400-inmate prison. Lawmakers feuded bitterly over the amnesty plan before adopting it late Friday, their last act before meeting for a final time Tuesday to officially dissolve East Germany. The amnesty was meant to help people who were given unjustly harsh sentences by the former Communist government, which often used sentences for petty crimes to punish people who resisted the rigidly controlled social system. ``Naturally, all of these people are very pleased,'' said Helmut Raschdorff, an official at Rummelsburg Prison. He said he expects 115 inmates at the prison to fall under the amnesty program and hundreds of others nationwide. Each will be released after serving two-thirds of his sentence. The amnesty is the second since the Communist government was ousted last autumn. Early this year, scores of political prisoners were released. The weeks of debate over the latest amnesty program coincided with uprisings at prisons across East Germany. Inmates occupied prison rooftops and staged hunger strikes to demand amnesty. The government of a united Germany still has to deal with perhaps an even more senstive topic: whether to grant amnesty to the spies and secret police agents from the former Communist government.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Second in Overnight Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes it pays to solve a case. The highly-publicized return of ``Twin Peaks'' Sunday night didn't solve who killed Laura Palmer and was second in preliminary ratings, Nielsen estimates showed Monday. ABC's show lost to NBC's Perry Mason, who solved ``The Case of the Defiant Daughter'' in a two-hour TV movie of the same name. NBC's film averaged a 13.9 ratings in overnight ratings from 22 U.S. cities. ``Twin Peaks,'' the surreal, brooding David Lynch-Mark Frost series about sex, violence and furtive doings in a Pacific Northwest town, averaged a 13.2 rating as it began its second season with a a tangled, two-hour premiere. The series goes into its regular time period Saturday. CBS' ``Face of Fear,'' a two-hour TV movie, was third in the Sunday movie battles, averaging a 12.8 rating. National ratings will be available Tuesday. The 22 cities in Sunday's overnight audience estimates represent 44.3 percent of the nation's 93.1 million homes with television, a Nielsen spokeswoman said. The overnight ratings usually are from 24 cities. But ratings from Portland, Ore., weren't available, ABC said, and ABC's Washington, D.C., affiliate, WJLA-TV, delayed the season premiere of ``Twin Peaks'' until 11:30 p.m. EDT. WJLA instead broadcast the Washington Redskins-Phoenix Cardinals National Football League game, for which it had contracted before ABC announced a premiere date for ``Twin Peaks,'' an ABC spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Crew Getting Used to Saying Goodbye
DOC.TEXT: Three times astronaut Mike Lounge has said goodbye to his wife and three children the day before Columonauts and a satellite that will study the sun's unexplored polar regions. Lounge, who was assigned to that flight before the 1986 Challenger explosion, said he will be relieved to see Discovery go up. It would be NASA's first shuttle flight since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. ``If they don't get off, all this clamor you hear in the press and on the street will be magnified by 10,'' he said. ``We need a win.'' Lounge said much of the criticism heaped on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in recent months is unwarranted. ``The NASA I see day to day is very meticulous and very honest and industrious about getting the job done,'' he said. Nonetheless, Lounge said he is as perplexed as anyone about the hydrogen leaks that have struck Columbia as well as Atlantis. ``I'm really surprised we're having this kind of problem in a mature system, a system that's flown 35 times and for nine years,'' he said. No matter how bad things are, it could be worse, Lounge said. ``We've still got a mission. We're still going to fly it. We're still healthy. We'll get it done, and it will be worth it when we get there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Sir David Lean, the 82-year-old director whose films have won 27 Academy Awards, is planning to marry for the sixth time, his lawyer said Monday. Lean will wed 51-year-old interior designer Sandra Cooke before Christmas, said attorney Michael Gee. The couple met five years ago in the frozen-food department of Harrods department store where Ms. Cooke went up to Lean and asked when his next film was due, said The Daily Mail's columnist Nigel Dempster. Lean and Ms. Cooke were vacationing in France, Gee said. The director's next film project will be an adaptation of Joseph Conrad's novel ``Nostromo.'' Lean is the director of such classics as ``The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' ``Lawrence of Arabia'' and ``Great Expectations.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - NBC newswoman Jane Pauley, who has interviewed hundreds of celebrities, says she's still waiting to land an elusive scoop: her husband, Garry Trudeau. ``I have thought about asking him,'' said Pauley, ``but a) he would never do it, and b) I would not ultimately do it. But I know it's a neat story.'' Trudeau, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist, celebrates Doonesbury's 20th anniversary this month. In an interview in the Oct. 8 issue of People magazine, Pauley said Trudeau believes that ``the more high profile you become, the more you have to maintain it. And you have to adjust your life for updates, just to keep everyone aware, which is time consuming.'' But Pauley said someone should persuade Trudeau to do an interview. ``It's not going to be me, but I'm just going to be really irritated if it turns up on somebody else's network.'' ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Former major leaguer Jim Bouton struck out Monday with his pitch to the Supreme Court to revive a big-stakes contract battle over a baseball bubble gum product. Bouton lost an appeal to revive a $1 million damage award. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the award against a subsidiary of the Wrigley chewing gum company. Bouton, a best-selling author and former pitching star, was with a minor league team in Portland, Ore., in 1977, when he and coach Rob Nelson came up with the idea that led to Big League Chew, shredded bubble gum in a pouch. The idea was to devise a good-tasting substitute for chewing tobacco, a macho symbol for many big leaguers. The novelty was a bonanza that launched Bouton's business career. Sales were $18 million in 1981 after Bouton and Nelson teamed up with Amurol Products Co. of Naperville, Ill., a Wrigley subsidiary, to market the bubble gum. Bouton, who lives in Teaneck, N.J., got into a dispute with Amurol in 1984 over an advertising campaign for the gum. That led to a Mailgram the company sent to Bouton agreeing to new contract terms. A federal judge in New York City ruled that Amurol violated the agreement, and ordered it to pay Bouton and his partner nearly $1 million plus interest. But the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May overturned the award. Bouton retired from baseball in 1970 and wrote ``Ball Four,'' a humorous account of his life in the sport that was on the best-seller list for months. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - A car dealer has offered Mayor Bill Boner $75,000 to resign. But Boner was busy in Hawaii, where he reportedly was marrying an aspiring country singer on Monday. ``It is obvious to all of Nashville that Bill Boner is distracted from his job,'' businessman Lee Beaman said Friday. ``Our city is suffering from the void in leadership. ``In order to make it easier for Mayor Boner to resign, I have offered to pay the $75,000 in salary he would be giving up if he resigns now.'' Boner, 45, turned heads in Nashville when he announced his engagement to Traci Peel, 34, while he was still married to his third wife. Boner's exploits were well chronicled after the Nashville Banner published an interview with Peel in which she said the mayor's passion could last seven hours. Bumper stickers quickly appeared that said: ``Seven hours for Traci, three years for Nashville.'' Boner spokesman Rick Runyeon said he knew nothing of the offer. --- COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) - The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, who spent seven months in prison for his role in the Watergate scandal, is off for a new pastorship in Kentucky. Magruder, 55, has been executive minister at First Community Church in Marble Cliff since 1984. On Nov. 1, he will take over as senior pastor of the 600-member First Presbyterian Church in Lexington, Ky. ``Life began for me again when I came here six years ago,'' Magruder told 1,000 worshipers Sunday. ``You gave me back my identity and you gave me the inspiration to continue in my ministry.'' Magruder pleaded guilty in 1973 to conspiracy and perjury charges stemming from the 1972 break-in at offices of the Democratic Party at the Watergate Hotel in Washington, D.C. He was deputy director of former President Nixon's re-election committee. --- PEORIA, Ill. (AP) - Scott Heimdal, who was held kidnapped earlier this year while working in a South American jungle, has married his Ecuadorian girlfriend and is settling back into a life ``as normal as can be.'' Heimdal, 27, married Sandra Durango on Saturday. Other than the groom forgetting his dress shoes on the way to church, the wedding went off without a hitch. The bride's family traveled to Peoria from their home in Quito, Ecuador. Heimdal was working for a mining company when he was taken captive April 28 in the jungle along the Colombian-Ecuadoran border. He was released two months later after his parents bought his freedom for $60,000, raised in a frantic four-day fund drive. ``Life is as normal as it can be, getting married and all,'' he said. But he was having trouble finding a job. ``I'll stay in Peoria if I can,'' said Heimdal, who specializes in computers. ``With getting married, it's very frustrating not being able to find work in Peoria.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. General Furls Flag of West Berlin Command
With AM-Germany, Bjt
LaserPhotos BER1, LaserColor BER101
DOC.TEXT: A high-profile American general furled the flag of his command Monday and said there was ``close cooperation'' with Soviet commanders who are also dropping some functions before reunification. For the first time in 45 years, Germany will be a sovereign nation at midnight Tuesday, and there will be no room for Soviet border checks within the former East Germany, or Western Allied military commandants with unusual law-making powers for West Berlin. The U.S. commandant, Maj. Gen. Raymond E. Haddock, formally deactivated his command at a ceremony attended by top-ranking diplomats and his two Allied counterparts, British Maj. Gen. Robert J.S. Corbett and French Maj. Gen. Francois Cann. The black-red-and-gold West German flag was flying for the first time beside the U.S. flag over the cobblestone parade ground in front of the old Nazi air force building that is the U.S. command headquarters in West Berlin. Honor platoons from the U.S. Army and Air Force stood at attention as Haddock furled his command flag, a red-and-white banner with the black Berlin bear emblem, and put it in an olive-drab cloth casing. The two-star general, who commanded the deployment of nuclear-tipped Pershing II missiles in West Germany before he took the top U.S. soldier-diplomat post in West Berlin, said Allied determination to keep West Berlin part of the democratic world had been tested repeatedly. ``We, in full cooperation with our French and British allies and our German partners, have passed the test,'' he said. ``Berlin and Germany are being united in peace, in freedom, and upon a firm foundation of democratic values and the rule of law. As a result, the U.S. Command Berlin is being inactivated.'' He told a later news conference that Soviet troops in East Germany were ceasing to operate some border checkpoints. The Soviets had even invited Western Allied officers to join closing-down celebrations, such as at the Glienecke Bridge, the famed spy-exchange crossing point between West Berlin and Potsdam in East Germany, he said. ``They are joining with us to return normality to what will be a sovereign nation in a few hours,'' Haddock said. ``It's a matter of close cooperation and working together.'' But no Soviets attended Haddock's deactivation ceremony, nor did military representatives from West Germany. Haddock said West German military officials had been invited to attend but declined because the present status of West Berlin forbids a German military presence in the city. ``I respect that decision but I want it made absolutely clear that an invitation was extended,'' he said, noting that a retired top West German general attended the ceremony. Forbidding a German military role in Berlin was a key element of the post-war Allied policy of demilitarizing Germany. The deactivation of the American, British and French commandant functions in West Berlin will be marked at a ceremony Tuesday in which generals of the three countries hand their powers over to German officials, opening the way for a German military presence in the city. The Soviets and the three Western allies will continue to base troops in Germany after the two Germanys unify. The Soviets have agreed to withdraw their troops by the end of 1994. The Western allies are talking about troop reductions in what is now West Germany, and are expected to pull their forces out of West Berlin as the Soviets leave East Germany. Haddock said the present U.S. strength of about 6,000 troops in West Berlin will be cut in the coming year by about 700 ``as a sign that we are ready to reduce our force in Berlin.'' And, as the Soviets are ending border checkpoints, so are the Allies, he said. But he refused to liken the Western presence in Germany to that of the Soviets. ``We have been asked to stay here, they have been asked to leave,'' he said. Haddock's post as commandant held an unusual combination of military and diplomatic duties, reflecting the fact that Berlin has been, in legal terms, an occupied city since 1945. Laws passed by the West German parliament have to be signed by the three Allied commandants before taking effect in West Berlin. That power fades into history at midnight Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Denouncing Saddam, Offers Hope of Negotiations for Israeli Withdrawal
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 21-22, bgng, On the ... to UPDATE with later Bush comment on Saddam, use of force
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today denounced Iraqi President Saddam Hussein as an international outcast who plundered Kuwait. But Bush also offered Baghdad hope that relinquishing its grip on its Persian Gulf neighbor could spur negotiations on the Arab-Israeli conflict. The president's speech to the U.N. General Assembly blended condemnation of Saddam with an overture for a resolution of the two-month crisis. ``We seek a peaceful outcome, a diplomatic outcome,'' Bush said. Significantly, he offered the Iraqi leader the prospect of ``new arrangements'' among the states in the gulf region as well as a chance for a settlement between the Arabs and Israel - provided Iraq leaves Kuwait unconditionally. ``Iraq's unprovoked aggression is a throwback to another era, a dark relic from a dark time,'' Bush said. ``It has plundered Kuwait, terrorized innocent civilians and held even diplomats hostage.'' The president, lining up with a proposal first advanced last week by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said Iraq and its leadership must be held liable ``for these crimes of abuse and destruction.'' But, at the same time, Bush edged perceptibly closer to Saddam's demand that his territorial dispute with Kuwait be linked to the Arabs' grievance with Israel for holding on to territory Syria and Jordan lost in the 1967 Mideast war. Shevardnadze said afterward that Bush had delivered ``a brilliant speech.'' A similar gesture last week by President Francois Mitterrand of France drew a mixed response Sunday from Saddam, who suggested that Iraq would fight to defend its seizure of Kuwait but also offered to open a `debate'' with France on the region's future. ``We intend to make contacts with the French government to explain after inquiry, questioning and dialogue our views accurately so that everything is based on clear ideas and actions,'' the Iraqi leader said in a broadcast message on the birthday of the Muslim prophet Mohammed. Mitterrand, in a four-step proposal, called first for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, which it invaded on Aug. 2. The pullout would be supervised by international observers as the emirate's sovereignty was restored. Then, negotiators would deal with the division of Lebanon and the Arab-Israel conflict. In the fourth stage, armaments in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf would be scaled down. Bush reiterated that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait will not be permitted to stand, and that Saddam has placed his country against the world. However, the president said, ``In the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe that there may be opportunities: ``For Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel. ``And yet,'' Bush said, ``the world's key task - now, first and always - must be to demonstrate that aggression will not be tolerated or rewarded.'' The speech seemed to reflect a U.S. policy shift. Throughout the gulf crisis, U.S. officials insisted that Iraq's seizure of Kuwait could not be linked in any way to the Arab-Israeli dispute or other regional problems. The United States has long been committed to a Mideast settlement in which Israel would exchange territory for Arab recognition of its right to exist. Bush made no reference on how the talks would be held; the Soviets and the Arabs demand a Mideast peace conference, but the Israeli government objects. In an exchange with reporters later, Bush said his position had not changed. ``There is no flexibility here,'' he said. Asked, then, if his speech reflected a shift in emphasis, Bush replied, ``You are reading too much into this. There is no nuance. ...'' to be read into the remarks. On the question of whether the U.N. should vote to authorize the use of force against Iraq, Bush said, ``We have not been pressing for that at this point.'' Bush said that some experts now believe that, ``this man (Hussein) if you look at his record, will do a `180.' You look at his history with Iran and he's done a 180-degree turn and done exactly what he said he wouldn't do.'' Bush assured Saddam that ``we seek no advantages for ourselves'' in the gulf. Nor, he said, ``do we seek to maintain our military forces in Saudi Arabia for one day longer than is necessary.'' Bush said the 165,000 U.S. troops defending the oilfields of Saudi Arabia were sent there at the request of the Saudi government following Iraq's Aug. 2 invastion of Kuwait. ``The American people - and this president - want every single American soldier brought home as soon as the mission is accomplished,'' he said. Bush praised the Soviet Union for collaborating with the United States in a worldwide cutoff of trade with Iraq. The superpowers ``had indeed put four decades of history behind us,'' he said. More than ever before, Bush said, the United Nations is now ``a center for international collective security.'' The passage hinted that the United States and Soviet Union would seek Security Council approval for military action against Iraq if Saddam does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait. U.S. officials said Sunday the two superpowers, as well as a number of other countries, had begun preliminary drafting of resolutions to authorize the use of force. Praising the U.N.'s resolve, Bush said, ``this challenge is a test we cannot afford to fail. I am confident we will prevail.'' The gulf crisis and the proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, along with the ballistic missiles ``that can rain destruction upon distant peoples,'' contrasted with the rosy picture of a world emerging from Cold War tensions. ``We've seen a century sundered by barbed threats and barbed wire give way to a new era of peace, cooperation and freedom,'' the president said. Behind the scenes, meanwhile, the United States, the Soviet Union and a number of other nations have begun drafting resolutions to take action against Iraq if the squeeze does not force Iraq to release its hold on Kuwait, U.S. officials said Sunday. ``Everybody is looking at options, thinking what can we do next,'' said a U.S. official who described the Soviet Union's approach to Saddam as potentially tougher than the stance taken by the Bush administration. The drafting has not reached the point where Bush is ready to make an announcement. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, described it as ``back of the envelope'' work at this point.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Reject 3 Appeals in Howard Beach Case
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court's rejection Monday of an appeal by three white defendants in the Howard Beach racial death case closes off only one avenue of appeal, a defense attorney says. ``There are some new trial issues which we will be exploring,'' said lawyer Charles Weintraub. The court made no comment when it let stand the manslaughter and assault convictions of Jon Lester, Scott Kern and Jason Ladone. Weintraub had argued they were wrongly limited in excluding blacks as trial jurors. New York's highest court rejected the argument last March. ``The issues were significant, but obviously the court is not prepared to address those issues at this time,'' Weintraub said. ``There are some other issues that will be addressed in new trial motions.'' He refused to discuss what the new issues would be. On Dec. 19, 1986, a car carrying four black men broke down in the predominantly white Howard Beach section of the borough of Queens. Three of the men - Michael Griffith, Cedric Sandiford and Timothy Grimes - left the car to seek assistance. The three were attacked by a gang of white teen-agers, including Lester, Kern and Ladone, according to trial testimony. The youths chased Griffith onto a highway, where he was struck and killed by a car. Sandiford was beaten with a baseball bat and tree limbs. The case galvanized black activists in New York. In the weeks that followed, police reported a sharp increase in racial violence in the city. Several fights between blacks and whites were punctuated by cries of ``Howard Beach, Howard Beach.'' During the 1987 trial of Lester, Kern and Ladone, prosecutors complained that the defense lawyers were using their peremptory, or automatic, challenges of potential jurors to exclude all blacks. In response to the prosecutors' complaints, the trial judge, Justice Thomas Demakos, barred the defendants' lawyers from using their automatic challenges to exclude potential jurors because of their race. Defense lawyers argued unsuccessfully that prosecutors were using their automatic challenges to keep whites off the jury. The state's highest court upheld the three men's convictions after ruling that defendants' lawyers in all criminal cases may be barred from excluding potential jurors because of their race. The U.S. Supreme Court in 1986 barred prosecutors from doing that, ruling that such exclusions are unconstitutional.
