But the justices never have said the U.S. Constitution imposes such a prohibition on defense lawyers. The state court's ruling appeared to rely solely on the New York Constitution. Lawyers for Lester, Kern and Ladone said the state court ruling was an unwarranted expansion of the Supreme Court's 1986 decision. The appeal said the New York Constitution, as interpreted by the state court, should be declared a violation of the U.S. Constitution's protections for criminal defendants' fair-trial rights. Lester was sentenced to up to 30 years in prison, Kern to up to 18 years, and Ladone to up to 15 years. Weintraub said all have begun serving time.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Town One of Eight Additions to 1990 Rand McNally Atlas
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old Indiana boy who was planning a trip to his grandparents' home but couldn't find their town on a map helped make Parrott one of eight towns added to Rand McNally's newest atlas. The western Virginia town of 800 people thanked Chris Muncy for its newfound recognition by designating Sunday as Chris Muncy Day. The 1991 atlas appeared nationwide Monday. ``I was helping my mom and dad plan our trip to my grandparents', but Parrott wasn't on the map,'' said Chris, of Mishawaka, Ind. Chris's maternal grandparents and great-grandmother live in Parrott. Chris wrote last year to Rand McNally asking that it include the town, which is about 35 miles west of Roanoke. Parrott was the only locality added this year as the result of a private request, Rand McNally spokesman Mike Braden said. There are no set rules for inclusion in the atlas, said Braden, noting that cartographers are always on the lookout for communities they may have missed. Most atlas revisions result from updates to federal, state or local government records, said Michael Dobson, Rand McNally vice president of Cartographic Services. The 1991 edition is the Skokie, Ill., map maker's 67th annual revision. The last addition in Virginia was Love, in the 1990 atlas. The other 1991 additions are: Stoneridge, Mo., Bell Terre, N.Y., Huntington Bay, N.Y., Old Field, N.Y., Poquott, N.Y., Saltaire, N.Y., and Sea-Tac, Wash.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Air Force Gen. Curtis Lemay Dies at 83
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Gen. Curtis Emerson Lemay, who directed the air assault over Japan in the waning years of World War II, died of a heart attack Monday at a base hospital. He was 83. The four-star general, who would have been 84 on Nov. 15, died at 8:08 a.m. at the 22nd Strategic Hospital at March AFB, said Sgt. Steve Mahnke.

DOC.HEAD: One Justice Shy, Court Takes on a Deep, Varied Load
DOC.TEXT: The Suprem Court, opening its 1990-91 term one justice short, agreed Monday to decide whether juries may impose stiffer sentences because of a crime's impact on the victims or their families. The court said it will use a case from Ohio to consider reversing recent rulings banning such victim-impact evidence. The case was among some 1,000 acted upon by the eight justices as they returned from a three-month summer recess. They rejected appeals in the vast majority, agreeing to hear and decide just 25. David H. Souter, President Bush's first nominee to the high court, is expected to fill the vacancy created by the July retirement of Justice William J. Brennan. The Senate is expected to confirm Souter on Tuesday, making him the 105th justice in the court's history. The court in this term plans to hear arguments in key cases involving abortion counseling, fetal protection, school desegregation and the war on drug. The justices previously granted review of appeals in those cases. For the first time in 34 years, Brennan was not on the bench as the court convened for a new term. He walked into the courtroom using a cane and sat in a section reserved for special guests as his former colleagues paid tribute to him. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist praised Brennan for his personal warmth and wise counsel as he read an exchange of letters between Brennan and the other justices. Brennan, 84, the court's leading liberal voice, retired because of failing health. In other matters, the court: -Agreed to consider letting states outlaw all barroom-style nude dancing. The court will consider reinstating such an Indiana ban. -Refused to free a Southern Baptist seminary in New Orleans from having to grant a divinity degree to a man the seminary says is unfit for Christian ministry. -Refused to block the possible rebroadcast of part of a television documentary about the internationally publicized child custody battle over Hilary Foretich. A lower court said it is unlawful censorship to keep off the air a four-minute portion of the telecast dealing with alleged sex abuse. -Agreed to use a dispute over the settlement of a Continental Air Lines pilots strike to set new guidelines on the duties of unions in representing their members. -Agreed to consider reinstating a libel lawsuit against Janet Malcolm, a writer for The New Yorker magazine. A lower court threw out a suit against her by a psychologist who said she made up quotes attributed to him. -Rejected an appeal by an Ohio woman who gave birth to a healthy boy after she underwent an unsuccessful abortion. The woman was barred from suing a doctor and hospital for the costs of rearing the child. -Asked the Bush administration for its views on the power of employers to bar workers from joining or serving in the military reserves. The court is being asked to revive the Baltimore Police Department's policy of limiting the number of employees allowed to be in active reserve units. In the victim-impact case, the court said it will consider reinstating the death penalty for Ediberto Huertas in a love-triangle murder. Huertas fatally stabbed Ralph Harris Jr. in Lorain, Ohio, on June 7, 1986. He now is serving a life sentence for the crime. On leave from the Air Force, Harris was spending the night with Elba Ortiz. Huertas, who had fathered two children with Ms. Ortiz, allegedly warned Harris he would ``waste him'' if he continued to see the woman. A state jury imposed the death sentence after hearing evidence that Harris' parents wanted Huertas to die for his crime. Elizabeth Harris, the victim's mother, also testified emotionally that she was proud of her churchgoing son and that his death had devastated the victim's young son. The Supreme Court in 1987 ruled that such victim-impact evidence should not be considered by sentencing juries. And last year, the justices voted 5-4 - with Brennan writing for the court - that a jury generally may not be told about the victim's character. The court said a South Carolina murderer unfairly was sentenced to die because the jury heard such testimony. The four justices who dissented from last year's decision said then they were ready to overturn the 1987 ruling and permit victim-impact testimony in criminal sentencing. The Ohio Supreme Court relied on both U.S. Supreme Court rulings when it reduced Huertas' death sentence to life in prison last May. Prosecutors argued that the jury should have been allowed to consider the impact of Harris' murder on his family because Huertas and Harris had been high school friends and Huertas knew the family. The killer was aware of the impact his crime would have on the family, they said. But the Ohio Supreme Court said such evidence is relevant to the sentence only when the evidence has ``a connection to the defendant's personal responsibility and moral guilt.'' Otherwise, the state court said, such testimony undermines the defendant's right to be sentenced by an impartial jury.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives Watch Last Radar Blips of Flight That Killed Loved Ones
DOC.TEXT: American and British relatives watched a video recording Monday of the last radar blips of Pan Am Flight 103, in which their loved ones were killed by a terrorist bomb. ``It was like watching them being killed,'' one said. The start of the first public inquiry concentrated on events of Dec. 21, 1988, when the Boeing 747 exploded over the nearby town of Lockerbie, claiming 270 lives. As family members watched video screens in the courtroom, air traffic controller Alan Topp traced the final moments of the square blips on a green radar screen that indicated Flight 103 until the moment the plane exploded. A square blip with a cross, from radar on the plane's flight deck, vanished immediately, leaving an empty square, designating ground radar readings. This single square gradually multiplied as the radar picked up separate pieces of the disintegrating aircraft falling to earth 31,000 feet below. Topp, 54, who was at the Prestwick, Scotland, air traffic control center, described frantic efforts to contact the plane. ``I came to the conclusion the clipper was lost when I didn't get through and saw this mess'' on the screen, he said. Light debris from the aircraft showed as blips on the radar screen drifting across the north of England and southern Scotland for the next 20 to 30 minutes, Topp said. The fuel-laden wing section and part of the fuselage crashed in Lockerbie less than a minute after the explosion, with a force equivalent to an earthquake of 1.3 on the Richter scale, said Terence Turbitt, a geophysicist with the British Geological Survey. ``The replay was horrible,'' said Dr. Jim Swire, who heads the group of British relatives. ``Before it exploded, I could see in my mind the inside of the cabin and its bright lights, warmth and companionship.'' ``From the moment the bomb went off, all hell must have broken loose. We know the plane turned on its left side and went into a vertical dive. What we don't know is how long they survived. That's what's worrying us,'' he said. ``Can you imagine going from warmth and bright lights to a gale with 400-knot winds which would blow your clothes off? ... That's why most of the bodies had no clothes,'' said Swire, whose 24-year-old daughter Flora was on the plane. George Williams of Joppatowne, Md., whose only son, Geordie, a 24-year-old Army lieutenant, died in the crash, said a lump came to his throat. ``To see the actual moment when my son lost his life was tough,'' he said. For Pamela Dix of Dublin, whose brother Peter, 35, died, ``It was like watching them being killed.'' ``This is just the start. There's worse to come,'' said Jean Flick of Coventry, whose son Clayton and his fiance were on the plane. Like all the relatives, Mrs. Flick said, she wants the fatal accident inquiry to reveal ``the truth'' about the crash. ``And those that haven't done their jobs right must be made accountable,'' she said. Williams was tougher. ``I want people from Pan Am jailed, people from the government censured and fired that were involved in the cover-up, and I want the criminals executed,'' he said. The inquiry will examine airport security but will not take evidence on the question of criminal responsibility for the bombing. Capt. Robert L. Gould, Pan American World Airways' senior vice president for operations who attended the opening, issued a statement saying the airline also wants the truth. He said Pan Am wants airlines protected from terrorist attacks but ``airports have not been built to meet today's sophisticated terrorist threats and risks.''

DOC.HEAD: Rates Fall on Bills
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.18 percent, down from 7.32 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.21 percent, down from 7.33 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.17 percent on Sept. 19, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 7.19 percent on Aug. 6, 1990. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.41 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,818.50 and 7.59 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,635.50 In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.79 percent last week, up from 7.77 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Court Halts Controversial Affirmative Action Program in India
DOC.TEXT: India's Supreme Court ordered the government on Monday to halt its controversial job quota program, and appealed for an end to protests against the policy that have killed dozens of people. ``We hope that the law and order situation will immediately improve,'' Chief Justice Ranganath Mishra said after issuing the ruling. The court's temporary injunction remains in effect until the panel rules on the legality of the quotas. Press Trust of India said the court could begin to hear arguments on the affirmative action program as early as Oct. 25. At least 70 people have died in a rash of riots and student suicides since Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced Aug. 7 that almost half of all government jobs would be reserved for lower-caste Hindus. Public opposition to the governmen has been widespread in the politically influential cities of northern India. The army has been called out and curfews clamped on several towns to control rioting students, joined sometimes by middle-aged housewives and government employees. Two members of Singh's governing party have resigned from Parliament and some colleagues demanded his ouster because of the quotas. Singh has refused to abandon the policy, saying it is an affirmative action program that would give social justice to the lower castes. Critics say he fears alienating the lower castes, which form a majority of the eligible votes among India's 880 million people. Upper-caste students say reverse discrimination will deprive them of government jobs for which they are better qualified. On Monday, the decision was taken out of Singh's hands. The Supreme Court said the government should take no action on the policy's implementation until its legality is determined. ``Until the matter is heard - and we expect it to be finished before the end of the year - no further steps should be taken,'' Mishra said. The court, however, allowed the government to continue assembling a list of the thousands of castes that will qualify for the job quotas. The plan reserves 27 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. An additional 22 percent already are set aside for the lowest strata in the rigid hierarchy of Indian society, tribespeople and the so-called untouchables. In Parliament, the government faced a separate problem Monday when it failed to pass a constitutional amendment extending federal rule in the northern state of Punjab, where Sikh militants are fighting for independence. The state govenment in Punjab was dismissed in 1987 and replaced by federal rule, which the Constitution limits to three years. Amending the document requires a two-thirds majority. In a surprise move aimed at embarassing the government, the opposition Congress Party refused to support the bill. Leaders of all the parties were summoned to the speaker's chambers to find a way out of the impasse. Singh' 10-month-old government suffered another setback when the speaker of the legislature agreed to hold a debate on a motion seeking to censure the government for mishandling the student protest. The motion, if passed, would put pressure on the government to quit, said Kewal Verma, a parliamentary analyst. ``There is no legal obligation on the part of the government to resign, but it would amount to its defeat in moral terms,'' Verma said. In the parliament, Congress Party members accused Singh of being ``obstinate'' for refusing to suspend or reconsider the affirmative action plan. ``Down, down, resign, resign!'' they shouted as Singh stood up to speak. He was prevented from addressing the house. ``Can't you see there is blood in your hands,'' said Congress lawmaker Ajit Panja. Some members advanced menacingly at Singh but were stopped by colleagues. ``You are a bloodstained politician,'' Panja said. Former Congress minister Vasant Sathe said he was beginning a ``fast unto death'' until Singh stops ``police terror'' on the students. In the northern town of Jammu, 17-year-old student Sandeep Sharma set himself on fire Monday in the latest suicide bid to protest the job quotas. He suffered third-degree burns over most of his body. At least 20 students have died in the past 12 days from self-inflicted injuries. Most left notes blaming Singh's job policy. In addition, 50 people have died by police gunfire in street battles.

DOC.HEAD: Seminary Loses Appeal in Forced-Degree Case
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Southern Baptist seminary in New Orleans being forced to grant a divinity degree to a man it says is unfit for Christian ministry lost a Supreme Court appeal Monday. The court left standing Louisiana rulings that force the seminary to grant the degree as it rejected arguments that the New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary's religious freedom is being trampled. The dispute centered on Rudolph Babcock's attempt to receive a master of divinity degree in marriage and family counseling. Seminary officials said Babcock was unfit because of ``continued physical and verbal abuse of his wife.'' A state appeals court ruled that it was not bound by numerous past decisions keeping courts out of ecclesiastical, or church-governing, disputes. ``This is not an ecclesiastical matter,'' the state court. ``This case involves an institution which, although perhaps having characteristics of a church, necessarily functions as a school.'' Lawyers for the seminary, after being denied help by the Louisiana Supreme Court, sought help from the nation's highest court. ``To permit such an action to stand would inextricably entangle the government in the affairs of the church and have dire consequences for every religious body in America,'' the seminary's appeal said. In a supporting brief, the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, the Christian Legal Society and the National Council of Churches called the Louisiana appeals court ruling ``as astonishing as it is unprecedented.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: recasts, CORRECTS to LeMay, sted Lemay, adds background.
DOC.HEAD: Retired Air Force Gen. Curtis LeMay Dies at 83
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Gen. Curtis LeMay, who relayed the orders to drop nuclear bombs Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died Monday. He was 83. The retired four-star general, who would have been 84 on Nov. 15, died of a hert attack at the 22nd Strategic Hospital at March Air Force Base, said Sgt. Steve Mahnke. LeMay directed the air attack on Japan at the end of World War II. Years later, he said the nuclear bombings were unnecessary to force Japan's surrender. ``We felt that our incendiary bombings had been so successful that Japan would collapse before we invaded,'' LeMay said in a 1985 interview. ``We went ahead and droppped the bombs beccause President (Harry) Truman told me to do it. He told me in a personal letter.'' But LeMay said he felt the United States could have defeated Japan in ``a few more days'' if it had continued the firebombing of Japanese cities. LeMay, who lived in Newport Beach, also ran for vice president with third-party candidate Geroge Wallace during the 1968 presidential campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Consider Letting States Bar Nude Dancing in Bars
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will consider letting states outlaw all barroom-style nude dancing. The justices voted to hear an effort to reinstate such a law from Indiana. The court will review a ruling that ``non-obscene nude dancing performed as entertainment is expression and as such is entitled to limited protection under the (Constitution's) First Amendment.'' In striking down the use of Indiana's public indecency law to prosecute nude dancing, the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May relied heavily on a 1981 Supreme Court ruling. In it, the justices said, ``Nude dancing is not without its First Amendment protections from official regulations.'' The 1981 decision did not specify the precise scope of those protections. The appeals court's ruling in May, reached by a 7-4 vote, said, ``While clearly not all conduct is expression, dance as entertainment is a form of conduct that is inherently expressive.'' The Indiana law was challenged by two South Bend businesses - a bar and an adult bookstore that features live dancers - and three women who say they want to dance without having to wear pasties and G-strings. Indiana's appeal was supported in ``friend-of-the-court'' briefs submitted by Arizona, Connecticut, Missouri, North Carolina and Pennsylvania and by the American Family Association, previously known as the National Federation for Decency.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Anti-Communist, Pro-Independence Rally in Ukraine
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Ukrainian nationalists marched to parliament in the capital of Kiev on Monday and chanted slogans against the Communist Party and the republic's leaders, witnesses and news reports said. One-day warning strikes idled factories in the more radical western Ukraine, but many enterprises in Kiev continued working, according to official Soviet media. Opposition members of the republic's Supreme Soviet, or parliament, walked out of the session, which opened Monday, after its Communist majority upheld a decree banning rallies in front of the parliament building, Soviet TV reported. The national evening TV news program ``Vremya'' showed scenes of pushing and shoving on the floor of parliament as some of the opposition deputies brought in the nationalist blue and gold flag of the Ukraine, and some briefly tried to block access to the podium. Leonid Dnitrenko, a spokesman for the pro-democracy Rukh movement, said workers at the Arsenal machine-building plant, a motorcycle plant and a shoe factory carried out a one-day warning strike in support of the demonstrators. Some taxi drivers and trolley bus drivers also went on strike, according to the independent Interfax news service. Tass said most of the strikes occurred in the western Ukraine's regions of Lvov, Ternopol and Ivano-Frankovsk. The rally began at October Square in the center of Kiev, after 20 minutes of speeches, demonstrators marched to parliament, where they presented a list of their demands to legislators, Dnitrenko said. Protesters carrying the traditional flags chanted slogans for independence and against the party, the Soviet government and the republic's leadership, according to ``Vremya'' and the official Tass news agency. Tass estimated the crowd at 20,000 people, although activists said there were more than 50,000. The rally paralyzed central Kiev for more than two hours. According to Petro Borsuk, a secretary of the Ukrainian Democratic Party, the demonstrators carried banners saying: ``The New Union Treaty is New Slavery'' and ``No to the Union Treaty.'' The treaty, which is still being negotiated, defines the relationship between the Kremlin and the republics. Although it would give the 15 Soviet republics more autonomy, nationalist groups believe it does not go far enough and want it scrapped. Other placards branded the Communist Party as a criminal organization that must go on trial and said the KGB was an enemy of the people, Borsuk said. Dnitrenko and Borsuk said police observed the demonstration, but did not try to interfere. They allowed a delegation to enter the Supreme Soviet to present their list of demands. ``The militia were very friendly,'' Borsuk said. Police were reinforced by Interior Ministry troops in armored personnel carriers, and members of special riot units were stationed on sidestreets. A large rally also occurred in Donetsk, with miners and factory workers demanding that the Chernobyl nuclear power plant be closed, that Communist Party property be nationalized and that economic reforms be speeded up, according to Interfax. Monday's demonstrations, as well as a protest rally Sunday in the capital, were organized by DemBlock, a coalition of the Rukh movement and other Ukrainian pro-democracy groups demanding greater autonomy from the Kremlin. Among the demands by the nationalists are that Ukrainian men drafted by the Soviet army serve only in the Ukraine; that the Ukraine refuse to sign the union treaty; and that the Communist Party be declared a ``criminal organization'' and stripped of influence in all Ukrainian government organizations. The Ukraine is the second most populous of the Soviet republics, after Russia, and is a key grain-growing area. Its parliament has declared sovereignty from Moscow and claims the right to overrule national law. Rukh and other nationalist groups want it to go further and take rapid moves toward secession.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell: No Intention of Apologizing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note content of 6th graf, first brief.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Theo Mitchell refused Monday to apologize for derogatory comments about blacks who support GOP Gov. Carroll Campbell. Mitchell, a state senator seeking to become South Carolina's first black governor, said he has no plans to retract his comments even though it may cost him the opportunity to debate Campbell before the general election. ``At this point in time, I see nothing to apologize for unless it can be shown there's a reason,'' Mitchell said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. He said he would elaborate on the controversy at a news conference Tuesday. Within the past two weeks, Campbell has won the endorsement of the predominantly black African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church and the South Carolina Conference of Black Mayors. Last week, Mitchell lashed out at the Rev. Richard Fisher, bishop of the AME Zion Church, and five black mayors who announced their support of Campbell. ``These are house niggers. ... These are Uncle Toms. These are black prostitutes who are still being bought by white politicians, selling out their people,'' Mitchell said during a radio program. Campbell and Mitchell were scheduled for a one-hour debate Oct. 22. But one day after Mitchell's comments, Campbell pulled out of the debate. ``I'm not about to give him a forum for his vitriolic diatribe that has come forth,'' Campbell said. The governor said he would reconsider the debate if Mitchell retracted the statements and apologized.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Voinovich Leading By 11 Points in Ohio Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: A statewide poll released Monday showed Republican George Voinovich leading Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. by 11 percentage points in the Ohio governor's race. The Ohio Poll found that Voinovich was favored by 50 percent of those surveyed, while his Democratic opponent was preferred by 39 percent. Eleven percent said they would vote for neither candidate or hadn't made a decision. The poll was conducted by the University of Cincinnati's Institute for Policy Research and was sponsored by the university, the Dayton Daily News and The Cincinnati Post. The institute said the telephone poll was conducted Sept. 17-25 in a random sample of 548 people who indicated they were likely to vote in the Nov. 6 election. Pollsters said the survey had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. An earlier Ohio Poll, published in May, showed Voinovich leading by 9 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Attorneys General Complain to Bush About GOP Fund-Raising
DOC.TEXT: Eight state attorneys general on Monday complained to President Bush about a Republican fund-raising scheme they compared to ``mail-order frauds and telemarketing scams.'' In a letter to Bush, the attorneys general objected to a program under which the Republican Presidential Task Force mailed $25 checks to more than a million potential campaign contributors. The task force asks recipients to deposit the checks in their checking accounts to test a new Republican fund-raising procedure. Cashing the checks authorizes the GOP to deduct $12.50 a month from the recipients' checking accounts indefinitely unless consumers take steps to halt the payments. ``This solicitation marks a shameful low in the history of American campaigning,'' the attorneys general wrote to Bush. ``It reduces the political process to the level of integrity normally associated with fly-by-night con artists, mail frauds and telemarketing scams.'' Besides Abrams, the attorneys general of Minnesota, Oregon, Alabama, North Dakota, Connecticut, Michigan and Illinois signed the letter. Attorneys General Don Siegelman of Alabama and Neil Hartigan of Illinois have filed lawsuits against the task force. The task force is an arm of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
DOC.HEAD: Oregon Supreme Court Restores Five Initiatives to Ballot
DOC.TEXT: The Oregon Supreme Court has restored five initiative measures to the Nov. 6 ballot, reversing a lower court ruling that had disqualified them on a technicality. In a secondary ruling, the Supreme Court upheld lower court decisions that had struck financial impact statements from three measures on grounds officials missed a deadline for approving them. State law requires that financial estimates be printed on ballots and in the state Voter's Pamphlet for measures having a substantial impact on the state treasury. Two Marion County judges ruled that fiscal statements for three measures were invalid because state officials approved them after a legal deadline. Election officials had removed fiscal statements from five other measures because they were handled under the same procedures. The result was that as many as eight of the 11 statewide measures on the general election ballot were in jeopardy because of the legal tangle. Elections officials have said the financial effects statements might be posted in voting booths as a substitute for having them on the ballot or in the Voters' Pamphlet. The Supreme Court announced its unanimous decision Friday after hearing oral arguments and had no further comment, saying written opinions would be issued later.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Gave Birth After Unsuccessful Abortion Loses Appeal
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio woman who sued a doctor and a hospital because she gave birth to a healthy boy after undergoing an unsuccessful abortion lost a Supreme Court appeal Monday. The justices left intact a ruling that barred Laura Harmath from suing for the costs of rearing her child. She sued Dr. George Goler, who performed the abortion, and Mt. Sinai Medical Center in Cleveland, where she had the operation in September 1985. Ms. Harmath gave birth to her son, Jayson, the following March. She said Goler and the hospital were negligent and sought $103,000 to pay for Jayson's upbringing until age 18. Ms. Harmath, 20 and single when she became pregnant, said having the child created a heavy financial burden. An Ohio appeals court threw out the suit in 1988. The state court said awarding damages in such cases would give parents ``a windfall'' and could cause psychological harm to a child who later discovers he or she was unwanted.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asked for Opinion on Reserves Limitations
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday asked the Bush administration whether employers should be able to limit the number of workers who join or serve in te military reserves. The court said it wants to hear what Justice Department lawyers think about a ruling that struck down the Baltimore Police Department's policy of limiting the number of employees allowed to be in active reserve units. After hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months, the court will decide whether to review the Baltimore dispute. Although the court's action comes at a time when President Bush has ordered tens of thousands of reservists to active duty in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, the Baltimore dispute dates back to 1986. At issue is whether a federal law, the Veterans' Re-employment Rights Act, gives employees an absolute right to join the reserves and an absolute entitlement to a leave of absence to fulfill reserve training obligations. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last March ruled in the Baltimore case that employers never may interfere with a worker's joining, or serving in, the reserves. Other federal courts, however, have said employers need not honor an employee's request for a leave to serve in the reserves if the request is not reasonable. Lawyers for the Baltimore Police Department urged the justices to resolve the conflicting rulings.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Shortage Forces Partial Shutdown at Government Newspaper
With AM-Soviet-Parliament, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government's main national newspaper, Izvestia, has missed publication the last two Sundays because of a newsprint shortage, indicating the severity of the breakdown of supplies to state enterprises. The government's flagship newspaper, a daily with a circulation of 10.1 million, did not come out on Sept. 23 and Sept. 30, the first such break since it began publishing seven days a week 10 years ago, managing editor Vasily Zakharo said Monday. The paper explained the breaks in publication Saturday in a four-paragraph column headlined ``For the Enlightenment of Readers,'' saying it hoped the breaks in publication would be the last. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, using his newly granted emergency powers, issued a decree last week ordering all companies to fulfill their supply contracts with state enterprises, ostensibly including newsprint. But it was unclear how effectively the order could be enforced. Supplies of many products, ranging from food to newsprint and other materials, have been increasingly hard to find as some factories refuse to honor contracts with enterprises in other republics or workers siphon off supplies for private sale. Zakharo also said Monday the newspaper's editorial board has decided to cut back to six days a week on Jan. 1, 1991, to meet a demand by mail carriers for a day off on Sunday. He insisted the decision was unrelated to the paper shortage, but added the size of the paper would not increase to make up for the lost day. Soviet mail service is miminal on Sundays, with the national newspapers Izvestia and Pravda accounting for much of the delivery work.

DOC.HEAD: Court Begins Term Without Brennan For First Time in 34 Years
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in 34 years, retired Justice William J. Brennan was not on the bench to begin a new Supreme Court term Monday. But he was in the audience as his former colleagues officially noted his departure. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist read an exchange of letters between the eight court members and Brennan, its longtime leading liberal. ``The personal warmth which you radiate has enriched all of our lives,'' Rehnquist read from the letter to Brennan. ``We will miss your wise counsel in our deliberations.'' Brennan's reply, also read by the chief justice, said, ``My reluctance to retire from the court was sharpened by an awareness that I will no longer sit with each you on the bench or in the conferences. ``I know that friendships forged in this court are sustained by more than a common endeavor, and I therefore take comfort in the expectation that our personal ties will endure in the years ahead,'' Brennan wrote. Brennan, 84, retired in July because of failing health. He used a cane to walk into the courtroom Monday and took a seat in a section reserved for special guests. The seating arrangement of the other eight justices had been changed to reflect their changed seniority. On the far right end of the bench was an empty chair that will be filled soon by David H. Souter, after his anticipated confirmation by the Senate on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Top Soviet General Visits Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, chief of the Soviet general staff, was welcomed to the Pentagon with a 19-gun salute Monday and told his hosts, ``We want every chance to get to know America.'' Moiseyev, who is the personal guest of Army Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will tour military bases in five states before returning to the Pentagon on Friday for a news conference. The Soviet general, who has been quoted as saying he is helping the United States with data on Soviet weapons given Iraq, went first to Powell's office for photographs. ``We've left a very good picture for the history books,'' the Soviet general said as the flash units flared. Powell escorted Moiseyev to the office of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for a visit, then led him to the meeting room used by the military chiefs for private talks. Following a private lunch, he helped lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery before beginning talks on Capitol Hill with congressional leaders. Over the week Moiseyev, 51, will visit Army, Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps units in New York, Michigan, South Dakota, California and Colorado. Moiseyev, who is also first deputy minister of defense, is the highest ranking Soviet military officer to visit the United States since Soviet Marshall Sergei Akhromeyev met with Frank C. Carlucci, then secretary of defense, in December 1987. The current visit is another sign of warming relations between Washington and the government of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Moiseyev was appointed chief of the Soviet general staff following Akhromeyev's retirement. He previously received public attention by calling for improved technical training for officers and improved military discipline. In an interview with the Washington Post immediately before his departure for the United States, Moiseyev warned that a military conflict in the Persian Gulf could escalate into world war and urged the United States to seek a political solution under the auspices of the United Nations. He predicted that in any conflict with the United States and its allies, Iraq would be joined by its old enemy, Iran. And he said he was personally involved in assembling for the United States information about Soviet weapons provided to Iraq. In the interview, Moiseyev also offered assurances that the Kremlin has withdrawn nuclear warheads from regions of ethnic unrest to ``a more secure place.''

DOC.HEAD: Economists Predict Fed Will Lower Interest Rates Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 4th graf with Bush comments; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs bgng, `Many economists'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve will move quickly to lower interest rates now that negotiators have reached agreement on a deficit-cutting plan, many economists predicted Monday. But these analysts said the interest rate relief will be too little and too late to avert a recession. This forecast was made on the eve of a key meeting Tuesday of the Fed's top policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee. The panel, composed of Fed board members in Washington and Fed regional bank presidents, meets eight times a year to set interest rate policies. President Bush told reporters Monday that he was looking for the Fed to lower interest rates ``once they see that a sound budget agreement has been put into effect.'' Bush and congressional leaders have pledged to try to write the agreement into legislation and enact it by Oct. 19. Many economists expected a vote at Tuesday's meeting to nudge short-term interest rates down by about one-fourth of a percentage point. The actual rate cut, they said, might come as early as next week. Some economists said the rate cut would be enough to prompt commercial banks to lower their benchmark prime lending rate from 10 percent to 9.5 percent, although there wasn't universal agreement on this forecast. Analysts who expect a fairly prompt Fed easing move noted numerous statements Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has made that the central bank stood ready to lower interest rates following a credible, multiyear deficit reduction package. ``Greenspan has got to ease. If he doesn't, he is telling the financial markets that he doesn't view the deficit agreement as credible,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist with DRI-McGraw Hill. Wyss said that if Congress showed evidence of moving quickly to approve the budget agreement and the September unemployment report, due out on Friday, showed a further rise in the jobless rate, then the Fed would move perhaps as early as next week to cut the federal funds rate from 8 percent to 7.75 percent. The Fed funds rate, the interest that banks charge each other for overnight loans, is the bellwether rate the Fed often uses to signal changes in its credit policies. Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co., said while he was looking for a quick rate cut on the Fed's part, markets should not expect anything beyond a quarter of a percentage point drop, given the inflationary pressures arising from a doubling of oil prices since August when Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait. ``The Fed is being tossed back and forth by the Iraqi event,'' Sinai said. ``It wants to ease because of an impending recession but aggressive easing is very hard to do as long as the inflation threat is as great as it is.'' David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York, said regardless of whether the Fed eases immediately or waits until Congress actually passes the budget agreement, the rate cut will not be in time to keep alive the current recovery, which has already lasted a peacetime record of eight years. ``The handwriting is on the wall,'' Jones said. ``The Fed has already waited too long if it had hoped to avoid a recession.'' Jones and many other analysts believe the first economic downturn since the 1981-82 slump will begin sometime in the final three months of this year. While a number of analysts forecast a Fed easing move to support a budget deal, this forecast was not universally shared. Jerry Jordan, chief economist of the First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, said it would be a mistake for the Fed to rush to support the budget deal with lower interest rates. Jordan, one of a group of economists who monitor Fed actions as part of the Shadow Open Market Committee, warned that Fed efforts to ease rates ran the risk of allowing the higher inflation from this year's oil shocks to become embedded in the economy. Many analysts who believe the Fed will begin to ease rates in coming months said they looked for those rate cuts to accelerate early next year once it becomes clear the country is in a recession. Jones said the Fed will be forced next year to keep pushing rates down because the banking system - which already faces heavy losses from collapsing real estate markets - will move slower than it has in the past to lower the cost of loans to businesses and consumers in response to Fed easing moves.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Opens 35-Nation Foreign Ministers Meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday launched a 35-nation meeting on how to facilitate the growth of freedom and the easing of East-West tensions in Europe. Bush called on the foreign ministers to strengthen the European Security Conference by giving it a permanent secretariat as well as an elections office to supervise the exercise of voting rights in Europe. Just before Bush opened the meeting, which is making arrangements for a summit to be held in Paris Nov. 19-21, the Big Four allies of World War II suspended their last controls over Berlin. In a ceremony capped by a champagne toast, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Foreign Ministers Douglas Hurd of Britain, Roland Dumas of France and Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union turned over supervision of access to Berlin and the German border to the Germans. Bush called it ``a moving moment,'' and said ``we really rejoice with the German people.'' East Germany will merge formally with West Germany, creating a single, more powerful and prosperous nation at midnight Tuesday. Bush said unification is an expression of the human rights and fundamental freedoms set down in the 1975 Helsinki agreement produced by the European Security Conference. Depending on the decisions taken by the foreign ministers, the Paris summit is expected to establish a new structure to bridge East and West and also a treaty to cut U.S. and Soviet weapons in Europe. Bush, after a meeting with Shevardnadze, said the Soviet minister was confident the accord would be ready for signing in Paris. ``I came out of the meeting encouraged also in asking for flexibility so these negotiators can polish off the remaining differences,'' Bush said. Baker and Shevardnadze made headway in two meetings last week and will meet here again Wednesday. Meanwhile, the administration gave its support to full membership for the three Baltic republics and said Albania may be allowed to participate as an observer.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Network Free to Show Parts of Film About Hilary Foretich
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As a result of Supreme Court action Monday, a cable network is free to rebroadcast any part of a television documentary about the internationally publicized custody battle over little Hilary Foretich. The court left intact a ruling that said it would be unlawful censorship to keep off the air a four-minute portion of the telecast dealing with alleged sex abuse. Hilary, 8, was sent into hiding by her mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, after a judge said the girl's father, Dr. Eric Foretich, must be granted unsupervised visits with his daughter. Morgan spent two years in jail for refusing to obey the judge's order and was freed only after Congress passed a law that limited her incarceration. It was revealed last March that Hilary was living in New Zealand under an assumed identity to avoid the visits with her father. The British Broadcasting Co. produced a documentary about the case, entitled ``Hilary in Hiding,' that chronicled the girl's odyssey with her maternal grandparents from northern Virginia to England and then New Zealand. The documentary shows Hilary, then 4, talking to her mother in a therapy session in which the child demonstrates with a doll alleged sex abuse by her father. He repeatedly has denied abusing his daughter. A lawyer representing Hilary sought to have banned any rebroadcast of that four-minute segment. The film was shown in the United States several times last April 6 on the Lifetime Cable network.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans, Not Unknowns, Chosen to Play Lucy and Desi in TV Movie
LaserPhoto LA9
DOC.TEXT: Despite nationwide casting calls for unknowns to portray the late Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, a pair of professionals were introduced Monday as stars for CBS' ``Lucy and Desi: Before the Laughter.'' Following auditions of ``a couple thousand'' Lucy lookalikes and desiring Desis, producer Larry Thompson said he selected Frances Fisher and Maurice Benard to play the famous husband and wife. Miss Fisher, who bears little resemblance to Miss Ball without makeup, has appeared in the television movies ``Cold Sassy Tree,'' ``Home'' and ``Broken Vows.'' Benard, who plays Nico Kelly on the soap opera ``All My Children,'' looks somewhat like a young Arnaz. He said he had a conga that he was learning to play at home. ``There are a lot of talented people who wanted to be Lucy and Desi,'' Thompson said of the search for the lead roles. ```I Love Lucy' is more than a title.'' The heavily publicized casting calls in Los Angeles, Miami and New York, he said, were not a public-relations stunt but helped ``form what we were looking for.'' He said one actor discovered in one of the calls will play a band member in the film, due to be broadcast in February. Miss Fisher and Benard told reporters they were not concerned about playing two of the best-kown actors in television history. They added that they were not bothered by concerns about the CBS project expressed by Lucie Arnaz, Lucy's and Desi's daughter. ``I'm very excited about playing a role as well-known as Lucy,'' Miss Fisher said. ``I saw that I could resemble her when I had makeup on.'' Said Benard: ``It's big shoes to fill. I'm an actor. I'm not an impersonator. But he's a lot like my father.'' The film, which is set to begin production on Monday, focuses on the private life of Lucy and Desi in 1940 to the night they filmed their first episode of ``I Love Lucy,'' which premiered Oct. 15, 1951. Thompson said he was close to signing another pair of actors to play Fred and Ethel Mertz.

DOC.HEAD: Heirs of Procter & Gamble Founder Fight Corporate Policy
DOC.TEXT: Two descendants of a founder of Procter & Gamble Co. said Monday they want stop the giant company from buying coffee grown in El Salvador in an effort to end that country's civil war. ``The coffee growers benefit from the war,'' James Gamble said at a news conference here. ``It produces ... a very cheap labor force that cannot organize because of the civil strife.'' But James Gamble and his brother Robert admit they have little chance of winning their proxy fight at the company's stockholder Oct. 9 meeting in Cincinnati. ``It was an accomplishment for us to get the resolution officially on the ballot,'' James Gamble said. ``We don't have an illusion of actually winning the vote, but if we're able to win 3 percent this year then the resolution stays on the ballot for next year.'' Salvadoran beans make up about 2 percent of the coffee used to produce Procter & Gamble's Folgers coffee. ``We could very easily replace the Salvadoran coffee with coffee beans from other countries, but this isn't an economic decision for us,'' said company spokesman Donald Tassone. ``As a company, we can't let a very small but vocal group inject us into their dispute with the U.S. government, no matter how well-intentioned it might be,'' he said. The White House has asked Procter & Gamble to continue buying the beans because of the importance of coffee sales to the Salvadoran economy. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu called a 10-month-old consumer boycott of some coffee that uses Salvadoran beans - including Folgers - a ``misguided attempt to cripple the Salvadoran economy'' that will ``do nothing to advance the peace process, democracy or human rights.'' Procter & Gamble calls the conflict a dispute between peace activists and U.S. foreign policy and would prefer not to get involved. In a position paper distributed to shareholders, the company noted that El Salvador's Roman Catholic bishops oppose the coffee boycott because lost sales would hurt farmers and workers. James Gamble said Salvadoran landowners would be likely to pressure their government to negotiate for peace if their sales to a major client were on the line. The corporation, he said, ``could play a very critical role in speeding up the negotiation process.'' There is a total of 346,425,304 voting shares in Procter & Gamble - James Gamble, 27, owns 24,806 shares worth about $2 million; Robert Gamble, 30, said he wasn't sure how many shares he controls. Both brothers said they had the support of their father and other family members. They wouldn't say how much stock owned by other family members would be voting their way next week, but conceded it would be less than 1 percent of the total.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Hear Suit Filed by Injured Passenger
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday said it will hear an appeal by a ship line that was sued for negligence by a Washington state woman injured on a cruise to Mexico. The court said it will decide whether Carnival Cruise Lines may be sued in federal court in the woman's home state. Eulala Shute and her husband, Russel, were taking a seven-day cruise on the Tropicale from Los Angeles to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, when she fell during a guided tour of the ship's galley. The ship was in international waters off Mexico at the time. Carnival Cruise Lines, with headquarters in Miami, is a Panamanian corporation. It said the passenger ticket agreement signed by the Shutes required them to sue in Florida. A federal judge in Washington state dismissed the suit. But it was revived by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in February. The appeals court said Carnival's advertising and promotional activities in Washington make it subject to a lawsuit there. The appeals court noted that the Shutes purchased their tickets in Arlington, Wash., and that Carnival advertises in Washington newspapers and provides brochures to travel agents there. The case is Carnival Cruise Lines vs. Shute, 89-1647.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Serbs Proclaim Autonony in Croatia
DOC.TEXT: Road and rail traffic was blocked in sections of Croatia on Monday after minority Serbs proclaimed autonomy in the region and staged anti-government rallies. ``The Serbian people must use all means to resist the terror of the fascist (Croatian) government and to protect its human dignity and civil and national rights,'' the Serbian National Council said in a statement carried by the Tanjug news agency. The council, an unofficial body claiming to represent the estimated 500,000 Serbs in Croatia, said the declaration was based on an August referendum that showed near-unanimous support for limited self-government. Croatian authorities declared the referendum illegal. Yugoslav leaders plan to meet Tuesday to discuss the conflict in Croatia, a northern state of about 5 million people, Belgrade television reported. Belgrade radio reported barricades were set up early Monday across roads and railway lines to Knin, a Serbian-dominated city of about 10,000 people near the Adriatic coast. The blockades sealed off traffic through much of western Croatia. Tension between Serbs and Croats, dating to the birth of Yugoslavia in 1918, intensified earlier this year following the first free elections in Croatia since 1945. The Serbs accuse the newly elected authorities of discrimination. Croatian leaders claim the unrest has been orchestrated by the Communist-ruled republic of Serbia to destabilize democracy in Croatia and gain support for its hard-line policies. In Belgrade, more than 1,000 Serbs rallied Monday night. A few thousand Serbs also gathered in Banski Grabovac, a village southeast of Zagreb, around a flame-shaped monument honoring the mainly Serbian partisans who fought the Croatian-led goverment established by Nazis during World War II. Borisav Mikelic, head of a faction of the Croatian Socialist Party, said Serbs cannot promise to halt attacks until authorities stop ``revanchist detentions and arrests.'' Last week, Serbs raided police armories in several towns and seized automatic weapons. Hundreds of Serbs have reportedly taken refuge in an army barracks in Petrinja, about 25 miles south of the Croatia'a capital of Zagreb, to escape riot police seeking to recover weapons. At least 27 people were detained in weekend clashes. An elderly Croat villager in Banski Grabovac said, ``We don't mind the demonstration if it leads to peaceful solution of our problems.'' He declined to give his name. There were no reports of violence at the rally. Also Monday, the largest opposition party in Serbia announced it was ceasing all campaigning for upcoming elections, after a spate of attacks on its members and disruptions of its rallies. ``If we do not receive immediate assurances from the Serbian authorities that our people will not longer be the targets of Communist hooligans, we will boycott the elections,'' said Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Party. Elections are scheduled for Dec. 9. President Borisav Jovic, a Serb now holding the annually rotating chairmanship of Yugoslavia's collective presidency, announced he would cut short his visit to the United Nations ``because of the deterioration of the political and security situation'' at home, Tanjug said Sunday. There was no word on when he was due to return. Croatia and Serbia are at odds over the future of Yugoslavia's fragile, six-republic federation. Croatia wants the nation changed into a looser confederation of sovereign states. Serbia seeks to maintain tighter central control, and change its border with Croatia to incorporate Serbs living there.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Hears Arguments on Back-to-Work Order
With AM-Teachers Strikes
DOC.TEXT: Temple University on Monday renewed its request for a court order ending a 27-day walkout by professors, claiming it will have to cancel fall semester classes unless they are back on the job by Tuesday. The 1,100-member union went on strike over pay Sept. 4 at the private university, which has 30,000 students. Union members Sunday night rejected the latest contract proposal by 372-62. Temple and union attorneys argued in court over whether the professors should be ordered back. Temple officials have said if pickets are still marching Tuesday, they will cancel 40 percent, or 1,900, of the 4,700 classes. Common Pleas Court Judge Samuel Lehrer said his response will hinge in part on determining how serious a threat the strike poses to the public. ``If it doesn't matter whether Temple goes out of business or cancels classes, then there is no public danger,'' Lehrer said. ``But if it does matter and if there is a threat to the public, then I must consider that.'' Lehrer denied a union request that he throw out the university's request for a back-to-work order. The hearing continued late in the afternoon. Alaine Williams, attorney for the Temple Association of University Professionals, said the university was trying to force the judge's hand by threatening to cancel classes. But the judge replied, ``I think they have made a case and your motion is denied.'' Temple officials have said that if the strike continues, there will not be enough time to make up lost class time before the spring semester. Some 23,000 students are missing at least one class and 6,000 have had no classes because of the walkout. Witnesses for the union argued that, even if the strike continued, professors would be able to make up for lost class time by extending the semester or scheduling extra class hours. ``It would be difficult, but we can work it out successfully,'' said Violet Kettles, of the English faculty. The proposal rejected Sunday included 5 percent raises in each of four years and a requirement that professors contribute $260 a year toward health coverage. The professors, whose salaries average about $45,500, want 7 percent raises and do not want to pay for health care. Some students have blocked city streets and stood outside a courtroom, demanding an end to the dispute. Some have been arrested for invading university President Peter J. Liacouras' office. ``We're very upset, we just want it over. Nobody is interested in the students anymore. We're like pawns,'' said Rachel Smith, a 19-year-old sophomore from Margate, N.J. ``If I transfer I'm not coming back.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Talks Tough to Iraq, Says Exit Could Help Arab-Israeli Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf pvs with three grafs to update with Bush-Shevardnadze meeting and talks on arms control; new grafs 19-22 with Mideast comments from Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that Iraq and its leaders must be held liable for ``crimes of abuse and destruction'' in the takeover of Kuwait. But he also suggested to Baghdad that an unconditional military withdrawal could help speed an end to the Arab-Israeli conflict. Bush, in a speech before the U.N. General Assembly, said all nations hope that military force will not be required to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Yet, he won applause by vowing anew that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``will not be allowed to stand.'' Praising the U.N.'s resolve, Bush said, ``This challenge is a test we cannot afford to fail. I am confident we will prevail.'' Even as Bush was speaking, the White House announced the United States was sending two batteries of Patriot air-defense missiles to Israel on an emergency basis. The weapons will help Israel defend against an increased threat from ballistic missiles in Iraq, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Nearly every seat in the General Assembly hall was full as Bush combined a blistering indictment of Iraq with an overture for Baghdad to end the two-month old Persian Gulf crisis. ``Iraq's unprovoked aggression is a throwback to another era, a dark relic from a dark time,'' Bush said. ``It has plundered Kuwait, it has terrorized innocent civilians, it has held even diplomats hostage.'' Aligning himself with remarks last week by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, Bush said Iraq and its leaders ``must be held liable for these crimes of abuse and destruction.'' Bush met separately with Shevardnadze later to discuss the gulf crisis, the plight of the Soviet economy and lagging arms control talks. Emerging from the meeting, Bush said Shevardnadze was ``very confident'' that a treaty between NATO and the Warsaw Pact to cut U.S. and Soviet non-nuclear weapons would be ready for signing at a 35-nation summit in Paris. Bush said he was not as confident about completing a separate accord with the Soviets to cut long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent. Bush had hoped to sign that treaty during a trip to Moscow in December but said Shevardnadze talked about completing the agreement early next year, if not by the end of 1990. Shevardnadze praised Bush's speech as ``brilliant.'' Aside from his hard-edged rhetoric, Bush appeared to try to undercut Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's demand that his territorial dispute with Kuwait be linked to Arab demands that Israel give up territory lost by Syria and Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war. Bush said that ``I truly believe there may be opportunities'' to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict and to build ``new arrangements'' among the states in the gulf - but only after Iraq makes an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Saddam has suggested he would pull his troops out if the Arab dispute with Israel is handled simultaneously. The United States has long been committed to a Mideast settlement in which Israel would exchange territory for Arab recognition of its right to exist. Bush said a military pullout by Saddam could clear the way for Iraq and Kuwait to permanently settle their territorial differences. ``And yet,'' Bush said, ``the world's key task - now, first and always - must be to demonstrate that aggression will not be tolerated or rewarded.'' Later, talking with reporters, Bush said his comment about ``opportunities'' created by an Iraqi withdrawal did not mark any change in policy and ``was not designed to convey flexibility or shift in position.'' He said he did not intend to suggest that Kuwait should make any territorial concessions. ``You've got to make whole Kuwait the way it was.'' Bush also said it was possible that Saddam will make ``a 180-degree turn'' and pull out of Kuwait. However, the president said ``there would be great unease'' about a simple return to the pre-invasion status quo if it left Saddam with a ``very troublesome capability'' of military power. ``The international community would have to have something to say about that,'' Bush said. ``I'm sure that neighbors would want to know that there was not a risk of another reckless invasion of this nature.'' In his speech, Bush did not mention his oft-stated demand that the exiled emir of Kuwait be restored to power. Yet, he told reporters later that the ``restoration of Kuwait's leaders is a terribly important part'' of any settlement. Bush assured Saddam that ``we seek no advantages for ourselves'' in the gulf. He said the 165,000 U.S. troops defending the oilfields of Saudi Arabia were sent there at the request of the Saudi government following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``The American people - and this president - want every single American soldier brought home as soon as the mission is accomplished,'' he said. Bush praised the Soviet Union for collaborating with the United States in a worldwide cutoff of trade with Iraq. The superpowers ``had indeed put four decades of history behind us,'' he said. More than ever before, Bush said, the United Nations is now ``a center for international collective security.'' Bush has met with more than 20 leaders here over the past three days, and he said he was encouraged by reports that Saddam ``is beginning to understand that it is him against the world.'' Bush also said, ``There is more optimism in various quarters that the sanctions are really beginning to bite hard.'' Even so, U.S. officials said Sunday the two superpowers, as well as a number of other countries, had begun preliminary drafting of resolutions to authorize the use of force against Iraq if Saddam does not withdraw his troops.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Earthquake Measuring 4.5 Rocks Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with houses, buildings shaken across Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, details. No pickup. Precedes to SAN JUAN
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake of moderate intensity shook houses and buildings across Puerto Rico on Monday, but there were no reports of injuries or damage. The quake registered 4.5 on the Richter scale and was centered near the coastal city of Humacao, 30 miles southeast of San Juan, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. The Seismological Survey in Cayey, Puerto Rico, said the temblor struck at 2:36 p.m. EDT, lasted five seconds and was felt as far away as St. John in the U.S. Virgin Islands, 50 miles east of Puerto Rico. It was strongest in Puerto Rico, particularly the San Juan metropolitan area, said Allan Smith, director of the Seismological Network of Puerto Rico at the University of Mayaguez. He said there were no reports of damage or injuries, but the quake prompted a flurry of telephone calls to television and radio stations. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage, while a 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Justices To Take Up Case Of Allegedly Faked Quotes
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will consider reviving a libel lawsuit against Janet Malcolm, a staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, by a psychologist who says she made up quotes attributed to him. The justices will review a federal appeals court ruling that last year threw out Jeffrey Masson's lawsuit. A decision is expected by July. The appeals court ruling was criticized by some who said it recognized ``the right to fake quotes.'' Also Monday, the court let stand rulings in four other libel cases: -It refused to kill a lawsuit stemming from advertisements comparing Blue Cross and Blue Shield services to those of a health industry competitor. A lower court ruling could send U.S. Healthcare's libel allegations against Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a federal jury in Philadelphia. -The justices turned down the appeal of a former San Jose City Council member who won, and then lost, a $1.01 million libel award against his local newspaper. The court let stand rulings that Claude Fletcher failed to prove the San Jose Mercury News published statements about him with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of their falsity. -It refused to revive libel suits by an unsuccessful mayoral candidate in Willoughby, Ohio, against two newspapers that covered controversy surrounding his campaign. Roland Mastandrea failed to prove his case against The Lake County News-Herald and The Lake County Telegraph. -The justices killed a nine-year-old libel lawsuit stemming from two leters to then-President Reagan opposing a North Carolina man's appointment as a federal prosecutor. A federal appeals court dismissed the 1981 suit filed by David Smith of Greensboro, N.C., against Robert McDonald, the operator of child care centers in Virginia. In the lawsuit against Ms. Malcolm, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that public figures who sue for libel over allegedly altered quotes must show that the quotes are not even ``rational interpretations'' of what was said. The appeals court did not rule on whether Ms. Malcolm actually fabricated quotes attributed to Masson, a former projects director of the Sigmund Freud Archives. It instead said the fake quotes alleged by Masson, when compared to what he contends he said, do not amount to actual malice. Ms. Malcolm's two-part article in The New Yorker focused on Masson's struggle with other archives officials over Sigmund Freud's abandonment of a theory that certain mental illnesses originate in sexual abuse during childhood. The article discussed Masson's claim that his contract with the archives was terminated because he made public his views that Freud abandoned the theory simply to further his career and placate his colleagues. The article subsequently was published in book form by Alfred A. Knopf Inc. Masson's suit named The New Yorker and Knopf as defendants also.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Rebuffs Arts Endowment Foes, Votes Fund Increase
DOC.TEXT: The House Appropriations Committee voted Monday to boost spending by the National Endowment for the Arts to $180 million next year and rebuffed attempts to abolish the agency or impose new anti-obscenity curbs on the projects it subsidizes. The committee, in effect, ducked the politically explosive issue of federal support for ``obscene art'' in favor of House floor action later this week on a separate proposal to shift the responsibility for deciding what is obscene from the NEA to the courts. An NEA compromise being patched together by Reps. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., is tentatively scheduled for floor debate starting Wednesday or Thursday. The pair circulated the outlines of a proposed compromise among their House colleagues for comment Monday, but Williams said there was no final agreement. Their proposal reportedly would extend the NEA's life for five years and drop the strict obscenity ban Congress slapped on the agency last fall at the request of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Instead, it would embrace a bipartisan Senate measure that would require the NEA to get its money back from any grant recipient who is convicted of violating obscenity laws. The guilty artist would be barred from receiving any new federal grants for at least three years. In a gesture to the NEA's congressional critics, the Williams-Coleman compromise reportedly would include a modest increase in the current 20 percent portion of federal funds allocated to state arts agencies. The bill's new proposed 27.5 percent share for the states is far less than the 60 percent originally proposed by the conservative Coleman, who also had sought a ban on NEA support for any works that violate the Supreme Court's obscenity standards. The $180 million the Appropriations Committee approved for the beleaguered arts endowment would be a 5 percent increase in its current $171 million budget. The NEA, an independent federal agency, spends most of the money on grants to artists and arts institutions that mut be matched by private funds. At the urging of Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., a staunch NEA supporter, the committee resoundingly defeated by voice vote a proposal by Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, to eliminate all funds for the endowment until Congress votes to extend its life in separate legislation. ``Some people want to abolish the NEA, and this is what this amendment is all about,'' Rep. Bob Carr, D-Mich., told his colleagues. ``If you are for this amendment, you are for the end of the National Endowment for the Arts,'' Yates said. Under heavy pressure from Yates and other committee Democrats, Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, withdrew a proposed amendment that would have banned subsidies for obscene or indecent works and required the NEA to support art that is ``appropriate for a general audience.'' Democrats said Regula's proposal was so vaguely worded it could not be enforced, and might be ruled unconstitutional on the ground that it involved prior restraint on an artist's First Amendment guarantees of freedom of expression. The committee bowed to pleas by Yates and Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., that it sidestep the ``obscene art'' issue in favor of House action on a Williams-Coleman compromise later this week. The NEA's proposed $180 million spending budget for fiscal 1991, which began Monday, was included in a $14.5 billion appropriations bill for a variety of federal agencies, including the Interior and Energy departments, the Forest Service and the Smithsonian Institution. The committee approved the bill by voice vote and sent it to the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Go for Senate Military Figures
With AM-Budget Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Budget negotiators agreed on a 1991 level of military spending that pits President Bush and the Senate against the House. ``Unbelievable,'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said Monday as members closely examined the details of the broad plan that includes tax increases and spending cuts. Defense spending authority in the fiscal year that began Monday would total $289 billion in the compromise worked out by White House and congressional bargainers. That was the same total proposed by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, earlier this year and adopted by the full Senate in its version of the defense bill in August. Although he originally proposed $307 billion in military spending back in January, Bush accepted the $289 billion amount in a speech this summer and the White House has endorsed the figure. The House last month approved a $283 billion defense bill that would slash more than $2 billion from the Strategic Defense Initiative, halt production of the B-2 bomber and cut troop strength by 129,500. The Senate legislation would cut $1 billion from the SDI budget and reduce U.S. troop strength by 100,000 but leave the B-2 stealth bomber program intact. ``I think the defense numbers are reasonable and I certainly can support those,'' Nunn said of the negotiators' agreement in an interview Monday. Members of the House and Senate planned to meet Tuesday to begin crafting a final defense package for fiscal 1991 from their two widely divergent bills. House Democrats and Republicans on the Armed Services Committee expressed the hope that lawmakers in their chamber would not give in to the Senate and the administration. ``I really hope we don't retreat and stand our ground at $283 billion,'' said Rep. Larry Hopkins, R-Ky., who envisioned lawmakers adding $6 billion of their pet projects to reach the higher number. ``They don't ever have any trouble ratcheting up. They'll find a good cause,'' Hopkins said. Lawmakers also expressed concern over the absence of the cost of Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. military deployment in the Persian Gulf, from the budget compromise. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has estimated that the buildup could cost about $15 billion in fiscal 1991. Schroeder suggested that the $6 billion difference between the House and Senate numbers could be used for Operation Desert Shield.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav President Says Bush Will Visit
With AM-Bush-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslav President Borisav Jovic said Monday that President Bush had accepted an invitation to visit Yugoslavia, but no date was set. Bush and Jovic conferred at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel after Bush's address to the United Nations General Assembly. Jovic told reporters later that Bush had expressed support for Yugoslavia's economic reforms. The Yugoslav leader praised Bush's U.N. speech, in which Bush again demanded Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait but held out the possibility that a peaceful solution could usher in a new era of stability for the Middle East. ``I think that it's main intention was seeking a solution in the best possible way,'' Jovic said. ``A military solution is the last solution - and the worst solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Would Upgrade Airport Security
DOC.TEXT: The House passed legislation Monday to upgrade security at airlines and airports, including directing the government to develop guidelines for warning passengers of terrorist threats. ``Never again do we want a situation where the insiders had notification but the rest of the world didn't,'' said Rep. Sherwood Boehlert, R-N.Y. ``If in the future there is a credible threat, there will be a mechanism for notification so that people can have a choice.'' The bill, approved on a voice vote without dissent, would put into law the reforms recommended in May by a seven-member presidential commission that investigated the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The legislation would require the Justice Department and Federal Aviation Administration to develop guidelines for notifying both the public and airplane crews of bomb or other security threats. Airlines, airports and travel agents would be required to relay any security threat immediately to government officials. The FAA also would be required to hire federal security managers at high-risk domestic airports and foreign security liaisons at those overseas. Airline and airport employees with access to security areas would have to undergo background checks and new training. To coordinate the activities, the legislation establishes a new assistant secretary's position in the Transportation Department for security and a similar new assistant administrator's post at the FAA. It would provide the families of the victims aboard Pan Am 103 the same tax relief provided to families of government employees aboard the flight, which exploded Dec. 21, 1988, killing a total of 270 people aboard and on the ground. The State Department would be required to negotiate agreements with other nations to achieve the enhanced security measures at foreign airports and domestic airlines would have to provide the department with a passenger manifest within three hours after a terrorist incident. The parts of the bill changing the State Department's airline and airport security programs were approved last week by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Many of the measures already have been adopted by the government; the Bush administration contends the legislation is not needed.

DOC.HEAD: Food Program For Women And Children Reduces Medical Costs
DOC.TEXT: A two-year study of WIC operations in five states showed Monday the supplemental feeding program can reduce medical costs of caring for low-income pregnant women and their babies. The study of the special supplemental food program for Women, Infants and Children was ordered by Congress in 1987 to help determine savings in Medicaid costs during the first 60 days after birth. Typically, the WIC program provides improved nutrition for poor women during pregnancy and for them and their infants after birth. From its beginning in 1972, the WIC program has grown to a $2.1 billion operation this year with an enrollment of 4.5 million women and children. Medicaid is a joint federal and state program that covers medical costs of low-income people. The $1.1 million study was done for the department's Food and Nutrition Service by Mathematica Policy Research Inc. of Princeton, N.J. Department officials said the study ``strongly'' indicated that WIC participation during pregnancy ``is associated with reduced Medicaid costs and increased birth weight.'' The study involved births and costs in Florida, Minnesota, North Carolina, South Carolina and Texas over periods in 1987 and 1988. Among the findings were increased birth weights and reduced Medicaid costs involving the women and their babies.
