However, the study cautioned that there are considerable variations among the WIC and Medicaid programs operated by individual states and that situations are changing rapidly. ``These problems are compounded by the exclusion of other indigent care costs from the study, which means only a partial picture of the health-care costs of low-income women and newborns is available,'' it said. Even so, the benefits of WIC participation by Medicaid recipients ``were so clearly demonstrated in all five study states, with all their population and program differences'' that a nationwide in 1987 would have shown positive benefits, the report said. Looking to the future, researchers said Medicaid expansion is allowing a higher-income group of pregnant women to enroll and that many of those are likely to participate in WIC. ``Conversely, aggressive outreach and improved eligibility procedures may bring a higher-risk group of pregnant women into the Medicaid and the WIC programs,'' the report said. ``The net effect of these enrollment changes on estimates of WIC benefits is uncertain.'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said in a statement that the study ``reaffirms the success of the WIC program and underscores our emphasis on serving pregnant women and infants as WIC's top priority.'' Yeutter said that in 1974 as an assistant secretary of agriculture he cut the ribbon launching the first WIC program facility in Pineville, Ky.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut Paper: Iran, Syria Agree on Plan to Free Western Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The Beirut newspaper Ad-Diyar reported Monday that presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran have agreed on a step-by-step plan to free Western hostages in Lebanon. The conservative daily, citing unnamed diplomatic sources, said Assad worked out the accord in talks with Rafsanjani last week in Tehran. Hours later, the South Lebanon Army, an Israeli-backed militia, announced it freed 40 Shiite Moslem detainees to mark the birthday of the Prophet Mohammed, founder of Islam. Shiite kidnappers holding most of the 13 missing Westerners, including six Americans, have repeatedly demanded the mainly Christian South Lebanon Army free the 340 Moslems it holds in exchange for releasing their captives. In New York, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States welcomes the move and said it is ``consistent with our position that for humanitarian reasons, all persons being detained without legal basis in the Middle East should be released immediately. ``As President Bush has indicated, the release of American hostages would help improve our relations with countries contributing to that release.'' Other Westerners held are four Britons, including Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite; two West Germans and an Italian. Most are believed held by Shiite factions linked to the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. It is Tehran's main ally in Lebanon. There was no way to assess the authenticity of the Ad-Diyar report. The Iranian Embassy in Beirut and the headquarters of the Syrian security force in the Lebanese capital's Moslem sector declined comment. But the report came amid indications that efforts to free the captives were gathering momentum amid the Persian Gulf crisis set off by Iraq's Aug.2 invasion of Kuwait. Among the signals: -Iran's ambassador to Pakistan, a country used by the Americans as a conduit into Tehran, said shortly before Assad's visit to Tehran that some hostages could be freed soon. -Tehran and London restored relations last week, ending a 19-month rift. Ad-Diyar said the release process would begin not in Lebanon, but in Iran, with Tehran's freeing British businessman Roger Cooper ``within the next few days to warm up the newly resumed diplomatic ties between Britain and Iran.'' Cooper has been in prison in Tehran since 1985 for allegedly spying. Iran says he was convicted last year, but never disclosed his sentence. Ad-Diyar said the next step would be release of British hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite extremists in Lebanon ``in a matter of days after Cooper's release.'' The third stage was said to be starting serious negotiations for releasing the six U.S. hostages simultaneously with unfreezing Iranian assets held in the United States since 1979. Washington last month agreed to hand over assets worth at least $200 million, and sources close to a U.S.-Iranian tribunal in The Hague have said larger claims are nearing settlement. Most of the hostages have been held three years or more. The longest held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The South Lebanon Army commander, retired Lebanese Army Gen. Antoine Lahd, said Monday the 40 Shiites were freed specifically to celebrate the prophet's birthday, an event traditionally marked in Arab countries by freeing prisoners. Lahd told the Voice of the South radio station: ``I also took into consideration their humanitarian condition.'' He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Budget Cuts May Axe `Point of Light'
DOC.TEXT: New England's first shelter for homeless veterans, honored by President Bush as a ``point of light,'' faces possible closure because of state budget cuts. ``To do this is unconscionable,'' Ken Smith, president of the shelter, said Monday. ``These guys have already paid the price.'' Officials of the financially strapped state said they were considering closing the New England Shelter For Homeless Veterans and one other homeless shelter in the Greater Boston area. That could put nearly 400 people onto the streets. Mayor Raymond Flynn said Sunday he might sue state officials if they do cut funds to the shelters. ``I believe it's a violation of the law to not provide protection and help for needy people,'' Flynn said. ``By cutting back these programs, they're leaving these people on the streets to die.'' Human Services Secretary Philip Johnston said he will meet with Flynn this week to try to save shelter funding. ``We'll do everything possible to help,'' Johnston said. ``We'll try to find cuts elsewhere to soften the impact on direct care.'' Soldiers homes in Holyoke and Chelsea also are threatened. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis announced last week the state would close the soldiers homes as part of a series of budget cuts as the state struggles to balance its budget. Officials said the soldiers homes could remain open if the Legislature can find equivalent cuts elsewhere. Western Massachusetts lawmakers met Monday at the Holyoke Soldiers Home and said they would fight a closing, tentatively set for April 1. ``To even propose that this institution be closed is really absolutely ridiculous so I'm confident that the governor will know that we will fight him tooth and nail on this and that if he hasn't gotten involved in a fight with western Massachusetts people before, he's got one on his hands now,'' said state Rep. Carmen Buell. The Boston veterans shelter opened in January and receives about $70,000 a month from the state, which marks about 90 percent of its budget. Smith said he was working on contingency plans, and trying to get veterans organizations in the state ``to draw their wagons around us.'' Also, the veterans shelter was making an appeal to Bush for help, Smith said, adding that the project received a ``point of light'' award from the White House for community service. ``We're one of the thousand points of lights,'' Smith said. ``We'll see what that means.'' Flynn called on gubernatorial candidates John R. Silber and William F. Weld to announce whether they support cuts in homeless services. ``If they do not support them, the cuts should not happen,'' Flynn said. ``There are only three months left in this administration. The next governor will be taking office with hundreds of people in the streets.''

DOC.HEAD: France Recalls Vichy's Anti-Semitic Laws
DOC.TEXT: Acts of persecution and harsh anti-Semitism among Nazi collaborators were relived and re-examined Monday, 50 years after the start of a notorious crackdown that led to the deaths of more than 73,000 French Jews. ``We must not blame the (Nazi) occupation for what was the sole responsibility of the legitimate French government. The laws met only utter silence from the French people,'' said former Justice Minister Robert Badinter, who presided over the daylong symposium on ``The Vichy Laws.'' ``Vichy was obsessed with taking measures against Jews,'' Badinter told about 250 people at the conference. ``The Vichy Laws,'' named for the Vichy Government that controlled unoccupied France and territories from 1940 to 1943, prevented France's 350,000 Jews from holding public office, teaching, attending university, owning stores and working in the media. It was implemented 11 weeks after Paris fell to the Germans. The laws, later reinforced by measures to send Jews to concentration camps, defined ``who is a Jew,'' using criteria far more sweeping than the racial laws drafted by the Nazis. Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld estimated 3,000 Jews died from cold and starvation from 1940 to 1942 in French-run camps ``where there wasn't a single German soldier.'' In all, 76,000 Jews were deported to death camps from France. About 2,500 survived, historians estimate. ``The Jewish Laws did not come out of the blue because anti-Semitism existed in France well before the German victory in June 1940,'' said Henri Amouroux, a historian at the symposium, sponsored by the Center for Contemporary Jewish Documentation and the Sons and Daughters of Jews Deported from the France. ``Anti-Semitism developed in the 1930s in a climate of economic and social crisis. Thousands of Jews, chased out of Poland and Austria, fleeing the Nazis, came to France and were accused of taking jobs,'' he said. Historians say the Vichy laws were a cornerstone of a right-wing ideology that sought to undo the liberalizing, human rights-oriented reforms of the French Revolution. ``The laws erased the advances made during the Age of Enlightenment,'' said Zev Sternhell, a history professor at the University of Jerusalem. ``They reflect a new concept of the nation, not as a melting pot but as an extended family with everybody having the same blood.'' For historian Denis Peschansky, the laws were a way for Marshal Philippe Petain, Vichy's leader, to explain the French military defeat and punish those deemed responsible. ``Petain had to find reasons within French society for the debacle - he certainly couldn't blame the army because it was in power - so he blamed the Jews, Communists, Freemasons and other foreigners,'' Peschansky said. The laws also revoked the citizenship of about 400,000 Jews in colonial Algeria and Morocco and Tunisia, which were French protectorates. ``My mother, who had six small children and worked in the arsenal in Algiers, was fired immediately,'' said a woman in the audience. Other survivors described the discrimination and persecution that followed. In September 1943, Samuel and Rachel Ewenczyk closed their dry goods store in Grenoble, fleeing to the Alps to escape deportation. ``One week later, thanks to the Vichy laws, the French police requisitioned the store as a Jewish store, and sold it to a non-Jewish person,'' Mrs. Ewenczyk, 78, recalled. After Grenoble was liberated by U.S. troops in August 1944, the family returned to claim the property. ``The man in the shop protested, saying he had bought the shop, but my husband asked, `Who did you buy it from? I never sold it.' We were back in business a week later,'' she said. The Vichy government, named for a city in central France, was never recognized by the Allies. The Nazis annulled the armistice with Vichy after the Allies invaded North Africa in November 1943 and occupied France.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Transfer Merabank Offices To Bank Of America
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators said Monday they had transferred most offices of the Phoenix-based Merabank to Bank of America, estimating the bailout of the thrift - once Arizona's largest - at $1 billion. Bank of America Arizona, a subsidiary of the San Francisco-based holding company, is taking over Merabank's 66 Arizona branches, the Resolution Trust Corp. said. The agency will keep Merabank's seven Texas branches and try to sell them as part of Merabank Texas - a separate institution created lout of three small thrifts by the RTC's predecessor, the Federin 1988 in a baial Home Loan Bank Board. The deal with Bank of America brings the RTC's ``resolution'' total to 287 since its creation in Aug. 1989. It still has another 207 institutions left to handle and several hundred others are expected to fail in the next year. Bank of America is assuming only $552 million of Merabank's $5 billion assets, leaving the RTC with the rest. Even the $552 million are being acquired with liberal rights to return the assets to the RTC if they prove to be worth less than originally estimated. The bank is paying a premium of $92.3 million to take over $3.5 billion in deposits in Merabank's Arizona offices. The trust corporation, which seized Merabank in February 1990, estimated the ultntury

DOC.TEXT:
GUBEN, East Germany - Butter brought Luise Orpitz and Ryszard Madejski together. Tough visa rules that start on unity day will drive the East German pensioner and the jobless Pole apart. Slug AM-Germany-Poland. Sent as a0652. By Deborah G. Seward.
With: - AM-Germany-Commandant from WEST BERLIN: A high-profile American general furls the flag of his command and says there is ``close cooperation'' with Soviet commanders also closing down some functions before unification. DOC.HEAD: SOVIETS:
Lawmakers OK Freedom of Religion, Debate Communist Control
DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW - The Soviet legislature gave final approval Monday to a law on freedom of religion, then began debating a bill that would reduce the influence of atheism's strongest advocate, the Communist Party. Slug AM-Soviet-Legislature. Sent as a0653. By Alan Cooperman.
DOC.HEAD: Tales From the Trenches on the `Potato Front'
DOC.TEXT: PESHKI, U.S.S.R. - Thousands of people, from alcoholics to soldiers, are slogging through the nation's potato fields in a race to salvage the rotting crop and save Muscovites from a hungry winter. Slug AM-Soviet-Potatoes. Sent as a0627. By Brian Friedman. LaserPhoto NY12, recovering alcoholics help harvest potatoes.
DOC.HEAD: KEATING-SENATORS: Special Counsel Links Timing of Gifts, S&L Help
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON - A special counsel's report establishes crucial links between the timing of contributions by Charles H. Keating Jr. to three senators and specific actions the lawmakers took to help the former savings and loan executive, congressional sources said Monday. Slug AM-Keating-Senators. Sent as a0675. By Larry Margasak.
DOC.HEAD: DOCTORS-TOBACCO: Some See Unhealthly Alliance in Health Campaign
DOC.TEXT:
NEW YORK - Two of the nation's leading doctors' organizations have angered some of their members by joining with a tobacco conglomerate to encourage Americans to lower their cholesterol. Slug AM-Doctors-Tobacco Money. Sent as a0689. By Science Editor Paul Raeburn.
With AM-Burger Slump from COHOES, N.Y.: Saying that Americans are eating less beef, a plant that processes ground meat for McDonald's hamburgers has laid off half its workforce.

DOC.TEXT: MIAMI - A flood of criticism of a pay-as-you-spray scheme to activate the city's Claude and Mildred Pepper Fountain with credit cards hasn't splashed cold water on the plan. Slug AM-Pepper Fountain. Sent as a0707. By Beth Duff Sanders. LaserPhoto MH1, Pepper Fountain.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Officers Keep Tabs on Village's Traffic Jungle
DOC.TEXT: It's a jungle out there on the streets of suburban Lisle. So village officials have hired four Brookfield Zoo police officers to slam the brakes on motorists speeding through the city and trying to escape the crowded highways that bisect the community. Lisle Police Chief Harold Fitzsimmons hired the four as part-time community service officers in February. Armed with city police vehicles and radar guns, the officers have issued almost 1,000 tickets to motorists speeding down Lisle's residential streets. Fitzsimmons indicated he chose the zoo officers because they knew how to soothe an angry motorist's temper. ``These guys know how to interact with people. The paid visitor comes to the zoo for a pleasant visit, and the officers are there mostly to help them out,'' Fitzsimmons explained in a telephone interview from the suburb, which is about 10 miles west of Chicago. Such skills are useful while patrolling Lisle's streets, the zoo officers said. Although the Brookfield officers graduated from the same police academy that trained Lisle's 25 regular patrol officers, they don't carry guns or make arrests while on patrol. ``I see how people are always in a hurry and they always have an excuse. On a residential street, there's no reason to be doing 14 or 15 miles an hour over the speed limit,'' said Lee Zeitlin, one of the four zoo officers. Fitzsimmons said that under the suburb's program, motorists cited by Zeitlin and his colleagues face a $25 fine, rather than the minimum $50 fine mandated by the state. Most motorists choose to pay the fine, which goes directly to Lisle because drivers are cited for violating village laws, not state traffic regulations. If the motorist pays the fine, city officials don't report the violation to the county clerk and the violation never appears on the driver's record, Fitzsimmons noted. As a result, not everyone is sold on the traffic program. DuPage County Circuit Clerk John Cockell said Monday that the city's traffic enforcement program may violate state laws. ``I think they're jumping around the law,'' Cockrell said. ``All traffic citations must be reported to the circuit court within 48 hours. That's the law. If they're not doing that, they've got a problem,'' he said. Bob Kay, village attorney, said city officials are trying to determine whether the program complies with state law.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Changes Position on Fernald Within Hours
DOC.TEXT: Energy Department officials raised more questions than they answered Monday about whether an Ohio atomic weapons facility would permanently stop producing uranium and shift to cleaning up decades of radioactive wastes. Henson Moore, the department's deputy secretary, first announced during a briefing with reporters that a decision had been made to ``never produce (uranium) again'' at the Fernald plant near Cincinnati. Instead, he said, the plant would concentrate on cleanup and development of cleanup technologies that also might be used at other weapons facilities with contamination problems. Within hours, however, a department spokesman disavowed Moore's characterization and said no decision on production would be made until January. The department said that management at Fernald had been shifted to the DOE office in charge of cleanup activities. The plant, which faces a major cleanup problem from past lax production procedures, has not produced weapons grade uranium since July 1989. The 1,000 plant employees have been awaiting word on whether production would ever resume. Some fear a shift away from production eventually would shut down the facility. Moore raised the issue of uranium production at Fernald in opening remarks at a briefing with reporters, saying he had wanted to take the opportunity to disclose that Energy Secretary James Watkins had decided ``making permanent what has been de facto for about a year.'' ``It (Fernald) will never produce (uranium) again,'' Moore said. Although not contesting what Moore had said, department spokesmen later said an actual decision by the department on the production question at Fernald is not expected to be made until January. ``We're probably on the road to closing down production,'' said department spokesman Bill Griffin. ``The decision will be made in January whether to at any point resume production or permanently turn the facility over to a cleanup mode.'' Dan D'Armond, a spokesman for Moore, later also acknowledged that a decision on the production issue at Fernald ``is not completely finalized'' but said the department was ``planning'' to stop uranium production at the Ohio facility. Uranium production has been suspended since July 1989 because of the facilities environmental problems including widespread contamination as a result of past lax production practices. Moore said he didn't anticipate that a permanent halt in production would cause job losses at Fernald. Instead the work at the 1,000-acre complex 18 miles from Cincinnati would focus exclusively on cleanup, safely packaging contaminated materials and developing new cleanup technologies, he said. The Fernald plant was opened in 1951 to process uranium for atomic weapons. The cost of cleaning up hazardous materials at the plant has been estimated at $1 billion to $5 billion. Stored at the plant are more than 500,000 metric tons of radioactive wastes dating from current plant operations to the World War II-era Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. Meanwhile, Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said the decision to shift management authority from DOE's production side to the cleanup offices was a major step toward ending uranium production Fernald and should trigger a retraining program for workers. ``According to my legislation which was passed last year, the end of Fernald's production mission requires DOE to have a job retraining plan for existing workers,'' Glenn said through his press office.

DOC.HEAD: Israel to Distribute Gas Masks to 4 Million Residents
DOC.TEXT: Israel will start distributing gas masks to its entire population of 4.7 million citizens next week following Iraqi threats to attack the Jewish state with chemical weapons, the army announced Monday. Each kit contains a gas mask, a syringe with a nerve gas antidote and purifying powder. Instructions will be in Hebrew, Arabic, English and Russian. The announcement followed assessments of an increased threat of war in the Persian Gulf and foreign reports suggesting that Israel has decided to absorb Iraq's possible first strike without taking preemptive action. Distribution was advanced by two months and ended a heated public debate. Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said Sunday it was originally planned to issue gas masks in December. Officials had feared an immediate distribution of gas masks could panic the Israelis or send Iraq an incorrect message that Israel planned an attack. The army sought to allay public concern, saying ``distribution of gas masks in no way whatsoever constitutes a change to an emergency status.'' ``The purpose . . . is to transfer the kits to citizens' homes to shorten the time of distribution, should a need arise.'' Army spokesman Brig. Gen . Nachman Shai maintained the distribution plan was developed long before the gulf crisis, and other officials say Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is unlikely to attack Israel, but that his actions are unpredictable. The spokesman said sealed gas mask kits will be distributed next week in three towns in the center of Israel, the Negev desert and the north. Starting Oct. 15, kits will be handed out at schools throughout Israel, beginning with cities and expanding to rural areas. Distribution announcements have gone to one-third of Israelis living in towns, Israel radio said. Shai estimated the overall distribution will take weeks. Shai said foreign residents also will get masks, and masks would be available for tourists at hotels. He expressed hope the army's decision would not deter foreigners from visiting. The spokesman said 140,000 Arabs living in the annexed east Jerusalem will be issued gas masks. He said purchase of the kits has begun for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, but they will have to pay the $100-plus cost because they are not covered by Israeli national insurance. Shai said the public will be ordered to keep the kits sealed under threat of legal punishment. Special sirens are supposed to sound a chemical attack warning, he said. Experts have said Israel could have little warning of attack. Zeev Eitan, a military analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffe Center for Strategic Studies, said Israel could get a six-minute early warning if it got immediate data from U.S. spy satellites. Debate about distributing gas masks began in April, when Saddam threatened to hit Israel with binary chemical weapons and ``make fire eat half of Israel'' in retaliation for an Israeli nuclear attack. Israel in 1981 bombed a nuclear reactor near Baghdad, saying Iraq was using it to develop weapons. Saddam's threats intensified after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Shai insisted, ``There is no urgency in the distribution now. We don't have any actual information stating, God forbid, that hostilities will start tonight or tomorrow or in a week or two.'' Still, signs of public anxiety emerged minutes after the army announcement. ``I never thought that would happen. When I heard it today, my first thought was, oh my God, this is not a joke,'' said Margo Iyoun, a 29-year-old immigrant from Orinda, Calif. ``Coming and living in Israel, that for me was an idealistic thing. But it's hard to leave anything on the level of idealism when you have a child.'' The only previous distribution of gas masks was experimental. It was conducted 1{ years ago in two towns and was declared successful after the army found the population kept the kits in good shape.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Scotus-Legal Fee,000
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to review a $1 million legal fee that the seller of a Louisiana television station was ordered to pay in a breach-of-contract case. The court said it will examine the power of federal judges to order such payments. The case stems from a 1983 agreement in which NASCO Inc., a Tennessee company, signed a contract to buy KPLC-TV in Lake Charles, La., for $18 million from G. Russell Chambers. NASCO later sued, accusing Chambers of breaking the contract. A federal judge ruled that Chambers acted in bad faith in conducting his defense in the suit and in 1989 ordered Chambers to pay about $1 million in legal fees to NASCO. The ruling was upheld in February by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. In his appeal to the Supreme Court, Chambers said Louisiana state law provided no basis for the attorney fee award. He said the award was unreasonable and violated his rights. The case is Chambers vs. NASCO, 90-256.
Eds: Please Disregard a0740, Scotus-Legal Fee. Material not intended for this circuit.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
New Nursing Home Requirements in Effect
DOC.TEXT: New requirements to improve the quality of nursing home care went into effect Monday, but nursing home owners say they will have trouble complying without adequate state funding or implementing regulations. The comprehensive nursing home reforms were passed by Congress in 1987, setting requirements for nursing homes to follow to participate in the Medicare and Medicaid programs. Those include provisions on quality of living conditions, access to social activities, accommodation of personal needs, assessments for health care services, protection of residents' personal funds and privacy. Other provisions require confidentiality of medical records, limitations on the use of physical and chemical restraints, choice of personal attending physicians and access to telephones. Some of the regulations to implement the new requirements are in place, but nursing home owners have complained that regulations for critical provisions of the law have not been issued. Gail Wilensky, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicare and Medicaid, said the majority of the regulations were in place and those that aren't yet final soon will be. ``States, consumer groups and nursing home industry groups have been consulted and have been fully informed of the new requirements as we have developed and issued guidelines, instructions and regulations during the past three years,'' she said. In a petition to the Department of Health and Human Services, the American Health Care Association said many states have not allocated adequate funds to implement the law. The association, representing 10,000 nursing homes, asked Wilensky's agency to issue regulatory guidance to the states outlining what actions the federal government will take to ensure that state plans are funded.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Nearly Doubles Price of a Big Mac
DOC.TEXT: Feasting on a Big Mac is going to take even a bigger bite out of Soviet wallets. McDonald's has nearly doubled the price of the two-patty hamburger in Moscow, where a meal at the restaurant has become ``practically unaffordable for the average Soviet citizen,'' the government newspaper Izvestia reported Monday. The price hike to 6.95 rubles - more than four hours' pay for the average Soviet worker - was attributed to the rising cost of meat, a newspaper reported Monday. The Oak Brook, Ill.-based fast-food chain has been serving more than 1 million customers a month in Moscow since the restuarant opened in January. Previously, a Big Mac cost 3.75 rubles. Restaurants in state hotels charge 2 to 3 rubles for an entree, while private restaurants may demand up to 50 rubles. The exchange rate for rubles varies greatly. In Chicago, near McDonald's headquarters, a Big Mac costs $1.95. Officials at McDonald's headquarters could not be reached for comment. The price-hike decision was made by the board of the joint Soviet-Canadian McDonald's venture after the Soviet government announced it was increasing prices for meat and other products this month, according to M. Tulupnikova, business manager of the Moscow McDonald's, the world's largest. The ingredients are produced locally at a $50 million factory built by McDonald's of Canada. The newspaper said the line at the restaurant wasn't noticably smaller Monday because of the price increase. During the summer, some customers waited up to 90 minutes to reach the counter. Last month, the official Tass news agency reported that ``it would be wrong to say that all Muscovites are satisfied with McDonald's.'' ``Some are deterred by high prices,'' it said. ``Visitors spend, on average, about 10 rubles in the shop. For many, this is much more than their daily pay.'' McDonald's plans to build 19 more restaurants in the Soviet capital.

DOC.HEAD: She Sells Sea Shells, So Why Not Gatorade?
DOC.TEXT: If she sells sea shells by the seashore, so will corporate America. Targeting Los Angeles County's big beachgoing crowd, advertisers are slapping their messages on trash barrels, phone booths, tide charts and county beach vehicles. The wave of ads could swell with a law passed last week in Sacramento that generally expands advertisers' access to the coast. ``It's not as if we're trying to sell every square inch of beach,'' said Dusty Brogan, who oversees marketing for the county's beaches. ``Everything has to be harmonious with the surroundings. We'd never permit something like free-standing billboards.'' The county is considering the sale of ad space on bicycle racks and benches to a swimwear maker and wants to post oversized thermometers, underwritten by advertisers, on lifeguard towers. Officials say the advertising will raise much-needed funds for the upkeep of 31 miles of Los Angeles County beach property. The beaches, which cost about $17 million to maintain and patrol, operate at an annual deficit of about $7 million. The county could eventually bring in up to $4 million in additional yearly revenue from various beach marketing programs, Brogan said. ``How else are we going to keep services up?'' she asked. ``Where do we go?'' The Board of Supervisors must approve each facet of the program. The ad expansion also is being closely watched by environmental groups. ``In Los Angeles, going to the beach is the closest many people come to a natural environment,'' said Peter Saundry, chairman of the Sierra Club's regional Clean Coastal Waters Task Force. ``It's of concern to us any time advertisers show up on the beach. But we realize the county is in a tricky situation,'' he said. ``Environmental groups like ours are pushing them to clean up the beaches, but those things do cost money.'' The new law, which goes into effect Jan. 1, broadens the authority of counties to sell ad space and license their property. Los Angeles County is considering licensing a clothing line similar to that worn by lifeguards. Companies that have tried beach ads include the maker of Gatorade sports drink, who paid the county $12,500 to place clocks featuring the Gatorade logo on 120 lifeguard towers this year. ``If the ad is relevant to what someone is doing, thinking or buying at the beach, it makes a lot of sense,'' said advertising executive Alan Pando, president of DDB Needham West. ``But it would be too bad if the beach ended up looking like NASCAR,'' he added, referring to the car racing circuit featuring autos plastered with sponsors' logos. Longtime lifeguard Larry Kraus is philosophical about the ad blitz. ``Look at all this graffiti,'' he said, pointing to a lifeguard tower at Venice Beach. ``On the scale of things that bother you at the beach, advertising is very low.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Criticize Administration on Jet Sale
DOC.TEXT: Five senators criticized the Bush administration Monday for refusing to give them documents on South Korea's plan to buy 120 F-A-18 jet fighters and components in a $4.7 billion deal. Democratic Sens. Alan Dixon of Illinois and Wendell Ford of Kentucky told reporters they plan to introduce legislation requiring President Bush to give House and Senate leaders documents related to the U.S.-South Korean deal worked out last year. ``To intelligently exercise our constitutional authority, we must be able to see and read the documents involved in this transaction with South Korea,'' the lawmakers said in a letter to their colleagues. Joining Dixon and Ford were Sens. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., and John Heinz, R-Pa. Under the arrangement, the South Koreans will buy 12 of the aircraft from U.S. production lines, will be provided with kits for 36 aircraft that will be assembled in Korea and have licensing agreements allowing 72 aircraft to be produced in Korea. The agreement has been a matter of dispute for some months in Congress, particularly among members who wanted more of the U.S.-produced aircraft to be included in the deal. But the arrangement also provides for modernizing South Korea's aging air fleet of F-4s and F-5s, and increases its military alignment with the U.S. forces. The primary contractor of the F-A-18 ``Hornet'' is McDonnell Douglas Corp. of St. Louis, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Peter Boyle in Fair Condition After Apparent ``Mild Stroke''
DOC.TEXT: Actor Peter Boyle was in fair condition at a hospital Monday after apparently suffering a mild stroke, hospital officials said. Boyle, 54, was expected to remain at the University of Utah Health Sciences Center for several days to undergo tests, hospital spokesman John Dwan said. Boyle was admitted to the hospital at Sunday after experiencing what a nursing supervisor described as ``mild weakness and a headache.'' ``It was a mild stroke,'' nursing supervisor Charlene Barrett said. ``His blood pressure was up, so we're giving him medicine for that.'' Boyle was in Salt Lake to film ``Rubin and Ed,'' a comedy produced by the British Working Title Productions, said Doug Lindeman, a Los Angeles-based spokesman for the company. Lindeman said Boyle and the rest of the company had been preparing to go to Hanksville, in southeastern Utah, to begin ``an intense stretch in the desert'' when Boyle became ill. Boyle was nominated for a 1989 Emmy as guest actor in the television drama series, ``Midnight Caller.'' His film credits include ``Young Frankenstein,'' ``Joe,'' ``Taxi Driver,'' ``F.I.S.T.,'' the ``Dream Team,'' and most recently, ``Speed Zone,'' opposite comedian John Candy.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Uses Turtle Power to Fight Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo's been called a lot of names in his political lifetime but on Monday he was given a bodacious new one: ``your honorable dudeship.'' The title was bestowed on him by a three-fingered, mutant amphibian named Michelangelo, one of the rock-singing Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The occasion was the start of the State Division of Substance Abuse's drug prevention program featuring the pizza-loving turtles at P.S. 33 in Manhattan. ``Anybody here know the Ninja Turtles?'' the governor asked a gymnasium filled with squealing first, second and third graders. The deafening, affirmative response prompted Cuomo to quip: ``Man, I hope they don't run for office.'' He then gave a high fived to turtle-member Donatello before the group performed their anti-drug song, ``Walk Straight.'' ``Hey, your honorable dudeship,'' Michelangelo said, looking around for Cuomo, ``we're gonna work together to beat this drug thing.'' The popular television turtles, who recently launched a singing career complete with a national tour and a show at Radio City, offered to help with the state's drug prevention campaign because ``they wanted to do something positive, give kids a positive message,'' said Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the Division of Substance Abuse. Cuomo said he personally thanked the turtles - Michelangelo, Leonardo, Donatello and Raphael - for their help. ``It's really a selfless thing for them to be doing this.'' Then the Italian-American governor added, ``And I love their names.''

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran President Proposes Truce With Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani on Monday proposed a cease-fire with leftist rebels in a bid to improve the atmosphere for peace talks. The truce would take effect as soon as the guerrillas declare a reciprocal cease-fire, Cristiani said in a speech to the General Assembly. ``Peace in El Salvador will not come out of the muzzle of any rifle,'' Cristiani said. ``There is no reason for war in El Salvador. We do not want war.'' The fifth round of U.N.-mediated peace talks between the government and rebels ended in a stalemate Sept. 18. Cristiani, who took office June 1989, also pledged to end abuses in the Salvadoran armed forces. The military has been linked to ``death squad'' activity against peasants and labor activists suspected of liberal or leftist tendencies, human rights observers say. A cease-fire arranged last year collapsed after several union halls were attacked and labor organizers were slain. The rebels blamed the killings on the government, and launched an offensive on the capital of San Salvador. Last November, during the height of the guerrilla attacks, men dressed in army uniforms killed six Jesuit priests who had criticized government policy. Their cook and her daughter were also slain. Cristiani said his government was not involved in the Jesuit slayings, but an army unit has been identified as being responsible. In late 1989, a U.N. human rights report said Cristiani's government presided over a ``resurgence of torture'' that included sexual abuse and beatings of prisoners, and executions of political opponents. The annual report by Jose Antonio Pastor Ridruejo, a special representative of the U.N. Commission on Human Rights, criticized both the government and leftist rebels. Pastor blamed the rebels for assassinating alleged collaborators with the armed forces, among others. Salvadoran authorities said the claims of torture were part of a campaign by the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Movement. The United States has heavily subsidized the Salvadoran government during the 11-year civil war, currently spending about $1 million daily in foreign and military aid. The U.S. Senate Appropriations Committee, however, is considering a bill to withhold half of the U.S. military aid to El Salvador for a year in retaliation for the slayings of the Jesuits and other abuses by the army.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Head to Moscow for Talks at Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis headed a delegation that will meet the Soviet leadership Tuesday to discuss the Baltic republic's drive for independence, it was reported Monday. Lithuania's prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, told a news conference Monday that she expected President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would take part in the talks, although he is not a member of the Soviet delegation, the Estonian News Service reported. The Soviet delegation will be headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, the Tass news agency reported. Neither side has called the forthcoming talks ``negotiations.'' The official Tass news agency referred to the session as a ``consultative meeting.'' Lithuania announced its independence March 11. It agreed to suspend the declaration in exchange for the lifting of an oil and natural gas embargo, which Gorbachev imposed on the republic in April, and start of negotiations with the national government.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Cuts Force Independence Park to Shut Down 8 Buildings
DOC.TEXT: A weekend budget agreement in Washington headed off federal spending slahes, but eight buildings at Independence National Historic Park closed Monday to save money anyway. ``We knew in March that we were looking at a possible shortfall in the range of $850,000,'' said Bernard Goodman, assistant park superintendent. ``We began reducing our hires of guides, substituting temporary workers who were hired through the month of September.'' The tight budget is expected to last through the fiscal year, so the buildings may not reopen until next October, Goodman said. Closed were Old City Hall, the home of the U.S. Supreme Court from 1791 to 1800; the reconstructed Graff House where Thomas Jefferson drafted the Declaration of Independence; the 2nd Bank of the U.S.; Pemberton House, which houses artifacts of the Army and Navy; New Hall, a museum dedicated to the Marine Corps; the Todd House, a refurnished Quaker home where Dolly Todd, better known as Dolly Madison from a later marriage, lived; and the Bishop White house, a refurnished historic house. Also, about 30 temporary guides were fired, according to Goodman. Goodman said more of the park's 19 historic buildings may be closed. He didn't say which ones. ``We chose this particular group because they are lesser-used buildings in the park,'' he said. ``We have decided that under no circumstances will we close Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell Pavilion or the Park Visitor Center.'' During 1989, Goodman said, attendance at the now-closed sites ranged from 12,869 at the Bishop White House to 140,036 at the 2nd Bank of the U.S. By contrast, more than 1,400,000 people visited the Liberty Bell pavilion last year, he said. A spokesman for the National Park Service said parks across the country are squeezed for funds and many can cut back on such things as lawn-mowing. The Philadelphia park doesn't have that flexibility, he said. Goodman said Monday's actions had nothing to do with the Graham-Rudman budget balancing law, which would have forced across-the-board cuts in federal spending and even more cutbacks here and at other parks. Those cuts were averted by the Sunday budget agreement in Washington, D.C. In Washington, park system spokesman Duncan Morrow said all of the national parks are acutely aware that government spending must be kept under control. The only difference is that the cutbacks at Independence National Historic Park may be ``a little more dramatic'' because about the only way to save is to close down buildings. ``Plenty of parks have to shorten hours at various facilities, close them on certain days a week or reduce their maintenance schedule,'' he said. ``But at Independence Hall, cutting back on maintenance is different from cutting back on lawn mowing at some of our other parks. When you cut back on maintaining a historic structure, it has a snowballing effect and the rate of decline accelerates rapidly - particulary in the face of heavy public use.''

DOC.HEAD: French Foreign Minister Shrugs Off Hostage Release
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas on Monday dismissed Iraq's release of nine French hostages as insignificant but suggested Baghdad may be softening its line in the gulf crisis. On Sunday, Saddam complimented President Francois Mitterrand for offering positive ideas to resolve the crisis and called for replacing the language of ``threats and warnings'' with dialogue. In an interview from the United Nations, Dumas told the French television network La Cinq: ``We are obliged to say that no gesture has yet come from Iraq that modifies the basic problems. We simply note a change in tone.'' But he added, ``This change in tone could be a prelude to a change in attitude. The coming days will show us.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced Monday he would free nine French hostages held at strategic locations throughout his country. ``It's good news that changes nothing,'' Dumas said. The official Iraqi News Agency reported that Hussein released the nine Frenchmen as part of a ``humanitarian gesture.'' In a speech to the United nations last week, Mitterrand suggested settling the conflict over Kuwait together with other regional problems. Dumas noted the positions of the French and American leaders ``are very close.'' Bush denounced Iraq on Monday for plundering Kuwait but suggested an Iraqi withdrawal could spur talks on Arabs' territorial grievances with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Sunny Weather Prevails Over Most of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Storms rumbled through the Southwest and parts of Florida on Monday, and showers were scattered over the Southeast and the Great Lakes region. Temperatures dipped into the 50s over the Great Lakes, the Pacific Northwest and northern New England. Widely scattered showers and storms swept over Florida on Monday afternoon, and showers were scattered over North Carolina, Michigan and northwest Texas. Skies were mostly clear over the rest of the nation. Strong winds prevailed over the Northwest behind a cold front pushing across Washington state and Oregon. A gale warning was in effect for the coast of Washington, with winds expected to reach 45 mph. A flash-flood watch was posted for much of central and southeastern Arizona as tropical moisture from what was once Hurricane Odile brought showers and thunderstorms to the Southwest. Heavier rainfall totals for the six-hours ending at 1 p.m. EDT Monday included an inch at Glendale, Ariz., and half an inch at Douglas, Ariz. Temperatures pushed into the 60s and 70s across most of the nation east of the Rockies, and highs in the 80s were confined to the Gulf coast. The low Monday for the Lower 48 was 28 degrees at Bismarck, N.D., and Jackson, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins: New Taxes for New Cops
DOC.TEXT: A Police Department report on how to deal with the city's crime wave is due on Mayor David Dinkins' desk, and officials said Monday the mayor will call for a tax on every paycheck earned in the city to help fund it. Under the fixed-rate tax, someone earning $50,000 a year would pay $50 in the first year and $75 in subsequent years, and employers would have to match their employees' payments, said a City Hall source, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Albany, Gov. Mario Cuomo was non-committal about whether the Legislature would approve the tax plan. ``We'll know quickly ... if there's any interest in doing it, because it's an election year,'' Cuomo said. Republican Sen. Nicholas A. Spano said he would try to organize opposition to the tax. ``At a time when suburbanites' property taxes are already a burden and their own municipal services are strained, it's unfair to expect them to pay for more of New York City's needs,'' he said. The Police Department report, due on the mayor's desk Monday night, is expected to shape the city's response to a flurry of violent, highly publicized street crimes. Dinkins said he would discuss the report with Police Commissioner Lee Brown on Tuesday, when he also is expected to announce plans to put 880 more police officers on subway duty. The additional transit police would patrol trains from 8 p.m. to 4 a.m., fulfilling one of Dinkins' campaign promises to put a cop on each train at night. Dinkins declined to comment on the number of extra police he wants or how he would pay for them, but agreed commuters should be taxed. ``They're (using) city services and of course I want them to pay for it,'' he said. Last week, the mayor said that other revenue options included a raise in real estate taxes and a 25-cent surcharge on $1 state lottery tickets sold in the city. It appears Dinkins wants the new payroll tax to cover half the initial cost of the new officers. All workers would be taxed at the same rate, no matter their income. The tax would start at one-tenth of 1 percent next July and jump by half a year later, the sources said. Brown was expected to recommend the hiring of 6,000 more officers and another 2,700 civilians to free officers from desk jobs. But the new officers won't be on the streets for months, and possibly years. The Police Academy can handle 2,600 students at one time by splitting classes into two shifts. It takes six months to train an officer.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Victors Suspend Their Rights in Germany
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The four victorious powers of World War II decided Monday to suspend their rights over Berlin and Germany, allowing the divided nation to become fully sovereign from the moment of reunification this week. Foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France signed a document suspending operation of the rights they have exercised in Germany since the war ended in 1945. The rights will formally terminate when all four powers have ratified a Sept. 12 Moscow treaty that paved the way for reunification Wednesday. ``Those strokes of a pen bring to an end an era of discord and division,'' said President Bush at the opening of a two-day, 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. ``We rejoice with the German people that their nation is united once more and we will soon welcome a united Germany into (the conference's) community of states,'' Bush said. The conference is an outgrowth of the 1975 Helsinki conference on European security that the nations intend to use as a framework for cooperation in the post-Cold War era. ``We are uniting in happiness and gratitude, not in nationalistic exhuberance,'' said West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. ``The dark chapters of our history are a cause for reflection ... on what was done in Germany's name. That will not be repeated.'' Genscher reaffirmed that a reunited Germany will make no territorial claims against its neighbors and will renounce use or possession of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. ``We commemorate all victims of the war and totalitarianism,'' he said, adding that Germans ``are conscious of our special responsibility in relation to the Jewish people,'' who were persecuted by Nazi Germany. The document, titled ``Declaration on the Suspension of Operation of Four-Power Rights and Responsibilities,'' makes Germany ``effectively sovereign from the moment of unification'' on Wednesday, said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The World War II victors ``declare that the effectiveness of their rights and responsibilities with regard to Berlin and Germany are suspended,'' the document said. It added that the suspension will run until the treaty itself comes into effect. The Moscow treaty, which must be ratified by the U.S. Congress and the Soviet, British and French legislative bodies, contains results of negotiations between the Soviet Union and the three Western allies on the future of Germany and Berlin. Monday's declaration was countersigned by the West and East German governments. East Germany ceases to exist Wednesday and becomes part of the Federal Republic of Germany, which has been the formal name for West Germany. Secretary of State James Baker was host of the signing ceremony here. East German Education and Science Minister Hans-Joachim Meyer signed for East Germany, one of the last acts in his government's existence. The other signers were Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. The signing ceremony took place without speeches before 300 journalists and diplomats. It was followed by applause and quick champagne toasts by the six ministers befoe they departed for the main conference.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Risks Suspension of U.N. Voting Rights over Dues Arrears
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who has praised the United Nations for its support of U.S. initiatives during the Persian Gulf crisis, promised on Monday to pay the $521.9 million in U.S. arrears to the U.N. budget. ``Some money from the United States will be necessary by the end of the year just to meet our daily operating expenses,'' U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said. U.N. officials said without the U.S. payment, they cannot meet the payroll in December. Undersecretary-General Ronald Spiers, the top-ranking American in the world body, recently warned that the United States could have its voting rights in the General Assembly suspended in the new year if it doesn't start to pay up. ``I am advised that the United States could be in that position Jan. 1 if no new payments are forthcoming,'' Spiers said. A State Department official refused to discuss the possibility, saying ``That is strictly hypothetical, and we don't comment on hypothetical situations.'' For years, however, the United States has come up with most of its annual dues in a lump sum in the last months of the year. Bush told the General Assembly on Monday, ``My administration is fully committed to supporting the United Nations, and to paying what we are obligated to pay by our commitment to the Charter.'' Congress and the Reagan administration began withholding part of the annual U.N. dues in the 1980s to goad the world body into trimming its budget and bureaucracy and reforming its budget process. By 1988, President Reagan announced his satisfaction with the United Nations' progress and recommended resumption of full funding. However, Congress has dawdled on payments.

DOC.HEAD: West African Force Attacks Rebels in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: Heavy fighting was reported on Monday after a West African task force, backed by Nigerian warplanes and heavy artillery, fired on Charles Taylor's rebel army. The force also began taking up positions around the Executive Mansion, where about 1,000 soldiers from the army of slain President Samuel Doe remain holed up. The firing signaled an end to a week-old truce, but that cease-fire had proved largely ineffective. Monday's action could force a quick conclusion to the fighting that has cut this capital city off from the outside world for three months. A second rebel faction, under Prince Johnson, has threatened to launch an all-out assault on Taylor's rebels and the remnants of Doe's army if the task force failed to intervene. The force - composed of more than 5,000 soldiers from Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Gambia - has come under criticism for failing to end the 9-month-old civil and tribal war that has killed at least 5,000 people here. Even a peace in Monrovia was not enforced. A new field commander was sent in last week. Under Nigerian Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro, tanks and armored cars from the five nations began moving throughout the city. Roadblocks were set up. The force's artillery opened fire on territory on the city's eastern edges held by Taylor. His fighters have fired on the regional force often, killing or wounding soldiers. Taylor says Nigerian jets also attacked his forces. Johnson on Sunday called the cease-fire a failure and demanded that the West African force act. He told reporters: ``If I do not see them out there, there will be trouble. I am ready to mount my missiles and attack the mansion. If they don't get them out, we will bomb the mansion. I am also ready to move against Charles Taylor, since aside from Doe, Taylor is my second target.'' Johnson killed Doe on Sept. 10 after taking the president prisoner in a surprise attack. Johnson supports the peace plan proposed by the Economic Community of West African States. It calls for an interim government to oversee elections restoring a civilian government. Taylor opposes a transitional government and has declared himself president. The move east by the task force also could be an effort to take the city's airfield, which could be used by Nigerian jets. A radio station used by Taylor to castigate the task force also is near the airport, and task force commanders would like to seize it.

DOC.HEAD: Gem of Sierra Celebrates Century as National Park
LaserPhoto XYOS1
DOC.TEXT: Rangers and tourists celebrated Yosemite's unique status as the granite gem of the Sierra on the park's 100th birthday Monday. A moment of silence recalling the tranquillity before humans came to Yosemite Valley highlighted a centennial ceremony in sun-drenched Sentinel Meadow. The silence was broken only by a blue jay's shrieks. ``Yosemite is not just for today; it is for the children and their children tomorrow,'' said Yosemite Indian Jay Johnson, reciting a traditional Miwok Indian blessing. Lee Stetson, who depicted naturalist John Muir during the ceremony, said ``wilderness is a necessity ... as fountains of life and fountains of people. If enough of us go among spirits of this wilderness, ... we need not despair.'' President Bush, restricted by the Middle East crisis, did not attend as expected, leaving it to other federal officials to depict the legacy of Yosemite in the majestic Sierra range. ``Given all the history relating to Yosemite and all of its controversies, still it's a marvelous place for the American public to see,'' Superintendent Michael Finley said in an interview. The history ranges from Muir's unswerving commitment to make Yosemite a national park in the late 1800s to lighting-caused fires that blackened 23,000 acres this summer, forcing an 11-day closure. Critics blame the National Park Service for failing to carry out a 1980 plan to remove most public facilities from the narrow valley, which is visited by 3.4 million people a year. Park Service Director James Ridenour said this summer that funds will be budgeted to relocate maintenance facilities. Another issue involves a concession contract with Yosemite Park & Curry Co., a subsidiary of the MCA entertainment conglomerate. An environmental group announced plans last week to take over the contract to run the park's hotels, restaurants and concession stands. The contract expires in 1993. Despite such issues, Finley said the Park Service has been a good steward of Yosemite and its famous features such as El Capitan, Half Dome and Yosemite Falls. ``We believe we've seen 100 years of preservation, and we're working hard to ensure that the next 100 years are even going to be better for the visitors and the park,'' Finley said. ``We've undertaken major programs for restoration of the ecology, reintroduced Bighorn sheep, recovered peregrine falcons - up to four nesting pairs at this point,'' he said. ``We're restoring trampled down meadows, replanting oak trees, have a major program to restore the Merced River and will undertake another program on the Tuolumne River and our lakes.'' No one would appear to know more of Yosemite's history than 87-year-old Carl Sharsmith, who has served as a naturalist in Tuolumne Meadows almost every summer for six decades. ``My duties are light,'' Sharsmith said. ``I get a group and go for a bit of a walk and chat along the way - three hours at the most.'' The park's centennial is attracting more attention in the area than did the historic formation of the park by Congress on Oct. 1, 1890. Back then, the weekly Mariposa Gazette, the closest community newspaper, put the story of Yosemite's beginning on page 2.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Views the Robert Mapplethorpe Photos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 17th graf, `He was one ...' to UPDATE with further testimony
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case Monday and jurors got their first look at the seven Robert Mapplethorpe photographs that resulted in obscenity charges against an art gallery and its director. The eight-member Hamilton County Municipal Court jury remained expressionless as the photographs were passed around. The Contemporary Arts Center and Director Dennis Barrie are on trial on misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. If convicted of both charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000 for conviction on both counts. The prosecution completed its case after questioning its third witness and entering the photographs into evidence. All of the witnesses were police officers. After prosecutors rested, Judge David Albanese rejected a defense request to dismiss the charges, and the defense began to present witnesses. The seven photographs were among 175 pictures in an exhibit called ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' The seven-week exhibit drew 80,000 people before it ended May 26. Five of the photographs show sexually graphic acts involving men, and two are of children whose genitals are exposed. Prosecutors contend all that is necessary for a conviction under Ohio obscenity law is to prove the photos were displayed. ``The bottom line is the pictures. We're not required to show contemporary community standards because the court determines that,'' prosecutor Frank Prouty said. The prosecution entered the photographs into evidence over defense lawyers' objections. They argued that the photos were being taken out of context and should be presented as part of the entire exhibit, as they were displayed. During questioning of the first defense witness, defense lawyer Marc Mezibov gave the photos to jurors to help them understand remarks by the woman who assembled the exhibit. Janet Kardon, former director of the University of Pennsylvania's Institute of Contemporary Art, testified that she worked closely with Mapplethorpe in choosing photographs for the exhibit. She said the 175 photos were culled from more than 2,000 and that each was chosen for its artistic merit. ``We looked for a body of work that has consistency - saying something that is important to say,'' Ms. Kardon said. She said she felt an urgency to put the exhibit together between April 1987 and December 1988 because Mapplethorpe was dying of AIDS. He died in Boston in March 1989 at age 42. ``He was one of the most important photographers working in the '80s. I felt it was my responsibility as a curator to work with him while he was alive,'' Ms. Kardon said. When asked by prosecutors to describe the artistic merit of four photos depicting sexually explicit acts, Ms. Kardon said they were artistically lighted and framed, and showed symmetry and use of horizontal and vertical lines. Jacquelynn Baas, director of the University of California's art museum, referred to texture and effectiveness of expression in describing the same photos. ``Robert Mapplethorpe was an artist who set out very consciously and with a great deal of courage to create a wide range of art. ... He very consciously explored what makes a work of art a very powerful experience,'' she said. Barrie's lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin, told jurors that the gallery director and its officers knew the exhibit would be controversial. But he said they believed the educational and cultural value outweighed other considerations and was consistent with the gallery's mission to display contemporary art. ``There was controversy, but there was only one intent and purpose ... to add to the cultural enhancement of the citizens of this city and this area,'' Sirkin said. ``It was brought here not to appeal to anyone's prurient interest,'' he said. ``It was brought here to teach and ... to show the world this brilliant photographer and some of the inner makings of that man and some of the torture that, perhaps, he suffered.''

DOC.HEAD: Love Canal Protesters Hold ``Mutant Pageant'' at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators staged a ``mutant pageant'' Monday, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the last evacuation of Love Canal, to protest resettlement of the neighborhood near the infamous dump. The demonstration attracted about two dozen environmental activists, some in costume to suggest the result of ruinous environmental policies. One woman dressed as a smiling face with only one eye. A multilegged ``mutant'' dubbed ``Miss Environmental Bonding'' was two women in one dress. The demonstration outside the Capitol included a blistering attack on Gov. Mario Cuomo, who is running for a third term this year and is considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential candidate. ``We are Governor Cuomo's walking, talking, living victims and potential victims of his bad policies,'' said Lois Gibbs, a former Love Canal resident who heads the Washington-based Citizens Clearinghouse for Hazardous Waste. One demonstrator serving as pageant judge dressed as a caricature of Cuomo, with fluorescent ping-pong balls coming out of his ears and a badge proclaiming him a ``part-time environmentalist.'' Among other things, the activists are fighting the state's effort to resettle part of Niagara Falls' Love Canal neighborhood, renamed ``Black Creek Village'' in an effort to attract potential home buyers. The activists also protested nuclear power and New York's effort to find a dump site for its low-level radioactive waste. Love Canal became a symbol of the nation's toxic waste problem in the late 1970s after about 2,500 people were forced to abandon their homes. They left when 22,000 tons of dioxin, PCBs and other hazardous chemicals dumped there 30 years earlier by the Hooker Chemical Co. were discovered to have spread through the neighborhood. The first evacuations were ordered in August 1978. Then-President Carter ordered the last round of evacuations on Oct. 2, 1980. The dump has been capped, but most of the chemicals are still buried under a fenced-off 70-acre mound. State officials insist the area planned for resettlement is no more contaminated than comparable neighborhoods in Niagara Falls. Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for Cuomo, said state Health Department studies were the only consideration in the Love Canal resettlement. ``Love Canal's resettlement was done exclusively on the scientific evidence, period,'' Conroy said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in Death of 26 Blacks in Train Massacre
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday announced the arrests of three black men in connection with a shooting rampage on a train that left 26 blacks dead and more than 100 injured. The statement by Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok did not name the men or say if they were associated to a particular political group. According to witnesses, men with guns and machetes randomly attacked black commuters on an evening train Sept. 13 heading from Johannesburg to the neighboring township of Soweto. The attack was one of the worst single incidents in the recent fighting in the townships around Johannesburg. About 800 blacks have died since early August. Most of the battles have been between the African National Congress and the rival Inkatha movement. But the ANC says it believes a ``third force,'' possibly tied to the security forces, has been orchestrating the violence. Also Monday, police said 11 blacks had been arrested in the killing of four whites in a black township. The four victims - three men and a woman - were stabbed and set ablaze Saturday evening after visiting a bar in Khutloanong, 150 miles southwest of Johannesburg, police said. The area has had several racial confrontations in recent months, but police have not said if Saturday's attack was racially motivated.

DOC.HEAD: Texas, California Dominate List ogf S&L Probes
DOC.TEXT: Texas and California savings and loans dominate a list of the top 100 federal thrift investigations by the Justice Department, a trade newspaper said Monday. Among the prominent S&Ls on the list are Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif., whose former owner, Charles H. Keatin Jr. has been jailed awaiting trial on criminal charges, National Mortgage News reported. Also listed are: -Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver, where Neil Bush, the president's son served as a director. -CenTrust Savings Bank, Miami, whose former chairman, David Paul, was a prominent Democratic campaign contributor. -Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Beverely Hills, Calif., which held the industry's largest junk bond portfolio and had extensive links with Michael Milken, once head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department. There were 36 Texas S&Ls on the list and 20 from California. Both states had liberal laws permitting S&Ls a wide range of investments not permitted most thrifts. Oklahoma and Illinois and eight institutions listed, Florida had six; Colorado, five, and Louisiana and New Jersey, four each. Nearly all of the thrifts already have been seized by the government. There are 116 institutions listed because in some cases several thrifts were part of one investigation. The weekly trade newspaper obtained a copy of the list, which has not been publicly released. It was compiled earlier this year by the Justice Department and the Office of Thrift Supervision as an aid to managing S&L probes.

DOC.HEAD: Opening Arguments Begin in Shawcross Trial
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer conceded Monday in opening arguments that his client killed the 10 women he is accused of murdering during the past two years. ``Only a fool would come up here and tell you that Mr. Shawcross did not commit some of these murders, or all of these murders,'' Thomas Cocuzzi told the Monroe County Court jury. Arthur J. Shawcross, 45, was arrested in January after state police found him near the body of one of the victims. During questioning, he told police he had killed the women during sexual encounters gone awry. ``One of the non-issues in this case is that Mr. Shawcross committed the acts that caused the deaths of these women,'' Cocuzzi said. ``But conduct alone does not constitute a crime. You must consider the context of the mental state of the accused.'' Cocuzzi said the defense will ask jurors to acquit Shawcross by reason of insanity. At the least, he said, the jury will be asked to reduce the charges from murder to manslaughter because he was emotionally disturbed at the time of the killings. Assistant County District Attorney Charles Siragusa said in his opening argument that Shawcross himself supplied police with their best evidence when he confessed. Most of the victims were prostitutes, he said. ``All were easy prey, easily approached, easily isolated, easily killed and easily disposed of,'' he said. Siragusa also said police found fibers on many of the victims' bodies that matched carpeting in cars used by Shawcross, as well as other evidence linking him to the killings. Judge Donald Wisner granted a request to impose an order prohibiting members of the district attorney's office and the offices of the defense lawyers from publicly discussing the case. The order does not extend to the defense lawyers themselves or to Siragusa, but does include District Attorney Howard Relin. Defense lawyers complained that comments Relin made last week to a newspaper about the insanity defense could affect the trial. When he was arrested, Shawcross was on parole after serving 15 years in prison for the 1972 strangling of an 8-year-old girl in Watertown, his hometown. Shawcross also confessed to killing a 10-year-old boy there. Shawcross' lawyers said during jury selection last week that there will be testimony that Shawcross was sexually abused as a child and had traumatic experiences in Vietnam. He faces a later trial in Wayne County for a November 1989 strangling.

DOC.HEAD: UCLA Math Program Cited For Asian Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department said Monday an investigation has proven that a graduate mathematics program at the University of California at Los Angeles discriminated against Asian Americans. Michael Williams, assistant secretary for civil rights, said a 30-month investigation found ``a statistical disparity in the rates of admission to the mathematics department on the basis of race'' and ``an inconsistency in how Asian and white applicants who received the same evaluation ratings were treated.'' There was ``insufficient evidence to show a nondiscriminatory basis for this pattern,'' said Williams. Seventy-five other departments were cleared of discrimination allegations, while eight departments were found to have inconclusive records, Williams said. The Office of Civil Rights also is investigating undergraduate admission practices at UCLA and at Harvard. As a result of the findings, Williams said UCLA must offer admission to five Asian-American students who had been ``discriminatorily denied admission.'' The university also must establish a uniform system of admission and improve recordkeeping ``to allow us to determine whether or not it is observing the civil rights laws.'' UCLA Chancellor Charles Young said the university will appeal the violation finding because te admissions processes, enrolling 15,000 students per year. A total of 2,000 student files were examined and dozens of interviews with students, faculty and administrators were conducted. The department said UCLA must maintain certain records on their admission decisions in eight other graduate programs, including the school of management, computer science department, electrical engineering department, philosophy department, biological chemistry department, school of public health and school of architecture and urban planning.

DOC.HEAD: News Report: 1,000 Egyptians Died in Iraq the Past 9 Months
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 1,000 Egyptian workers died in Iraq the past nine months, and evidence from those who had autopsies performed showed that 60 percent of the deaths were caused by bullet wounds and skull fractures, the government said. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa told the state newspaper Al-Ahram the dead were all men aged 19 to 44. Moussa's statement is set for publication Tuesday, but an advance copy of the report was obtained by The Associated Press. Moussa made his statement after submitting a report Monday to President Hosni Mubarak about the marked increase in the number of Egyptians dying in Iraq following Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. More than 1 million Egyptians - most of them imported workers - were in Iraq when it invaded Kuwait. Egypt has strongly opposed the invasion and has contributed thousands of troops to the multinational force sent to Saudi Arabia to defend against a possible Iraqi attack. There were reports before the invasion that some Iraqi soldiers returning home after the 1988 cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war attacked Egyptian workers in the belief the Egytians had taken their jobs. Moussa said 995 bodies of Egyptian workers arrived from Iraq the past nine months and autopsies by Egyptian doctors indicated 60 percent of the deaths were caused by assault. It was not immediately known how many autopsies were performed. He said recent Iraqi medical reports shipped with the bodies said the deaths resulted from bullet wounds or skull fracture, but did not indicated the circumstances that led to the violent deaths. Before the invasion, Moussa said, Iraqi medical reports mentioned only natural causes for the deaths. He said the number of deaths since the invasion has grown sharply, but there were no reliable detailed figures. He said the Egyptian foreign ministry has asked Iraq for detailed reports on the circumstances of the deaths and added that his ministry is questioning Egyptian workers returning from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Donates $3 Million for Research
With AM-Mapplethorp Trial
DOC.TEXT: The Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation said Monday it will donate 20 percent of its yearly gross revenues for the next three years to the American Foundation for AIDS Research. The foundation said the pledge could amount to $3 million and is the largest amount ever pledged by a single donor. ``Robert Mapplethorpe lives though his art and now also through his legacy to those who will put an end to the scourge of AIDS,'' said director Mathilde Krim. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS in March 1989. He was 42. The Mapplethorpe Foundation said the money would come primarily from the sale of Mapplethorpe's photography. Cincinnati's Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, are on trial on charges of pandering obscenity and using a child in nudity-related material because of seven photographs in the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista `Strike' Flops; Managua Normal
LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: A highly publicized strike called by the leftist Sandinista labor unions fizzled on Monday. Most people went to work and only minor incidents were reported. Tires burned at a few intersections, but drivers skirted them as traffic proceeded as usual for a Monday morning. A protest march called by the unions drew at most 500 people. Expecting a bigger turnout, the government had assigned about 2,500 police to the route. The only violence was the burning of the transmission tower of a pro-Sandinista radio station Sunday night. The strike was called to protest an austere economic recovery program by President Violeta Chamorro's government. It includes privatizing the broad state sector, trimming the public payroll and doing away with state subsidies to diminish the financial deficit. Those programs plus weekly devaluations of the Nicaraguan currency, the cordoba, have boosted inflation to about 80 percent a month. The government granted broad concessions Friday, hoping to head off strikes similar to those that crippled the nation in May and July. Labor leaders said the strike would take place anyway, although the government announced a suspension of layoffs, a food distribution program for peasants, a commission to supervise land distribution and a job bank. Pro-Sandinista newspapers ran exaggerated front-page headlines Monday promoting the strike call. ``The People To Defend Themselves'' trumpeted Barricada, official newspaper of the Sandinista Front. ``Neighborhoods On Fire!'' a headline read in El Nuevo Diario, with a second line below, ``Civic Protest Takes Off in Managua.'' However, ENABUS, the government bus depot, was the only site in Managua where Sandinista supporters were visible. Even there only a dozen militants showed up, all helping keep the fires going. ``Bums! Why don't you go to work!'' shouted a taxi driver at the supporters as they piled fresh tires on the pyres. ``I don't agree with this,'' carpenter Mario Mora, 61, said of the announced strike on his way to work at the state construction company Sovipe. ``Even an illiterate can understand that we can't behave like macho cats all the time. ``It's like Dona Violeta says. If we don't work, this country is going to go down the drain.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Mauritania Waging `Undeclared War' Against Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Mauritania's Arab-led security forces have stepped up a campaign of murder and torture against blacks in the northwest African nation, Amnesty International said in a report released Tuesday. Some of the victims were decapitated or their heads were crushed by stones, according to the London-based human rights organization. ``A year ago, we said the persecution of Mauritania's black community had reached a peak,'' the organization said. ``That appalling situation has now gone from bad to worse.''
