The conflict began with a 1989 border dispute between predominately Arab Mauritania and Senegal, a mostly black nation to the south. The two former French colonies are separted by the Senegal River. Amnesty said Mauritanian troops have abducted and killed hundreds of Mauritanian blacks and paraded through rural villages with the decapitated bodies of victims. About 19 percent of Mauritania's 1.9 million people are black. ``What is taking place in southern Mauritania is, in effect, an undeclared war in which one community is using the resources and power of the state against another,'' Amnesty said. In April 1989, two Sengalese goat herders who crossed the border were shot. Hundreds of Mauritanians and Senegalese were killed in the ensuing clashes and tensions escalated between Mauritania's black and Arab-Berber communities. Tens of thousands of blacks were expelled from Mauritania. The report said the government troops were backed by Haratine militia, composed of descendants of freed black slaves who share Arab-Berber culture. ``People are `disappearing' or being killed by government soldiers in the south every day,'' the report said. ``People taken by troops have had their heads crushed with heavy stones or cut off and paraded around village centers to intimidate others. Other have been shot dead simply for fishing while a curfew was in force,'' the report added. Amnesty said security forces have picked up hundreds of black villagers the past year and detained many without trial. Authorities have imposed curfews that vary in different areas. ``The security forces seem to have a free hand in abusing innocent villagers,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Stay Away From Classes As University Reopens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout that school was officially opened Monday, DELETES references to students rejecting a proposal to expand the board to 21 members in last graf
DOC.TEXT: Protesters at the University of the District of Columbia said they were successful in persuading most students to stay away from classes Monday, the sixth day of a demonstration called to oust the school's board of directors. Administrators opened the university for the first day since Wednesday, when several hundred students barricaded themselves inside a campus building and refused to leave until the 11 mayoral appointees to the 15-member board resigned. All buildings except the one occupied by the students were reopened. But instructors were seen conducting classes with fewer than 10 students each. Some students who arrived on campus Monday said they showed up even though they were not sure whether classes would be held. ``As far as we are concerned, school is still closed,'' student Mark Thompson, a leader of the protest, told about 500 students who were on campus Monday morning. Trustees and students have reached agreement on nearly all of about 40 demands submitted by students. Talks have stalemated on the issue of the resignations, with most board members refusing to quit. ``It would not appear to be in the best interests of the university for them to quit,'' UDC spokesman John Britton said. ``We want to reiterate that the resignations are still on the table and it is ludicrous for them not to do what we've asked them to,'' Thompson said. Two trustees have agreed to resign, but for personal reasons, not because of the protest, Britton said. Trustee Lourdes Miranda submitted her resignation three weeks ago, and Trustee Arthur Reynolds has verbally agreed to resign, he said. Thompson said Trustee Herbert O. Reid has agreed to quit because of illness, but Britton said the school had not received a letter of resignation from him. Trustee Nira Long has agreed to step down as board chairwoman, but has refused to resign.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Sold 2 Live Crew Record Goes to Trial
DOC.TEXT: An all-white jury on Monday began hearing the trial of a record store owner who is charged with selling a 2 Live Crew album to an undercover officer after a judge had ruled it obscene. The trial is the first time the black rap group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has faced scrutiny in criminal court. Charles Freeman was arrested in his E-C Records store by six undercover Broward Sheriff's deputies on June 8. The arrest came two days after U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez said the Miami-based group's album was obscene. The lyrics include sexually explicit language and have been criticized as promoting violence against women. Using Gonzalez' ruling, prosecutors say they have a strong case before Broward County Judge Paul Backman. ``When you have listened to (the album), you will know that it is openly offensive to an average person,'' Leslie Robson, Broward assistant state attorney, told the jury in her opening statement. If convicted of selling obscene material, 31-year-old Freeman faces up to one year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Freeman, who is black, said before the panel was chosen that he would be comfortable if other blacks were selected. But he declined to comment about the jury's racial makeup after its selection. His attorney, Bruce Rogow, who also represents 2 Live Crew, said the defense was surprised that of a pool of about 35 potential jurors, only one was black. Rogow said he was confident that if the defense's arguments are clearly presented, ``whatever kind of jury we have will come back with the right answer.'' The defense, which will present its case after the state rests Tuesday, will argue the album does not appeal to anyone's prurient interests and that it has literary and artistic value, Rogow said. ``They may be strong words, words that are not used in everyday conversation but they are spliced together into ways that are imaginative and creative,'' said Rogow. ``The mistake here is to only hear the nasty words. You have to listen to the whole record.'' Although Backman refused to allow a transcript of the ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' lyrics presented in court, he did allow the album to be played Monday. The judge also has forbidden prosecutors from referring to Gonzalez' ruling. The federal judge ruled that the album violated community obscenity standards in three south Florida counties. Backman said that since Freeman was arrested for selling the record to an adult, prosecutors will not be allowed to discuss any possible impact on juveniles. First Amendment experts are monitoring the case, and that of the 2 Live Crew members who were arrested after performing live versions of the banned lyrics at a nightspot in nearby Hollywood. Their trial is scheduled to begin Oct. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake Rattles Homer
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the Kenai Peninsula on Monday but no damage or injuries were reported, according to the Tsunami Warning Center here. The quake was centered 30 miles north of Homer, about 90 miles southwest of Anchorage, and struck at 2:23 p.m. It registered magnitude 3.8 on the Richter scale. A quake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage in populated areas, while a quake of magnitude 4 can cause moderate damage. ``It was felt sharply in Homer for a few seconds,'' said geophysicist Bob Hammond at the center.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Bombed DEA Office Gets Life in Prison Without Parole
DOC.TEXT: A man who bombed a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office was sentenced Monday to life imprisonment without possibility of parole. Jeffrey Matthews, also known as Jeffrey Ciganek, had entered a guilty plea July 31 to federal charges including the March 17 bombing that leveled the DEA office in Fort Myers and homicide in furtherance of a criminal enterprise. U.S. District Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich also sentenced Matthews, 23, for running a criminal enterprise and possession with intent to distribute more than 11 pounds of cocaine. The judge also sentenced Matthew's uncle, Kenneth Bird Sr., to 70 months in prison for possession with intent to distribute more than 11 pounds of cocaine. Bird also had pleaded guilty. The case stemmed from an investigation of the drug-related slaying of a federal witness and the activities of Matthews' drug trafficking organization in Fort Myers Beach, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office. In his plea, Matthews admitted to killing witness Steven Franken in January to further his cocaine-trafficking. Matthews' brother, John Ciganek, along with Kelly Susskind are scheduled to be sentenced Dec. 17 for conspiracy to possess and distribute cocaine. Agents say John Ciganek and Susskind, who pleaded guilty last month to the charges, conspired with Matthews and Bird. The bombing of the DEA office came two days after federal drug indictments were issued against the four. Matthews was the only person charged in the bombing, which caused damages estimated at $4 million. No one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: 17 Soldiers, Shining Path Rebels Killed in Jungle Clash
DOC.TEXT: A clash in the coca-rich Upper Huallaga River Valley has left 15 Maoist Shining Path guerrillas and two soldiers dead, the army said Monday. The battle Friday was the latest in fighting that has left at least 70 dead on both sides in the region the past week. In the central Andes, Shining Path rebels killed six members of a local peasant defense unit 155 miles northeast of Huancayo, police said Monday. Huancayo is a major central Andean city 120 miles east of Lima. In Lima, meanwhile, the newspaper Expreso reported Monday that the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement had offered to lay down its arms. The jungle ambush came two days after President Alberto Fujimori rejected $36 million in U.S. military aid for Peru's armed forces to fight drug trafficking. Fujimori had criticized the proposed military aid package, saying military repression alone will not put an end to the coca trade in the Upper Huallaga region. Hundreds of thousands of peasants grow coca in the valley. Fujimori says economic aid is needed to develop the area and wean farmers from coca. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration already operates an airbase jointly with Peruvian police in the Huallaga Valley. In Lima, Tupac Amaru leader Victor Polay, who escaped from prison in July, offered to halt attacks if the government accepted certain conditions, the newspaper Expreso reported. A man identifying himself as Polay called the newspaper and said he he had made the offer in an interview with Interior Minister Gen. Adolfo Alvarado. An Interior Ministry spokesman had no comment on the news report. The Tupac Amaru group, which began operations in 1984, is a smaller and less dangerous band than the Shining Path. Nearly 20,000 people have died in the 10 years since the Shining Path took up arms. The majority of the victims have been civilians caught in the crossfire between the rebels and the armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: 10 People Reported Wounded in Lebanese Clash
DOC.TEXT: A Lebanese radio report said at least 10 people were wounded Monday night by gunfire from troops loyal to rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun at a checkpoint at the Death River in east Beirut. The broadcast by Voice of Free Lebanon, outlet for the rival Lebanese Forces militia, was monitored in Nicosia. It said some victims were taken to two hospitals after gunfire erupted in the Christian enclave north of Beirut, but others lay where they fell. The radio quoted the Lebanese Red Cross as saying the area was full of land mines and too dangerous for ambulances at night. Neither Aoun's forces nor authorities in Beirut could be contacted immediately for comment on the report. The checkpoint area is less than 1 mile from the northern edge of Christian east Beirut. The radio claimed that pro-Aoun troops, manning a roadblock on the crossing, let almost 150 people cross, then opened fire from behind to make it appear the shooting came from a rival checkpoint manned by the Lebanese Forces. Aoun refuses to recognize the government of President Elias Hrawi. He has been increasingly pressured by an economic blockade imposed by Hrawi's army. The maverick general has accused Hrawi's government of seeking Syrian army support to attack the enclave held by Aoun's 15,000 troops in parts of east Beirut and the adjoining mountains in the Christian heartland. Newspaper reports said Hrawi would order a military thrust to evict Aoun from the Presidential Palace if the blockade against his 60-square-mile enclave fails.

DOC.HEAD: Bentsen Acknowledges Tax Was at His Insistence
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, acknowledged Monday that the home heating oil tax of 2 cents per gallon in the budget deal between the White House and Congress was included at his urging to spread the pain of tax increases to the Northeast. Bentsen, who chairs the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, said he objected to home heating oil being left out of the agreement just before it was struck Sunday. ``It's a question of equity, of ensuring that all regions of this country bear a fair share of the burden of reducing the federal deficit,'' Bentsen said. Residents of the South and West will have to shoulder a greater burden through the increase in taxes on gasoline amounting to 12 cents per gallon eventually, 2 cents from a general fuels tax and 10 cents specifically levied on gasoline. ``Symbolically it is important to send a signal that the different regions of the United States will all carry a fair share of this burden,'' Bentsen said. The inclusion of the tax was done so close to the announcement of the agreement by President Bush on Sunday that it stunned Rep. Silvio Conte, a Massachusetts Republican who opposed it in the budget talks. It caught Senate Finance Committee staffers by surprise. They told told reporters heating oil had been exempted from the fuel tax. ``When I went into the White House, it was not taxed,'' Conte said on Sunday. ``When I left, it was taxed.'' The Northeast is not the only cold region of the country in winter by any means, but it is the one where oil dominates the home heating market. Conte said Monday he was furious at the last-minute change and was trying to get Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who selected Bentsen as his vice presidential running mate in 1988, to lobby the Texas senator. He used unusually harsh language in criticizing Bentsen. ``It was real affront to his running mate Mr. Dukakis,'' Conte said of Bentsen's move. ``He spat at him. He spat at (New York Gov. Mario) Cuomo. He just better not come up to the Northeast; there's a bounty on that guy.'' Both Conte and Bentsen were participants in the budget summit. Bentsen said home heating oil was in the tax provisions Saturday but on Sunday it was gone. ``When I learned Sunday morning that, in a midnight deal, home heating oil had been totally exempted from any tax at all, I protested in the strongest possible terms,'' Bentsen said. A typical New England household used 736 gallons of home heating oil in the winter of 1987, the latest for which figures are available, said Tom Welch of the Energy Information Administration. The increased tax would add $14.72 to the cost of that much fuel oil. In 1988, average gasoline consumption per household was 917 gallons in the Northeast, 1,016 gallons in the Midwest, and 1,046 gallons in the South and West, Welch said. Based on those figures, the average driver in the Northeast would pay $110.04 more each year with the gasoline tax increase. A Midwest driver would pay $121.92 more while one in the West or South would pay $125.52 more. The tax on home heating oil is expected to yield the government $200 million over five years. The gasoline tax is expected to bring in $45 billion in that period. Both fuels have seen sharp price run-ups since the Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Speech Postponed Following Bush's Address
With AM-Bush-UN
DOC.TEXT: Iraq unexpectedly postponed its speech to the General Assembly on Monday, just hours after President Bush hinted an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could help resolve Arab-Israeli tensions. Iraq's U.N. Mission gave no explanation for rescheduling the address to Wednesday, but diplomats speculated Baghdad wanted time to evaluate Bush's message. Earlier Monday, Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari praised Bush for saying he preferred ``a diplomatic outcome.'' In his speech, Bush said Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait could create ``opportunities for Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' Bush, in the speech and in a later news conference, did not elaborate on what settlements could be possible. The United States has long been committed to a Mideast settlement in which Israel would exchange territory for Arab recognition of its right to exist. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has suggested he would pull his troops out if the Arab dispute with Israel is handled simultaneously. On Sunday, Saddam announced he wanted to pursue dialogue toward a ``reasonable solution, and that this solution should be comprehensive so that we could enjoy peace.'' Saddam also said Palestinians should be given a homeland that ``occupation armies'' must leave the region. ``We do support any peaceful settlement of the situation, or of the crisis,'' said al-Anbari, who is scheduled to give Iraq's U.N. speech. ``Fortunately, he did mention he would prefer to have a peaceful diplomatic solution.'' The tone of Bush's remarks echoed French President Francois Mitterrand's speech to open the 45th General Assembly on Sept. 24. ``If Iraq were to withdraw its troops and free hostages, everything may be possible,'' said Mitterrand. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: New Yorkers Endure Near Gridlock as World Leaders Depart City
With AM-Bush-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 70 world leaders prepared to leave the city Monday after the historic Childrens Summit, not soon enough for New Yorkers who leaned on car horns because of chaotic traffic conditions all around the town. Streets around the United Nations and the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the President and Barbara Bush were staying, were blocked off at various times during the day, leading to near-gridlock in many areas and frustrated drivers. ``Traffic is a nightmare,'' said Martin Furillo, 26, who said he jumped out of a friend's car coming out of the Holland Tunnel because the traffic was at a standstill. ``It was backed up forever.'' Miles uptown, several blocks around the Waldorf were blocked off by police when Bush left for the Jacob Javits Convention Center to address the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe on Monday afternoon. ``Traffic is basically gridlock all over,'' said Tom Lodato, an inspector with the Department of Transportation's Traffic Major Incident Response Team. Crowds of irritated pedestrians were forced to congregate for more than five minutes at the intersections of Park Avenue and East 50th Street near the Waldorf as hundreds of police officers and Secret Service agents guarded the t. Transportation officials were relieved Sunday when the predicted traffic nightmare never materialized.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers in Washington, New York Reach Tentative Agreements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6 through 10, `The pact ...' with 9 grafs to UPDATE with approval in NYC and Washington state; picks up 11th graf, `In New ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Temple Strike
DOC.TEXT: New York City's 85,000-member teachers' union reached a tentative agreement Monday hours after its contract ended, and negotiators in Washington state agreed to settle the nation's longest strike of the school year. A strike by public school teachers in New Orleans entered its third week after union negotiators rejected what Orleans Parish School Board officials said was a $13 million contract. In New York, the city and its teachers' union reached a tentative agreement on a $236 million contract that would raise salaries 5.5 percent, both sides said. The pact was limited to one year because of the rocky economy. ``To enter into a multi-year contract without some concept of your ability to fund it doesn't seem to be wise,'' Mayor David Dinkins said. ``We're fortunate everybody sort of understood that.'' The raise would bring starting salaries to $26,375 and senior salaries to $52,750. The old contract, covering 65,000 public school teachers and 20,000 other school employees, expired at midnight. School was in session Monday. The pact went to the United Federation of Teachers' 3,000-member delegate assembly, which voted overwhelmingly Monday to recommend it to the full membership. Voting by the membership could three weeks. About 80 percent of the delegates backed the new contract in a voice vote, said union spokeswoman Susan Amlung. ``It was a very strong vote, but I don't think anyone is really content,'' said Amlung. ``The feeling is that the city went as far as it was reasonably expected to go, given the financial situation. It was clearly a compromise.'' She said the teachers had been seeking a raise of at least 8 percent. The new contract will cover employees of about 1,000 elementary, junior high and high schools that serve about 946,000 students. The 20,000 employees who are not teachers include counselors, social workers and secretaries. In Everett, Wash., where 460 teachers have been on strike since Aug. 30, negotiators assisted by three state mediators reached a tentative agreement after talking through the night, said Washington Education Association spokesman John Cahill. The proposal was ratified on a voice vote Monday evening by teachers in the Mukilteo School District, but contract details were not immediately disclosed. Classes were set to start Wednesday for the 9,100 students. ``We are especially pleased for the children. It's been a long month out of school,'' said Schools Superintendent James Shoemake. Classes were to have started Sept. 5. Key issues included class size, teacher assignment and transfer policies, school decision-making panels and pay for extra time, responsibility and incentives. In New Orleans, about 3,000 of the city's 4,500 teachers are on strike, which disrupted classes for 84,000 students. Board president Dr. Carl Robinson said there was little else the financially strapped school system could do to meet the demands of the United Teachers of New Orleans and its president, Nat La Cour. ``We stepped over backwards to do what we've done, and his response was to ask for more money,'' Robinson said. LaCour said the offer was unacceptable because it did nothing to raise teacher salaries this year.

DOC.HEAD: Owners Of House Where Family Slain In Celebrated Case Call Off Tours
DOC.TEXT: The owner of the home where four members of the Herb Clutter family were slain in a celebrated 1959 murder case has changed his mind about offering tours. For years the house near this southwestern Kansas community has attracted gawkers who ignored the ``no trespassing'' signs posted by owner Leonard Mader, who lives in the house. Finally, Mader decided to capitalize on interest in the death house and began offering tours on weekends, at $5 per person. But after about a month, Mader has concluded it was a bad idea. ``We just got too many phone calls, too many complaints,'' he said. The house was the scene of the murders of Clutter, his wife, Bonnie, and their children, Nancy, 16, and Kenyon, 15. They were slain by Richard Smith and Perry Hickock, who were convicted of murder and hanged in 1965. That year author Truman Capote published his book about the case, ``In Cold Blood,'' which was later made into a movie.

DOC.HEAD: House Sends Decoder Provision to President
DOC.TEXT: New television sets with 13-inch screens or larger would have to include built-in decoders for displaying closed captions for the deaf under a bill approved Monday by the House and sent to President Bush. On a voice vote the House approved a measure passed by the Senate in July requiring TV sets sold after July 1993 to be equipped with circuitry for converting audio portions of a TV program into subtitles on the screen. Decoders are available now but they sell for $160 to $200 separately. The House Energy and Commerce Committee estimated that decoder chips could be included in sets when manufactured without adding more than $15 to the retail price. ``For a small cost ... we can ensure that the promise of the Information Age is accessible to all Americans,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the committee's telecommunications and finance subcommittee. In addition to the estimated 20 million to 24 million Americans who are deaf or hearing impaired, Markey said the decoders also would benefit millions of children and functionally illiterate adults in learning to read as wells as immigrants trying to learn English. All prime-time television shows broadcast by the three major networks now carry closed captions, as do most national news shows and sports events.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Two Hurt in Suspected Gas Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A explosion believed caused by a gas leak leveled a townhouse Monday, killing an elderly woman, injuring two people in nearby houses and scattering debris over a wide area, authorities said. Firefighters found the body of Marian Wilderson under a stove in her kitchen, said Fire Capt. Pat Flynn. Wilderson was in her 70s, he said. The blast flattened her house, tore away large chunks of another house and blew a hole in the wall of third house. The explosion rattled windows blocks away. Samuel Bianco, 74, and Kathleen Billnyre, 70, were treated in hospital for cuts, officials said. Beams, roofing slate and glass from Wilderson's brick house, as well as pieces of furniture and clothing, were strewn around the neighborhood. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known, but a gas leak was suspected, said Peggy Mulloy, spokeswoman for Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. More than 50 homes were evacuated while utility crews tried to shut off the gas. The utility said it received a call about a strong odor in the neighborhood at 9:51 a.m. The explosion occurred about 10 minutes later while a crew was on its way to investigate, said spokesman Art Slusark. ``It just sounded like a great big boom,'' said Ernest Ennels, who lives five blocks away. ``I thought it was right next door.''

DOC.HEAD: Louisville Publisher Named Vice President of Gannett's Metro Group
DOC.TEXT: George N. Gill, president and publisher of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky., has been named a vice president of the Metro Newspaper Group of Gannett Co., it was announced Monday. Gill will have responsibility for Gannett newspapers in Nashville and Des Moines. He will continue his full responsibilities at the Louisville newspaper, the company said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Father, Son Get Prison Terms in Gun-Smuggling Case
DOC.TEXT: A retired Philippine Supreme Court Justice and his son were sentenced Monday to a year in prison for trying to smuggle hundreds of guns into their homeland. Antonio Paredes, 65, of Long Beach, and Quintin Paredes III, 42, of the Philippines, also were fined $6,000 each by U.S. District Judge A. Wallace Tashima. Antonio Paredes is the former vice governor of Abra province. His son was a lawyer in Manila. The men pleaded guilty in August to exporting guns without permits. They were charged in an attempt to smuggle 371 pistols and 500,000 rounds of ammunition into the Philippines. The shipment included 299 low-quality Targa brand handguns and 72 higher quality Colt .45-caliber semiautomatic pistols. Assistant U.S. Attorney Carol Gillam said authorities were investigating allegations the guns were intended for opponents of Philippine President Corazon Aquino. Defense attorney Ronald Litt dimissed the allegations. He said the motive was profit, arguing that a weapon that might sell for as little as $30 in the United States could bring $800 in the Philippines. He said the guns had little military value. Kerwin Hang, 42, and his wife, Maria Louisa Tan Hang, 34, both of the Philippines, also have pleaded guilty in the case. Maria Hang was sentenced last month to nine months in prison. Her husband received six months.

DOC.HEAD: Cristiani Tells Bush He Will Pursue Killers of Priests
DOC.TEXT: The president of El Salvador assured President Bush on Monday that he will pursue the murder investigation of six Jesuit priests and two others ``to the end,'' a U.S. official said. Bush met with Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani during his string of one-on-one meetings with world leaders attending a United Nations session. Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for Latin American affairs, told reporters Bush noted the importance of the case for U.S.-Salvadoran relations and said he supported Cristiani's efforts. The priests, their housekeeper and her daughter were shot to death last November. Eight military officers have been charged with the crime, but none has been brought to trial. Aronson quoted Cristiani as saying he would ``push the murder investigation ... until the end.'' This is the same message that Cristiani has been giving members of Congress in a lobbying effort aimed at heading off deep cuts in U.S. aid The judge in the case, according to Aronson's account of Cristiani's conversation with Bush, is more optimistic about a resolution of the case since members of the military high command visited him to promise cooperation in the investigation. He quoted the Salvadoran leader as saying he was concerned that the rebels in his country were waiting to see what Congress did about aid before agreeing to a cease-fire. The House already has voted a 50 percent reduction in the $85 million in annual military aid. The Bush administration is trying to keep the Senate from going along. Cristiani has he would accept the cut if Congress made it contingent on the rebels signing a cease-fire.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Bodies Recovered From Wreckage of Vintage Plane
DOC.TEXT: Divers recovered the remains of a seventh person Monday and searched for a possible eighth victim of the crash of a World War II plane that intruded on an air show and performed stunts before plunging into a lake. No one survived the crash of the Lockheed P2V Harpoon, which went down nose-first in six feet of water Saturday. Divers pulling pieces of the Navy patrol plane out of the murky water found the remains of a seventh victim and were looking for another body Monday because the aircraft could seat eight, the Sheriff's Department said. The plane had intruded on a seaplane air show, staging an aerobatics display before crashing into Clear Lake, 100 miles north of San Francisco. Pilots and spectators said the plane made four low passes over the crowd and floating seaplanes, then stalled and plunged into the lake, sending up a plume of water 60 to 70 feet high. Aviation officials said a heavy load of fuel and passengers combined with high temperatures may have caused the stall. The identities of those aboard were not immediately released, although officials said Doug Lacey, 40, of San Rafael, the plane's owner, was at the controls when the aircraft stopped to refuel Saturday morning in Santa Rosa.

DOC.HEAD: China Celebrates 41st National Day
DOC.TEXT: Chinese attended sports events and viewed floral displays on the site of last year's savage crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators as part of National Day celebrations Monday. The holiday, marking the 1949 birth of the People's Republic of China, was extended this year because it fell just two days before the traditional autumn moon festival, a time for family reunions. Tens of thousands took advantage of the day off from work to visit the 11th annual Asian Games under way in Beijing. The Olympic-style event features athletes from 36 nations this year. In Tiananmen Square, where hundreds of pro-democracy activists died when stormed by troops in June 1989, more than 100,000 potted plants were arranged in a dozen floral arrangements - including one depicted Pan-Pan, the panda mascot for the Asian Games. ``I've lived in Beijing for 36 years now, (and) come to see the flowers every year. They get prettier every year,'' official reports quoted Zhang Shuyu, an old woman from the captial's Qianmen district. Last year, the government held an elaborate evening ceremony in the square with fireworks, a 28-gun salute and performances by thousands of dancers. Such events are held only once every five years. But in Hong Kong on Monday, vandals doused two stone lions outside a Bank of China building with black paint in an apparent protest of the 41st National Day, celebrating the defeat of the Nationalist government. Last year, vandals splashed red paint on the lions. The acts were widely regarded as a protest over the Tiananmen Square crackdown. Hong Kong, under British administration, is scheduled to return to China in 1997. Stores and shops will be closed in China until Wednesday. On Sunday night, Premier Li Peng toasted the party's 41-year rule at an annual reception for foreign diplomats. The Communist Party turned ``an impoverished, backward old Chian which was subjected to the bullying and enslavement by colonialism and imperialism, into a socialist new China with initial prosperity,'' Li said. The premier's National Day toast serves as an abridged state-of-the-nation address, summarizing China's political and economic situation and the basic domestic and foreign policies. This year's toast contained no surprises, reaffirming the government's determination to maintain a planned economy.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Assails Iraq, Sounds Conciliatory Note; Israel Issues Gas Masks
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Thatcher comment, gold drops, U.S. to pay U.N. dues, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush assailed Iraq on Monday for invading Kuwait, but hinted an Iraqi withdrawal could lead to settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Israel warned its response to an Iraqi attack would be ``harsh and painful,'' and said it was giving out gas masks to all citizens. America announced it was sending two batteries of Patriot air-defense missiles to Israel to help defend against an increased threat from ballistic missiles in Iraq. In Baghdad, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered the release of nine French nationals believed to have been held at Iraqi targets as shields against attack - his second conciliatory gesture in two days. On Sunday, he urged a peaceful international dialogue, and mentioned France as a possible negotiating partner. U.S., French and British officials said Monday they wouldn't talk until Iraq withdrew from Kuwait. Also Monday, Iran's official news agency said the foreign ministers of Iran and Saudi Arabia met Sunday in New York for the first such high-level talks since the nations broke diplomatic ties 2{ years ago. No progress was reported, but the meeting was the most positive sign yet the two countries may be moving toward a rapprochement. A reconciliation would help draw Iran into the anti-Iraq camp and intensify Saddam's isolation. Saddam has been courting Iran, its war enemy from 1980-88, for help in puncturing the U.N. economic embargo imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. In other developments: -Oil prices tumbled $3 per barrel to $36.10 following Bush's speech at the United Nations, which was seen as raising hopes of a diplomatic solution to the 2-month-old crisis. As oil fell, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 63 points to 2,515.84. Gold prices fell $15.90 an ounce, to $386.60, on the New York Commodity Exchange. -Saddam addressed a message to participants in a U.N. summit on children, telling them U.N. sanctions are depriving Iraqi children of milk and food - ``a matter of deep concern and regret.'' -Iraq denied responsiblity for a grenade attack Thursday on a Djibouti cafe in which a French child was killed. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said France would retaliate if Iraq was found responsible. -Britain announced it is sending a 3,500-strong support force, including a 400-bed field hospital, to the gulf to back up an armored brigade, the Desert Rats. In his address to the General Assembly, Bush echoed his previous harsh line against Iraq but tempered it with talk of a diplomatic solution. Iraq ``has plundered Kuwait, terrorized innocent civilians and held even diplomats hostage,'' Bush said. Aligning himself with remarks last week by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, Bush said Iraq and its leaders ``must be held liable for these crimes of abuse and destruction.'' A British U.N. briefing quoted Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as saying on a talk show Monday, ``You can't go in and cause all that damage and desolation and damage to life . . . without expecting to have to pay some compensation. . . . Nor can you go and have your soldiers do some of the things that have been done without expecting them to be brought before the court and be answerable for their terrible deeds.'' In Bush's demand for unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, he suggested this could lead to a resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``In the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe that there may be opportunities,'' he said. ``For Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' The Bush administration has rejected Saddam's attempts to link his pullout from Kuwait with a simultaneous Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Bush, who has praised the United Nations for its handling of the crisis, also promised to pay the $521.9 million in U.S. arrears to the U.N. budget. Shevardnadze called Bush's speech ``brilliant.'' Iraq's ambassador said his government ``disagreed with everything,'' but took positive note of Bush's mentioning a desire for a peaceful solution. A spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he did not see Bush's speech as linking the gulf crisis to Israel's conflict with the Arabs. ``I don't think that is a linkage,'' Avi Pazner said. ``He said similar things before.'' The Israeli army announced it will begin distributing gas masks next week to all its 4.7 million citizens, including Jews and Israeli Arabs. Saddam has repeatedly threatened to attack Israel, at one time threatening to burn half the Jewish state with chemical weapons. Officials said the distribution plan was developed long before the gulf crisis. The 140,000 Arabs living in annexed east Jerusalem will be issued gas masks. The government said the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza will have to pay the purchase price of $100-plus per kit because they are not covered by Israeli national insurance. Each kit contains a gas mask, a syringe with a nerve gas antidote and purifying powder. Instructions will be in Hebrew, Arabic, English and Russian. Gas masks will be available for tourists at hotels, officials said. At the United Nations, Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said Israel ``will know how to defend itself if attacked and its response will be harsh and painful.'' Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was quoted as saying on the French La Cinq television network on Monday that Saddam has had secret contacts with Israel during the gulf crisis. Israel denied it.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Protesters Seize College Building
DOC.TEXT: Disabled activists barricaded themselves in the president's office at Morehouse College on Monday to try to force a meeting with Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, a former dean at the college. More than a dozen demonstrators in wheelchairs rolled into Morehouse President Leroy Keith's office before noon Monday. Scores of additional protesters followed, blocking the front door and hallways and chanting, ``We want Sullivan!'' and ``We shall overcome!'' Keith left by a rear door. The protesters belonged to Americans Disabled for Attendant Programs Today, or ADAPT, a national advocacy group for the disabled. The group's members were angered that Sullivan, a former dean of the Morehouse School of Medicine, did not respond to an invitation to meet with them but agreed to speak at a recent AIDS symposium in San Francisco. ``This group invited him to speak on an issue as serious as AIDS. He chose to ignore the issue,'' said Michael Auberger, co-founder of ADAPT. At least 50 demonstrators said they planned to remain in the president's office overnight. Morehouse officials told the protesters that Sullivan had refused to meet them. ``He will not meet with you under these circumstances - by holding an institution hostage,'' said Richard Ammons, vice president of development. The protesters said they came to Georgia because the state is one of the worst at caring for its disabled citizens. Georgia and 12 other states do not provide state-funded care for disabled people outside of nursing homes, said Mark Johnson, spokesman for the Georgia branch of ADAPT. Protesters also complained that many operators of nursing homes for the disabled have nothing more than a business license. ``The nursing home lobby is real strong in Georgia, and that is who the decision makers are listening to right now,'' Johnson said. ``Institutions are being rewarded for bad work and the people who need help are not getting it.''

DOC.HEAD: Greek Ex-Premier Papandreou Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Former Premier Andreas Papandreou was hospitalized early Tuesday after complaining of heart and breathing problems. A medical bulletin at the cardiac unit of the General State Hospital described the 71-year-old Papandreou's condition as satisfactory. It said he was being treated for a possible irregular heartbeat, slight breathing difficulties and bronchial spasms. Papandreou, socialist prime minister from 1981 to 1989, was treated for kidney problems last June and underwent triple-bypass heart surgery in August 1988. Since then, he has led a campaign against the governing conservatives, despite being indicted on corruption charges in connection with a bank scandal. No trial date has been set. Papandreou complained shortly after a parliamentary debate late Monday that he was having trouble breathing, and his doctor decided he should be hospitalized immediately, radio stations reported. Another former official charged in the Bank of Crete scandal, Agamemnon Koutsogiorgas, was jailed Monday pending trial. Koutsogiorgas, a deputy premier and justice minister under Papandreou, is accused of accepting a $2 million bribe for helping block an audit at the bank, and two other charges.

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Commit Non-Soldiers to Persian Gulf, Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said Monday that his country intends to commit non-military personnel and material to other nations to bring peace to the Middle East and Cambodia. Kaifu said the Persian Gulf crisis provides an opportunity for Japan to consider ``what it can do to cooperate fully with the U.N. and other countries,'' although its constitution restricts such action. ``We have heard that when we cooperate with the United Nations, we should not limit ourselves to simply putting up money but should should toil together with others. That is my feeling as well,.'' Kaifu said. He spoke hours before his departure for a seven-day trip to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Oman - the first visit to the Middle East by a Japanese prime minister since Takeo Fukuda visited Saudi Arabia 12 years ago. Kaifu told a news conference Japan is not only commiting $4 billion in the crisis, but, ``It is also Japan's policy to commit personnel, material and wisdom and toil together with all the other countries.'' Japan has committed $2 billion to support the multilateral military operation in the gulf and another $2 billion to support countries in the area hard hit by the crisis. Japan is giving humanitarian aid to refugees, he said. His country's post-World War II constitution bars stationing soldiers outside Japan's territory. Kaifu said his government is trying to amend it to permit a non-military presence in U.N. and international peace operations abroad. The prime minister said Japan may be able to provide civilian monitors of free and fair elections and aid in Cambodia's reconstruction under a U.N. peace plan.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Halts Commercial Traffic from Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the Customs Department, Mahdi Farhan, said Monday that Jordan stopped commercial traffic from Saudi Arabia, but stressed that Jordan was not closing down its borders with that country. ``Jordan has stopped all trucks from entering its territory through the Saudi border,'' Farhan said. He said it was in reponse to an unexplained closure of Saudi borders to Jordanian commercial trucks Sunday. The development was another sign of the growing tension between the two kingdoms because of Jordan's pro-Iraqi stance in the Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will use a dispute growing out of a settled strike by Continental Air Lines pilots to set new guidelines on unions' duties to represent their members. The court will consider killing a lawsuit against the Air Line Pilots Association by striking pilots who said their union denied them fair representation. The Bush administration had urged the justices to hear the case. ``Uncertainty regarding the extent to which settlements will expose unions to liability for a breach of the duty of fair representation can only complicate the efforts of management, unions and federal mediators to achieve negotiated resolutions of those disputes,'' government lawyers told the court. A strike against Continental that began in October 1983 ended two years later. In the interim, more than 1,600 pilots either stayed on the job or were hired to replace the strikers, who numbered about 1,000. The pilots union agreed to a settlement that let striking pilots return to work on terms considerably less favorable than pilots who flew for Continental during the strike. Striking pilots sued in federal court, accusing the union of violating the Federal Railway Labor Act that governs employment for railroads and airlines. A federal appeals court said the case should go to trial to determine whether the settlement was ``arbitary and a breach of the union's duty to represent its members.'' Continental filed for bankruptcy protection in 1983 and has undergone an extensive financial reorganization.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Air Force Gen. Curtis LeMay Dies at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to RAISE comment about bombing North Vietnam `back into the Stone Age'; PICKS UP 17th graf pvs, `His reputation ...'; SUBS grafs 26-28 bgng `Shortly after ...' with one graf to conform; PICKS UP 29th graf pvs, `LeMay had ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY29
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, who relayed the order to drop the A-bomb on Japan and said the United States should threaten to bomb North Vietnam ``back into the Stone Age,'' died Monday. He was 83. LeMay, who also directed the 1948 Berlin Airlift and ran for vice president in 1968 as George Wallace's running mate, died of a heart attack at the 22nd Strategic Hospital, said Sgt. Steve Mahnke. An ambulance had picked him up minutes earlier at his retirement home outside this base east of Los Angeles. ``He was one of the real American heroes of World War II,'' Wallace said. ``I am proud to have served under him in World War II and proud to have had him on the ticket as a vice presidential candidate in my third-party campaign. ... I will always count it a high honor to have been his personal friend.'' The former four-star general who built the Strategic Air Command into a global strike force. Considered the father of strategic bombing, LeMay and his tactics were instrumental in pressing the daylight bombing offensive against the Nazis in Europe in World War II. LeMay was the architect of B-17 bombing formation tactics in Europe, and later transferred to the Pacific where he organized the B-29 bombing campaign against the Japanese islands. Years later, he said the nuclear bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki were unnecessary to force Japan's surrender. ``We felt that our incendiary bombings had been so successful that Japan would collapse before we invaded,'' LeMay said in a 1985 interview with the Omaha (Neb.) World-Herald. ``We went ahead and droppped the bombs because President (Harry) Truman told me to do it. He told me in a personal letter.'' But LeMay told the newspaper he felt the United States could have defeated Japan in ``a few more days'' if it had continued the firebombing of Japanese cities. After the war, LeMay was given command of the U.S. Air Force in Europe. He was there in 1948 when the Soviet Union cut off ground access to West Berlin. His management of the airlift that kept West Berlin supplied brought LeMay much notice at home. He was named commanding general of the Strategic Air Command in October 1948 and held the command until June 1957 - longer than any other general. The 1955 Jimmy Stewart movie, ``Strategic Air Command,'' provided a glimpse of the strike force LeMay built. A cigar-chomping Frank Lovejoy portrayed a character that displayed LeMay's tough, demanding persona. He was SAC's second commander but was widely credited with having built its bomber force to a formidable level. Within a few short years he transformed the largely demobilized air arm into a global striking force that could deliver nuclear weapons anywhere at any time. In a 1965 biography, ``Mission with LeMay,'' published in 1965 after his retirement as Air Force chief of staff during the early years of the Vietnam War, h wrote that a solution to the war might be to warn the North Vietnamese that they ``have got to draw in their horns and stop their aggression, or we are going to bomb them back into the Stone Age.'' His reputation was that of a man who was equally unsparing of his men and himself. He said he was unable to distinguish between the unfortunate and the incompetent, and he tolerated little if any error from his subordinates. But he would willingly do any job that he demanded of his followers. He was as comfortable in a machine gun cupola as he was in the cockpit. He personally led dozens of missions in Europe. One of many famous stories about LeMay was that he once found a SAC sentry who had put down his weapon to eat a sandwich. ``This afternoon I found a man guarding a hangar with a ham sandwich. There will be no more of that,'' LeMay's subsequent memo said. He was promoted to full general while at SAC. After leaving SAC, LeMay became vice chief, then President Kennedy named him chief of staff of the Air Force. LeMay retired in 1965, frustrated by the politics of the Pentagon and by Robert S. McNamara, defense secretary under presidents Kennedy and Johnson. McNamara had denied LeMay the B-70, which the general had wanted as the successor to the B-52, and forced him to accept the F-111 fighter-bomber. In so doing, McNamara had subordinated LeMay's coveted bombers to the new ballistic missiles. LeMay also grew angry over McNamara's restraints on U.S. air power in Vietnam, a sore point for LeMay who believed in an all-out war. At a news conference at which he was introduced as Wallace's running mate, LeMay said he saw nothing wrong with using nuclear weapons to shorten any war and, thus, save lives. LeMay had been living in Air Force Village West, a military retirement community outside March. A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday at the air base chapel. Burial will be at the U.S. Air Force Academy on Thursday. He is survived by his wife, Helen, and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: San Jose City Council Member Loses Libel Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A former San Jose, Calif., City Council member who won, and then lost, a $1.01 million libel award against his local newspaper lost a Supreme Court appeal Oct. 1. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that Claude Fletcher failed to prove the San Jose Mercury News published statements about him with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of their falsity. Fletcher sued the Mercury News over a series of 1984 articles reporting on his conduct while a city council member and as a board member of a local antipoverty agency. Fletcher's 1984 bid for re-election failed after the articles were published. The articles reported that five agency officials said Fletcher tried to steer a $1.6 million contract to an insulation business in which he became a partner. The articles quoted the agency's executive director as saying Fletcher once offered him and his wife a trip to Hawaii, which the agency official interpreted as a bribe. A jury in 1986 awarded Fletcher $250,000 in general damages, $25,000 in special damages and $735,000 in punitive damages. But the trial judge threw out the award, ruling Fletcher had failed to prove the articles were published with actual malice - a burden facing any public official who sues for libel. A state appeals court upheld the dismissal of the award, and the California Supreme Court refused to hear Fletcher's appeal last February. In its 1989 ruling, the appeals court said, ``The evidence suggests a sincere attempt to report what the Mercury News viewed as unethical behavior on the part of a San Jose public official.'' It added, ``Clearly the articles contained factual errors. But was there clear and convincing evidence that (the paper's reporter) did not believe his story was true? We do not think so.''
DOC.HEAD: Top Court Won't Let Newspaper See Some Pentagon Probe Documents
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused Oct. 1 to let the St. Louis Post-Dispatch see some confidential documents in the government's corruption investigation of Pentagon contracts. The court, over two dissenting votes, let stand a ruling that the privacy rights of McDonnell Douglas Corp., the nation's largest defense contractor, and some of its employees outweigh the public's right to know more about the weapons procurement case. Justices Byron R. White and Harry A. Blackmun voted to hear arguments in the case, but four votes are needed to grant such review. The Justice Department investigation, called ``Operation Ill Wind,'' began in 1987 and has yielded more than three dozen guilty pleas or convictions on fraud- and bribery-related charges. Among the contractors investigated was McDonnell Douglas, which is based in the St. Louis area and receives some $9 billion a year in Pentagon contracts. The FBI in 1988 conducted a search of defense contractor offices, including those of McDonnell Douglas and its vice president Thomas Gunn. Search warrants were based on information the FBI obtained listening to wiretapped telephone conversations. The Post-Dispatch asked to see sealed documents related to the warrants, particularly government affidavits that might reveal what was learned by listening to the wiretaps. The Justice Department initially opposed making the documents public but substantially dropped its opposition in December 1988. The government, now siding with the newspaper, said it no longer had a compelling interest in keeping portions of the material secret since it had concluded part of the investigation. But McDonnell Douglas, Gunn and five unidentified employees continued to oppose disclosure. A federal judge ordered parts of the documents unsealed. But the ruling was reversed in February by the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals court said the absence of an indictment against the company and its employees ``weighs heavily in favor of the privacy interests and non-disclosure.'' ``These search warrant affidavits implicate some individuals directly in criminal misconduct, others only indirectly,'' the appeals court said. ``Disclosure could seriously damage their reputations and careers.''
DOC.HEAD: Court Permits Libel Suit in Comparative Ads Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Oct. 1 refused to kill a libel lawsuit stemming from advertisements comparing Blue Cross and Blue Shield services to those of a health industry competitor. The court, without comment, left intt could send U.S. Healthcare's libel allegations against Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a federal jury in Philadelphia. At issue was whethact a ruling thaer some libel cases involving commercial speech could be held to less stringent standards than others. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in reviving Healthcare's suit last March, relaxed the rules for commercial-speech libel cases. Since 1964, public figures - including most businesses - suing for libel must prove that the sued-over statements are false and were made with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of falsity. Private citizens suing for libel face a far less demanding burden: having to prove only that the statements are false and were made negligently. In ruling on Healthcare's lawsuit, the 3rd Circuit court said the more stringent ``actual malice'' standard need not be arise over what the agency is entitled to censor. Snepp worked for the Central Intelligence Agency from 1968 to 1976, working either in Vietnam or on Vietnam matters at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va. In 1977, he published a critical account of the final days of U.S. involvement in Vietnam. The book, ``Decent Interval,'' was published without first having been submitted for agency preclearance. The Supreme Court in 1980 ruled that Snepp's publication of the book was a breach of his employment contract with the CIA and ordered that he forfeit all proceeds from the book to the agency. The high court also ruled the CIA could continue to require Snepp to submit any agency-related writings for prepublication approval.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Sues National Enquirer for $20 Million
DOC.TEXT: Actress Elizabeth Taylor filed a $20 million libel suit Sept. 25 against the National Enquirer, over articles in the tabloid that labeled her as a heavy drinker with a disfiguring disease. The Superior Court suit says the actress was hospitalized earlier this year with a near-fatal pneumonia when a front page headline June 12 screamed: ``Liz Docs Furious. She's Boozing It Up In The Hospital.'' The newspaper will not back down from the stories, Editor Iain Calder said. ``All I can really say is we stand by our story, which we investigated very thoroughly,'' he said, declining to discuss the suit further on the advice of the newspaper's attorneys. The complaint alleges the Enquirer was notified about inaccuracies in its stories and headlines four days before publication. ``Both the cover headline, as well as the accompanying article, are and were false, untrue, libelous and defamatory and were published at a time when defendants . . . knew such allegations to be false . . . ,'' the lawsuit said. The complaint also points to a Jan. 19 article titled: ``Liz's Beautiful Face Ravaged By Killer Disease. Doctors Order Suicide Watch After They Finally Diagnose The Mystery Illness.'' The suit states that story suggested Miss Taylor had lupus, a destructive skin condition. The story also said Miss Taylor had liquor smuggled into her hospital room. The articles were ``outrageous and extreme conduct intended to cause (Miss Taylor) to suffer great humiliation, mental anguish and emotional and physical distress, and substantial loss of income, with the sole purpose of improving sales of the National Enquirer for the weeks in which the articles appeared,'' the lawsuit claims.
DOC.HEAD: Evening Express To Close, Merge With Press Herald
DOC.TEXT: Guy Gannett Publishing Co. said it will close the Evening Express afternoon newspaper in February and merge it with the Portland Press Herald. The last edition of the Express will be Feb. 1. Reporters and editors at both papers said the decision was not a surprise. They said the Express had been losing circulation steadily for almost 10 years. Its daily circulation is now between 22,000 and 23,000. ``While we're very proud of the Evening Express, changing lifestyles have, for the past decade, caused an increased readership of morning newspapers and a corresponding decrease of evening circulation,'' Jean Gannett Hawley, publisher of both papers, said Sept. 25. The new Press Herald will continue to publish Monday through Saturday mornings and include many of the features now contained in the Evening Express. The company also will continue to publish the Maine Sunday Telegram, which has been produced by the Press Herald. The Press Herald has a daily circulation of 64,000 and the Sunday Telegram has a circulation of about 150,000. The closing of the Express will leave Maine with only two afternoon dailies, the Journal Tribune in Biddeford and the Times Record in Brunswick.
DOC.HEAD: Starting Salary Offers Drop for Journalists
DOC.TEXT: Journalists just out of college are getting starting salary offers lower than their counterparts who graduated a year earlier, a survey says. College Placement Council Inc. released its annual salary survey on Sept. 28. The report was based on offers extended to students graduating between Sept. 1, 1989, and Aug. 31, 1990. The information was gathered from 428 career service offices at U.S. colleges and universities. Journalism was one of the few fields in which offers to graduates declined. The average offer was $19,488, a 3 percent drop from the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Author Cancels Book Promotion Trip After Threats
DOC.TEXT: A Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, reportedly threatened with ``bodily harm'' over his book that takes a critical look at an obsession with high school football in Odessa, Texas, canceled a promotional visit to the city. The book by H.G. Bissinger, ``Friday Night Lights,'' focuses on Permian High School, where funds for film prints of its football games exceed teaching materials for the English department by $1,000 a year. The school won the Class 5A football championship last year and has won the state title four other times since 1965. In his book, Bissinger refers to the alleged illegal use of pain killers and to a pattern of apparent racism. Odessa police said they were aware of the threats. Lee Buice, president of the Odessa School Board, said the book had angered some in the community. ``Mr. Bissinger has every reason to think he might face an unpleasant situation if he came. I'm not sure that it would be life-threatening, but I think he made a good call,'' she said. She said people were angry because they felt the book ``had a significant impact in a decision made last week to bar Permian from this year's state football playoffs.'' The ban was imposed by the State Executive Committee of the University Interscholastic League, which regulates high school sports and other extracurricular activities in the state's public schools. Bissinger is an investigative reporter at the Chicago Tribune. When he was working at The Philadelphia Inquirer, he was part of a three-person team that won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for a series of articles on corruption in the Philadelphia court system.
DOC.HEAD: Cartoonist Fired Over Cartoon of Slaves
DOC.TEXT: The Miami University student newspaper fired its cartoonist after black students protested a cartoon that compared a new grading system to slavery. Cartoonist Richard Carr said in a column afterward that the Sept. 11 cartoon in The Miami Student was supposed to highlight student objections to the grading system. It showed five barefoot black men, labeled as students, looking on as a faculty member said, ``From now on you won't just pick cotton . . . but you will pick cotton and be graded with this new plus-minus grading system that I have devised.'' Carr's column said the cartoon was intended to compare slavery forced on blacks to the grading system forced on unwilling students. About 3 percent of the school's 15,500 students are black. Carolyn Pione, the student editor of the newspaper, and another editor approved the cartoon before it went into print. Students have demanded Ms. Pione's resignation. The newspaper is published twice a week and has a circulation of 10,500.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Guild Authorizes Strike in San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: The Northern California Newspaper Guild has authorized a strike if talks with the city's two papers fail to produce an agreement soon. No deadline was specified. ``We've been bargaining since last February and our members are increasingly upset that no contract has been reached yet,'' union spokesman Bernie Beck said after the Sept. 27 vote. The Guild represents about 1,200 reporters and other employees at the Chronicle, Examiner and the Newspaper Agency, the jointly owned company that prints and distributes both papers.

DOC.HEAD: California Reporters Protected in Civil Suits
DOC.TEXT: Reporters can't be jailed for refusing to provide notes, photos or news sources to people who sue one another based on an eventthe reporter covered, the state Supreme Court ruled Sept. 27. California's press shield law, which forbids holding reporters in contempt for withholding confidential sources or unpublished material, provides ironclad protection in civil cases, the court said in a unanimous decision. The shield law was made part of the state Constitution by the voters in 1980, in response to the jailing of several reporters for refusing to reveal their sources. The court ruled in May that in criminal cases, reporters can be required to testify or provide evidence if necessary to protect a defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial. But the justices ruled Sept. 27 that parties to a civil suit have no similar constitutional right that can overcome the shield law. ``This is a complete victory for the journalists and the public,'' said C. Michael Cooney, lawyer for New York Times Co., publisher of the Santa Barbara News-Press. The case arose when an automobile company, sued in a 1984 accident, sought a News-Press photographer's pictures of the crash. Michael Zuk, lawyer for the company, Volkswagen of America, said the ruling would ``deny my client access to what may be critical evidence in civil litigation.'' The voters who passed the shield law did not intend to foreclose any evidence held by reporters that could be essential to a civil suit, he argued. The ruling's main impact is on civil suits that do not directly involve the news media, in which evidence is sought from a reporter. If the reporter cannot be held in contempt of court, and jailed until he or she testifies, there is little a judge or a party to a suit can do to compel the testimony. The opinion by Justice David Eagleson said the party seeking the evidence could sue the reporter, under a law providing a $500 penalty plus actual damages caused by a witness' refusal to provide evidence. But Eagleson said the law was rarely used and would be ``virtually ineffectual'' in compelling testimony. In a case that has a news organization as a party, such as a libel suit, the ruling has a lesser impact, because judges can take other steps against parties who withhold evidence, such as deciding the case in the opponent's favor.
DOC.HEAD: Lowell Sun Gets $26 Million Loan From Providence Journal
DOC.TEXT: The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin said Sept. 28 it has agreed to lend The Lowell Sun $26 million. A story in the Sun said it will use the proceeds to pay off debt. The Journal has the option after three years to convert the loan into a one-third interest in the Lowell newspaper. Providence Journal Publisher Stephen Hamblet will become a director of the Sun.
DOC.HEAD: Environmental Conference Scheduled
DOC.TEXT: The Foundation for American Communications and the Gannett Foundation are sponsoring an environmental conference for journalists. ``Covering the Clean Air Act in the 1990s'' is scheduled for Oct. 26-27 at the Harrison Conference Center in Wellesley, Mass. Speakers include toxicologist Arthur Craigmill of the University of California-Davis, economist Robert Stavins of Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, environmental law specialist James Krier of the University of Michigan and Bud Ward of the Environmental Health Center. Information and registration are available through the Foundation for American Communications in Los Angeles, 213-851-7372.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Cable Controls Vow Tougher Bill Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Backers of legislation to re-regulate cable television prices and services say they'll be back next year with an even tougher bill following a defeat in the Senate. On Sept. 28, Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., objected to bringing the bill to the floor for debate or a vote, where it was expected to pass easily. Faced with a possible filibuster, a sponsor of the bill, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, declared the measure ``dead and buried'' for the 101st Congress. Congress is expected to adjourn as early as the middle of October. Backers of the bill said that the cable industry's victory might be short-lived and that it would only strengthen the hand of would-be competitors. Home satellite companies are itching to compete with cable and are expected to push provisions of the Senate bill that would guarantee them access to cable programming. Broadcasters also want cable to pay for the programming it now takes virtually for free. ``There may come a time when the cable industry will devoutly wish they had taken today's deal,'' said Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters. The Office of Management and Budget had issued a veto warning on the bill, which would have restored some of the government oversight of cable that Congress lifted in 1984. OMB said that the bill imposed too many restrictions on cable and that increased competition - perhaps from the telephone industry - was the answer to any problems in the cable industry. Basic cable prices on average have risen 43 percent in the past three years.
DOC.HEAD: Networks Use Saddam Tape
DOC.TEXT: The four major U.S. television networks broadcast all or parts of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's videotaped address to the American people. Saddam gave his side of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait in a 75-minute address, sitting at his desk with an Iraqi flag at his side. The Sept. 25 broadcast was in Arabic, the remarks translated with English subtitles supplied by Iraq. The networks broadcast excerpts of the tape on their evening news shows. Saddam had asked that they show the entire tape. Only CNN scheduled the whole thing, for 1 a.m. EDT the next morning. The network said it was not honoring Saddam's request, but making an independent decision. ``We did not decide until 6:30 p.m. . . . after seeing the whole damned thing and only after seeing the whole damned thing,'' said CNN spokesman Steve Haworth.
DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Denied Meeting With Mohawks
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson was prevented from meeting with Mohawks holed up in a drug and alcohol detoxification center in nearby Kahnesatake on Sept. 25, a day before the standoff ended. Canadian military officials said Jackson, who is host of a syndicated television show, was being treated like any other journalist when he was refused entry to the center. Jackson was accompanied to the reservation, about 18 miles west of Montreal, by Kahnawake Mohawk Chief Joe Norton. ``The Mohawks in the detoxification center cannot get spiritual or legal advice and, moreover, the Canadian and the world press is denied access to them,'' Jackson said. ``This is undemocratic and inconsistent with Canada's great history.'' Canadian forces surrounded the treatment center Sept. 1 after about 50 Mohawks, some armed, occupied the building. The standoff ended Sept. 26 when the 22 people remaining inside left. Several scuffles broke out as some of the Mohawks refused to submit to questioning afterward. There were no serious injuries.
DOC.HEAD: CBS Remembers Quake and Packs Generator
DOC.TEXT: CBS is determined not to be shaken if there is a replay of last year's World Series earthquake. The quake rocked San Francisco's Candlestick Park, where the third game of the 1989 World Series was just getting under way last Oct. 17. ABC, which broadcast the championship series last year, didn't have a backup power supply and lost all video from the stadium for about 30 minutes. CBS promises it won't be caught in the dark during upcoming playoff American League Championship Series telecasts from Oakland. The network will lug a generator to the Coliseum for a standby power source in the event of a disaster similar to last season's temblor. ``We will be self-sufficient in Oakland,'' said producer Rick LaCivita. Playoff games are scheduled in Oakland Oct. 9, 10 and 11.
DOC.HEAD: Jane Pauley Gets New Contract, Mid-Season Series
DOC.TEXT: Jane Pauley has a new five-year contract with NBC and is assured a new midseason series, the network said Sept. 24. The series' title, ``Real Life With Jane Pauley,'' also was the title of five Pauley specials broadcast in prime time this summer. All did well in the ratings, averaging a 21 percent share of the audience, NBC said. Terms of the new contract weren't disclosed. Pauley, who turns 40 on Oct. 31, left ``Today'' in December after a series of changes and turmoil there led to her departure. She was succeeded as co-anchor by Deborah Norville.
DOC.HEAD: New CNN President To Join Turner Board
DOC.TEXT: Tom Johnson, the new president of Cable News Network, has been nominated to join the board of CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting, board chairman Ted Turner said Sept. 25. Johnson succeeded Burt Reinhardt as president of Atlanta-based CNN on Aug. 1. He is a former publisher of the Los Angeles Times.

DOC.HEAD: Trounson First Civil Top Editor for Stars and Stripes
DOC.TEXT: W. Robert Trounson, deputy business editor of the Los Angeles Times, was named the first civilian chief editor of Pacific Stars and Stripes on Sept. 26. Trounson worked for the Times for 23 years. In 1974-75, he studied Japanese history, politics, language and art at Stanford University under a journalism fellowship. He was a copy editor and news editor at the Stars and Stripes in 1963-67. Stripes ombudsman Philip M. Foisie recommended naming of a civilian chief editor last January after studying allegations of censorship at the paper, including charges by staff members that senior editors had killed stories critical of the military or of host countries. The editor in chief's position was previously held by the paper's senior military officer, who now holds the title of commander-publisher, with editorial control delegated to the civilian chief editor.
DOC.HEAD: Lake Appointed Publisher in Marion, Ohioi
DOC.TEXT: Steven C. Lake, publisher of The Free Press, a semiweekly in Canton, was appointed publisher and general manager of The Marion Star. The appointment was effective Sept. 24. Before The Free Press, Lake was advertising director of The Repository in Canton for seven years. He also worked for Vermont Publishing Co.
DOC.HEAD: General Manager of Phoenix Newspapers Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix Newspapers Inc. said Sept. 25 that vice president and general manager Wm. R. Hogan will resign to become president of a land management company he has formed with a partner. The company said in a statement that Hogan would step down Dec. 31 to work full time with Natural Resources Group Inc. and become an officer in Oakridge Holdings Inc., a funeral services and real estate company.

Thomas C. Fichter, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, died Sept. 29. He was 51. The cause of death was not disclosed. Fichter, who had been with the organization for 29 years, also was treasurer of the ANPA Foundation and chairman and president of ANPA's Credit Bureau Inc.

Harold King, a reporter who covered the battle of Stalingrad and forged close ties with French leader Charles de Gaulle, died Sept. 24 of heart failure. He was 91. King worked as a correspondent in Paris for The Wall Street Journal and the Financial Times and later headed Reuters' Paris bureau from 1944 to 1967. Reuters also sent King to the Soviet Union, where he wrote on the Red Army victory at Stalingrad and covered Stalin's breakup of the Communist International in 1943. He cultivated his contacts with de Gaulle during the general's postwar withdrawal from political life. After leaving Reuters' Paris bureau, King worked as a correspondent for the Toronto Telegram.

The Rev. Lazlo Ladany, whose journal of China-watching made him famous on university campuses and in embassies on both sides of the Iron Curtain, died Sept. 23 of lung cancer. He was 76. The revolution of 1949 forced the Hungarian-born Ladany and other Jesuits to flee China. He arrived in the British colony of Hong Kong and began publishing China News Analysis in 1953, the world's oldest China-watching journal. Operating out of a small room in a student hostel at the University of Hong Kong, Ladany monitored news broadcasts from almost every Chinese province.

President Bush and key lawmakers avoided a crisis as the new fiscal year dawned today but they now must convince an election-year Congress to vote for $134 billion in new taxes and widespread cuts in federal programs. ``It's a tough sale,'' said Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, one of many lawmakers who was troubled by what he was hearing of the package Sunday. Democrats, too, were expected to swallow hard before agreeing to raising Medicare premiums while cutting the benefits, increasing taxes on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes, and trimming everything from defense to student loans. And despite a claimed $500 billion in deficit reduction, it would stretch out the goal of a balanced budget and let the national debt increase another $1 trillion. ---=

Toning down his bellicose rhetoric, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has urged an international dialogue and mentioned France as a possible partner. But both French and British officials said they won't talk until Iraq quits Kuwait. Moreover, the nations allied against Iraq have pressed on with laying the groundwork for possible military action. U.S. and Soviet officials were reported Sunday to be drafting new United Nations resolutions that would authorize the use of force against Iraq if the U.N.-ordered economic blockade fails to force Saddam to pull out of Kuwait. President Bush was to address the U.N. General Assembly in New York today. Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, said Friday that U.S. officials are considering asking U.N. authorization for military action. ---= WELLESLEY, Mass. (AP) - Boston Celtics rookie Dee Brown, forced from a car by police and ordered to lie on the ground at gunpoint in a case of mistaken identity, is thinking twice about moving to this wealthy, mostly white suburb. The basketball team's top draft choice is black, 21 and fresh out of Jacksonville State in Florida, where he heard of Boston's reputation for racism. ``When you think of towns up North and you think of racism, you think of Boston,'' Brown said. Wellesley police converged on Brown and his fiancee, who is white, as they sat in a parked car Sept. 21 across from a bank that had been robbed of about $1,700 a few days before. Police arrived after a bank employee saw Brown and reported he could be the robber. Brown, who is 6-1, said he was forced from the car by at least five officers, told to lie face down on the pavement and had guns pointed at his head before his identity was confirmed and the two were freed. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - Comiskey Park, where the Black Sox scandal of 1919 was hatched and the first All-Star Game was played, is ready for the wrecking ball after a final ``hey-hey goodbye'' from fans.
