DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Found Writer From the Lost Generation
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nobody from the Lost Generation of American expatriate writers has been more lost than Robert McAlmon. He squandered fame, fortune and friends during the 1920s in Paris. He lost the manuscript of his major work, ``Family Panorama,'' and practically all his belongings fleeing the Nazi occupation in 1940. And, somewhere near oblivion, McAlmon lost his life - to alcohol - at Desert Hot Springs, Calif., on Feb. 2, 1956. McAlmon, the last of the Lost, is the one whose life most exactly fulfilled Gertrude Stein's prophecy that his generation was indeed lost. But as Ernest Hemingway replied to Stein, ``the sun also rises.'' It is rising finally for McAlmon 35 years after his death with the publication for the first time in the United States of his two surviving novels, ``Village'' and ``Post-Adolescence.'' The University of New Mexico Press, with the prodding and editing of English doctoral candidate Edward N.S. Lorusso, sold out it first printing of ``Village'' in a few months this summer and is going into a second printing. ``Post-Adolescence,'' and about 20 McAlmon short stories will be published next year. ``At this point, McAlmon is a discovery,'' Lorusso says. ``Most people have only known him as a footnote to the story of the Lost Generation, more of a social figure than a literary figure, and that may change.'' The spare, straightforward ``Village'' is a series of loosely linked sketches set in the fictional town of Wentworth, N.D., around the turn of the century. Turning the century is precisely what McAlmon set out to do, Lorusso says. ``There is a difference between `Village' and `Winesburg, Ohio,' or `Main Street' that really does give McAlmon the edge,'' he says. ``He has one foot in the 20th century, I think, while (Sinclair) Lewis and (Sherwood) Anderson are still sort of 19th century in their approaches. There's sentimentality and a lot of judgment and direction on how the reader should feel about characters, which McAlmon doesn't do and which Hemingway also went on not to do. ... It's left to the reader to make those kinds of decisions, and I think McAlmon might really have been the starting point of that.'' Like many American towns, Wentworth is made up of disparate, desperate people who somehow nonetheless have a collective conscience, consciousness and will. McAlmon's eye roves from family to clique, quirk to eccentricity. ``Having grown up in a town very similar to the Wentworth of `Village,' I think he (McAlmon) is very conscious of this fact that the individual is robbed of his or her individuality because of this collective consciousness.'' McAlmon was born on March 9, 1896, in Clifton, Kan., son of an Irish-born Presbyterian minister and the youngest of eight children. The family moved from town to town and stayed mainly poor, says McAlmon's nephew, George McAlmon, an attorney in El Paso, Texas. ```Village,' that's the family. That's autobiographical as far as I can tell,'' George McAlmon says. As a young man, Robert went to New York and became an artist's model. There he met and married British heiress Winifred Ellerman, who wrote under the pen name of Bryher. An odd marriage, as Bryher was an acknowledged lesbian. When they divorced, McAlmon received a large settlement which enabled him to establish a small publishing business in Paris during the early '20s. ``If he has his rightful place, it's more often given him as a publisher than as a writer,'' Lorusso says. ``He did publish Hemingway's `Three Stories and Ten Poems.' He did publish Stein's `The Making of Americans.' He did publish other things by H.D. (Hilda Doolittle), William Carlos Williams and Nathanael West. It's easy to see, yes, he was the one who started these people and got them into print first. ``But as a writer, I think this is where he is likely to be some kind of a discovery.'' Lorusso says the missing body of McAlmon's work, including dozens of short stories, must be resurrected in print so his proper place in literature can be assessed. ``I think at that point we can decide objectively whether or not McAlmon was the beginning of the whole new literary tradition, the break from the 19th century, the break from the British English so commonly used by people like Henry James and Edith Wharton.'' His own generation of writers, with a few exceptions, already had relegated him to a literary scrapheap, even though he had given so many of them money, food and their first break. It had been McAlmon who paid for Hemingway's 1923 trip to Spain, from which emerged ``The Sun Also Rises.'' He helped James Joyce type ``Ulysses,'' editing and rearrangingportions of Molly Bloom's concluding stream-of-consciousness soliloquy. ``He literally supported Joyce for a long period of time,'' Lorusso says. But when McAlmon wrote a memoir about the Paris period, ``Being Geniuses Together,'' Joyce called it ``the office boy's revenge.'' And when F. Scott Fitzgerald learned that Charles Scribners' Sons might consider publishing McAlmon's ``Family Panorama,'' he wrote to Scribners editor Maxwell Perkins advising him to pass. ``By the way,'' Fitzgerald's letter says, ``McAlmon is a bitter rat and I'm not surprised at anything he does or says. He's failed as a writer and tries to fortify himself by tying up to the big boys like Joyce and Stein and despising everyone else. Part of his quarrel with Ernest (Hemingway) some years ago was because he assured Ernest that I was a fairy - God knows he shows more creative imagination in his malice than in his work. Next he told (Morley) Callaghan that Ernest was a fairy. He's a pretty good person to avoid.'' Perkins passed. ``All those people he literally supported turned on him,'' Lorusso says. What was it about McAlmon, anyway? ``Honesty,'' says Lorusso, ``because he was willing to look objectively at people around him, including himself.'' Generosity. ``I think it's like with any kind of handout,'' says Lorusso. ``Maybe at first you're appreciative of it, then after a while you become resentful. ... ``McAlmon had money, McAlmon had a press, plus with his own personality he ended up alienating just about everybody. When he tried to establish a foothold in America to try to get some of his work published here, it all worked against him.'' After McAlmon returned to the United States in 1940 with little more than the clothes he wore, he took a job in his uncle's medical supply business in El Paso. ``He got out of Europe just ahead of the Germans,'' nephew George McAlmon says. ``At that time I was 16. I knew him pretty well. He had a drinking problem. All those guys (writers) ... they either went to AA or they died from it. He died from it. ``It was a sad existence for him. ... He wasn't doing any literary work. He went downhill, lost a lot of interest. His friends died. I remember him commenting on when James Joyce died.'' He moved to California in 1953 to be near his sister, Victoria. Less than three years later he was dead.

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Vince Gill Resurrects Career With a Weeper
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Vince Gill has resurrected a sputtering recording career with a classic country music weeper about lost love. Gill was a little noticed singer throughout the mid-1980s who finally asked to be released from his recording contract with RCA Records in 1987. He went without a record deal until he emerged this year with MCA Records and put out the acclaimed single ``When I Call Your Name'' and the album of the same name. The LP is closing in on gold status (500,000 copies sold) - or 10 times more than his three previous albums. ``A lot of people figured I was done,'' the amiable 33-year-old Gill said as he reflected on his lean years. ``Nothing major had happened, and people started losing enthusiasm. ``I never doubted the fact that I had a hit record in me. It was just trying to find it.'' Gill found it with ``When I Call Your Name,'' which he wrote and which has become one of the year's top country hits. The song featuring a whining steel guitar and a compelling piano solo, tells the story of a man who thinks about his lover all day and rushes home to find a goodbye note on the table. Patty Loveless provides backup vocals. ``It's the kind of song that gave me goose bumps,'' said Gill, former lead singer for Pure Prairie League. ``It has a haunting chorus and it's a very lonesome and sad song. ``When I first heard it, I definitely felt that if this was not a hit, then I could throw my hands up and say I don't have a clue to what is.'' Gill said he treats records the way a casting director does a movie: ``Every part is so critical. There are things that can enhance them or detract and I think we made all the right calls in what we did to the record. ``It really took off when Patty put her vocals on there. I just love our voices together.'' Even without his newfound success, Gill had fashioned a rewarding behind-the-scenes career using his velvet tenor as a backup vocalist for recording sessions. By his count, he has sung on records done by more than 100 other singers. He was with Pure Prairie League from 1979 to 1983, recording three albums and singing their hit ``Let Me Love You Tonight.'' Gill, the son of a lawyer in Norman, Okla., grew up playing bluegrass and country music. He was considering a career as a pro golfer when he chose to join the group Bluegrass Alliance instead. He later joined Sundance, then hooked up with Pure Prairie League. He arrived in Nashville with dreams of a country music career, but found himself perceived as a pop singer instead because of his stint with Pure Prairie League. ``I had sung `Let Me Love You Tonight' and been on `American Bandstand,' '' Gill said. ``But I can't complain that I got to sing a No. 1 pop record and met the Solid Gold Dancers.'' He was able to launch his solo career but didn't meet with much success until this year. His album has been near the top of the country music charts and the single was No. 1 during the summer. ``It's been like Christmas a few months early,'' Gill said. He called on some old recording session friends to provide guest vocals on the album: Loveless, Emmylou Harris, Reba McEntire, Herb Pederson of the Desert Rose Band and Kathie Baillie of Baillie and the Boys. ``I was there for their careers and helped their careers and they seemed to have a similar feeling for me,'' Gill said. ``I think it's a good calling card to have them in your camp.'' The album includes dance hall swing tunes, rodeo songs and contemporary pop music. ``We've got a real good chance to go gold,'' Gill said. ``We even got on the pop charts for awhile. It's been fun. ``Looking back, I'm kind of thankful in a way that the success didn't happen right away. That's real dangerous to go to the top and be the rage. It doesn't allow time to build. The way down might be just as quick.'' He has no regrets about choosing music as a career instead of golf. ``Music is more fun, much more creative. I love golf but music is much more rewarding by writing songs and communicating with folks,'' he said. ``That's the true God-given talent I was given. I don't think a golf swing is my best blessing. I can sing a little better than I can make a four-footer.''

DOC.HEAD: Former TB Patients Remember Days in Saranac Lake
DOC.TEXT: The joy of life is what most people recall about the years they battled death in Saranac Lake's tuberculosis sanitariums. ``It was a very hopeful atmosphere, there was very little depression,'' said George Conklin, 81, of Woodbridge, Conn. His wife, Anne, moved with the couple's two children to Saranac Lake when her husband contracted TB in the Navy in 1944. Mrs. Conklin remembered ``lots of parties'' in the village that came to be known as the ``City of Sick.'' ``We had parties for the people who lived here and parties for the patients. . . . it was very cheerful,'' she said. The Conklins were among about 100 people at a reunion last month of former TB patients who took the open-air ``cure'' in the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York. Extended exposure to the bracing mountain air and regimented bed rest was thought to arrest the disease, which was brought under control by antibiotics in the early 1950s. In the Trudeau Sanatorium and the private ``cure cottages'' with rambling unheated porches, where patients would sit by the hour in the mountain air, the goal was to get well. The enemy was a congestive respiratory disease that attacks the lungs and other organs. So prevalent was TB in the early decades of this century that it became known as the ``White Plague'' and, experts say, many of those afflicted with it carried the stigma that people do now who suffer acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Indeed, the AIDS crisis is blamed for a resurgence in TB. This summer, experts at an AIDS conference in San Francisco were told that TB has emerged as the world's biggest bacterial killer and that scientists fear the immune system-weakening AIDS will again allow it to become a major health problem, especially in Africa. Kenneth Ho, 67, of Syracuse, N.Y., said doctors tricked him and other patients when lung X-rays revealed his TB infection in late 1948. ``You accept the news of the diagnosis: TB. Then comes word of the therapy: a sanitarium,'' he recalled as he and about three dozen other reunion participants toured the grounds of the former Trudeau Sanatorium, which has been a training center for a corporate management group since the early 1960s. ``The doctors fool you into accepting it. They say, `Well, maybe you'll be there three months,' '' he said. ``It turns out to be three years. It turns out there are people who've been there five years.'' Some patients stayed longer, though usually doctors tried to move them from Trudeau to cure cottages to make beds available for newer patients. The families paid for their stay, Ho said. Many of the one-time tuberculars said they were too young to be daunted by spending several months or years doing, quite literally, nothing. The motto of open-air ``curing'' was, ``Never stand when you can sit and never sit when you can lie,'' the one-time patients said. Edward Burgeni, 76, of Greenville, S.C., said he ``worked out all kinds of strategies'' to pass his two years of bed rest in Saranac Lake, starting in 1934. Once, he recalled being chided by a doctor just for playing chess with another patient. Time still had a way of going by, he said. ``People who were ambulatory would come in, the nurses would come in,'' he said. ``Each thing was an event, a highlight. I would tell you, quite frankly, that time did not wear heavily at all.'' Burgeni said many people who survived TB were strengthened emotionally. Others turned into what he called ``professional invalids.'' ``Some people used this as a stepping stone in life, as part of a growing experience,'' he said. ``There were some people who found in this life their mother, and they were afraid to get well. . . . They never made the break to get out. Or, if they did, they would return very promptly because the outside world was very frightening.''

DOC.HEAD: System Allows Seniors To Check on One Another
DOC.TEXT: Some elderly residents can have a watchful eye as near as their front door. Borrowing on the familiar ``Do Not Disturb'' signs found in hotel rooms, two Rhode Island Crime Stoppers programs have started in-house monitoring systems. Plastic cards are distributed to interested residents in senior citizens complexes. One side of the card is blue and printed with the words, ``I'm OK, A.M.'' The other side is red and reads, ``I'm OK, P.M.'' ``During the day, they put the card on the blue side, at night they switch it to red,'' said Police Chief Robert Sasso. ``A floor captain will check the doors every day. If the card hasn't been changed, they'll call management.'' ``We've had cases where people in manors have died and no one knew for a while. This is an in-house system for them to check on each other,'' he said. The program was invented by the late Doris Dubios, who was president of the Riverside Village complex in Cumberland. It started in Cumberland earlier this year and spread to neighboring Central Falls. The cards cost about $1 each to print and there are about 1,100 targeted apartments in Central Falls. The money was raised through bake sales, car washes and donations. ---
DOC.HEAD: Hospitals Offer Non-medical Stays at Lower Raare is not inexpensive, but it's worth
DOC.TEXT: it,'' said Bill Perry, a 55-year-old postal service employee. He and his wife, Linda, take care of his 88-year-old aunt, Mini Satterfield. They were the first to use the service. ``I was going out of town on a business trip, and had the chance to take my wife with me, and at the time we really needed a break,'' Perry said. ``And you can be gone and be confident that if something happens, the appropriate care will be given.'' The fee at Riverside includes three meals a day, housekeeping, a television and phone, and a certified aide to assist with dressing. Nurses supervise any required medication, and doctors are consulted if a client becomes ill.

New York manager Stump Merrill has stopped his daily medical checks on Don Mattingly. Mattingly is feeling just fine, even if it's way too late to the help the Yankees this season. But there's 1991 and the Yankees, buried deep in the American League East cellar this season, will need all the help they can get. And that starts with Mattingly, their former All-Star first baseman. ``The first couple of days back he (Merrill) was asking me how I felt. Now he just puts me in there,'' said Mattingly, who has rebounded the last three weeks after spending six weeks on the disabled list with a bad back. Mattingly went 2-for-3 with three RBIs Sunday as the Yankees beat the Milwaukee Brewers 7-2. Since coming off the DL earlier this month, he's 16-for-42 and has hit safely in 11 of 13 games. Sunday's performance lifted his batting average to .260, far below his career mark of .332. But he's demonstrated to Merrill and himself he's ready for next year. ``As far as coming back off injury, I think I've accomplished all I wanted to do, getting back and just playing some defense and playing on a regular basis and knowing that I'm going to be fine for next year,'' Mattingly said. ``That's really what I wanted to accomplish. I think it's been a success. `It's a good step for us. Coming into next year I'll just keep up with the work and stay with the routines and next season I can play every day with it.'' When did Mattingly know he'd be able to play again with his back? ``Soon as I got all the information from the doctors, who assured me that there was really nothing I could do to hurt it. I just needed to keep up with my work and if I do exercises and strength I'm going to be fine,'' he said. ``He's all right,'' Merrill said. ``If we get the question answered before this season even ends so you don't go to spring training with some doubts, it's great. He's worked hard on his rehabilitation and gone about his business.'' Jesse Barfield also had three RBIs Sunday, including a bases-loaded double to spark a four-run fifth inning. Greg Cadaret pitched four perfect innings of relief for his third save and Dave Eiland (2-1) got the victory. Greg Vaughn hit his 17th homer of the season for the Brewers, who are just above the Yankees in the AL East. MIlwaukee starter Bill Krueger left after 1 2-3 innings with a groin strain and reliever Tom Edens (4-5) gave up the four runs in the fifth. ``It was all-in-all a lackluster Sunday afternoon game,'' said Milwaukee manager Tom Trebelhorn. The Yankees' big inning started when Bob Geren, batting .212, walked and Alvaro Espinoza, hitting .224, was hit by a pitch. ``You allow less than .220 hitters to get on base without swining the bat, you set yourself up for something negative,'' Trebelhorn added. ---

President Bush and congressional leaders forged a $500-billion, five-year compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts, giving Congress a down-to-the-wire chance to block slashes in federal services due today. The package contained $134 billion in new tax revenues, including new taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, alcohol and luxury items. Medicare costs for the elderly and disabled were increased; defense spending was slashed as well. The pact, described by Bush in a mid-afternoon Rose Garden announcement, was likely to prevent a chaotic disruption in federal programs that would otherwise have occurred when the 1991 fiscal year begins Monday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The government's main economic forecasting gauge plunged 1.2 percent in August, its steepest fall in three years and an indication, one economist said, of ``nothing but dark clouds'' ahead. Seven of the 11 components of the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Indicators were off, including stock prices and an index measuring consumer confidence, the department said Friday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The House voted to give President Bush authority to triple the Strategic Petroleum Reserve oil sale he announced Wednesday, but a White House spokesman said he has no intention of doing so. On a voice vote Friday with no dissent, the House raised to 15 million barrels the ceiling on test sales from the government stocks after Energy Secretary James Watkins told lawmakers Thursday a 5 million-barrel test was inadequate. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil prices closed little changed in a quiet yet volatile session Friday. Traders saw evidence that President Bush's attempt to calm the energy markets was having some effect. The November contract for delivery of light sweet crude fell 3 cents to $39.51 a 42-gallon barrel Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after trading as high as $39.95 a barrel and falling as low as $38.65. There was no news directly from the Middle East to influence trading. --- PARIS (AP) - The International Energy Agency advised Western nations to brace for a possible oil shortage but said there was no immediate need to tap strategic reserves to offset the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Echoing the conclusions drawn at a meeting last month, the group's governing board said in a comunique Friday that rising oil price rises were driven by ``extreme political uncertainty,'' not short supplies. Supplies lost due to the embargo on Kuwait and Iraq's oil have been offset by increased production by other nations, it said, and oil markets remain adequately supplied. --- MOSCOW (AP) - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, struggling to maintain central control over Soviet political and economic life, plans to transform 550 armament factories to civilian production, his spokesman said. Gorbachev and top aides met Friday to complete the conversion plan as representatives of seven Soviet republics agreed to bypass central authorities in working out a new system of economic and political cooperation. The Supreme Soviet parliament has been unable to pass a cohesive reform plan, and on Monday granted Gorbachev extraordinary powers to transform the national economy from a planned to a market system. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - California adopted strict auto emission rules to compel production of a new generaion of ultra-clean cars and fuels, toughening the strictest air quality controls in the nation. The effort, announced Friday, is an attempt to grapple with California's enormous dilemma: some of the wors air pollution in the nation, a population of 30 million people, 22 million vehicles on the road and few mass-transit alternatives. --- CHICAGO (AP) - Whitman Corp. announced it will spin off its slumping Pet foods division, consolidate several of its operations and lay off about 1,000 employees. The company said Friday it will take a charge against its third-quarter earnings to pay for the program, which will cause losses for the quarter and year. The reorganization is an attempt by the consumer products conglomerate to cope with lagging profitability. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Plans to rescue two United Mine Workers health care funds, now staggering under an $88 million deficit, are stirring anxiety among non-union coal operators. The operators fear a new industry-wide coal tax will be proposed to bail out the troubled 1950 and 1974 UMW health benefit trusts, which serve 127,052 retired union miners, widows and dependents. In March, U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole appointed an 11-member commission to study the trusts. The panel, which has no lawmaking power, will release its recommendations at two meetings, scheduled for Oct. 11 and Oct. 17. ---

The stock market staged an impressive turnaround Friday after an initial plunge. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.00 to close at 2,452.48. Bond prices rose as traders anticipated a weekend accord on the federal budget. The dollar gained against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart. Gold futures prices fell; energy futures showed signs of breaking the $40-a-barrel barrier once again, but fell in the last hour of trading; silver and platinum extended their losses; soybean futures prices slipped; grains were mixed; livestock futures were mixed; and pork futures were higher.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Oil Prices Will Boost Farm Costs, But Crop Exports May Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Soaring crude oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis will mean higher operating costs for farmers, but an Agriculture Department analysis says there is a brighter side too. Exports of U.S. agricultural products are expected to rise as recycled oil dollars whet the appetites of overseas buyers. ``The shutoff of petroleum exports from Iraq and Kuwait has raised the specter of rapid, destabilizing oil price increases, perhaps by enough to spark a worldwide recession,'' the report said. But the track record of previous oil price shocks in 1974-75 and again in 1979-81 shows that U.S. agricultural exports do not necessarily decline. ``Recycled petrodollars can, under the right conditions, boost world demand for U.S. farm products,'' the report said. ``The strength of this linkage, to a large degree, depends on the monetary policies adopted by the industrialized countries.'' According to USDA researchers, if oil prices were to average $25 per barrel in 1990 and continue up at a 12 percent annual rate, the value of U.S. agricultural exports would rise $1 billion to $3 billion over the next three years. The lower value in the range would reflect tight monetary policies, while the higher value assumes that more ``accommodative'' policies will be adopted. In another report - both were in the October issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine - the department's Economic Research Service said farmers are not only seeing higher fuel prices but can expect costlier agricultural chemicals and fertilizer. World crude oil prices jumped 50 percent within three weeks of Iraq invading Kuwait, the report said. Further price increases have occurred. Last week, for example, the November contract for light, sweet crude oil traded for as high as $40.10 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, double the July price. The USDA agency, using computer simulations, said that while farm chemical and fertilizer prices are rising, they will not do so in step with the crude oil increases. Instead, the report said, those supplies probably will rise about one-fourth the percentage increase in oil prices and would be spread over 24 to 28 months. However, analysts cautioned that factors other than oil prices will influence the costs of agricultural production items, or inputs, in the coming months. ``Farmers' expectations of crop and livestock prices will help determine acres planted next year and the demand for inputs,'' the report said. ``All these factors will further influence chemical and fertilizer prices.'' But a review of trends over 28 years and computer models used in the projections suggest that prices for agricultural chemicals - including petroleum based pesticides - would rise 0.24 percent for each 1 percent rise in crude oil prices. The initial 50 percent increase in crude oil prices, for example, would generate a 12 percent increase in agricultural chemical prices over the following 28 months. By the same token, August's 50 percent hike in crude would mean fertilizer prices would go up about 13 percent. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Chile has been officially declared by the Agriculture Department to be free of foot-and-mouth disease and rinderpest, two major cattle diseases that have impeded livestock and meat imports from the South American country. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said last week that the absence of the two diseases in Chile means ``some of our prohibitions and restrictions on importing meat from Chilean cattle, sheep and goats'' can be removed. ``However, we must keep in place a number of special restrictions on imports of these meat products, and we also will continue current restrictions on swine and pork products,'' he said. Glosser said he doesn't expect Chile to ship much meat but foresees the possibility of ``a new flow of llamas and alpacas'' coming into the United States under the liberalized rules. Special health certification, testing and quarantine requirements have been developed for these animals, he said. Llamas and alpacas will continue to be quarantined at the Harry S. Truman Animal Import Center, a high-security facility on Fleming Key, near Key West, Fla., before they are allowed U.S. entry. Rinderpest and foot-and-mouth disease are viral infections that strike cloven-hoofed animals and are no threat to human health, Glosser said. Rinderpest has never been known to occur in Chile, and foot-and-mouth was eradicated in 1987. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An annual report by the Agriculture Department shows the 1989 potato crop was worth a record $2.72 billion to growers. That was up 27 percent from the value of the 1988 harvest and 61 percent more than the 1987 crop, the report said. Production, at 370 million hundredweight, was up 4 percent from 1988 but was down 5 percent from 1987. Prices paid to farmers averaged $7.36 per 100 pounds last year, compared with $6.02 in 1988 and $4.38 in 1987, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Partially Recover After Drop Below 20,000 Level
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices partially recovered after a precipitous fall today on expectations the government will take action to support the stock market, traders said. Meanwhile, the dollar fell against the Japanese yen following news of a budget agreement in Washington. The closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 issues finished the day at 20,221.86, down 761.64 points, or 3.63 percent, from its Friday finish. At one point the index fell below the key 20,000 level for the first time in 3{ years. ``It's really snowballing. Everything, all that's bad is just carrying over,'' one stock trader said during the slide. The Nikkei's fall brought it closer to 19,458 points, the level at which it would have erased half its value from a peak of 38,915.87 points at the end of last year. Dealers said the fall was caused in part by uncertainty over the Middle East, combined with continuing sales of stock by individual investors. An estimated 400 million shares changed hands. In a report released today, Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. said the continuing distress of Tokyo equity markets was primarily linked to growing fears about the possibility of war in the Middle East. But ``second, and most ironic, the market is suffering from the economy's strong momentum: above-potential growth and higher oil prices together imply that central bank policy will need to tighten further later this year to stem inflationary pressures,'' it said. Higher interest rates, if realized, would make stocks less attractive to investors. Monday's decline was halted by a last-minute buying spree stimulated by rumors that the Ministry of Finance would announce new market support measures, traders said. In foreign exchange dealings, the dollar closed at 137.15 yen, down 0.80 yen from last Friday's close. Dealers said the day's trading was mixed on news of a budget settlement in the United States that might lead to lower interest rates, as well as rumors that Iraq might be willing to negotiate a compromise in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Hits Many Economies Hard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's conquest of Kuwait has sent economic shock waves around the globe, doubling oil prices, plaguing stock markets, undermining business confidence and leaving poor countries in Eastern Europe and Asia in dire straits. But it has brought windfalls for oil-producing countries who will make billions of extra dollars this year as crude prices climb. Since Iraq's invasion, they have gone from $16 a barrel to around $40. Some analysts believe prices could pass the $65 mark before long, fueling inflation and raising the specter of recession and higher interest rates. ``The (Persian) gulf crisis is not only disrupting world peace and security, it's also casting a dark shadow over the prospects for world economic development and prosperity,'' Japan's Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, declared last week in Washington. The industrialized world was better prepared to cope with this crisis than the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979, despite inflationary pressures. But the debt-ridden Third World faces a grim time. The Financial Times, London's respected business daily, said the Iraqi invasion ``has put on hold hopes that the 1990s might usher in a new world order, founded in the eclipse of Communism and generating prosperity in which all mankind might share.'' Among the hardest hit victims so far are the infant democracies of Eastern Europe, who face a hard winter as they struggle to reorient their socialist economies to the marketplace. They have been dependent for decades on cheap Soviet oil and made little effort to develop alternative energy supplies or curb consumption, which had been double that of Western Europe. Earlier this year, Moscow cut back on its oil deliveries because of declining production and its own economic woes. Now Romania, Poland and much of the rest of Eastern Europe - with little hard currency to pay for increasingly expensive oil - are in deep trouble. In Czechoslovakia, officials say they will not be able to cope if oil prices hit $65 dollars a barrel. ``If that happens, we'd have to give up on economic reforms. I guess we wouldn't be the only ones,'' said a Finance Ministry official in Prague. ``If the price of oil goes as high as $50 a barrel, retail prices will go up so much that gasoline will become a luxury item,'' said Leszek Plotczyk of the Poland's state fuel monopoly CPN. The United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq is squeezing Baghdad, as intended - but it is also causing hardship to many other countries, costing them billions of dollars in lost trade. Iraq owed $30 billion to $40 billion to the Soviet Union, France, Italy and others. It was repaying some of that with oil. Now that that flow has been cut, economists and government officials say the debts are a writeoff. Some countries are hoping that the positions they stake out in the gulf crisis - even if painful now - will pay off in the long run. Turkey, which hopes some day to become a member of the European Community trading bloc, has taken big losses supporting the embargo against Iraq. ``This crisis will set a precedent as to how the West acts toward its allies,'' said Turkish Central Bank Governor Rusdu Saracoglu. Impoverished Asian countries like India, the Philippines, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, as well as Arab states, have lost billions of dollars in remittances from two to three million of their nationals working in Kuwait. The cost of airlifting home the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have fled Kuwait and Iraq has further drained their treasuries. Few of these countries, already deep in the red, will be able to cope with rising oil prices without substantial aid. In India, political analysts are predicting trouble for Prime Minister V.P. Singh's already unstable government once the financial effects of the crisis are fully felt. The World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the European Community and other organizations have rallied to help cushion the economic hardships caused by the crisis. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar reported that 11 countries have asked for assistance: Bulgaria, India, Jordan, Lebanon, the Philippines, Romania, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Tunisia, Yemen and Yugoslavia. Japan has pledged $2 billion to help Egypt, Jordan and Turkey bear the brunt of the embargo. South Korea says it will donate 30,000 tons of rice worth $10 million to these countries and extend long-term, low-interest loans of $40 million. The EC has pledged another $2 billion. IMF and World Bank officials have said more money will be available from oil producers, who are reaping hefty benefits from high oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Economies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the countries hit hardest by the Persian Gulf crisis, and their economic prospects: ---

TURKEY: As one of the so-called front-line states, it will lose an estimated $7 billion because of higher oil prices and reduced exports and tourism by the end of next year. Turkey got 60 percent of its oil from neighboring Iraq before the crisis and earned $300 million a year from Iraq in oil pipeline fees. ---

INDIA: India will lose $3.5 billion this year, said a senior Foreign Ministry official in New Delhi. That includes $1 billion spent evacuating Indian nationals from Iraq and Kuwait. Half the 185,000 Indians in the two countries have been repatriated so far. The cost of oil imports, 40 percent of which came from Iraq and Kuwait, will rise by $1.5 billion to $6 billion a year. That will drive the balance of payments deficit to a critical $5.5 billion. Fuel prices were raised by 20 percent shortly before the crisis broke, and another increase is expected. ---

THE PHILIPPINES: Few statistics are yet available, but Merill Lynch said in its monthly Asian commentary that the Philippines economy will likely be the hardest hit in the Far East. Manila imports all its oil and high prices mean a severe drain on its foreign currency reserves. Inflation is expected to increase by as much as 5 percent to 16-18 percent this year. More than 15,000 of the estimated 93,000 Filipinos in Kuwait and Iraq have been repatriated and thousands more are expected to need return home. Apart from the loss of remittances, the returning nationals will push up unemployment past the current 8 percent total. ---

EGYPT: Officials expect Egypt can weather the crisis provided aid is forthcoming, although it has a $50 billion debt. Prime Minister Atef Sedki has estimated losses at $4.5 billion, including $2.4 billion in remittances from the 1 million-plus Egyptians who worked in Kuwait and Iraq. That total does not count $10 billion to $12 billion Egyptians lost in Kuwait banks looted by the Iraqis, or writing off $446 million owed by Iraq. However, Egypt will earn an extra $1 billion this fiscal year from oil exports. President Bush has asked Congress to write off Egypt's $6.7 billion foreign debt. ---

BRAZIL: Soaring oil prices mean its import bill could double to $6 billion a year. That will make it harder to pay off Brazil's $117 billion debt. Fuel price increases will push up the cost of living and there is already speculation of rationing, which would slow down the economy. Brazil was Iraq's closest ally in South America, but economic and military links have been sharply reduced. Brazil has not sold weapons to Iraq since 1988 because of debts on previous arms sales unofficially estimated at $3 billion. ---

ROMANIA: Officials estimate the crisis will cost $3 billion, including writing off Iraq's $1.7 billion debt. Baghdad was to repay 70 percent of that in cheap oil. Now Romania, its Soviet supplies curtailed, will have to pay out an estimated $770 million. Officials estimate that contracts with Iraq worth $1.2 billion have been lost. ---

CZECHOSLOVAKIA: The embargo will cost Czechoslovakia an estimated $1 billion and it will have to write off Iraq's $1.7 billion debt, mostly for arms purchases. The loss of these sales will deprive the country of sorely needed foreign currency to buy oil after the Soviets slashed deliveries by 18 million barrels this year. ---

POLAND: Warsaw has told the U.N. Security Council the crisis has caused ``serious social and economic problems.'' Iraq was Poland's biggest trading partner in the Middle East. Losses will total about $2.4 billion for a country saddled with a $42 billion foreign debt. Warsaw was owed $500 million by Iraq, mainly for arms purchases and cancelled contracts amount to $1.5 billion. Iraq was Poland's main source of oil after the Soviet Union. Already hit by recession because of tough economic reforms, Poland is highly vulnerable to high oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Bundesbank Issues New 100 and 200 Banknotes
DOC.TEXT: Germany's central bank began on Monday issuing new 100 and 200 mark banknotes that it says are virtually impossible to forge. The notes also have an imprint that makes them readable to blind people. The Bundesbank said the new notes will replace old money over a period of two years. The 200-mark note is introduced for the first time. The issue comes one day before German unification, but the move had been planned for several years.

DOC.HEAD: China Announces Record Harvest
DOC.TEXT: China will harvest a record 422 million tons of grain this year, providing the economy's lone bright spot amid poor factory output and growing government debt, official reports said Monday. The China Daily quoted Agriculture Vice Minister Chen Yaobang as saying the grain crop will be about 15 million tons over last year's record 407 million tons. He said good harvests also are exected in cotton, edible oils and sugar. Chen's announcement comes as good news to the Communist Party leadership, which typically emphasizes grain production on the premise that a well-fed population is its best guarantee of staying in power. During the past 18 months, the party has been under particular stress from the collapse of Communist rule in the East bloc, demands for greater democracy at home and deep divisions among party leaders on how to respond. Determined to maintain stability in the countryside, at least, the government last spring increased investment in land reclamation and irrigation and made more credit available to farmers. It recentralized the sale of fertilizer and pesticides, which had been sold on the free market and were becoming expensive as demand drove up prices. The government also renewed its insistence that farmers plant more grain and fewer vegetables and other crops. Grain production slumped in the mid- and late 1980s because farmers found they could earn more by planting other crops. This summer, the government announced plans to raise its grain purchase price but did not say by how much. It also said the state would buy the entire grain harvest, a practice abandoned in the 1980s. In recent years the state contracted with each farmer to buy part of his harvest, leaving him free to sell the rest on the free market for a potentially higher price. The arrangement was considered a first step toward market reform. However, the China Daily said the government feared farmers would not get good prices on the free market this year because the supply of grain was so plentiful, and that would discourage them from planting grain next spring. So far, the government has not announced any increase in the price at which it sells grain to city residents, which has remained unchanged for 25 years. City dwellers pay about 2 Cents a pound, about one-seventh of what the state pays the farmers. Subsidizing grain has become a major drain on the state budget. The China Daily recently said that by Western accounting methods, the budget deficit this year will total $9 billion. State-owned industry has become another drain, with profits down more than 50 percent from last year's level. A record number of state factories are reported in the red.

DOC.HEAD: JVC, MCA Announce Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Victor Co. of Japan said Monday it will create a new record company with the music division of the U.S. entertainment giant MCA. The new company, formed between JVC and MCA Music Entertainment Group, will market and promote the record labels MCA, Geffen and GRP in Japan, according to a statement from JVC, manufacturer of a wide range of audio equipment, records, compact discs. JVC spokesman Masayuki Murakami said the move was not related to reports of a buyout of MCA by JVC's parent company, the consumer electronics giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Murakami said the agreement will cover records and compact discs; music videos were under negotiation. Among the artists that record under the three labels are Tom Petty, Guns 'n Roses, Aerosmith and Chick Corea. The deal gives Matsushita access to audio software while helping MCA market its products in Japan, said Barry Dargan, senior technology analyst at James Capel & Co. The new venture, which will be owned equally by the two companies and begin operations next year, also could help JVC develop a market for digital audio tape, or DAT. Murakami said MCA approached JVC about the record deal, and negotiations began last spring. ``As far as our talks with MCA are concerned, it was ... nothing related to Matsushita talks with MCA,'' Murakami said. Last week, Matsushita confirmed it was holding talks with MCA but refused to elaborate. Reports said the Japanese company was considering a buyout of MCA, which includes Universal Pictures, valued at $7 billion. Last year, rival Sony Corp. acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment, in large part to gain control over its rich library of old films and television shows. Purchases of film libraries allow consumer electronics companies to release old movies and television shows for the videotape recorders they manufacture, and also provide material for future high-definition television recordings. JVC originated the VHS video format, while Sony is a strong backer of 8-millimeter video.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers React to Budget Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The 133-percent rise in the federal gasoline tax included in the proposed budget agreement could be good news for the nation, Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca says. ``Our biggest economic need is lower interest rates, everybody agrees to that,'' Iacocca said in a statement after negotiators reached agreement on the program Sunday. ``This budget package gives (Federal Reserve Chairman) Alan Greenspan the tools to make sure we get them.'' But other U.S. automakers, who have been wrestling with slumping sales, rising gasoline prices and declining profits, were more cautious when reacting to the greement reached this weekend between congressional leaders and the Bush administration. General Motors Corp. spokesman Bill Noack said this morning that company officials were reviewing the proposal. In the past, GM has oppos, let the FBI keep parts of its file on Todd Patterson of North Haledon, N.J., secret for ``national security'' reasons. When Patterson was an elementary school student in 1983, he began an ambitious project - to prepare a personal world encyclopedia. To that end, he wrote letters to representatives of 169 countries seeking information about their peoples and governments. Patterson mailed his inquiries in envelopes bearing the return address of Laboratory Disposable Products, a business operated by his parents from their home. According to government lawyers, the large amount of international mail generated by the project ``came to the attention of the Federal Bureau of Investigation through classified means.'' The agency opened an investigation, but it apparently was halted after an agent visited the Pattersons' home and discovered the nature and purpose of Todd's correspondence. Patterson, now a student at the State University of New York at Plattsburgh, requested copies of his personal FBI file in 1987. The request, made under the Freedom of Information Act, was denied. Patterson was told the files could not be released because of national security reasons. Some information from the files subsequently was released, but the rest remained classified. Patterson sued the FBI and an unknown government agency in 1988, seeking full disclosure of the files and monetary damages. In response to his lawsuit, the government offered to expunge his name from all FBI records. The offer was not accepted. U.S. District Judge Alfred M. Wolin in New Jersey threw out Patterson's suit last year after looking at the entire FBI file. He ruled that the files properly were exempted from disclosure under the FOIA. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that rulin last January. In the appeal acted on today, Patterson contended that his rights under the Privacy Act of 1974 were violated by the FBI investigation. The law strictly limits government investigations into the free-speech activities of U.S. citizens. The case is Patterson vs. FBI, 89-1731.

Prices moved higher on Wall Street today in response to the federal budget agreement reached over the weekend. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.32 to 2,469.80 as of 10 a.m. EDT. Advancing issues surpassed decliners by a margin of about 5 to 2 in the early going, with 826 stocks rising, 321 falling and 338 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 29.57 million shares after the first 30 minutse of trading. The long-awaited budget accord announced over the weekend in Washington raised hopes that the Federal Reserve would finally allow interest rates to decline. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan has said the approval of a deficit cutting agreement would give the nation's central bank more leeway in allowing rates to drop. Stocks also got some help today by a drop in oil prices. The November contract for light, sweet crude fell $1.46 to $38.05 a barrel in early New York Mercantile Exchange trading. Among blue chip issues, IBM was up 1{ to 107~, Boeing rose 1[ to 42}, and General Electric advanced | to 55[. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.00 to 168.85. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 307.84, up 0.11. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average gained 25.00 to 2,452.48. Advancing issues narrowly outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 877 up, 693 down and 408 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 201.01 million shares, against 182.69 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Resolve Arkansas Dispute over Cable TV Taxation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to resolve a dispute from Arkansas over the power of states to tax cable television companies and subscribers. The court said it will review a ruling that Arkansas may tax cable TV as long as it also imposes the levy on similar communication services, such as the unscrambling of satellite signals. With millions of dollars in tax revenue at stake, the ruling was challenged in separate appeals by both the state and cable operators and subscribers. Arkansas in 1987 imposed its sales tax on cable TV service. The law did not apply to those who own satellite dishes and subscribe to services that unscramble satellite signals. Also exempted from the tax were all newspaper sales and magazine subscription sales. The Arkansas Supreme Court ruled in February that the tax unlawfully discriminated against cable TV service because satellite service was excluded.But the state court said it is permissible for the state to exclude the newspaper and magazine sales. ``We are unwilling to hold that all mass communications media must be taxed in the same way,'' the state court said. ``We must, however, hold, that a tax which discriminates between mass communicators delivering the same service runs afoul of the First Amendment'' guarantee of free expression. By the time the state court ruled, the Arkansas Legislature had amended the law to extend the tax to satellite service ``and all other distribution of television, video or audio services with or without the use of wires.'' The state court ordered Arkansas officials to refund to cable operators and subscribers more than $8 million in taxes paid prior to enactment of the amended tax. State officials, seeking to avoid the refunds, asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overrule the state court decision. The cable operators and subscribers also appealed, urging the high court to issue a more sweeping decision that the state may not single out the electronic media for taxation when print media are exempt. The justices in 1987, in a case from Arkansas, said states generally may not tax some types of publications while exempting others. The court, by a 7-2 vote, struck down an Arkansas sales tax imposed on general interest magazines but which exempted newspapers and religious, professional, trade and sports journals. The cases acted on today are Pledger vs. Medlock, 90-29, and Medlock vs. Pledger, 90-38.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Oklahoma Case on Cigarette Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether Oklahoma may collect a sales tax on cigarettes and other items sold at a Shawnee convenience store owned and run by an Indian tribe. The justices said they will review a ruling that would bar the imposition of such a tax. Asked for its views, the Bush administration advised the justices to send the case back to a federal appeals court for further study. The justices ignored that advice. The store belongs to the Citizen Band Potawatomi Indian Tribe, and is located on land held in trust for the tribe by the federal government. Oklahoma law requires all vendors to collect from consumers sales taxes of 6 or 7 percent - 4 percent for the state and 2 or 3 percent for local communities. The state also imposes an excise tax on the sale of cigarettes. The Potawatomis have never collected sales taxes or the cigarette excise tax on items sold in their convenience store. In 1987 state officials assessed the tribe $2.7 million for the sale and distribution of untaxed cigarettes. The tribe challenged the assessment in court, and U.S. District Judge Lee R. West blocked enforcement of the cigarette tax pending the tribe's lawsuit. West later ruled that cigarettes sold to tribal members could not be taxed but that the tribe must collect taxes on cigarettes sold to non-members. But the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last November ruled that the tribe does not have to collect any state or local taxes on items sold at the store, even to non-members. The appeals court said Oklahoma officials wrongly relied on a 1980 Supreme Court ruling in a Washington state case to justify the taxing of sales to non-tribal members. In the 1980 case, the appeals court said, ``the Indian tribe had opted to come under state jurisdiction.'' It said, ``Because no such jurisdiction exists in this case, Oklahoma's reliance on (the 1980 decision) is misplaced.'' In the appeal acted on today, Oklahoma officials said, ``The case turns on whether federal law has pre-empted state law or whether state action has infringed tribal self-government.'' The appeal added, ``The state simply suggests that the tribe may operate its government in any way that it sees fit. However, if the tribe operates a business in the state, it must obey applicable state laws.'' The case is Oklahoma Tax Commission vs. Citizen Band Potawatomi Indian Tribe, 89-1322.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Will Hear S&L Tax Liability Case from Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether savings and loan associations and other financial institutions may claim tax deductions for ``reciprocal sales'' of mortgage loans. With a reported $419 million plus interest at stake, the court said it will hear Internal Revenue Service arguments against allowing such deductions. Two federal appeals courts have ruled against the IRS and one has ruled for the tax agency. The justices' decision, expected by July, will resolve the conflicting rulings. An IRS victory would mean more bad news for some struggling S&Ls. In the lead case granted review today, a Greenville, Texas, savings and loan challenged an IRS refusal to treat the sale of its mortgage loans to another S&L as a transaction that generated a loss for tax purposes. Centennial Savings Bank, formerly known as First Federal Savings and Loan of Greenville, entered into a deal with another savings and loan in which it sold a package of interests in a group of residential mortgage loans for a similar package of mortgage loan interests. The thrifts were taking advantage of a rule adopted in 1980 by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board allowing reciprocal sales of depreciated ``substantially identical mortgage loans'' without having to record a loss for regulatory accounting purposes. The rule allowed savings institutions to engage in transactions to generate deductible losses for federal tax purposes without worrying about failing to meet the bank board's minimum reserve and liquidity requirements. In 1981, Centennial's mortgage loan portfolio was comprised primarily of long-term home mortgage loans that had been issued in the late 1960s at fixed interest rates significantly lower than current rates. Because of the low interest they earned, the fair market value of these older loans fell far below their face amount. Centennial had a tax incentive for disposing of the old mortgage loans. Selling them would enable it to realize a tax loss based on the difference between the face amounts and the sale prices of the mortgages it sold. After the IRS ruled that Centennial could not claim a tax deduction for the transaction, the savings and loan paid its assessed taxes and sued for a refund. A federal judge ruled for the government, but the New Orleans-based 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last November reversed the judge's ruling. The appeals court also ruled in cases involving savings and loans from San Antonio and Temple, Texas. In seeking Supreme Court review, government lawyers noted that the Cincinnati-based 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had ruled that such transactions do not result in tax-deductible losses. That case involves the Cottage Savings Association of Cincinnati. ``The IRS has advised that there are currently pending administratively and in the courts 96 cases involving approximately $419 million (excluding interest) that turn on the resolution of the mortgage exchange issue,'' the government's appeal in the Centennial case said. While the dispute was pending before the 5th Circuit court, Centennial was found insolvent by the bank board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation was appointed as receiver. The successor Resolution Trust Corp. then took over as receiver. The cases are U.S. vs. Centennial Savings Bank, 89-1926, and Cottage Savings Association vs. Commissioner, Internal Revenue, 89-1965.

DOC.HEAD: Court Permits Libel Suit in Comparative Ads Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill a libel lawsuit stemming from advertisements comparing Blue Cross and Blue Shield services to those of a health industry competitor. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that could send U.S. Healthcare's libel allegations against Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a federal jury in Philadelphia. At issue was whether some libel cases involving commercial speech could be held to less stringent standards than others. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in reviving Healthcare's suit last March, relaxed the rules for commercial-speech libel cases. Since 1964, public figures - including most businesses - suing for libel must prove that the sued-over statements are false and were made with ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of falsity. Private citizens suing for libel face a far less demanding burden: Having to prove that the statements are false and were made negligently. In ruling on Healthcare's lawsuit, the 3rd Circuit court said the more stringent ``actual malice'' standard need not be used when the allegedly libelous statements were advertisements. The appeals court overturned a ruling by U.S. District Judge Marvin Katz, who had dismissed the suit. As described by the appeals court, the underlying dispute stems from ``a comparative advertising war between giants of the health care industry in the Delaware Valley'' of southeastern Pennsylvania. Blue Cross and Blue Shield fired the first salvos in 1986 after losing some subscribers to the health maintenance organization (HMO) offered by Healthcare. Blue Cross and Blue Shield ran what it termed a deliberately aggressive and provocative comparative advertising campaign for about six months at a cost of $2.17 million. Healthcare responded to that campaign by starting its own comparative ad campaign and by suing. Its suit alleged, among other things, defamation. The case is Independence Blue Cross vs. U.S. Healthcare, 89-1869.

DOC.HEAD: Hussein's Calmer Tone Pushes Oil Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Oil and petroleum products prices fell on the futures market this morning as traders sensed a more conciliatory stance being taken by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Saddam today ordered the release of nine French nationals who were believed to have been held at key locations in an effort to deter an attack by Western military forces. The release comes a day after Saddam praised French President Francois Mitterrand for offering ``positive'' ideas on resolving the Middle East crisis. Light sweet crude was down $1.61 to $37.90 per barrel for November contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange late this morning. Other contract months were also trading lower. Home heating oil fell 3.22 cents to $1.027 per gallon for November delivery, with other months also lower. Unleaded gasoline dropped 3.56 cents to 95.15 cents per gallon on November contracts, with other months also down. Natural gas contracts were down for all months, with November delivery falling 1.5 cents to $1.92 per 1,000 cubic feet. ``This is just not a buying opportunity,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``Most important is a slight ease in tensions now. It might be premature, but it's some type of hope that we haven't been seeing.''

DOC.HEAD: Alabama's Roberts Sworn in as SEC Commissioner
DOC.TEXT: Attorney Richard Y. Roberts was sworn in Monday to fill a vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Roberts, 39, a native of Birmingham, Ala., was sworn in by U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin, a former chief of the SEC's Enforcement Division. Roberts, a former top aide to Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., was nominated by President Bush in early August. He succeeds Joseph Grundfest, who left the five-member commission in January. While he has no professional experience in securities law, Roberts said at confirmation hearings that he would bring a ``useful congressional perspective to the commission,'' which was created in 1934. The SEC regulates stocks and bonds markets, the exchanges that trade in them and other financial markets such as mutual funds.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Announces Contracts to Buy Up to 118 Airbuses
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines on Monday announced agreements to buy or lease 74 to 118 Airbus Industrie A-320s in a deal worth up to $5 billion. Airline President Michael J. Conway said the carrier has lined up 74 aircraft on firm order, including the lease of 16 immediately, and has options on another 44. Assuming the exercise of the options, Conway said, the aircraft will be delivered over a 15-year period. Parties to the agreement include Kawasaki Enterprises, which is to deliver 24 aircraft over a five-year period beginning in 1992; Guinness Peat Aviation, which will supply the first 16 planes and lease another 10 to America West through an affiliate between 1993 and 1996; and International Aero Engines. International Aero builds the engines for the fuel-efficient, 148-passenger jetliner. America West plans to begin A-320 service in January and have 16 in service by mid-1991, Conway said. He said as part of the agreement, America West received cash advances, supplier and lessor support, and spare parts totaling $220 million. ``This is by far the largest single aircraft order in our history, and by its terms it makes America West a much stronger carrier,'' Conway said. ``With long-term lease financing already in place for the first 50 aircraft, and a very strong up-front support package, our company is in an excellent position to realize several opportunities in the marketplace over the near term,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Issues 3 Recalls; Extends 1 Warranty
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Monday issued three safety- and emissions-related recalls and extended a transmission warranty affecting about 606,000 civilian and 1,200 police cars. No injuries have been reported stemming from any of the problems, Ford said. The automaker said it would replace heavy-duty steel wheels on the 1990-model Taurus police cars because they could break apart. The company said it has received one report of a cracked wheel and would replace all wheels, including spares. The company also recalled about 144,000 1989-90-model Ford Bronco and F-series super cabs with tip-slide seats to reinforce the floor pan under the seats. The company said crakks have been noticed in seats in about 10 percent of the trucks. Ford said it was recalling about 228,000 1986 Ford Thunderbird, Mustang, LTD and Mercury Cougar, Capri and Marquis cars with 3.8-liter engines because of potentially excessive hydrocarbon and carbon monoxide exhaust emissions. Finally, Ford said it would extend the transmission warranties on about 234,000 1986-87 Ranger and Bronco II vehicles to six years or 60,000 miles, or six months from the notification date. The company said a shift-lever housing could crack during a hard shift into gear, which may freeze the transmission in the last gear selected. Ford will replace the shift lever and housing in vehicles where such cracks occur. Repairs or replacements will be performed for free.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Commission Votes Against Raising Oil Production
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Railroad Commission voted 2-1 Monday against raising oil production in the East Texas Field by 8,000 to 15,000 barrels a day. One commissioner said the extra oil isn't needed despite the Persian Gulf crisis. ``There is no shortage of oil on the market any more. ... The only thing hiking the price of oil is the New York Mercantile Exchange, based on rumor,'' said Commissioner John Sharp. Sharp and Commissioner Jim Nugent outvoted Chairman Kent Hance in keeping the East Texas Field production at 86 percent. The U.S. Energy Department had asked the commission to increase production to help offset oil lost due to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The commission in August voted to allow the production of about 20,000 more barrels of oil per day from wells outside the East Texas Field. Most of the higher production is coming from fields in the Austin Chalk in South Texas. ``All of the oil that was stopped from Kuwait and Iraq has been replaced either domestically, by Venezuela or by Saudi Arabia,'' Sharp said. According to the Railroad Commission, the state produced 1.78 million barrels of oil a day last year, down from 3.36 million a day in 1974 and 2.55 million a day in 1980. Many independent oil producers in East Texas opposed the production incrnglish husband. An Americanized version of the British film starring Dudley Moore, the show was started while the team was still taking classes at BMI. Only later, when the musical was nearly finished, did the two collaborators learn they couldn't get the rights to the movie. They still haven't, but that hasn't stopped them from trying. Ira Weitzman, major domo of the musical theater program at Playwrights Horizons, spotted them at one of their many presentations of songs from ``Bedazzled.'' ``He was interested in us as writers,'' Flaherty recalls. ``He said, `Show me what you have.' '' Through Playwrights, the team got a government grant and a lot of encouragement to keep writing. Weitzman put them together with George C. Wolfe, author of such off-Broadway hits as ``The Colored Museum'' and ``Spunk.'' They collaborated on a musical called ``Antler,'' but it fizzled too. ``It was a good idea in search of a story,'' Ahrens says now. Then they wrote ``The Emperor's New Clothes,'' which was produced as an hour-long children's musical by Theaterworks U.S.A. at New York's Town Hall and later toured the country. Playwrights Horizons nourished their next show, ``Lucky Stiff,'' a non-stop musical farce in which the title character is anything but alive. The musical had a short run at Playwrights Horizons in 1988, and since then has had productions around the country and in Japan. A Toronto company is pending for this season. Emotion was what Ahrens and Flaherty were looking for in their fifth musical project. They found it in ``My Love, My Love'' by Trinidad-born writer Rosa Guy. Ahrens discovered the novel on a remainder shelf in a discount book shop. It eventually became ``Once on This Island.'' The story, set in the French Antilles, is simple and sweet. It tells the tale of i Moune, a dark-skinned peasant girl who falls in love with a wealthy young mulatto. She saves his life, but he marries among his own class. Ti Moune dies of a broken heart but the gods take pity on her. They transform her into a tree to guard the young man's home. The pair wrote ``Once on This Island'' in about six months. ``We made an outline of the scenes,'' Ahrens recalls. ``We said, `This or that will happen here.' And then we just started coming up with the songs. And the songs became the story.'' Ahrens also wrote dialogue for the musical, but the team found the show's energy level dropping whenever the characters stopped singing and began speaking. ``It's not that we set out to musicalize everything, it's just that's the way it evolved,'' Flaherty says. If they can, composer and lyricist work together five days a week, usually three or four hours a day in either Ahrens' Greenwich Village apartment or Flaherty's tiny East Side studio. Their newest project, musical No. 6, is ``My Favorite Year,'' based on the Peter O'Toole movie about a drunken movie star and the young writer hired to keep him out of trouble. Act 1 is complete, as are parts of the second act. The book is by Joseph Dougherty, writer of television's ``thirtysomething.'' Eventually the team hopes to have a reading of the show, perhaps at Playwrights Horizons, and then maybe shop it around to a regional theater before braving New York again. ``It's a big musical with 12 principal roles,'' says Flaherty. ``It's got a real brassy, '50s sound to it. It's so much fun.'' ``The show is what musicals used to be like,'' sighs Ahrens. ``It really belongs on Broadway.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court to Decide on Cable TV Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also on general news wires
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to resolve a dispute over the power of states to tax cable television companies and subscribers. Separately, the court also left intact a policy that allows federally regulated banks to sell insurance and agreed to decide whether U.S. businesses break the law if they discriminate against Americans they employ outside the country. In the cable TV case, the court will review a ruling that Arkansas may tax cable TV as long as it also imposes the levy on similar communication services, such as the unscrambling of satellite signals. A 1987 Arkansas law imposed a sales tax on cable TV service but did not apply to newspaper and magazine subscriptions as well as to those who own satellite dishes and subscribe to services that unscramble satellite signals. The Arkansas Supreme Court ruled the tax unlawfully discriminated against cable TV service and ordered officials to refund to cable operators and subscribers more than $8 million in taxes paid. State officials, seeking to avoid the refunds, asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overrule the state court decision. Separately, the court rejected an appeal by insurance industry lawyers who said the Federal Reserve Board policy of allowing federally regulated banks to sell insurance could lead banks into the same ``morass that has befallen the savings and loan industry.'' In other matters, the court: - Will decide whether Congress intended a major anti-bias law to reach beyond the nation's borders. The case involves a former oil industry employee who was working in Saudi Arabia. A federal appeals court said the law has no effect outside the country, but federal trial judges have ruled otherwise. - Agreed to decide whether Oklahoma may collect a sales tax on cigarettes and other items sold at a Shawnee convenience store owned and run by an Indian tribe. The justices said they will review a ruling that would bar the imposition of such a tax. - Left intact a ruling that USX Corp. illegally discriminated against blacks at a Fairless Hills, Pa., steel mill. - Let stand a ruling that threw out former major leaguer Jim Bouton's $1 million damage award over a baseball Wrigley subsidiary's bubble gum product that resembles chewing tobacco. - Refused to kill a libel lawsuit stemming from advertisements comparing Blue Cross and Blue Shield services to those of a health industry competitor. Without comment, the court left intact a ruling that could send U.S. Healthcare's libel allegations against Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a federal jury in Philadelphia. - Asked the Bush administration whether state ``lemon laws'' should be allowed to give buyers of chronically defective automobiles more legal protection than they receive under federal law. The court invited Justice Department lawyers to comment on arguments by domestic and foreign car makers that such state laws impermissibly conflict with federal law.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Beans Down
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were sharply down Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, as a result of increased harvest pressures and declines on the precious metal and energy markets. Wheat futures prices fell to levels from two weeks ago amid doubts the Soviet Union does not plan to buy subsidized wheat flour from the government, along with professional selling by major companies and near-ideal harvest conditions, analysts said. ``There's a very weak export outlook to buy grains,'' said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co. in New York. ``You're moving grains into positions to be sold and you don't have any ready buyers, so that's going to push prices lower.'' Soybean futures pushed toward double-digit losses as major corporations sold off their interest. Near-ideal weather conditions in areas where the crop is grown also added pessimism the entire harvest would be sold, Spilka said. Corn followed soybeans and wheat amid the same fears. DOC.HEAD: AmBase Corp. in Definitive Pact to Sell Insurance Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: AmBase Corp. said Monday it has reached a definitive agreement to sell its insurance subsidiary to a group of European investors in a deal valued at $970 million. The deal, with Trygg-Hansa Holding AB, Sweden's second-largest insurer, and the European investor group Vik Brothers International, finalizes a tentative agreement announced in August. Under terms of the deal, which includes the brokerage unit Gruntal Financial Corp. and Sterling Forest Corp. real estate holdings, the acquirers will pay $507 million in cash and assume outstanding debt. The deal is subject to regulatory and shareholder approval. The sale comes as AmBase, a financial services holding company, faces lower earnings stemming from weak insurance results, a decline in the value of its junk bond investments and a slow banking business due partly to weakness in the real estate market. AmBase common stock was trading below $1 a share in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The company's bonds, however, were up as much as $14 per $100 in face value. AmBase will retain Carteret Bancorp, leaving itself as a holding company with assets totaling $6 billion and less than 2,000 employees. AmBase currently has $13 billion in assets and 9,400 workers. AmBase said in February it was putting its insurance operations on the auction block to help boost its stock price and repay debt. Home Insurance, which was founded in 1853, is AmBase's largest insurance company with 2,000 agents and brokers nationwide and $2.3 billion in gross premiums written in 1989. Most of its premiums were in commercial and specialty lines.

It might be a good-looking pro 1988, citing Iranian terrorism and subversion. The Saudis were one of Iraq's main backers in the Iran-Iraq war. The meeting apparently did not go much beyond both sides spelling out their positions. But it was the most positive sign yet that the two countries may be moving toward a rapprochement amid the political upheaval triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The meeting apparently came out of a mediation effort by Syrian President Hafez Assad, Iran's key Arab ally and longtime rival of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Assad, who is now also allied with the United States and Saudi Arabia against Iraq, visited Tehran for the first time last month. He apparently encouraged Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani to speed up efforts to end the feud with Riyadh. Healing the rift would help draw Iran into the anti-Iraq camp and intensify Saddam's isolation at a time when U.N.-imposed sanctions are believed to be having an impact and a U.S.-led multinational force is growing mightier by the day. An Iran-Saudi rapprochement would be a major setback for Saddam not only in his efforts to rally Moslems to his cause, but by perhaps causing Iran to seal its long border with Iraq, making sanctions more effective. Saddam has been courting Iran in efforts to puncture the U.N. embargo. Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, is keen to end Iran's isolation and restore relations with the West and gulf states. Rafsanjani faces powerful, anti-Western radicals at home who favor helping Iraq confront the swelling multinational military buildup in Saudi Arabia. But the diplomatic and economic gains Iran has garnered since the gulf crisis erupted has helped strengthen Rafsanjani's hand. IRNA gave no timetable for a rapprochement. But it quoted Saud as saying his country is eager to resolve the issue of how many pilgrims Iran can send to Mecca, Islam's holiest shrine, before the next pilgrimage season that starts in June. IRNA quoted Velayati as telling Saud that the main stumbling block for resuming relations is the pilgrimage dispute. Prince Saud ``promised that his government will do its best so that Iranian Moslems perform their rituals in a suitable manner,'' the agency said. In 1987, more than 400 people, most of them Iranian pilgrims, were killed in what the Saudis said were Iranian-inspired riots in Mecca, birthplace of the Prophet Mohammed, Islam's founder.
