The following year, the Saudis announced a quota system that restricted the number of pilgrims to 1,000 for every 1 million citizens of Moslem countries. The Iranians protested the move, which would have cut their contingent from 150,000 to around 55,000. They have boycotted the pilgrimage since then. IRNA said Velayati stressed that Tehran ``is strongly opposed to the presence of foreign forces in the Persian Gulf and especially holy lands'' in Saudi Arabia. However, the Iranians have also condemned Saddam's invasion of Kuwait and blamed him for bringing U.S.-led Western forces back into the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Economy Hits Lowest Level Since Late 1982
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contains summary of other economic reports
DOC.TEXT: The nation's manufacturing economy last month hit its lowest level since the end of the previous recession in late 1982, according to a key business survey released Monday. The third straight monthly drop in the National Association of Purchasing Management index provided more evidence of an imminent recession and reflected increased prices from the Persian Gulf crisis. The group said its indexes for production, new orders, imports, inventories and employment all dropped sharply last month. Meanwhile, its price index shot up to its highest level since September 1988. ``Coupled with sharply rising prices for petroleum-related products spawned by the Middle East crisis, the immediate outlook appears to be the worst of all combinations, a declining economy with rising inflation,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the group's business survey committee. The group's Purchasing Managers' Index, which tracks overall business activity at 300 industrial companies, fell to 44.4 percent, down sharply from 47.0 percent in August. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing economy is declining. September's reading was the lowest since 42.8 percent in December 1982, the first month of the current economic expansion. The index stood at 46.0 percent a year ago. In other economic news, the government reported that construction spending stalled in August after posting its first gain in four months in July. Sagging consumer confidence and the Gulf crisis were to blame, analysts said. A real estate trade group said the average American family's ability to buy a home improved in August, thanks to a combination of falling prices, lower mortgage rates and rising incomes. But the National Association of Realtors said the improvement was curtailed by the Gulf crisis and the general weakness of the economy. The purchasing management report, although grim, helped spark a rally in the stock market. Coupled with the long-awaited federal budget accord announced over the weekend, the report raised hopes that the Federal Reserve would finally allow interest rates to decline. David Wyss, chief economist with DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., said the purchasing management figures were not surprising because the manufacturing sector has been slumping for more than a year. But he added that ``right now we're looking for evidence of recession and this is certainly one more bit.'' The manufacturing sector has been in what some economists label a recession because of a decline in consumer purchases of durable goods such as automobiles, a slowdown in non-defense capital goods purchases and a decline in defense spending. New orders by companies fell for the third straight month, to 44.5 percent from 46.4 percent in August, the lowest level since November 1982 at the trough of the recession. Thirty percent of those businesses surveyed said their new orders declined from August, while 23 percent said they were better and 47 percent unchanged. The group's production index fell to 45.1 percent from 48.5 percent in August, its lowest level since December 1982. A total of 29 percent of those surveyed said production declined, while 23 percent said it increased and 48 percent reported no change. The imports index fell to 45.5 percent from 47.5 percent, its lowest level in nine months. New export orders, though, increased for the 33rd straight month, with the index up to 54.0 percent from 53.0 percent. But Wyss said even the exports sector is likely to be pinched in the coming months. ``Now with the oil shock hitting the rest of the world too, that is likely to be slowing down,'' he said. Inventories declined in Septmeber for the 22nd straight month, while supplier deliveries were slightly faster, indicating a declining economy. Prices shot up, with 50 percent of those surveyed reporting increases against just 6 percent reporting decreases. The price index leaped to 73.4 percent in Septemer from 58.2 percent in August, the biggest one-month gain since August 1975. Meanwhile, the group's employment index declined for the 19th straight month at its greatest rate in five years, adding to the sector's woes. The group said purchasers were concerned suppliers would use uncertainty from the Middle East crisis to raise prices more, even when increases are not warranted. In a special question on capital spending plans for the next six to 12 months, 88 percent of respondents said their plans had not changed because of the Gulf standoff, 8 percent said they were revised downward and 4 percent revised upward. Of the 69 percent of respondents who said they had requested new or additional credit since June, 96.5 percent said they had encounted no difficulty and 3.5 percent reported tightened lending conditions. The National Association of Purchasing Management is a research and education organization with more than 33,000 members.

The stock market staged a strong rally today, encouraged by falling oil prices and hopes for lower interest rates. A monthly report on the economy from the National Association of Purchasing Management, coupled with the long-awaited federal budget accord announced over the weekend, raised hopes that the Federal Reserve would finally allow interest rates to decline. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, has said the approval of a deficit cutting agreement would give the nation's central bank more leeway in allowing rates to drop. The purchasing managers report, meanwhile, provided further evidence of a weakening manufacturing economy. The purchasing managers monthly index fell sharply in September for its third consecutive drop. The market expected the report to put further pressure on the Fed to lower rates as a means of stimulating the economy. Stocks also got some help from a drop in oil prices. Crude oil for November delivery fell more than $3 a barrel to just above $36 a barrel in New York Mercantile Exchange trading.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi To Increase Output, Calls For Stockpile Dips By Companies
DOC.TEXT: Oil Minister Hisham Nazer expressed concern about spiraling oil prices on Monday and said Saudi Arabia would continue to increase production. The kingdom has raised its own output by more than 2 million barrels per day to help remedy the situation and ``will increase its output at close intervals in the near future,'' Nazer was quoted as saying before the weekly session of the Saudi government chaired by King Fahd. ``There is no need whatsoever for panic to spread in the market, since consumption in the fourth quarter of the year is estimated at 54.5 million barrels per day, with various sources capable of providing 53 million barrels per day,'' Information Minister Ali al-Shaer quoted Nazer as saying in a report on the cabinet session to the Saudi Press Agency. ``The remainder would be no more than 1.5 million barrels per day or 2 million at most, and that can be withdrawn from the commercial stockpiles which are estimated at 700 million barrels at present,'' Nazer said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the price of oil has reached as high as $41 dollars a barrel for Brent crude and $37 for Dubai crude. Nazer warned that ``the effects of such increases, if they continue to escalate, will be grave for both developing as well as industrialized countries.'' He recalled the special meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the outset of the gulf crisis, when prices were $27.50 per barrel for Brent and $25 for Dubai. ``It was a price far beyond what the market could absorb economically or be borne by the developing nations,'' he said. With the Aug. 2 invasion, the market suffered a shortfall of 4.5 million barrels per day that the two countries used to export. Nazer noted that Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, had raised its oil by ``more than 2 million barrels a day.'' The kingdom is using the best industrialized techniques in its production, he said, ``and will increase that output at close intervals in the near future without affecting its oil fields.'' The statement was an apparent denial of reports that Saudi Arabia might not be able to maintain its output of 7.5 million barrels per day because of technical difficulties.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Next for Auto Talks
DOC.TEXT: Workers at General Motors overwhelmingly ratified a new three-year contract, the United Auto Workers union announced Monday. Union and company officials said the next round of talks would shift to Ford. UAW President Owen Bieber plans to resume negotiations Tuesday with Ford Motor Co. which had been placed on hold for over a month during the General Motors Corp. talks. ``We want to get on with this thing,'' Ford spokesman Dick Routh said Monday. Negotiations between the union and Ford had been stalled since Aug. 28, when the UAW chose to focus its attention on GM. The new GM-UAW pact was approved by 86,032 votes in favor to 21,461 opposed, the union said in a statement Monday. Less than 36 percent of the approximately 300,000 eligible UAW members cast ballots during elections last week and Sunday. About 100,000 active Ford employees are covered under the existing contract that technically expired at midnight Sept. 14. Contract provisions at all three auto makers were extended while bargaining continued. In all, more that 450,000 active auto workers are covered by the three contracts. ``This agreement will serve as an excellent pattern for new contracts at Ford and Chrysler,'' Bieber and Vice President Stephen Yokich, in charge of the union's GM Department, said in a joint statement. There are a few provisions of the GM-UAW agreement that will be troublesome to Ford, including new premiums on overtime work. But it's expected that an agreement nearly parallel to the GM deal will be signed by Ford. The GM agreement contains three years of income guarantees for workers laid off because of slumping car and truck sales. GM has said it would spend up to $4.1 billion on income-guarantee programs in the new contact, compared with about $1.3 billion in the 1987 agreement. Various estimates put the cost of similar guarantees for Ford workers at about $1.4 billion. The GM-UAW agreement also calls for a 3 percent increase in the base wage in the first year and lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent in the second and third years. Cost of living adjustments on wages were continued from the previous contract negotiated in 1987. Barring unforeseen complications, it's expected that negotiators will be able to present a tentative agreement to Ford workers within two weeks. The story may be different when intensive bargaining resumes with Chrysler after a Ford agreement is reached. Chrysler officials have called UAW-GM agreement very expensive. Chrysler, by far, is in the worst financial shape of the Big Three. Later this month, it's expected to report a substantial loss of $200 million or more for the third quarter.

DOC.HEAD: The Proposed Budget and Tax Changes
With AM-Budget Rdp, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Around Washington, legislators, lobbyists and public interest groups looked Monday at the plan to cut government spending with the foreboding of a motorist receiving his mechanic's estimate. They knew it would be costly but not exactly how costly. The $500 billion dent the government plans to make in its red ink the next five years will trickle up from many streams small and large: From a nickel from each gallon of gasoline, at first, to an added $5.70 a month for Medicare, from $134 billion in new taxes and fees to a $182 billion cutback in defense and domestic programs. It starts with $40 billion in cutbacks the first year. The broad targets are there, but the details will have to be worked out. Here's a quick look at some of the prospects. - Medicare: The federal health care program for 33 million elderly and disabled Americans would take the largest hit of any of the entitlement programs, with a hoped-for reduction of $60 billion. About half would come from recipients, whose $28.60 monthly premium for doctors' care would increase to $34.30 next year, and whose $75 deductible on doctors' bills would double by 1995. The other half would come from cutting back on reimbursements to hospitals and physicians. The 1.45 percent tax that helps support the Medicare program would rise from the first $51,300 of income to the first $73,000. Groups representing the elderly cried foul. Arthur Flemming, head of the Save Our Social Security coalition, said it was indefensible that the summiteers put half the revenue burden on Medicare. ``President Bush and the budget summiteers are asking one eighth of the population to shoulder one-half of the cuts in domestic spending, and that eighth represents the oldest, the sickest, the poorest adults - those least able to pay,'' said Ron Pollack, director of Families USA. - Agriculture: House and Senate agriculture committee leaders spent Monday conferring with staff over how to cut $13 billion from agriculture programs without seriously damaging farmers' income. Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas was said to insist on across-the-board cuts so no single commodity gets hurt worse than others. Crops protected by government price supports are wheat, rice, cotton and feed grains. If market prices fall below the target price set by Congress, the government makes up the difference with a direct payment to the farmer. The 1990 farm bill being worked out in a House-Senate conference committee calls for $54 billion in spending on such subsidies over the next five years. However, under the budget agreement that figure must be cut 25 percent. ``We don't want to see target prices dropped, but we'd rather see target prices go down than loan rates go up,'' said Don Lipton, director of media relations for the American Farm Bureau Federation. Loan rates are a method of helping farmers who sell abroad, a big moneymaking enterprise for American farmers. Leland Swenson, president of National Farmers Union, said the $13 billion slash in USDA programs would ``throw the farm sector into a tailspin.'' - Post Office: Postmaster General Anthony Frank says the price of stamps will go up more and sooner than had been planned because the budget agreement calls on the Postal Service to absorb some $5 billion over the next five years. ``Postage rates will be as much as 5 cents higher by 1995 than they otherwise would have been,'' Frank said. There already is an increase scheduled for next February, expected to raise the price of a first class stamp to 30 cents. ``This is a conscious decision to shift obligations from the Treasury to the Postal Service and has been characterized by many as a `stamp tax.' Clearly it is,'' said Frank. - Energy:
Henson Moore, deputy energy secretary, said he did not think the cutbacks would affect the department's massive cleanup efforts at atomic weapons plants. - Taxes:

The gasoline tax, now 9 cents per gallon, up 5 cents Dec. 1, another 2 cents Jan. 1 and 5 cents more next July 1 for a new total of 21 cents per gallon. The cigarette tax, now 16 cents per pack, up 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993, for a new total of 24 cents per pack. Beer and wine: The 16-cent tax on six-packs doubles; the $12.50 per gallon tax for 100 proof (50 percent) alcohol goes up to $14, with lower-proof liquor going up by the same ratio; and the 3-cent tax on a fifth of wine goes up to 25 cents, all in January. Cars worth more than $30,000, private boats exceeding $100,000, furs and jewelry exceeding $5,000 face a 10 percent on their value exceeding those levels. The tax applies to newly manufactured items. Individuals or couples earning more than $100,000 could lose 3 percent of their deductions for their income over that amount. The largest increase in federal fees will be an increase in the amount the government charges banks to insure deposits, a boost that will garner $4 billion. - Defense:
Cut $68 billion below the amount needed to stay even with inflation for the first three years, as much as $182 billion over five years. - Education:

The budget agreement calls for trimming $2 billion from the guaranteed student loan program. Negotiators suggested that officials eliminate from the federal loan program all schools with default rates above 30 percent. Officials acknowledge that many trade and vocational schools, as well as historically black colleges, will be eliminated. - Other benefit programs cuts:

Save $8 billion by no longer letting civil service retirees take their benefits in a lump sum, after a one-month grace period; $4.6 billion from delaying start of unemployment insurance; $2.5 billion from Federal Housing Authority; $1.6 billion from changing the way the government buys pharmaceuticals.

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Energy, Grains Slide As War Fears Ease
DOC.TEXT: Gold, grains and energy futures prices declined sharply Monday as conciliatory gestures from the United States and Iraq's Saddam Hussein produced a domino-effect easing of war jitters. On other commodity markets, silver and platinum continued their slide; meat futures prices were sharply higher; and soybeans were lower. Gold settled $19.30 to $15.90 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in October at $386.60 a troy ounce. Gold extended its losses from Friday's poor close. It followed energy futures and continued its fall after saber-rattling speeches and comments from Iraq and the United States softened Monday, analysts said. ``There was no fresh (bad) news,'' said John Sak, a metals analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. ``Nothing in the market propelled gold upwards, then you had the oil markets crack - that's all you needed.'' Energy futures led off the markets' decline, opening lower amid a perceived decline in chances of impending war. Prices fell further after President Bush made a moderate speech to the United Nations. Light sweet crude oil settled $2.42 to its $1 limit lower with November at $37.09 a barrel; heating oil was 5.89 cents lower to unchanged with November at $1.0003 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4.8 cents to 2.5 cents lower with November at 93.9 cents a gallon. Platinum settled on the New York Mercantile Exchange $7.30 to $6.30 lower with October at $426.80 a troy ounce. Silver settled 15.5 cents to 12.1 cents lower on the Commodity Exchange with October at $4.64 an ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices were sharply down on the Chicago Board of Trade, as a result of increased harvest pressures and declines on the precious metal and energy markets. Wheat futures prices fell to levels from two weeks ago amid doubts the Soviet Union does not plan to buy subsidized wheat flour from the government. Analysts also attributed the losses to professional selling by major companies and near-ideal harvest conditions. ``There's a very weak export outlook to buy grains,'' said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co. in New York. ``You're moving grains into positions to be sold and you don't have any ready buyers, so that's going to push prices lower.'' Soybean futures pushed toward double-digit losses as major corporations sold off their interest. Near-ideal weather conditions in areas where the crop is grown also added pessimism the entire harvest would be sold, Spilka said. Corn followed soybeans and wheat amid the same fears. Wheat futures settled 10 cents to 5 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.67} a bushel; corn was 5 cents to 2{ cents lower with December at $2.23 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to } cent lower with December at $1.19\ a bushel; soybeans were 13 cents to 9{ cents lowe with November at $6.04{ a bushel. Meat futures were sharply higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hogs and frozen pork bellies futures prices closed at their trading limits after speculators reacted favorably to Friday's release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly hogs and pigs report, which showed a slower-than-expected growth in the breeding herd and a decline in market hogs. Cattle rose on spillover support from hogs and pork bellies and higher cash prices. Live cattle settled .48 cent to 1.12 cents higher with October at 80.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .85 cent to 1.37 cents higher with October at 88.12 cents a pound; hogs settled at its trading limit 1.5 cents higher with October at 56.32 cents a pound; pork bellies closed at its trading limit 2 cents higher with February at 60.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Files Papers Paving Way to Eventual Lawsuit of Coast Guard
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. and its shipping subsidiary have filed notices of claims against the U.S. Coast Guard totalling more than $2 billion in connection with the Exxon Valdez shipwreck. Exxon spokesman Les Rogers said the Sept. 21 filings satisfy an administrative requirement that preserves options for Exxon and Exxon Shipping Co. to sue the Coast Guard over the spill. Exxon has said it has spent more than $2 billion for both its cleanup efforts and payments to fishermen and related businesses for losses related to the spill. ``The claimants allege the Coast Guard is wholly or partially liable for costs Exxon incurred in cleaning up the spill and for amounts paid to parties in settlement of claims, as well as for future costs expected to be incurred by Exxon as a result of pending litigation,'' said Coast Guard Cmdr. John McElwain. Exxon declined to offer an explanation for why company officials think the Coast Guard should share responsibility for the March 24, 1989, oil spill that dumped nearly 11 million gallons of crude into Prince William Sound. But in the past Exxon has claimed that the cleanup was hindered by cleanup authorities' refusal to give it blanket permission to use dispersants in the first three days after the spill. The Coast Guard was involved in the decision. Exxon has said broader use of the chemical would have kept more oil off the shores of the Sound. ``We're trying to evaluate the claims (against the Coast Guard) to see if they have any basis in admiralty law,'' McElwain said. Some 200 civil lawsuits involving thousands of plaintiffs have been filed against Exxon, mostly in state court in Alaska. Plaintiffs include the state, residents of villages in the spill's path, fishermen, fish processors, tourism companies, fishing lodges and some of the nation's largest environmental organizations. Court dates have not been scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of Saber-Rattling Pushes Oil Down Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The volatile price of oil took its second-sharpest fall of the Persian Gulf crisis, tumbling more than $2 per barrel Monday as traders thought they saw glimmers of peace. Light sweet crude for November delivery dropped $2.42 to $37.09 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil's largest one-day fall since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 was $4 per barrel on Aug. 27. Crude was down as much as $3.66 per barrel in light trading Monday afternoon, but regained part of that ground late in the day as some speculators bought futures to avoid being short on oil overnight. Later contract months for crude delivery fell by the exchange's limit of $1 per barrel. Oil opened lower on a weekend statement from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that was viewed by traders as being more conciliatory than usual. Oil then fell sharply around midday, when President Bush told the U.N. General Assembly he hoped there could be a diplomatic solution to the Mideast turmoil. ``The market was looking for some saber-rattling,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``We know Bush wants the U.N. to approve taking military action. We thought there might be mention of that. There was none. It was a very peaceful speech.'' Refined petroleum products also fell Monday. Home heating oil dropped 5.89 cents to $1.0003 per gallon on November delivery contracts, with later months also falling. Unleaded gasoline fell 4.80 cents to 93.91 cents per gallon for November, with other months down as well. Natural gas fell 2.6 cents to $1.909 per 1,000 cubic feet for November. Later contracts months also went down. As oil fell, stock prices increased. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 63.36 points to 2,515.84, its largest point gain since rising 78.71 points on Aug. 27. Traders said oil's fall on Monday was evidence of shifting psychology in the chaotic markets. ``Most important is a slight ease in tensions now,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. ``It might be premature, but it's some type of hope that we haven't been seeing.'' Brokers said oil prices seemed to be testing the $36 range as a potential base for future trading, after hitting the $40 level late last week in what is viewed as the potential ceiling for prices, at least in the short term. ``The market is just trying to find a range,'' said trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Falls $16 an Ounce; Dollar Lower in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices fell nearly $16 an ounce Monday, following the price of oil lower on a belief of better prospects for a negotiated settlement to the Middle East crisis. An agreement on a U.S. deficit-reduction package sent the dollar lower against major foreign currencies. Traders said the package heralded a move to lower interest rates soon by the Federal Reserve. Lower U.S. interest rates would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreigners seeking high yields. The decline in gold prices in New York followed sharp drops in Asia and Europe, which reacted to weekened reports that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might be willing to negotiate with Kuwait over his occupation of the Persian Gulf nation. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for October delivery settled at $386.60 a troy ounce, down $15.90 from Friday's close. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late gold bid of $387.90, down $15.10 an ounce from Friday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $395.25 per ounce, from $404.75 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $396.60, down from $406.25 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $5.67 to close at a bid $398.07. Gold futures prices have mirrored the rise and fall of oil futures since Iraq's takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The pattern held Monday, as light sweet crude dropped $2.42 to $37.09 a barrel for November delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Higher oil prices increase inflation, which tends to push investors to gold, which is seen as stable in times of economic turmoil. The U.S. budget accord also helped to push down gold, traders said. ``With oil prices down, the pyschology is to get out of gold,'' said Jim Koppel, managing director of Deak International Trading (U.S.) Ltd. The idea of a negotiated settlement in the Middle East gained strength Monday when President Bush told the U.N. General Assembly he wanted a peaceful, diplomatic solution to the crisis. In the currency market, the dollar ended lower in New York after sharp declines overseas with selling linked to the U.S. budget accord providing for large tax increases and spending cuts. ``People went out and sold the dollar because they're looking for the Fed to cut the discount rate,'' said Arnold Sherrer, chief foreign exchange trader for the Royal Bank of Canada. Traders said, though, that the decline stalled in New York with some selling to take profits after the drops on foreign markets. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.80 yen to a closing 137.15 yen. Later in London, it was quoted lower at 137.00 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 136.75 yen, down from 138.50 late Friday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8890, more expensive than $1.8735 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.8830 to buy one pound, up from $1.8760 late Friday. Other dollar rates late in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes included: 1.55735 German marks, down from 1.5670; 1.2960 Swiss francs, down from 1.29735; 5.2195 French francs, down from 5.2455; 1,167.25 Italian lire, down from 1,173.25; and 1.153825 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15425. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late Friday's rates included: 1.5520 German marks, down from 1.5655; 1.2885 Swiss francs, down from 1.2980; 5.1985 French francs, down from 5.2420; 1.7495 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7655; 1,163.50 Italian lire, down from 1,172.25, and 1.1526 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1563. Silver prices declined more than 12 cents an ounce in New York. On the Comex, silver bullion for October delivery settled at $4.64 a troy ounce compared to the Friday settlement price of $4.761. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.725 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.79.

DOC.HEAD: Regan Says Reagan's Policies Delayed S&Ls' Worst Troubles
DOC.TEXT: Former Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said Monday the savings and loan industry would have plunged ``into the tank'' deeper and faster without the deregulatory policies of the Reagan administration. ``Absolutely not,'' Regan replied when asked by Rep. Chalmers Wylie, R-Ohio, if the thrift debacle discredited deregulation. Regan appeared before the House Banking Committee in the first of a series of hearings examining the causes of the S&L mess. ``When you see the Eastern European countries ... coming over here to find out how did we do it, you have to say our policies were correct and deregulation was one of them,'' said Regan, who served as Treasury secretary from 1981 to 1985, when he became White House chief of staff. Regan said that after interest rates soared in the 1980s, a result he said of the economic policies of the Carter administration, it became clear that a financial business confined to taking deposits from savers and lending the money to home buyers could not survive. He said he had favored giving thrifts the same investment powers as commercial banks, but had opposed the broader deregulation in some states that had given thrifts non-bank powers. If not for the administration-backed banking deregulation bill of 1982, ``I think the thrift industry would have gone into the tank sooner and may have never emerged,'' he said. Regan, who was chairman of Merrill Lynch before becoming treasury secretary, was described as ``the father of brokered deposits'' by Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass. Such high-interest deposits, placed by Wall Street brokerage houses, usually in amounts just under the $100,000 deposit insurance limit, are blamed for fueling the explosive growth in risky investments at many S&Ls. Regan, however, said he had recused himself from any policy matters affecting brokered deposits because of his connection to Merrill Lynch and said the firm did not deal in them extensively until after he left. ``I want a blood test as far as being the father of brokered deposits. I am not - in no way, shape or fashion,'' he said. Kennedy countered that Regan allowed his subordinate, Deputy Treasury Secretary R.T. McNamar, to forcefully advocate their use. Regan blamed the explosion of brokered deposits on Congress' 1980 decision to raise the deposit insurance limit from $40,000 per account to $100,000. As a reform, he advocated forcing depositors to pay for their own deposit insurance on amounts over $100,000. Edwin Gray, the nation's top thrift regulator from 1983 to 1987, has accused Regan of trying to force him from office when he tried to rein in the industry in general and brokered deposits in particular. Regan, who previously had not had a chance to reply to Gray in a public forum, described him as an absentee, lax regulator. ``In 1985, when I became chief of staff, I began to hear rumors that this man was not paying attention; he was part of the problem, not the solution. ... He was sort of a front for the industry. I didn't like that,'' Regan said. He sid that between September 1983 and June 1986, Gray was in his office only 397 weekdays and absent 466 days. He also noted that Gray was forced to repay his agency, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, $26,000 for travel and entertainment. ``He want to Pebble Beach. He went to Greenbriar. My crack was, `I think he's working more on his handicap than he's working on the thrifts,''' Regan said, adding later, ``This guy gets religion when he's found out.'' Gray and former Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul Volcker are scheduled to appear before the committee Wednesday. The committee chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, plans to hear from Carter administration officials later. Richard T. Pratt, Gray's predecessor at the bank board from 1981 to 1983, testified after Regan. Pratt said he was rejected by Congress and the Reagan administration in his attempts to get money to pay for more S&L examiners. Regan, he said, would not take his calls. Pratt also defended his decision early in the S&L crisis to permit thrifts to use accounting techniques to hide their losses. Otherwise, it would have cost $178 billion - $350 billion in 1990 dollars - to liquidate insolvent thrifts, he said. Pratt said when he took office nearly every S&L in the nation was technically insolvent because soaring interest rates had drastically cut the value of their low-interest, fixed-rate mortgages. Regulators' strategy was to close the worst institutions and to buy time for the others until interest rates fell, as they did, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Emerson President Resigns, Other Changes Announced
DOC.TEXT: The resignation last week of the president of Emerson Radio Corp., was unconnected with the simultaneous announcement of two international joint ventures, the new chairman said Monday. Stephen Lane, resigned on Friday amid questions over whether he was competent to manage his firm's affairs because he was recuperating from surgery for two brain tumors. The resignation coincided with the announcement of two major international joint ventures, one with a Japanese firm and a second with a Swiss concern, said William Lane, the new president and chief executive, who assumed those positions from his brother. In resigning, Lane said he also feared that adverse publicity from a lawsuit he filed against investment bankers Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. could harm Emerson, where he worked for the past 30 years. The suit charged that Lane lost millions of dollars during the 1987 stock market crash because Drexel's broker - Lane's wife, Tina - was unqualified. He will continue as a consultant to the firm, which produces consumer electronic products, Lane said. Tomei Industrial Holdings Ltd., based in Hong Kong, has purchased 2 million shares of Emerson's common stock at $3.75 a share, or nearly $7.5 million, for 5 percent of the company, the company announced Friday. Emerson stock closed at $2.875 that day, up $0.25. The agreement includes a seat on the eight-member board of directors. Tomei will have to purchase another 2 million shares at $4 per share within a year in order to retain its board seat, William Lane said. Emerson also plans to enter a joint venture with Zurich, Switzerland-based Fidenas Investment Ltd., Emerson's largest shareholder at 12 percent, William Lane said. ``Fidenas will run Emerson operations in Europe, where it has contacts and expertise,'' William Lane said. Fidenas will seat two directors on the board, William Lane said. The Fidenas agreement must still be formally presented to Emerson stockholders and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler's Up Less than 1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Monday that prices for its 1991 cars and trucks would rise an average of less than 1 percent over comparably equipped 1990 models. Earlier, Ford Motor Co. announced its 1991 prices would increase an average of 3.2 percent and General Motors Corp. said its 1991 models would cost an average of 2.3 percent more than 1990 versions. Prices for Chrysler's two best-selling and most profitable lines of vehicles - minivans and Jeeps - will go up 2 percent and 3.2 percent respectively. The company said the price changes vary from a $1,270 increase in the cost of a Chrysler Imperial to a $1,300 reduction in the base price of a Dodge Monaco.

DOC.HEAD: Comfed Savings Files Suit Against 34 Former Employees
DOC.TEXT: A Massachusetts thrift filed suit Monday against 34 former employees, claiming that widespread misconduct exacerbated the financial troubles of the struggling Comfed Savings Bank. Among the defendants named in the suit were Raymond F. Miller Jr., who was ousted as bank president; and James G. Baldini, former president of Comfed Mortgage Co. Inc. The suit filed in Middlesex Superior Court marks the latest development in Comfed's battle for survival. Company Chairman Jack Zoeller said Comfed, like most banks in New England, ``has sustained substantial losses as a result of the downturn in the region's real estate market.'' ``However, we firmly believe that our loan losses were increased materially due to the misconduct of the individuals as alleged in this suit,'' Zoeller said in a statement. The charges contained in the suit include intentional misconduct, mismanagement and fraud in the processing and approval of residential and commercial loans. Comfed said it will seek to recover the amount of losses determined by the courts. Miller was unavailable for comment Monday. Baldini said he could not respond to specific allegations since he had not seen the complaint. But he added, ``I have done nothing wrong.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after the 13th with nationwide volume; picks up 14th graf, As measured . . .
DOC.TEXT: The stock market recouped some of its summer losses with a sharp rally Monday, encouraged by falling oil prices and hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 63.36 points to 2,515.84, for its largest point gain since it rose 78.71 points on Aug. 27. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,203 up, 442 down and 365 unchanged. A monthly report on the economy from the National Association of Purchasing Management, coupled with the long-awaited federal budget accord announced over the weekend, raised hopes that the Federal Reserve might adopt an easier credit policy. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, has said the approval of a deficit cutting agreement would give the nation's central bank more leeway in allowing rates to drop. The purchasing managers report, meanwhile, provided further evidence of a weakening manufacturing economy. The purchasing managers monthly index fell sharply in September for its third consecutive drop. The market expected the report to put further pressure on the Fed to lower rates as a means of stimulating the economy. Stocks also got some help from a drop in oil prices. Crude oil for November delivery fell $2.42 a barrel to $37.09 a barrel in New York Mercantile Exchange trading. Point-plus gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 2{ at 47}; General Electric, up 1} at 56\; Boeing, up 2| at 44\; International Business Machines, up 2| at 109, and American Telephone & Telegraph, up 1] at 32\. Energy stocks were mostly lower. Atlantic Richfield dropped 2] to 132; Amoco 1 to 55}; Texaco ~ to 60], and Halliburton 1~ to 49{. But Exxon rose | to 49|. Airline issues climbed on hopes for relief from soaring fuel costs. AMR gained 2} to 45; UAL 6[ to 103], and Delta Air Lines 2[ to 57[. Precious-metals stocks weakened as the price of gold fell. ASA Ltd. dropped 1~ to 47{; Battle Mountain Gold 1 to 9{; Newmont Gold 3~ to 41{, and Homestake Mining 1| to 20. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 202.21 million shares, against 201.01 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 235.96 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $75.41 billion, or 2.62 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 4.37 to 172.22. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 10.07 to 370.54, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 8.89 at 314.94. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 10.14 to 354.65. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 308.44, up .71.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Agrees To Hear Age Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether workers who accuse employers of violating a federal law against age discrimination sometimes may be forced to submit their case to arbitration. The justices said they will hear an appeal by a North Carolina man fired at age 62 by a securities firm. Robert Gilmer was fired in 1987 as manager of financial services for Interstate-Johnson Lane Corp. and was replaced by a 28-year-old who Gilmer said was less qualified. Six years earlier when he was hired, Gilmer signed a registration form as a securities representative with the New York Stock Exchange in which he agreed to submit any dispute between himself and his employer to arbitration. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in February that the arbitration agreement is binding. Gilmer said the agreement violates the federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act. But the 4th Circuit court said nothing in the law forbids arbitration. ``Congress clearly did not intend that all ADEA disputes be resolved in federal court,'' the appeals court said. It also noted that the Supreme Court in recent rulings has endorsed arbitration as an alternative to lawsuits in some cases. The case is Gilmer vs. Interstate-Johnson Lane, 90-18.

DOC.HEAD: High Court To Review Telephone Directory Copyright
DOC.TEXT: Copyright ownership of telephone directories will be explored in a Kansas case granted Supreme Court review Monday. The justices said they will hear an appeal by a company that distributed an edited version of a Kansas telephone directory. The company, Feist Publications Inc., unsuccessfully tried to buy the white pages from Rural Telephone Service Company, which has customers in the northwest part of the state. The telephone company has a monopoly for its area. Feist then edited the Rural directory, relisting the names by towns in a 15-county region that included the area served by Rural. Feist has distributed its directory since 1978. A federal judge ruled that Feist violated copyright law and awarded Rural $6,000 and attorneys fees. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the damage award last March. The appeals court rejected Feist's arguments that Rural violated antitrust law by monopolizing the listing of its customers. Feist's appeal to the high court is supported by the Association of North American Directory Publishers and the Directory Publishers Association representing more than 100 publishers of telephone directories. The case is Feist Publications vs. Rural Telephone, 89-1909.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Industry Bracing for Gas-Tax Increase
DOC.TEXT: Two of the nation's Big Three automakers said Monday a deficit-reduction proposal that includes a hefty gasoline-tax increase is difficult, but good for the country. ``The nation needs a meaningful budget-reduction package,'' said Susan Shackson, Ford Motor Co.'s director of public policy development. ``Is this the best one? Probably not. But we are where we are. I would say at this point, let's get on with it.'' Congressional and administration negotiators reached an agreement Sunday which would, if enacted, boost the federal gasoline tax by next July to 21 cents a gallon from the current 9 cents. It also would impose a 10 percent tax on new cars that cost more than $30,000. On the positive side, Shackson and Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca said the proposal was likely to be accompanied by interest-rate reductions. ``This budget package gives (Federal Reserve Chairman) Alan Greenspan the tools to make sure we get them,'' Iacocca said in a statement. General Motors Corp. spokesman Bill Noack said company officials were reviewing the proposal. In the past, GM has opposed any gas tax increase earmarked for deficit reduction. ``We have said we thought a gasoline tax used in that way would be a regressive tax and would be disproportionately burdensome on low-income families,'' he said. ``And there are Americans who drive long distances, and for those people it would be difficult.'' The three-step boost in the gas tax - 5 cents on Dec. 1, 2 cents Jan. 1 and another nickel on July 1, 1991 - couldn't have come at a worst time for the auto industry. Oil prices have been creeping up ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Today, gasoline prices are about 30 percent higher than before the invasion. So far, automakers have insisted that consumers aren't turning toward smaller, more fuel-efficient cars and away from large, gas-gulping cars and trucks. But evidence of a change may show up Wednesday when the companies report September car and light truck sales figures. It's expected the downward trend sales have shown since the first of the year will continue. The degree of decline may indicate if consumers are beginning to take a wait-and-see approach to purchasing a new car or truck. Through Sept. 20 of this year, the Big Three have sold 7,196,364 North American-made cars and trucks, 8 percent lower than sales during the same time last year.

DOC.HEAD: Electric Boat Lays Off 582, Mainly Support Personnel
DOC.TEXT: Electric Boat gave layoff notices Monday to 582 employees at its Groton and Quonset Point, R.I., plants, citing declining military orders and uncertainty about federal defense expenditures. The layoffs, mainly of support personnel, represent less than 3 percent of the total work force of Electric Boat, a division of General Dynamics Corp. But company officials said as many as 5 percent could receive layoff notices by November. ``How many people we're going to lay off in the end will depend on the defense budget. It could be up to 1,000, but it won't be more than the 4 percent to 5 percent we've announced,'' said Neil Ruenzel, a spokesman for the submarine builder. Of the employees laid off Monday, 415 are salaried staff and 167 are hourly, Ruenzel said. Most of the layoffs occurred in Groton, where 17,000 are employed. About 110 of those getting notices work at the Rhode Island plant, which employs about 5,000. A few workers are also being laid off at EB satellite locations in such places as Avenel, N.J., and Charleston, S.C., Ruenzel said. ``This will affect primarily overhead and support personnel - people in areas like financial management, purchasing and materials control - and few of the men and women actually involved in building the submarines,'' Ruenzel said. ``We may have fewer orders now, but we still have to build the ships.'' Employees in all departments of the Groton plant milled around nervously Monday during breaks, many of them reading and re-reading an announcement distributed all over the plant that morning in the company's employee bulletin. The company said employees were being notified on a one-on-one basis by their supervisors. Employees laid off Monday will lose their jobs 60 days later, Ruenzel said. In the meantime, the company's new Career Transition Center will help laid-off employees think through their options, manage their stress and work on brushing up resume and interview skills. But to many of those who woke up Monday uncertain whether they would come home at the end of their shifts with or without their jobs, the center is little comfort. ``It's like propaganda. First they take away your job, then they say they want to help,'' said one employee of the nuclear department who asked that his name not be used. ``It doesn't help much to work on your job skills when the only job you're likely to get has just been taken away from you.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Surge as Oil Prices Fall, Budget Accord Reached
DOC.TEXT: Treasury bond prices surged Monday as the market cheered a sharp drop in oil prices and the federal budget accord reached by Congress and President Bush over the weekend. ``The bond market was kind of deluged with good news today,'' said Susan Hering, a Treasury bond economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. The widely watched 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 1-32 point, or $10.32 for every $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, dropped to 8.84 percent from 8.94 percent late Friday. It was the lowest yield for the ``long bond'' in about six weeks. Bond prices usually rise on signs that inflation may be easing. One such signal is a drop in oil prices, which bonds have tracked closely since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The November contract for oil dropped $2.42 a barrel to $37.09 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the second-largest price drop since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis. Oil prices were influenced by a weekend statement from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that appeared to ease tensions in the Middle East, and by comments from Bush, who told the U.N. General Assembly on Monday that he hoped there could be a diplomatic solution to the Mideast turmoil. Meanwhile, the bond market was encouraged by the accord on the fiscal 1991 federal budget. The market has looked to the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates after the budget was resolved. Lower rates benefit fixed-rate securities such as bonds. William V. Sullivan, director of money market research for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., attributed the sharp run-up in bond prices to ``one-third budget, two-thirds oil.'' ``It wasn't until the sharp plunge in oil (following Bush's United Nations address) that the bond market re-energized itself,'' he said. Bond prices also were supported by another signal of growing weakness in the economy. The nation's corporate purchasing managers announced that their widely watched monthly index of industrial activity dropped for the third straight month to its lowest level in nearly eight years. Signs of economic sluggishness often are viewed favorably by bond investors because they may cause the Fed to ease interest rates. But Ms. Hering wasn't optimistic that bond prices would retain their new-found strength. She said the market remains tied to Iraq and its effect on oil prices. Also Monday, the Treasury sold at auction $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.18 percent, and $9.2 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.21 percent. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.17 percent on Sept. 19, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 7.19 percent on Aug. 6, 1990. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term issues gained 3-32 point to 3-16 point, intermediate maturities rose 11-32 point to 13-16 point, and long-term issues jumped 29-32 point to 1 1-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, advanced 3.61 to 1,150.16. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 7.34 percent as the discount remained at 7.12 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell marginally to at 7.504 percent as the discount remained at 7.15 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.61 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points to 7.11 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest banks charge one another for overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, up from 8 percent late Friday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose ] point to 88 19-32. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.78 percent from 7.79 percent late Friday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS new 4th graf, Joe Joyce, with Tonka comment. Picks up 4th graf pvs, In the.
DOC.HEAD: Possible Takeover Bid for Toymaker Tonka Announced
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm I. Glazer, a businessman who last year bought a sizeable chunk of Harley-Davidson Inc., announced Monday he holds an 8.6 percent stake in Tonka Corp. and may seek control of the Minnesota-based toymaker. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Glazer, who maintains offices in Rochester, N.Y. and Boynton Beach, Fla., said he and his six children have acquired approximately 1.25 million Tonka common stock shares for a total of $4.4 million. The Glazer group said in the filing that it had ``no definitive plans at this time'' but ``may seek to acquire a controlling interest'' in Minnetonka, Minn.-based Tonka or to obtain seats on the board of directors. Joe Joyce, general counsel for Tonka, said the company is aware of the SEC filing but will not comment on it. He declined to answer whether Glazer has contacted the company or whether Tonka officials view it as a serious takeover threat. In the SEC filing, Glazer described himself as a self-employed, private investor with holdings in the communications, real estate, health care and banking industries. Last fall he purchased a large chunk of Harley-Davidson, the Milwaukee-based motorcycle manufacturer. After acquiring a 7.26 percent stake, he urged the motorcycle maker to sell off its recreational vehicle subsidiary. Harley-Davidson refused and Glazer later reduced his stake. The Glazer group said it bought Tonka stock at prices ranging from $4.55 to $5.50 per share between Aug. 7 and last Thursday. All of the Tonka shares were purchased in open-market transactions on the New York Stock Exchange, according to Glazer's SEC documents. Tonka stock closed down 25 cents Monday, at $4.37{ a share.

DOC.HEAD: Ralph Nader Says He May Sue Forbes If It Doesn't Retract Article
DOC.TEXT: Ralph Nader said Monday he would consider suing Forbes magazine if it doesn't respond within a week to his request to retract a highly critical cover story on the consumer activist. Nader, in an interview, called the story in the Sept. 17 issue of the biweekly business magazine ``on the low order of journalism.'' ``They didn't do their homework,'' he said, claiming the article contains ``deep-rooted error.'' ``Almost every derogatory statement is wrapped around a false statement,'' he continued. ``They're used to going after people who have skeletons in their closet,'' he said. ``They picked on the wrong crowd this time. By the time we get through with Forbes magazine there will be a case study for journalism schools.'' Nader said he would consider filing a suit seeking a retraction if the magazine doesn't voluntarily print one. The story claims that although Nader portrays himself as an independent activist free of outside influence, he in fact represents the interests of trial lawyers who sue companies in product-liability cases and take other legal actions against companies. In turn, these lawyers contribute financially to Nader's organizations, Forbes claims. The article also claims that one of Nader's groups, the Center for Study of Responsive Law, founded in 1968, has never made required tax filings with the Internal Revenue Service. In addition, Forbes wrote that though Nader says he lives a Spartan life in ``a simple room'' near his Washington, D.C., office, he actually lives in an expensive townhouse that is owned by his sister. Forbes Editor James Michaels said the magazine stands by its story. ``At this point, and we're making a very careful check, we don't see that there's anything to retract,'' he said. He said the magazine also hasn't decided whether it would print a letter from Nader rebutting the article. ``It's a very abusive letter,'' Michaels said.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Relieved by Compromise But Wary of Implications
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs ``Assuming ...'' to CORRECT revenue reductions to spending reductions. Picks up 6th graf ``To the extent ...''
DOC.TEXT: A sigh of relief sounded on Wall Street Monday after the Bush administration and leaders of Congress finally compromised on a budget, but the best thing many observers could say of the accord was that it exists. ``I think the financial markets are grateful that the issue is going to be put behind us for a while,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``Regardless of whether people like or dislike the compromise, there is some feeling that an albatross has been removed from around the market's neck.'' A stalemate in the negotiations over a package of tax increases and spending cuts had added to the worries weighing down the stock market in recent weeks. Markets welcomed the break in the deadlock as a sign that interest rates could be header lower. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 63.36 points, closing at 2,515.84, amid hopes that the budget accord will make the Federal Reserve more likely to relax its monetary policy. In the credit market, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained 1[ point, or $11.25 for each $1,000 in face value. Assuming that Congress enacts most of what has been cobbled together by White House and congressional negotiators, the most crucial question about the new 1991 budget proposal can only be answered over time: Will the higher taxes and spending reductions hit the economy too hard? ``To the extent one can see through the smoke and mirrors, I don't think it will harm the economy as it sinks into recession,'' said Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.'s chief economist Irwin Kellner. ``In the short-term, it probably isn't enough fiscal restraint to push the economy down any more than it's going on its own.'' Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu, said there is a danger, however, that the 1991 budget ``could be viewed in history as maybe the most ill-timed fiscal response ever.'' With the economy entering or already in recession, this year might be the wrong time to enact measures that further discourage consumer spending. A report released Monday by the National Association of Purchasing Management furnished fresh evidence of economic problems. The group's index that tracks the manufacturing sector sank in September to the lowest level since the cusp of the last recession eight years ago. Imposing heavier taxes on alcohol, tobacco and gasoline will take money out of people's pockets, meaning there will be less income available for discretionary purchases of other items, Fabbri said. Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc., said he expects the Fed will ease policy slightly, soon nudging down short-term interest rates by about \ percentage point. If the economy continues to deteriorate, the central bank might have to ease again later. The Fed might wait to act until after Congress completes the ratification process and the budget is a done deal a few weeks from now. No matter what the Fed does or when it does it, interest rates probably will sink. Resler said rates will go down as credit demand shrinks ``because the economy is crumbling beneath our feet.'' The deficit-cutting blueprint isn't without merit, which even cynical Wall Street insiders were willing to concede. Fabbri of Midland Montagu said the plan is based on fewer phoney economic estimates and less accounting gimmickry than past budgets because it includes some genuine tax hikes and spending cuts. The administration also owned up to more realistic projections. For Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover, the White House and Congress appear headed on a proper course. ``It is encouraging. For the moment, it seems to be one tiny step in the right direction,'' he said. ``I'm sure glad that they reached some semblance of an agreement instead of not reaching one at all.''

DOC.HEAD: US Sprint Announces Toll-Free Service for Residential Customers
DOC.TEXT: Toll-free numbers no longer will be limited to business telephones with the availability of a new 800 residential service, US Sprint announced Monday. The service will offer an alternative to collect and operator-assisted calling, said Steve Akin, president of Sprint's Consumer Services Group. ``Parents of college students can stay in touch with their sons and daughters on a regular basis and control costs,'' Akin said. ``Large, scattered families can talk economically with each other.'' He said the service is also aimed at independent business people, such as real estate agents, sales representatives and attorneys, who would offer the 800 number to out-of-town clients and friends. Robin Pence, a US Sprint spokeswoman in Washington, D.C., said the 800 service would save customers about 50 percent over collect, credit card or operator-assisted calls. Customers also would save between 12 and 15 percent over direct-dial calls, Pence said. Users will be billed a flat $10 monthly fee, plus normal long distance charges for calls received. US Sprint said it would waive the $50 installation fee for those signing up in the next three months. Customers won't be required to change their long-distance companies. The service uses existing equipment and telephone lines. US Sprint is a unit of United Telecommunications Inc., a diversified international telecommunications company based in Kansas City.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Lycoming Signs $1 Billion Contract With Army
DOC.TEXT: Textron Lycoming announced Monday it has signed a $1 billion contract extension with the U.S. Army to build more than 2,000 gas turbine engines for tanks. The contract calls for Lycoming to build 2,081 AGT1500 gas turbine engines for the Army's M1A1-M1A2 battle tanks, the company said. It also allows for an additional 308 engines to be built if needed. The contract runs from 1991 to 1994, the company said, and extends a contract Lycoming currently has with the Army. The AGT1500 turboshaft engine is produced specifically for main battle tanks and armored ground vehicles. With it, tanks can go from zero to 20 mph in seven seconds, and can travel up to 30 mph cross country and 45 mph on paved surfaces. Textron Lycoming has manufactured to date more than 9,000 AGT1500 engines for the Army's fleet of Abrams tanks. The Stratford-based company is a subsidiary of Providence, R.I.-based Textron Inc., with businesses in aerospace technology, commercial products and financial services.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Get Promotions at TBS; Say Ted Turner Still Runs The Show
DOC.TEXT: Three veteran executives at Turner Broadcasting System Inc. were promoted, but they said company Chairman Ted Turner, while less of a day-to-day presence, remains at the controls of the cable television empire. ``This doesn't change Ted's role at all. He's still extremely pervasive. But there are some areas he doesn't need to be involved in day to day,'' said Terence F. McGuirk, who was promoted from president of Turner Sports to executive vice president of TBS. McGuirk, who has been with Turner since 1972, will retain his position as head of the TBS sports division. Also promoted Monday was Scott Sassa, from executive vice president of Turner Network Television to president of Turner Entertainment Networks. Sassa first joined TBS in 1982. And Julia W. Sprunt was promoted from supervisor of the company's advertising and promotions department to vice president of marketing and communications. She joined Turner, in the company's cable affiliate, in 1981. McGuirk told reporters in a conference call that he has worked closely with Ted Turner for many years. McGuirk said there would be no radical changes as a result of the management moves. The promotions follow a string of defections from the TBS upper echelon over the past year, including senior executive Robert Wussler and, last month, entertainment networks president Gerry Hogan. McGuirk characterized the recent departures as part of the natural evolution of the 4,500-employee company. ``We're a big and deep company,'' McGuirk said. ``The fact that a few people have left ... I don't follow the story that there's any pattern to that.'' He also denied that the changes signal the end of an entrepreneurial spirit at TBS in favor of a more conservative approach to business. ``I don't think that our growth is coming to an end,'' McGuirk said. ``I don't think the entrepreneurial spirit will ever go away. Ted sets the tone for that.'' Sassa said one of his main goals is to usher in the ``next stage of maturity'' for the Turner's flagship cable SuperStation. He said he wanted to inject some new life into the station's marketing and promotions, rather than make any significant changes in its content.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Settlement Talks on Asbestos Claims
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday ordered Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. and lawyers for asbestos disease victims to begin settlement talks on tens of thousands of claims that threaten the company's future. Also, Eagle-Picher asked U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein to rule that the company has limited funds to meet its asbestos liability, which would allow him to declare a mandatory class-action lawsuit to resolve the claims. Eagle-Picher has said it has more than 64,000 asbestos claims pending with another 20,000 being filed each year. Weinsten did not certify the proposed national class but appointed two lawyers to serve as counsel for the proposed class and ordered settlement talks to begin immediately. ``It is necessary and in the best interest of the proposed class to expedite resolution of this matter to prevent further financial deterioration of Eagle-Picher so as to secure prompt and equitable payments to eligible present and future claimants,'' the judge said. A former federal judge, Marvin E. Frankel, recently found that Eagle-Picher likely faces insolvency unless it finds a way to resolve asbestos personal injury claims. The Cincinnati-based company makes industrial products that used asbestos widely for years. Weinstein said efforts must be made to agree ``quickly and consensually'' on the claims of the proposed class members against Eagle-Picher. The judge has said he would pool the resources of Eagle-Picher, the Manville settlement trust fund and up to four other companies that cannot afford to fight cases in court or pay asbestos claims. Weinstein appointed New York attorney Kenneth R. Feinberg as a special master to coordinate the settlement talks. Feinberg is to present an oral report to Weinstein by Oct. 10. Weinstein also named Peter G. Angelos of Baltimore to serve as counsel for the members of the proposed class with an existing claim against Eagle-Picher. Angelos' firm currently represents about 11,000 victims of asbestos-related diseases. David I. Shapiro, a Washington lawyer who served as a settlement master in the Agent Orange litigation, will represent class members who may file future claims against the company. Asbestos, a mineral used for decades for insulation and construction, causes lung cancer and other respiratory diseases. More than 90,000 lawsuits surrounding asbestos ailments are pending in state and federal courts. Weinstein has taken the lead is resolving the asbestos litigation. He is supervising the reorganization of the Manville trust, the nation's biggest asbestos claims resolution facility, which earlier this year ran out of money to pay new claims.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Unveils Strategy To Link Its Computers With Competitors'
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. on Monday unveiled its strategy to link its computers with those of competitors, saying it would provide a method unmatched by IBM, Digital Equipment Corp. and other computer makers. Unisys, the nation's third-largest computer company, said its Integrated Information Environment would provide software that would mask the differences between Unisys machines and those of other companies so they can be joined in a network. Unisys said it would do this by adhering to the increasingly popular ``open systems'' strategy, in which computers and software follow sets of industry standards so they can be used interchangably. ``It's a milestone in the strategy we've been pursuing since Burroughs and Sperry became one,'' said James Unruh, Unisys' president and chief executive, referring to the 1986 merger that formed the company. However, Unisys' plan is similar in many aspects to the strategies of other computer companies as they contend with computer users who want their machines to operate together no matter which brand. That means Unisys will face tough competition. ``They have no choice - it's a standards world,'' said Daniel Mandresh, a computer analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. But, he said, ``You've got to capture the customer before the other guy.'' As part of its plan announced at a news conference here, Unisys said it would provide a new version of the operating system for its mainframe computers. Operating systems control a computer's internal functions. The new mainframe operating system will allow the machines to serve as ``information hubs'' in networks with other types of computers, Unisys said. That strategy is similar to a plan announced last month by International Business Machines Corp., which also said it wants to position the mainframe at the center of computer networks that link personal computers and midsize machines. But Unisys claims its strategy for linking computers of different makes differs from that of IBM and other companies because it is not based on the computers themselves but on an overlay of software based on industry standards. The strategy also differs from that of NCR Corp., which announced last month that it would replace its entire computer line with models based on industry standards. In contrast, Unisys has said it will continue to make its two older mainframe lines, based on proprietary standards, but will mesh them with other machines with the new software. On another matter, Unruh said the company's directors put great thought into their decision last week to eliminate Unisys' quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share. The move is designed to save cash and help reduce Unisys' debt. He said that ``philosphically'' Unisys wanted to pay stockholders a dividend, but that it would not resume doing so until ``the company's profitability and capital structure warrant it.'' Unisys, based in Blue Bell, Pa., has been struggling to return to profitability since reporting a $639 million loss last year. Last October, it announced it would eliminate more than 8,000 jobs, close plants and refocus its mishmash of product lines inhereted from its predecessor companies. Unruh again said the company expected to report a loss for the third quarter but that it expected a profit in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman Denies Allegations Of Improper Share Dealings
DOC.TEXT: Asil Nadir, chairman of Polly Peck International PLC, Monday night denied allegations of improper dealings in the shares of the beleaguered conglomerate. Polly Peck's shares have been suspended from trading since Sept. 20 when their price fell 55 percent within hours. The stock traded at 108 pence ($2.04) at the time of the suspension, a 135-pence slide ($2.55) from its close a day earlier. Nadir's statement Monday night said: ``Any suggestions that I have been involved in improper share dealing are false.'' Polly Peck's interests span Turkish leisure industries, Japanese electronics and North American and European fresh fruit distribution. The stock crashed after it was revealed that investigators from the Serious Fraud Office had searched the London premises of a company called South Audley Management. Nadir, Polly Peck's largest shareholder, said in his statement Monday night that South Audley Management is owned indirectly by a Nadir family trust of which he is a principal beneficiary. He said it provides management and administration services to the other Nadir family interests. ``There is no connection between Polly Peck and South Audley Management,'' he said. On Sept. 20, Nadir was interviewed for 3{ hours by investigators of the Serious Fraud Office. The Serious Fraud Office is a department of the attorney general, the governments's senior law officer. Working with the police and staffed by lawyers and accountants, it investigates and prosecutes cases where serious fraud is alleged. He said of his Sept. 20 interview by the Serious Fraud Office: ``I attended a meeting at their office and answered the questions put to the best of my information.'' He said he had informed the Stock Exchange of all transactions of which he was aware involving Polly Peck shares and companies in which he held an interest. In a separate statement Monday night, the Polly Peck directors said they were ``cooperating fully with Serious Fraud Office in providing them with information and documentation.'' They added: ``The board has also offered to provide any help it can to assist with the speedy resolution of this investigation.'' News reports said Polly Peck is facing a growing liquidity crisis caused by the share price collapse. One of its bankers has called a meeting of lenders for Friday to plan a financing package. The steering committee of London's Stock Exchange said Monday it would remove Polly Peck shares from the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index, effective immediately. The index represents Britain's top 100 stocks in terms of market capitalization, and the exchange's committee adjusts the index at least four times a year. Food and commodities concern Dalgety PLC will replace Polly Peck in the key index, beginning Tuesday, the stock exchange said.

DOC.HEAD: Patty Producer for McDonald's Lays Off Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf, `But he told ...' to UPDATE with comment from McDonald's; PICKS UP 6th graf, `Hugh Zurkuhlen ...'; Version also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Layoffs at a company that supplies meat to McDonald's Northeast restaurants is the latest indication that Americans are looking beyond the burger for fast-food fixes, analysts said on Monday. The Equity Group, a processor of hamburger patties and steaks for McDonald's, gave notice Friday to 54 of its 115 employees that they would be laid off Oct. 26. The layoffs are to let the subsidiary of Philadelphia-based Keystone Foods ``reposition itself for the 1990s,'' said Andrew Kornick, vice president and general manager of the plant just north of Albany. Kornick would not say Monday what precipitated the layoffs. But he told the Albany Times-Union on Friday that the cuts at the plant, which produces exclusively for McDonald Corp., were ``due to a national decline in beef consumption.'' McDonald's Northeast regional coordinator, Terri Capatosto, denied hamburger consumption has fallen. She said work at the upstate New York plant has been moved to plants in Pennsylvania and Ohio to be closer to beef suppliers in the Midwest and Southwest. ``We are in fact selling more hamburgers this year than last ... by several million pounds,'' she said. Overall sales at McDonald's have risen 8 percent in the first six months of 1990 compared with the first half of last year, Capatosto said. She could not say how much of the increase could be attributed to hamburger sales. Hugh Zurkuhlen, an industry analyst with Salomon Bros. in New York, said the layoffs were the first of their kind he had heard about. He said they are probably due to the ``double hit'' of a weak economy and the national decline in beef consumption. ``There's no question that beef consumption could have something to do with it,'' Zurkuhlen said. ``Restaurant sales in the industry are very, very soft, and any future growth in sales in McDonald's is not likely to come from hamburgers. They account for less than 50 percent of sales.'' Kathy Duguid, regional marketing supervisor for McDonald's in Albany, said she could not comment on Equity's decision or reveal the company's meat patty demand from Equity. The burger, once the undisputed king of fast food, began facing challenges in the 1980s as health-conscious Americans switched from fat-heavy beef to lighter fare. Fast-food restaurants began offering more non-beef items. McDonald's introduced Chicken McNuggets in 1983, salads in 1987 and a chicken sandwich in 1989. In May, Miami-based Burger King Corp., the nation's No. 2 fast-food chain after McDonald's, introduced the ``BK Broiler,'' a broiled chicken sandwich on an oat bran bun. Cori Zywotow, director of media relations for the chain, said the new sandwich has been a ``tremendous success.'' She said the company is selling 1 million BK Broilers a day, already half as much as Burger King's flagship sandwich, ``The Whopper.'' Burger King, like other fast-food chains, does not release a breakdown of sales figures. Hardee's Food Systems Inc., which ranks right behind Burger King, has in the last 18 months introduced a non-fried chicken sandwich and ``The Lean 1,'' advertised as the quarter-pound hamburger with the least total fat - 18 grams - in the fast-food market. ``Look at the menus at any of the burger giants and it becomes clear that Americans are leaning to more low-fat, low cholesterol items,'' said Jerry Singer, director of public relations for the Rocky Mount, N.C.-based chain. ``Sales of red meat in the entire industry have been declining for the past five years,'' he said. ``White meat has been on the increase for the past five years.'' James Murren, an industry analyst with C.J. Lawrence, suggested that a decline in beef production probably wouldn't be enough in itself to cause the layoffs. He said he thinks the plant likely closed because of reduced overall sales at McDonald's. ``McDonald's is declining most severely in the Northeast,'' he said. Michael Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities, said the layoffs also could reflect sales losses McDonald's has incurred since 1988 due to lower-priced competition and delays in diversifying their menu. ``A lot of McDonald's problems are self-inflicted,'' Mueller said. Zurkuhlen said that although the hamburger will probably never regain the dominance it once had, it will remain a fast-food anchor for the foreseeable future. ``Hamburgers are always going to be part of McDonald's as long as people are eating them,'' he said.
